The DPA further claimed that this was a violation of the principle of storage limitation. Additionally, the DPA discovered that the data controller had insufficiently informed the data subjects about the processing of the location data, thus violating its information obligations as per Art. 13 GDPR.

allItems.name: Luxembourg
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c), e) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 32 (1) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The DPA from Luxembourg (also known as CNPD) has fined a company with EUR 7,200. The company had previously installed a video surveillance system to safeguard the company’s assets and prevent unauthorized entry by random individuals. However, the cameras also captured parts of the employee’s work area and the smoking area that employees would frequently use to relax. Moreover, the data controller had also installed location sensors on the cars in its fleet. It did this to enhance the company’s operations. The DPA also discovered that the recordings were not only unnecessary to ensure the purposes associated with the video surveillance, but that the data controller thus violated the principle of data minimization under Article 5 (1) c) of the GDPR. The location data that the company collected by the controller was stored for a period of eight months, and this was completely unnecessary for the purpose of the security surveillance system. The DPA concluded this as a violation of the principle of data retention. Moreover, the DPA also found the company guilt of a violation of the information obligations set out in Art. 13 GDPR. Finally, the DPA claimed that the company was guilty of a violation of Art. 32 (1) GDPR. In essence, any individual who used the software with authorized access used the same account, not individual ones.

allItems.name: Luxembourg
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The DPA from Luxembourg (also known as CNPD) has fined a company with EUR 7,600. The company had previously installed a video surveillance system to safeguard the company’s assets and prevent unauthorized entry by random individuals. The only problem was that two of the cameras also captured part of the public space (public street), and six cameras covered the workplace of the employees. The DPA also discovered that the recordings were not only unnecessary to ensure the purposes associated with the video surveillance, but that the data controller thus violated the principle of data minimization under Article 5 (1) c) of the GDPR. Finally, the data controller failed to comply with its information obligations as per Art. 13 GDPR.

allItems.name: Luxembourg
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 38 (1), (3) GDPR, Art. 39 (1) a), b) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to appoint data protection officer
allItems.summary: The DPA of Luxembourg fined a company with EUR 15,000 because the data controller had insufficiently involved the data protection officers in matters related to the protection of personal data. Moreover, the data controller also gave the data protection officer insufficient independence and autonomy. Lastly, the data protection officer received insufficient training from the data controller.

allItems.name: Luxembourg
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The DPA from Luxembourg (also known as CNPD) has fined a company with EUR 12,500. The data controller had previously installed a video surveillance system to safeguard the company’s assets and prevent unauthorized entry by random individuals. The original purpose of the recording was to secure access to risky and private places, as well as ensure the safety of employees and prevent any accidents. However, the security surveillance system also captured some parts of the public space. The DPA concluded that the data controller had violated the principle of data minimization under Article 5 (1) c) GDPR. Moreover, the data controller failed to inform the data subjects (employees) about the recording/data processing, violating its duty to inform.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as EPD) has fined Aparcamiento Arcusa S.L.U with EUR 1,500. The data controller had previously installed a video surveillance system that also covered the public space. The DPA concluded this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. Furthermore, the data controller had failed to properly inform the data subjects about the data processing through the video surveillance and had thus violated its duty to inform. The fine includes EUR 1,000 for a violation of Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR and EUR 500 for a violation of Art. 13 GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Telefónica Mobiles España, S.A.U. with EUR 45,000. A data subject complained to the DPA against the controller. He stated that his telephone number and customer profile had been used by the data controller’s employees to conduct tests in call centers and other branches without his consent. As a result of this, the data subject had received 247 unsolicited calls from the data controller. The original fine of EUR 75,000 was reduced to EUR 45,000 due to immediate payment and acknowledgement of responsibility.

allItems.name: Denmark
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Danish DPA (also known as Datatilsynet) has fined the Region of Syddanmark with EUR 67,900 for failing to comply with its data controller obligations to implement proper security measures. The issue at hand came to the attention of the DPA when a citizen issued a complaint to the authority in 2020, regarding improper use of security in the personal data processing of the citizen’s child by the region. Afterwards, the region reported the matter to the authority as a personal data breach. The Region of Syddanmark had kept at the time a database for research and clinical purposes for a period of more than 1.5 years. However, the database inadequately secured against unauthorized access by unknown individuals. Through a manipulation of URLs, everyone could technically gain access to PDF documents stored in the database. This allowed all citizens who were registered in the database – and who also had login information to the database – to access the personal data of all the individuals registered in the database. The database also contained questionnaires with health information on more than 30,000 children receiving psychiatric care.

allItems.name: France
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) e) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art .14 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The French DPA (also known as CNIL) has fined the private insurer SGAM AG2R LA MONDIALE with EUR 1,750,000. The CNIL had performed an inspection at the AG2R LA MONDIALE group back in 2019. Then, the CNIL discovered that the data controller was keeping the data of millions of individuals for an unjustified period of time and also failed to comply with their information obligations regarding the telephone canvassing campaigns. Regarding the data of prospects, the data controller failed to comply with the maximum retention period of three years as outlined in the reference framework and in the Group’s processing register. Therefore, the data controller kept the data of nearly 2,000 customers who hadn’t maintained contact with the controller for a period greater than three years, and in some cases five years. Regarding the customer personal data, the data controller failed to comply with the maximum statutory retention periods as stipulated in the Insurance Code and the Commercial Code. In this case, the data controller had retained the data of more than 2 million customers. Some sets of this data were sensitive (health data and banking data), and the company wasn’t legally permitted to retain this data for as long as it did.

allItems.name: Luxembourg
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles, and others
allItems.summary: The DPA authority in Luxembourg fined Amazon Europe Core S.a.r.l. with EUR 746,000,000 ($887,000,000) because the US subsidiary did not process personal data according to the GDPR regulations. Apparently, Amazon Europe Core had misused its customer data for targeted advertising. But the company defends itself, saying that there was no data breach and at not time was customer data exposed to other unauthorized third parties. The fine enforced by the Luxembourg DPA came as a result of a 2018 complaint by French privacy rights group, La Quadrature du Net. They argued that Amazon, among other big companies, manipulate customers through targeted content and advertising. They further argued that this was against the principles or privacy and information freedoms of all Europeans. Whether Amazon’s defense wins the case remains to be seen.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c), e) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 22 (3) GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 30 (1) c), f), g) GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR, Art. 37 (7) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined the food delivery service Deliveroo Italy s.r.l. with EUR 2,500,000 because the company had unlawfully processed personal data of approximately 8000 drivers. During the investigation, Garante discovered several serious data protection violations. These violations included a clear lack of transparency regarding the algorithms used to manage drivers, both during the assignment of jobs and when they booked work shifts. Deliveroo had been using a centralized system to manage its drivers, but the system also processed the assignment of orders and the booking of work shifts. However, Garante noticed that the data controller failed to properly inform its drivers about how the system they had installed on their smartphones worked, and also failed to ensure the accuracy and correctness of the algorithmic systems they used to evaluate the drivers. Additionally, Garante also found that Deliveroo had underwent a detailed assessment of the drivers’ work performance – through the continuous geolocation of their device, which was disproportionate to the assignment of the order (e.g., recording the drivers’ position every 12 seconds) – and through the retainment and storage of a certain amount of personal data the company collected during the execution of the orders, including any communication with customer service. In this sense, the company failed to mention or define the storage period of the personal data they had collected from the drivers. Instead, the data controller had only defined a flat storage period of six years. Moreover, Garante discovered that the data controller had failed to implement the necessary technical and organizational measures that would ensure adequate security of the data processing. Deliveroo Italy also failed to conduct a data protection impact assessment, despite this being necessary, considering the risk the drivers were exposed to.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The data controller did not have an adequate privacy statement on its website.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Fincas Miguel García S.L. with EUR 2,000. A data subject had previously filed a complaint against the data controller, claiming of a breach of Art. 13 GDPR. The DPA discovered that the information provided to the data subject by the controller wasn’t compliant with the regulations of Art. 13 GDPR. More specifically, there were certain aspects missing, such as information regarding the purposes of the data processing, the purpose for this data collection, and a legal basis for the collection, as well as any information regarding the legitimate interests of the company for collecting the data. The company also had to mention the period for which the personal data will be stored, as well as the right to withdraw consent at any time.

allItems.name: France
allItems.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItems.summary: The French DPA (also known as CNIL) has fined MONSANTO with EUR 400,000. Back in May 2019, several media outlets revealed that MONSANTO possessed a file that contained the personal data of more than 200 political figures or members of civil society (e.g., scientists, farmers, journalists, or environmental activists) who would most likely be influential in the public debate regarding the renewal and authorization of glyphosate across Europe. The CNIL also received seven complaints from various data subjects affected by this file. For each of these individuals, the aforementioned file contained information regarding the organization the data subjects belonged to, the position they held, their cell phone number, business email address, business address, business phone number, and even Twitter accounts. Additionally, CNIL stated that each person had been assigned a score from 1 to 5 to evaluate their credibility, support, and influence for Monsanto on several issues. The DPA believes that the company had critically violated the regulations of the GDPR by failing to inform the data subjects that their personal data was processed and stored in this file. Furthermore, the CNIL claimed that the company had foregone the contractual guarantees which would have regulated the relationships between the company and other subcontractors. Still, creating contact files for lobbying purposes by stakeholders is not illegal. But the data subjects were still within their rights to be informed about their data being in this file, in order to exercise other rights, such as the right to object to the data storage. Moreover, the CNIL discovered that the data collection had been carried out by a data provider that Monsanto had contracted, though in violation of Article 28 of the General Data Protection Regulation because it failed to include in its contracts with the data processor the provisions stated in the GDPR, more specifically the provisions regarding data security.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 25 (1) GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Mercadona S.A. with EUR 2,520,000. The data controller had previously installed facial recognition systems in many Mercadona stores to track individuals with criminal convictions or restraining orders. However, the system also captured everyone who entered the stores, including minors and employees of MERCADONA. During the investigation, the DPA discovered numerous privacy violations. For example, the system violated the principle of data minimization, and the principle of necessity and proportionality. Apparently, the data controller would process multiple biometric data that went beyond the purpose of the system. Additionally, the DPA claimed that Mercadona’s privacy impact assessment was insufficient because it failed to take into account the specific risks to Mercadona’s employees, which were posed by data processing through the facial recognition systems. Moreover, MERCADONA had also violated its duty to inform accordingly by by failing to properly provide data subjects with information about the personal data processing. The original fine of EUR 3,150,000 consisted of EUR 500,000 associated with a violation of Art. 5(1)(c), EUR 2,000,000 associated with a violation of Art. 6, and Art. 9 of the GDPR, EUR 100,000 associated with a violation of Art. 12 and Art. 13 of the GDPR, EUR 500,000 associated with a violation of Art. 25(1) of the GDPR, and EUR 50,000 associated with a violation of Art. 35 of the GDPR. The original fine was reduced to EUR 2,250,000 due to voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The website operator’s privacy policy did not comply with Art. 13 of the GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The company was fined by the Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) because one website of the data controller did not properly provide data about the owner (postal address and tax number).

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: A data subject filed a complain against the company to the DPA, claiming that she had been receiving promotional text messages from the data controller. The data subject had previously requested the deletion of her personal data from the databases of the data controller several times before.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined the political party PODEMOS PARTIDO POLÍTICO with EUR 2,400. The data controller had installed video surveillance cameras that also covered the public space. The DPA claimed this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. Additionally, the data controller had failed to properly inform the data subjects about the data processing by the video surveillance, thus violating violated its duty to inform. Because of voluntary payment and acknowledgement of guilt, the original fine of EUR 4,000 was reduced to EUR 2,400.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: An owners’ association was fined with EUR 900 by the Spanish DPA for installing a video surveillance camera on the house of a data subject, which covered both the public pool area and certain parts of the house. Because of voluntary payment and acknowledgment of guilt, the original fine of EUR 1500 was reduced to EUR 900.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: An owners’ association was fined with EUR 2000 by the Spanish DPA for installing a video surveillance camera on the house of a data subject. The data subject complained that the camera captured both the public pool area and the interior of several rooms in the data subject’s house.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined PRA Iberia S.L. with EUR 60,000. A data subject had previously filed a complaint against the data controller with the AEPD. The data subject complained that the data controller had made a claim based on a contract that the data subject had no knowledge of, and which he hadn’t concluded with the data controller. The AEPD also concluded that the data subject had previously attempted to exercise his right to information, but he received no response from the data controller. Instead, the data controller continued to add interest to the data subject’s alleged debt.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.controller: Universidad A Distancia De Madrid, S.A
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined UNIVERSIDAD A DISTANCIA DE MADRID, S.A. with EUR 3,000. A data subject had previously filed a complaint against the distance-learning university. He claimed that he had requested from the controller the deletion of all his personal data, and a guarantee that the data controller would not process his data again. He received a confirmation, that his data had been completely deleted. However, the data subject received email advertising from the data controller, despite his request for data deletion. The AEPD then imposed a fine of EUR 5,000, which was reduced to EUR 3,000 due to acknowledgement of guilt and immediate payment.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b), (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 14 (1), (4) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA (also known as ANSPDCP) has fined a private individual with EUR 200 because of the unlawful disclosure of personal data. The data controller had disclosed personal data of many individuals by posting various materials on Facebook and distributing them to several households. The personal data included a photo of the salary statement of a data subject, which further included his first name, surname, salary, and place of work. In the file, there was another photo from the register of children who were enrolled in the kindergarten of the municipality, which included personal data of a minor child. The DPA discovered that the data controller had processed the data without having a legal basis. It had also not informed the data subjects about the data processing.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Club Náutico el Estacio with EUR 3,000. A data subject complained against the controller to the DPA because the data controller had previously announced publicly a record of the club’s meetings on its website. By doing this, it disclosed personal data of the data subject because the records had no access restrictions.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Body Tonic Shop S.L with EUR 2,000. A data subject had previously signed a contract with the gym Fitness Place. In the contract, the data subject agreed that his personal data could be shared with the company Vasco Andaluza de Inversiones S.L., the actual owner of Fitness Place sports centers. However, the company also shared the data with Gerco Fit S.L. and Body Tonic Shop S.L., despite this not being included in the contract. Gerco Fit S.L. and Body Tonic Shop S.L. processed the data without a legal basis.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Body Tonic Shop S.L with EUR 2,000. A data subject had previously signed a contract with the gym Fitness Place. In the contract, the data subject agreed that his personal data could be shared with the company Vasco Andaluza de Inversiones S.L., the actual owner of Fitness Place sports centers. However, the company also shared the data with Gerco Fit S.L. and Body Tonic Shop S.L., despite this not being included in the contract. Gerco Fit S.L. and Body Tonic Shop S.L. processed the data without a legal basis.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Body Tonic Shop S.L with EUR 2,000. A data subject had previously signed a contract with the gym Fitness Place. In the contract, the data subject agreed that his personal data could be shared with the company Vasco Andaluza de Inversiones S.L., the actual owner of Fitness Place sports centers. However, the company also shared the data with Gerco Fit S.L. and Body Tonic Shop S.L., despite this not being included in the contract. Gerco Fit S.L. and Body Tonic Shop S.L. processed the data without a legal basis.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined APARTAMENTOS PLAYA DE COVACHOS, S.L. with EUR 1,000. The data controller had installed a security surveillance system at the resort and proceed to inform about the system on information posters. However, the posters offered no details about the contact details and identity of the person responsible for the security system.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined UST GLOBAL ESPANA, S.A. with EUR. An employee had filed a complaint against the data controller with the AEPD. UST GLOBAL ESPAÑA, S.A. was, at the time, acting as a service provider for OpenBank regarding a project. On the 1st of August 2020, the data controller emailed OpenBank that two new employees (one of them the complainant) would join the specified project, and proceeded to request access to various applications, including a VPN. This email included the professional email addresses, first and last names, as well as ID card numbers of both employees. This way, both OpenBank and the other employee gained unauthorized access to the complainant’s data. The DPA concluded this was a violation of the principle of integrity and confidentiality.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) a) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined INSTAPACK, S.L.  with EUR 3,000. A data subject complained to the DPA that he had been receiving many SMS messages on his phone every month in which he was informed of the receipt of orders and deliveries. He was also asked to rate the company. He’d stated that he had previously sent a request for deletion of his data to the contact address on the controller’s website, but that he had received no reply. Instead, the messages kept on coming even after he submitted the deletion request.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA fined a private individual with EUR 4,000 for installing two security cameras on a public road without proper authorization. The security cameras covered parts of a private property, and the DPA also discovered that he had been storing the recordings for longer than necessary. The DPA concluded this was a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 600 for unauthorized video surveillance. The data controller had installed a video surveillance camera that covered neighboring houses and a public street. The DPA concluded this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. However, due to voluntary payment, the original fine in the amount of EUR 750 has been reduced to EUR 600.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) fined a private individual with EUR 2,000. The data controller had created a fake profile by the name of Katy on a dating website, using the data subject’s phone number attached to the picture of another person. The data controller managed this because the website asked for no proof of identity when creating a profile.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a gas inspector. The data controller had performed butane gas checks in the private homes of the data subjects based on a list containing their surnames, first names, addresses and telephone numbers. But, the data subjects hadn’t consented to this list. The original fine of EUR 5,000 was reduced to EUR 4,000 due to acknowledgement of guilt.

allItems.name: Austria
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 7 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Austrian DPA has fined Rewe affiliate Ö-Bonus Club GmbH with EUR 2,000,000. During the signing up procedure for the jö Bonus Club customer loyalty program, the data controller failed to adequately explain that customers’ data and shopping behavior are directly used to create individual profiles, and that the collected information is also passed on to partner companies. According to the GDPR, the information provided must be easily accessible understood. However, the data controller had designed the registration procedure for the jö Bonus Club in a way that the clarification about the data usage and profiling was only accessible after scrolling down. But the consent was located higher up, so in all cases, the customers would give the consent before reading the clarification. Moreover, the physical flyers also contained a signature bottom on the bottom that not only acted as a confirmation in the enrollment to the club, but also a consent to the data profiling (which wasn’t stated as such). The DPA concluded that the data controller violated its duty as a data controller to provide consent and clarification in an understandable and easily accessible form in clear and simple language. As such, the DPA deemed the consents to be invalid, and the profiling that had been performed based on these consents were unlawful.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA fined Vodafone Espana, S.A.U with EUR 96,000. A data subject had complained with the DPA against the data controller for failing to comply with her request for data deletion. The data subject claims that she had been receiving calls from the company ISGF, which acted on behalf of the data controller, claiming a debt received from a third party for an ADSL connection for the residence of the data subject. However, the data subject had never concluded a contract for an ADSL connection. Instead, a third party fraudulently used the name and ID number of the data subject to conclude a contract in her name. The data subject then requested ISGF to cancel the contract and asked the data controller to delete her personal data. However, the data controller had failed to respond to her deletion request. The DPA then imposed a fine of EUR 120,000 which consisted of EUR 70,000 due to a violation of Art. 6 (1) GDPR and EUR 50,000 due to a violation of Art. 17 (1) GDPR. The original fine was reduced to EUR 96,000 due to voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 3,000. Two neighbors had constantly complained about the individual to the DPA because he had installed two video surveillance cameras retrofitted with motion detectors on a public street. These cameras recorded clear images of the neighbors entering their properties from the street. The DPA considered this to be a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The AEPD (Spanish DPA) fined Future Vinline S.L. because its privacy policy did not comply with the regulations of the GDPR. However, the original fine of EUR 10,000 was reduced to EUR 6,000 because of admission of guilt and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The data controller used surveillance cameras without offering proper contact information, as per Art. 13 GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined CLUB GIMNASIA RITMICA SAN ANTONIO with EUR 5,000. An individual had complained against the data controller with the AEPD because the data controller had posted pictures and videos of her two underage daughters on Instagram. The complainant had previously informed the data controller that she did not want pictures of her daughters on social media, and she refused to give permission for her daughters to be photographed and recorded.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (AEPD) has fined DESPACHO TEJEDOR INFANTES CONSULTORES ASESORES with EUR 2,000 because the data controller had mistakenly sent an employee two emails containing personal information (payroll as well as extension of working hours) of the data subject.

allItems.name: Norway
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Norwegian DPA (also known as Datatilsynet) has fined a waxing salon operator of Waxing Palace A.S. with EUR 9,600. Apparently, the data controller was using camera surveillance that captured the reception area. The DPA found out that the data controller didn’t have a legal basis for this camera surveillance, and also did not provide adequate information about it. This camera surveillance affected both customers and employees.

allItems.name: France
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: CNIL fined the French newspaper Le Figaro with €50,000 for placing cookies on its lefigaro.fr website without users consent. This is one of the very few fines issued against a website for cookie consent violations.

allItems.name: Czech Republic
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 12 (2), (3), Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 16 GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR, Art. 18 GDPR, Art. 19 GDPR, Art. 20 GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 22 GDPR
allItems.type: Multiple
allItems.summary: A company unlawfully copied personal data from public registers, and the Czech DPA fined it.

allItems.name: Czech Republic
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: A TV broadcaster was offering an online section on its website about the processing of persona, yet the section was both hidden and inaccessible because of inaccurate links.

allItems.name: Czech Republic
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Czech DPA (also known as UOOU) fined Mall.tv with EUR 2,700 for because the company had recorded parts of the public space unlawfully. The DPA investigated this event and found out that the company had used two security cameras for the recordings. These cameras were recording parts of the public space which they would then broadcast in real time over internet television. These recordings were such high-quality that anyone could identify passing pedestrians and vehicles as well as their license plates.

allItems.name: Czech Republic
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: A person had been receiving invoices for goods she had ordered that came from other companies than the ones she had bought the goods from. So, the data subject filed a complaint to the actual company she’d ordered the goods from, requesting information about the processing of her personal data, such as the reason for the processing and the legal basis. The company failed to reply to her request for information, which led the data subject to contact the DPA. During the investigation, the Czech DPA requested from the data controller to provide the data subject with the information she’d requested. Again, the data controller failed to respond, and the DPA fined the company with EUR 1,900.

allItems.name: Czech Republic
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Czech DPA (also known as UOOU) investigated the operator of a non-governmental medical facility due to an alleged data security breach. The data operator offers diagnostic tests for medical patients. During one such operation, the test results of several patients were posted on the operator’s website, as a communication method to physicians and patients. This security breach on the data operator’s website was the result of an unknown individuals’ actions, no less. After the incident, the data controller stopped using its website and thought of technical and organizational measures to implement that would increase overall security. However, the DPA discovered that the data controller was using other websites for the same purposes, and these websites suffered from the same security weaknesses. Still, the data controller did not stop using these other websites, and it did not propose the implementation of new security measures either. So, the UOOU fined the company with EUR 387.

allItems.name: Czech Republic
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 7 (1) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 16 GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR, Art. 18 GDPR, Art. 19 GDPR, Art. 20 GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR
allItems.type: Multiple types of violations
allItems.summary: The Czech DPA (also known as UOOU) fined a ski rental company because the data controller asked its customers to provide a full copy of their IDS or a financial deposit when they rented sports equipment. Apparently, the company requested consent for these ID copies in the sports equipment rental agreements. So, when the customers signed the sports equipment rental agreement, they also consented to their IDs copies being obtained by the data controller. However, the DPA claimed this method of obtaining consent was unlawful and had no legal basis. Additionally, the data subjects received no clear clarification about this personal data processing.

allItems.name: Czech Republic
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The public university demanded their students to provide personal data during the application procedures, which was unlawful.

allItems.name: Czech Republic
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 12 (1) GDPR, Art. 28 (2), (3) GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The healthcare provider used a software from a third party to collect personal data from its patients without informing them about the data processing.

allItems.name: Czech Republic
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 48 (1) b) LGT, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 23 (4) LOPGD
allItems.type: The bank made it mandatory for customers to provide a copy of their IDs when opening an account. This was unlawful.
allItems.summary: Non-compliance with subjects’ rights protection safeguards

allItems.name: Czech Republic
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: Violating the principle of data minimization, the company stored biometric signatures of its customers.

allItems.name: Czech Republic
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 (3) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: A public school disclosed personal information with the municipality mayor, who further released this information on the city radio mobile application.

allItems.name: Czech Republic
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: A state-subsidized company shared employee photos on its website without obtaining their consent and without having a sufficient legal basis to do so.

allItems.name: Czech Republic
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Czech DPA (also known as UOOU) fined a company for illegal personal data processing. The sales staff of the data controller contacted several individuals for advertising purposes. Apparently, these data subjects had used the services of the company’s sales staff in 2016 to conclude financial and insurance contracts. However, back then, the sales staff had been working for another company and they’d concluded an agency contract with that company. The DPA states that the use of such personal data that these sales representatives knew from previous activities to other companies represented a breach of contract with that company. Moreover, there was no legal basis justifying the data processing for advertising purposes regarding the present data controller.

allItems.name: Estonia
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Estonian DPA fined Südameapteegi e-apteek with EUR 100,000 for illegal processing of personal data without obtaining the consent of the data subjects. The personal data was related to the prescriptions for medicines. In this sense, other third parties could access another data subject’s current prescriptions on the online website of the pharmacies without the data subject’s consent. The access was made only on the basis of their personal identification code. The Estonian DPA also noticed that, indeed, an e-pharmacy should allow people to purchase prescription medicine on behalf of others, the processing of the data subjects’ personal data should still be done with the consent of the data subjects in question. The claim of another party that the data subject has given their consent does not equal to an official voluntary consent, since the pharmacy cannot check whether the data subject has indeed given their consent, and to what purpose.

allItems.name: Estonia
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Estonian DPA fined Azeeta.ee e-apteek with EUR 100,000 for illegal processing of personal data without obtaining the consent of the data subjects. The personal data was related to the prescriptions for medicines. In this sense, other third parties could access another data subject’s current prescriptions on the online website of the pharmacies without the data subject’s consent. The access was made only on the basis of their personal identification code. The Estonian DPA also noticed that, indeed, an e-pharmacy should allow people to purchase prescription medicine on behalf of others, the processing of the data subjects’ personal data should still be done with the consent of the data subjects in question. The claim of another party that the data subject has given their consent does not equal to an official voluntary consent, since the pharmacy cannot check whether the data subject has indeed given their consent, and to what purpose.

allItems.name: Finland
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, § 3 Law 759/2004
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: A higher education institution received a fine of EUR 25,000 from the Finnish DPA for violating data protection regulations during the processing of employee location data. The data controller had previously implemented a mobile application, allowing teleworkers to clock in and out. However, to use this application on a mobile device, the workers had to provide location data. The data collection took place automatically when the workers clocked in, and it was an in-built feature of the app. Without this feature, the workers couldn’t clock in. Based on the information provided by the data controller, this location data was not used nor exploited in any specific way, but rather it was only processed when the workers clocked in, for technical reasons. However, the simple fact that the app doesn’t allow workers to clock in without collecting their location data doesn’t make it a necessity to collect that data. The company could have devised the app differently. At that point, the Finnish DPA concluded that the company had violated data collection principles as well as the principle of data minimization, since it wasn’t necessary to collect location data.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The DPA of Lower Saxony has fined a company with EUR 65,000. The caused for this fine was a report made by the company regarding a data breach as per Art. 33 GDPR. The DPA began a security audit of the web presence of the company. Then, the DPA discovered that the company was using an outdated web store application which no longer received security updates. The application developer had specifically stated that no one should use that version of the app anymore because it had major security vulnerabilities. During the investigations, the DPA noticed that the passwords stored in the company’s databases were insufficiently secured. Consequently, the DPA concluded that the company had failed to take the necessary technical measures as per the protection requirements of the DPA, thus violating Art. 32 GDPR.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The Bavarian DPA fined a company with EUR 7,000 because it had refused access to the DPA on the business premises during an on-site inspection, following an alleged breach of Art. (1) f) GDPR. The DPA fined the company with EUR 20,000 but the district court reduced the fine to EUR 7,000.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) f) GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA (also known as HDPA) fined Ιγνατιάδης Νικόλαος και ΣΙΑ Ε.Ε. with EUR 2,000 because the data controller had installed and used surveillance security cameras in areas where company employees were present. The data controller claims that these cameras were there for security purposes after some theft incidents had occurred in the past. The security system was meant to detect and take notice of anyone entering the facilities. However, the DPA found out that the camera installations weren’t only used for property protection purposes. So, the DPA concluded that the company had violated the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA fined a pediatrician with EUR 5,000. The data controller did not comply with a father’s request to view his son’s medical records through e-mail.

allItems.name: Hungary
allItems.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItems.controller: Budapesti Műszaki és Gazdaságtudományi Egyetem (Budapest University of Technology and Economics)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 9 (2) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItems.type: Multiple
allItems.summary: The Hungarian DPA (also known as NAIH) fined the Budapest University of Technology and Economics with EUR 22,200. The data controller had unlawfully processed the personal data of many individuals during the audit of social scholarship applications. The data controller had no legal basis to process the personal data, especially sensitive data, since there was no good reason to process it for the evaluation of the applications.

allItems.name: Hungary
allItems.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 9 (1) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Hungarian DPA (also known as NAIH) fined a credit institute with EUR 97,150. After receiving complaints from two parents about an unlawful processing of personal data regarding a “childbirth incentive loan”, the NAIH started investigating the credit institute. The two parents had requested a suspension of repayment, and for this, they had to prove that the fetus was at least 12 weeks old. The data controller copied their entire pregnancy booklet to prove this. However, the DPA concluded that copying the entire booklet was a violation of the principle of data minimization, because the booklet contained a lot of health data irrelevant do the purpose of the data processing. So, the NAIH stated that the data controller had no legal basis to collect this data.

allItems.name: Hungary
allItems.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Hungarian DPA (also known as NAIH) fined a website operator with EUR 2,800. The data controller couldn’t prove the lawfulness of processing the personal data when requested by the DPA. So, the DPA concluded that the data controller breached its duty of accountability.

allItems.name: Hungary
allItems.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) d) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 12 (2), (3), (4) GDPR, Art. 17 (1) GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: he Hungarian DPA (also known as NAIH) has fined Magyar Telekom Nyrt. with EUR 28,400. The data controller had mistakenly sent email newsletters to the data subject because a third-party had entered the wrong email address to the newsletter list. Then, the data subject requested numerous times for the data controller to delete his personal contact data. But despite this, he continued receiving the newsletter, and the data controller sent him a link that he could use to unsubscribe from the newsletter.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: Mapei S.p.A. did not respond to the request for access to personal data from a data subject. Additionally, the company did not close down the email account of the data subject even after terminating the work contract.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The community unlawfully published personal data on its website.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) fined Charly Mike s.r.l with EUR 3,000. The data controller is an operator of Hotel Olimpo in Alberobello. The Italian DPA received a complaint about the hotel’s video surveillance system. The investigation pointed out that the hotel had installed 17 fixed cameras and one with 360° recording. These cameras were placed both inside and outside the hotel, and they recorded customers and employees alike. This system had been operated without any sign of its existence, as well.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.controller: Azienda Unita Sanitaria Locale Toscana Sud Est
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 28 GDPR, Art. 30 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) fined Azienda USL Toscana Sud Est with EUR 100,000. The data controller works in the healthcare sector and has launched the “Sanita di iniziativa” program. This program encompasses participating companies transmitting healthcare data of chronically ill patients to the data controller. Then, the controller will develop personalized health plans for these patients, based on the provided health data. However, the Italian DPA noticed several data protection violations regarding the program. One such violation regarded the consent that data subjects would have to provide to have their health data processed. The data subjects weren’t properly informed about the length of the data storage, their rights (right of access and complaint), for what purpose and how their data would be processed. Moreover, the data controller didn’t keep a register of the processing activities. It also did not protect the data processing and also did not conduct a data protection impact assessment, despite this being necessary because of the sensitive nature of the personal data.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), f) GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) fined Istituti ospedalieri Bergamaschi with EUR 45,000. During an investigation prompted by a report of a data breach, the DPA found out that a patient had mistakenly received clinical documentation and medical records from seven patients in this digital medical record.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) fined Azienda Ospedaliera Universitaria Careggi with EUR 6,000 for violating Art. 5 GDPR and Art. 9 GDPR. The institution had previously notified the Italian DPA of a data breach as per Art. 33 GDPR, regarding the transmission of health data to a wrong individual. Apparently, the institution had sent medical documents belonging to a patient to another person, by mistake. The data controller claims that this incident took place because of a printing process. Out of two printers present at the ward where the affected patient was being treated, one had preloaded medical health data of another patient, which a doctor sent to his print job (documents of the wrong recipient).

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.controller: Ministero dell’Istruzione, Ufficio Scolastico Regionale per il Lazio
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined the Lazio Region School Authority with EUR 4,000. A parent had previously filed a complained against the school authority because it had forwarded personal data of his disabled son to the Office of Public Administration. This personal data included information about the underaged child’s health condition. The parent had complained in the past about various irregularities found in the allocation of support hours for disabled students at the I.C.G. Pitocco school of Castelnuovo di Porto. Apparently, the school authority had transmitted that personal data to discard this allegation, but the DPA concluded that the data transfer was unlawful.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.controller: Azienda Provinciale per i Servizi Sanitari di Trento
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) fined Azienda Provinciale per i Servizi Sanitary di Trento with EUR 150,000. The data controller mistakenly sent 293 medical records of 175 patients to their respective general practitioners, despite the patients requesting them not to do this. Two of the affected patients were minors, and several other patients were women who had undergone abortions. During the investigation, Garante discovered that the health data was transmitted because of an error in the patient report management software.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) fined Azienda Usl della Romagna with EUR 120,000. The health authority of Romagna had mistakenly transmitted the abortion health report of a patient to a general practitioner despite the patient requesting not to inform her general practitioner about the abortion. The report was transmitted via the regional network “Sole.” During the investigation, Garante found out that the software that manages discharges, transfers, and patient admissions glitched, which resulted in the data transmission.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.controller: Aeroporto Guglielmo Marconi di Bologna S.p.a.
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The identity of the whistleblowers that contributed to this report requires protection from special confidentiality because the processed information is sensitive. Moreover, the risk of retaliation and discrimination in the work environment is unusually high. Moving on, the data controller is always obliged to comply with the principle of data protection, as well as ensure the security and integrity of the data. In this context, the Italian DPA (also known as Garante) fined Aeroporto Guglielmo Marconi di Bologna S.p.a. with EUR 4,000 and its software supplier, aiComply S.r.l. with EUR 20,000. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the application used for managing and collecting criminal reports had been accessed without a security protocol. Moreover, the application failed to provide encryption for the reporting party’s identification data, the attached documents, and any information about the reports. The DPA concluded this was a violation of the obligation to take adequate organizational and technical measures that would ensure a proper level of security relevant to the risk to the data subjects. Moreover, the DPA found out that the data controller should have carried out an impact assessment, considering how sensitive the processed data was, and the magnitude of the vulnerabilities of the data subjects.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.controller: Aeroporto Guglielmo Marconi di Bologna S.p.a.
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The identity of the whistleblowers that contributed to this report requires protection from special confidentiality because the processed information is sensitive. Moreover, the risk of retaliation and discrimination in the work environment is unusually high. Moving on, the data controller is always obliged to comply with the principle of data protection, as well as ensure the security and integrity of the data. In this context, the Italian DPA (also known as Garante) fined Aeroporto Guglielmo Marconi di Bologna S.p.a. with EUR 4,000 and its software supplier, aiComply S.r.l. with EUR 20,000. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the application used for managing and collecting criminal reports had been accessed without a security protocol. Moreover, the application failed to provide encryption for the reporting party’s identification data, the attached documents, and any information about the reports. The DPA concluded this was a violation of the obligation to take adequate organizational and technical measures that would ensure a proper level of security relevant to the risk to the data subjects. Moreover, the DPA found out that aiComply did not contractually regulate the relationships with two other third-party companies that processed data for aiComply.

allItems.name: Lithuania
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Lithuanian DPA (VDAI) fined a company with EUR 8,000 for carrying out sound recordings on public transport buses, violating Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR, and Art. 35 GDPR.

allItems.name: Norway
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b) GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Norwegian DPA (also known as Datatilsynet) fined the municipality of Asker with EUR 100,000. Back on the 20th of May 2020, the DPA received a complaint about the unlawful publishing of personal data on the municipality’s official website. Anyone could view document names that were previously sent through the municipality’s email distribution list. Additionally, these documents also contained dates of birth and names of more than 127 people, and this included children. Even though the distribution lists were checked by two people daily, the municipality failed to detect this security breach. The Norwegian DPA states that this data breach was at least partly caused by a lacking security routine regarding the email lists.

allItems.name: Poland
allItems.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItems.controller: ID Finance Poland Sp. z o.o.
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 25 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b), d), (2) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Polish DPA (also known as UODO) fined ID Finance Poland Sp. z o.o. with EUR 235,300. Because of an error during the restart of a server, a server’s security server suffered an error and its settings were reset. This made the personal data of 140,699 individuals become publicly available. This data contained information about their addresses, first and last names, marital status, and nationalities. Moreover, the database containing this information was downloaded and deleted from the servers by an unknown third party who later asked the company for a ransom if they wanted the database back. The DPA concluded that the data controller had taken inadequate and insufficient organizational and technical measures that would protect the data processing, despite the existence of a high risk for the data subjects.

allItems.name: Poland
allItems.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItems.type: Failure to notify DPA of a data breach
allItems.summary: The Polish DPA (also known as UODO) fined a hospital operator with EUR 19,000 because a former employee had illegally copied the personal data of more than 100 patients directly from the computer network of the hospital. The data, once leaked, included names, dates of birth, social security numbers, telephone numbers, and physical addresses of data subjects. Despite classifying this data breach as extremely risky for the data subjects, the data controller still didn’t inform the data subjects about the incident. The DPA asked the data controller to inform the data subjects immediately and offer advice on adequate ways to minimize the impact of the data breach. However, the data controller failed to comply with the DPA’s request.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: Due to an unlawful disclosure of customer personal data through an SMS to another customer, the DPA fined Vodafone Espana S.A.U. with EUR 50,000 but it was reduced to EUR 30,000.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: Vodafone Espana S.A.U. had charged a Netflix service that the claimant hadn’t solicited. The claimant could further prove that the aforementioned service had been used by another household who was in control of the claimant’s phone number and bank account, which he had gotten from Vodafone. The company couldn’t prove that the claimant had freely consented to a contract regarding the Netflix services, so AEPD issued a fine of EUR 40,000. The company had charged a Netflix service that had not been solicited by the claimant. The claimant could prove that the service had been used by another household which allegedly had received the claimant’s bank account and phone number from Vodafone. Since Vodafone could not prove that the claimant had consented to the conclusion of the contract concerning the Netflix services, the AEPD imposed a fine of EUR 40.000.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The employer was using security cameras to record not only the company property but also employees, which is a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The employer was using security cameras to record not only the company property but also employees, which is a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: Vodafone Espana had sent a customer’s invoice data to an unauthorized third party because of a customer invoice complaint. The initial fine of EUR 75,000 was reduced to EUR 60,000 due to immediate payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: Vodafone Espana had sent the invoice history to a subscriber regarding an invoice complaint made by the subscriber. This invoice history contained the invoice data of another third party.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The company processed the personal data of a data subject unlawfully by sending him an invoice without being able to prove that they had any contractual relationship to begin with.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Vodafone Espana with EUR 60,000. The data subject, a former customer of the data controller a couple of years back, had received payment reminders from Vodafone via SMS for various services that she had never booked. She then informed the data controller about this, asked for clarification, and requested for deletion of her data. Vodafone replied positively, yet the SMS messages kept coming. The data subject then filed two other complaints with the Spanish DPA against Vodafone Espana. In both cases, the company had thought that the error was corrected and that the data subject’s contact details had been deleted. However, the data subject kept receiving SMS messages, which led the data subject to file a third complaint. The AEPD initially fined Vodafone Espana with EUR 100,000, but it was reduced to EUR 60,000 because of immediate payment and admission of guilt.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The company failed to provide the AEPD with enough information within a required timeframe, violating Art. 57 GDPR. The original fine of EUR 5,000 was reduced to EUR 3,000 because of admission of guilt and immediate payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Marbella Resorts S.L. with EUR 7,000. In this case, a data subject had previously booked a room in the company’s hotel complex. When the data subject was scheduled to arrive, a concierge copied the data subject’s data despite not being authorized to do this. The concierge should only have verified the data subject’s reservation and give the data subject the keys to the room. After the provided the concierge with his personal data, the data subject noticed that his personal data was published on a website with online content for adults. Therefore, the DPA concluded that the data controller didn’t show enough diligence in taking care of its clients’ personal data, violating Art. 29 (3) GDPR. The fine is composed proportionally of EUR 2,000 for a breach of Art. 22(2) LSSI and 5,000 EUR for a breach of Art. 28(3) GDPR. However, the original fine of EUR 7,000 was reduced to EUR 4,200 due to the immediate payment and admission of guilt.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 1,500 because he had published personal data of the data subject on a specific website without obtaining her consent first. This data included personal notes, photos, and even information about the sexual relationship between the data subject and the data controller. The AEPD concluded that the data controller had processed this personal data without a good legal reason, violating Art. 6 (1) a) GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The data controller had used CCTV cameras to capture the public space, violating the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a company with EUR 1,000. The data controller had been using the personal data of a third party in order to obtain a microcredit. However, the DPA claims that the data controller didn’t have a valid legal reason to process the data, violating Art. 6 (1) GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 6,000. Back on the 8th of July 2020, the AEPD took notice of the publishing of a video on social networks. The video showed a man aggressing a woman, with a younger male minor intervening and trying to stop the first man from abusing the woman. However, the faces of both the woman and the minor were not pixelated. The original fine of EUR 10,000 was reduced to EUR 6,000 because of admission of guilt and timely payment.

allItems.name: Sweden
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 (2) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Västerbotten Region failed to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures to ensure proper information security. The Swedish DPA found that the company carried out no risk analyses regarding access to patient data. The hospital information system Cosmic had not assigned the authorization for users according to the principle of minimum access. All the users had full access to all patient data, irrespective of work purposes or not.

allItems.name: Netherlands
allItems.authority: Dutch Supervisory Authority for Data Protection (AP)
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Dutch DPA (also known as AP) fined Overijssel with EUR 7,500 because it failed to notify the DPA of a personal data breach, violating Art. 33 GDPR. Due to a human error, an email containing information about a meeting had been set through an open distribution list. All 101 recipients were addressed as “Friends of the PVV” in this email, which openly stated their political beliefs, something that’s unlawful and against their basic privacy.

allItems.name: Netherlands
allItems.authority: Dutch Supervisory Authority for Data Protection (AP)
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Dutch DPA (AP) has imposed a fine of EUR 525,000 on Locatefamily.com. Locatefamily.com is a platform where people can search for the contact information of family members they have lost contact with or other people they would like to get in touch with. The data subjects complained that their contact information (name, address, phone number) was published on the website without their knowledge. The data subjects were not able to request the deletion of their data published on the site easily, because Locatefamily.com did not have any representation in the European Union. Organizations offering goods or services in the EU must have a representative to whom EU citizens can turn to obtain information or exercise their data protection rights. Accordingly, the Dutch data protection authority found a breach of Art. 27 GDPR.

allItems.name: Netherlands
allItems.authority: Dutch Supervisory Authority for Data Protection (AP)
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Dutch DPA (also known as AP) has fined CP&A with EUR 15,000. As part of the recording procedures of employee absences due to illness, the data controller documented the causes of illness and complaints of the data subject. However, the DPA discovered that this was unlawful because health data has special protection from this. Employers aren’t allowed to record the causes or reasons of sick leave. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the data controller failed to implement the required organizational and technical measures that would protect the data processing when recording absences. More specifically, the absence registration was accessible online with no authentical procedure in place. Normally, when the absence system is available online, it should have a multi-factor authentication procedure in place. According to the DPA, a more complex form of authentication. should have been put in place, aside from the normal login procedure.

allItems.name: Netherlands
allItems.authority: Dutch Supervisory Authority for Data Protection (AP)
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Dutch DPA (also known as AP) has fined an orthodontic clinic with EUR 12,000. As part of the online sign-up procedure for new patients (mostly underaged), there were mandatory fields with various patient personal data. This data, after being entered into the fields, was sent to the orthodontic clinic through an unencrypted connection. Clearly, this pose a massive risk of unauthorized access from unknown third parties, exposing the data subjects to danger.

allItems.name: Netherlands
allItems.authority: Dutch Supervisory Authority for Data Protection (AP)
allItems.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItems.summary: The Dutch DPA (also known as DPA) has fined TikTok, a video portal, with EUR 750,000 because it violated the privacy of young children. The privacy policies presented to Dutch users (mostly underaged children) was in English, making it difficult for them to understand the policies. Because the privacy policies were not in Dutch, TikTok failed to adequately explain how their app processes, collects, and reuses personal data. The DPA concluded that this is a violation of the company’s duty to provide accurate information.

allItems.name: Ireland
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: Facebook owned messaging app WhatsApp has been fined by the Data Protection Authority of Ireland with a huge sum of €225 million. This concludes an investigation spanning from 2018. The Data Protection Authority of Ireland commented that WhatsApp discharged its GDPR transparency obligations with regard to the provision of information and the transparency of that information to both users and non-users of WhatsApp’s service. This includes information provided to data subjects about the processing of information between WhatsApp and other Facebook companies.

allItems.name: Poland
allItems.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItems.controller: Fundację Promocji Mediacji i Edukacji Prawnej Lex Nostra
allItems.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItems.summary: The Polish DPA (also known as UODO) has fined the Fundację Promocji Mediacji i Edukacji Prawnej Lex Nostra with EUR 3,000. The institution promoted the mediation and legal education. But the data controller did not inform the DPA about a data breach regarding some data subjects. A couple of folders with personal data were stolen from the data controller in 2020. These folders had names, addresses, telephone numbers, and even PESEL numbers of more than 96 data subjects.

allItems.name: Denmark
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Danish DPA has fined Midtjylland Region with EUR 53,800. On the 12th of June, 2020, the DPA was notified by the region regarding a personal data security breach as per Art. 33 GDPR. According to the region, all staff and patients at a lifestyle center could access a building where approximately 100,000 physical patient records were stored. These records included health information and personal identity number details. This data breach took place because both staff and patients had received key cards that allowed them to access all three buildings of the lifestyle center, even though the users may not require to use them. Additionally, passersby could see the covers of some records though a window on the building. These covers showed personal data such as identity numbers and names. Therefore, the DPA concluded that the Midtjylland Region had failed to take adequate security measures to store the personal data. Moreover, the region had further failed to establish enough guidelines for access restrictions when creating the security key cards, and had also failed to conduct the necessary periodic testing, assessment, and evaluation of the security measures it had taken. In assessing the question of whether a fine should be imposed, the Danish DPA took into account, as an aggravating factor, that the region processed large amounts of sensitive data, such as health data.

allItems.name: Ireland
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Irish DPA has fined Vodafone Ireland Limited with EUR 1,400. Vodafone had previously sent marketing SMS, emails, and made telephone calls without obtaining the consent of the data subjects. Despite several complaints of the data subjects, Vodafone continued sending SMS messages, emails, and making calls to the data subjects. In one case, a former customer had contacted Vodafone a total of seven times, asking not to receive any more advertising calls on his cell phone. Despite his request, he continued to receive advertising calls. In another case, a customer had received an advertising call on his mobile phone number and told Vodafone that he did not want to receive more advertising calls. Despite this complaint, Vodafone made twelve more marketing calls to his cell phone. Another data subject filled out a form where he stated that he wanted Vodafone to refrain from making advertising calls to his cell phone. However, the employee who processed his request did not register the customer’s marketing preferences. So, the customer subsequently received fourteen more unsolicited commercial messages – seven emails and seven text messages.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) c), e) GDPR, Art. 6 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (3) b) GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined the Region of Lombardy with EUR 200,000. The region had previously published on its website the personal data of more than 100,000 students who had applied for state scholarships or financial grants to buy technical equipment, textbooks, and teaching materials. During the preliminary audit of Garante, one could view and download the full list of approved and funded applications, as well as the lists of state scholarship recipients, and the list containing ineligible applications on the official website of the region. These lists contained personal data that could identify each individual, including the names, IDs, grades, names and codes of the school, and the application number. The DPA concluded that the personal data of applications applying for these economic benefits should be protected at all times through special ways in order to prevent and social and economic problems.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 28 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Roma Capitale with EUR.
