The DPA had previously launched an investigation after an individual had complained to the authority about the newest parking meters installed in the city in 2018. In fact, the company who managed the parking lots and who was contracted by the city, Atac s.p.a., had performed a technical upgrade of the parking meters to provide new services (such as the payment of fines/fees or the purchase/renewal of public transport tickets) and introduce new payment methods that could also take into account the vehicle’s license plate number. Some of the equipment had been supplied by another company called Flowbird Italia s.r.l. All the parking information was then pooled and managed through a centralized system that could also be accessed through an app by any employees responsible for managing parking fees. The DPA investigation found some irregularities with this process. The city of Rome, as the data controller, had failed to provid information on the processing of the drivers’ data, failed to designate the company Atac as its data processor, and has also failed to provide the necessary instructions to process the data collected. Also, the subcontractor that the city had hired did not receive any formal instructions on how to proceed with the data processing. It was also discovered that the companies had failed to establish a data processing register. Moreover, the retention periods for the collected data had not been specified, and appropriate security measures had not been taken. For instance, the DPA found out that, at the time of the audit, some data leaks going to and from the system installed by Atac had been going through insecure channels. Additionally, officials of the city could have easily checked any license plate en masse and repeatedly to, say, find out a person’s parking location and habits. When calculating the fine for this unlawful data processing, the DPA took into account and aggravating factor, that of the large amount of personal data processed (from June 2018 to November 2019, the system established by Atac had already finished collecting the data of approximately 8,600,000 stops. This could potentially affect all users of the paid parking service in the city area), as well as the sanctions already received for data protection violations, but also the helpful cooperation offered by the city officials and the companies to remedy some violations detected during the inspection.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 30 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Flowbird Italia s.r.l.  with EUR 30,000. Garante had previously launched an investigation because of a complaint from a data subject who had issues with the new parking meters that were installed in the city of Rome in 2018. In fact, the company Atac s.p.a., which was contracted by the city to manage the aforementioned parking lots, had performed a technical upgrade of the parking meters to provide new services (such as the payment of fines/fees or the purchase/renewal of public transport tickets) and introduce new payment methods that could also take into account the vehicle’s license plate number. Some of the equipment had been supplied by Flowbird Italia s.r.l. All the parking information was then put through and managed by a centralized system that could also be accessed through an app by any employees responsible for managing parking fees. During the investigation, Garante discovered that Flowbird Italia had not established a data processing register either.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 30 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Atac s.p.a.  with EUR 400,000. Garante had previously launched an investigation because of a complaint from a data subject who had issues with the new parking meters that were installed in the city of Rome in 2018. In fact, the company Atac s.p.a., which was contracted by the city to manage the aforementioned parking lots, had performed a technical upgrade of the parking meters to provide new services (such as the payment of fines/fees or the purchase/renewal of public transport tickets) and introduce new payment methods that could also take into account the vehicle’s license plate number. Some of the equipment had been supplied by Flowbird Italia s.r.l. All the parking information was then put through and managed by a centralized system that could also be accessed through an app by any employees responsible for managing parking fees. It was also discovered that the companies had failed to establish a data processing register. Moreover, the retention periods for the collected data had not been specified, and appropriate security measures had not been taken. For instance, the DPA found out that, at the time of the audit, some data leaks going to and from the system installed by Atac had been going through insecure channels. Additionally, officials of the city could have easily checked any license plate en masse and repeatedly to, say, find out a person’s parking location and habits.

allItems.name: Poland
allItems.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItems.controller: President of the Zgierz District Court
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 25 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b), d), (2) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Polish DPA (also known as UODO) has fined the president of the Zgierz District Court with EUR 2,200. The president had previously reported a data breach that involved the loss of an unencrypted USB stick by a probation officer. The stick was used to store the data of about 400 persons under probation supervision. The lost and unencrypted data carrier has been found yet, so this means that unauthorized persons could still be able to access the personal data it contained. The president had wrongfully assumed that the duty to secure the data wasn’t his but the respective probation officers’ who were using this data stick. However, the DPA found that the president himself should have secured the USB sticks.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 28 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 33 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA (also known as ANSPDCP) has fined Actamedica SRL with EUR 3,000. The data controller had previously informed a data subject about the misplacement of her biological samples as well as a sum of money sent via a courier service. When the data subject inquired on the specific personal data that had been discloses during this data breach, and whether the company had informed the ANSPDCP, the data controller provided only the contact details of its lawyer as well as the email address of the courier service that the data subject could complain to. The ANSPDCP discovered a data breach regarding the controller’s obligation to implement organizational and technical measures that would ensure a proper level of protection appropriate to the risk to data subjects, as well as a breach of the controller’s obligation to notify the ANSPDCP of the data breach.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined an employer with EUR 1,000. The data controller had previously installed a video surveillance system without properly informing employees.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a company owner with EUR 2,000. A private individual had applied for a job at the data controller’s company and sent the controller his CV through WhatsApp. From that point on, the data subject was not informed about the processing of his personal or his data subject rights. The AEPD considered this to be a violation of Art. 13 of the GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined an agency with EUR 1,800. The data controller had improperly disposed of documents containing personal data of its clients in the garbage. The AEPD claimed this to be a total lack of security and data protection countermeasures as outlined by Art. 32 GDPR, which states that ‘the controller and processor shall implement appropriate technical and organizational measures to ensure an adequate level of security.’ The original fine of EUR 3,000 was reduced to EUR 1,800 due to voluntary payment and acknowledgement of guilt.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria, S.A with EUR 120,000. This happened because a private individual had complained to the AEPD about a lack of authentication. More specifically, when providing information via telephone, the bank would only request the ID number as sufficient identification. Theoretically, this means that anyone could call the bank, provide an ID number and impersonate the owner of the ID number to access private information about that person. No further authentication was needed. The DPA concluded this was a failure to implement the necessary technical and organizational measures that would ensure a level of security appropriate to the risk posed to the data subjects. The original fine of EUR 200,000 was reduced to EUR 120,000 due to voluntary payment and acknowledgement of guilt.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined an owners’ association with EUR 1,000. The data controller had illegally installed a video surveillance system in a residential complex that recorded, among others, public areas like the swimming pool, and of the public space. Additionally, surveillance cameras had been installed in the rooms where the guards of the residential complex changed their clothing, without any notice being given. The DPA considered this to be a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 21 (4) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) fined FurnishYourSpace S.L. with EUR 6,000. The AEPD had previously received a complaint from the Berlin DPA through the EU Internal Market Information System regarding the inadequate design of the data controller’s privacy notice. More specifically, both the contact data and the identity of the data controller were included in the privacy notice, but they were provided under false pretenses. Additionally, the data controller did not clarify the goals of the data processing. Moreover, he provided no legal basis for the processing and retention of the personal data, and no information was offered regarding the data subjects’ rightto object. Also, the privacy notice was complicated, with the wording containing grammatical errors and making use of uncommon and needlessly complex terminology. Finally, the privacy notice also required a tax identification number in order to issue a simplified invoice, i.e., an invoice that did not exceed the amount of EUR 3,000. The AEPD stated that this was a violation of the principle of legality. The fine is composed as follows: EUR 3,000 for a breach of Art. 12 GDPR and Art. 13 GDPR; EUR 1,000 for a breach of Art. 21 (4) GDPR; and EUR 2,000 for a breach of Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR and Art. 6 GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 21 LSSI
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Automecanica Jerez, S.L. with EUR 4,000. The data controller had previously sent several commercial e-mails to a large number of people without obtaining their consent. By doing so, the data controller did not anonymize the personal data of the recipients, such as the surname, first name and email address. This allowed the other recipients to view the data of other recipients, as well. The AEPD concluded that this was a violation of Article 5 (1) f) GDPR and Article 32 GDPR, since the controller had ultimately failed to implement technical and organizational measures that would ensure a sufficient level of security in the processing of personal data. Furthermorem the AEPD found a breach of Art. 21 LSSI.

allItems.name: Cyprus
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Cypriot DPA has fined the soccer club APOEL FC with EUR 40,000. Because of a lack of security measures in the club’s ticket sales system, unauthorized individuals could access the even disclose personal data of fans visiting the club’s website. This data involved the names, the fan card numbers and the ID numbers of the data subjects. The DPA concluded that the club had failed to implement the adequate technical and organizational security measures that would protect the personal data. In separate proceedings, the DPA fined AC Omonia and Hellenic Technical Enterprises Ltd. for the same violations.

allItems.name: Cyprus
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Cypriot DPA has fined the soccer club AC Omonia with EUR 40,000. Because of a lack of security measures in the club’s ticket sales system, unauthorized individuals could access the even disclose personal data of fans visiting the club’s website. This data involved the names, the fan card numbers and the ID numbers of the data subjects. The DPA concluded that the club had failed to implement the adequate technical and organizational security measures that would protect the personal data. In separate proceedings, the DPA fined APOEL FC and Hellenic Technical Enterprises Ltd. for the same violations.

allItems.name: Cyprus
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Cypriot DPA fined the Hellenic Technical Enterprise Ltd. with EUR 40,000. The data controller had designed the ticket sales system for the two soccer clubs, APOEL FC and AC Omonia FC. Because of a lack of security measures in the club’s ticket sales system, unauthorized individuals could access the even disclose personal data of fans visiting the club’s website. This data involved the names, the fan card numbers and the ID numbers of the data subjects. The DPA concluded that the club had failed to implement the adequate technical and organizational security measures that would protect the personal data. In separate proceedings, the DPA fined APOEL FC and AC Omonia FC for the same violations.

allItems.name: Denmark
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Danish DPA has fined the Favrskov Municipality with EUR 10,000. Back on the 19th of August, 2020, the DPA received a notification from Favrskov Municipality regarding a personal data breach under Art. 33 GDPR. The notification claimed that, during a break-in at the municipality’s premises, a laptop had been stolen that contained a program which provided overviews of the municipality’s care facilities and information about the names and personal identity numbers of more than 100 individuals with mental or physical disabilities. The specific computer hard drive was unencrypted and the program, which contained sensitive and private personal data, wasn’t equipped with any security measures. While investigating the case, the DPA discovered that the Favrskov Municipality had failed to ensure the encryption of the laptops’ hard drives for a long time before August 12, 2020, which resulted in an inadequate level of security. The DPA considered this to be a violation of Art. 32 GDPR, since the municipality had failed to implement the proper technical and organizational measures that would ensure a level of protection commensurate with the risk.

allItems.name: Denmark
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Danish DPA fined the Syddanmark Region with EUR 67,200 on. On March 9, 2020, the DPA received a notification from Syddanmark Region regarding a personal data breach pertaining to Art. 33 GDPR. The Syddanmark Region claims that, since May 2011, a PowerPoint presentation made at Odense University Hospital for training purposes and containing personal data (ID card number details and health information of 3,915 patients, was made public on the official website of the region. The region had been using a screening tool to analyze for inadvertent posting of any personal identity numbers on its website. But this tool couldn’t scan any data in PowerPoint presentations. As such, the DPA discovered that the region had failed to implement the proper organizational and technical measures that would ensure the adequate level of protection appropriate to the risk at hand. When assessing the necessity of a fine, the DPA also considered that aggravating factor of the region’s processing of large amounts of personal data, which also included health data.

allItems.name: France
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 16 GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR, Art. 30 GDPR, Art. 31 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The French DPA (also known as CNIL) has fined Société nouvelle de l’annuaire français (SNAF) with EUR 3,000. SNAF operates the website annuairefrancais.fr, which lists French companies based on data published by the French Statistical Office. Between 2018 and 2019, the CNIL received a total of sixteen complaints that indicated problems when requesting the erasure and rectification of personal data. As a response, the CNIL promptly requested that SNAF complies with the requests within two months, which SNAF failed to do. Henceforth, the CNIL imposed the fine on SNAF, mainly for failing to comply with the rights of rectification and erasure of the data subjects, as well as for the lack of cooperation with the CNIL.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Insufficient data processing agreement
allItems.summary: The DPA from Hamburg has fined Vattenfal Europe Sales GmbH with EUR 900,000. The fine relates to data matching, which the data controller had carried out between August 2018 and December 2019 in the course of contract inquiries for special contracts. These special contracts were issued in order to attract potential new customers, and also came with bonus payments for these customers. The data controller made a comparison between contracts concluded by existing customers and potential customers who had previously submitted inquiries for special contracts. The data controller would reject the application for special contract if it was revealed that the application had previously signed a contract with the data controller then switched to another supplier. This was done to avoid any “bonus shopping”, which companies find unprofitable. However, the data controller failed to inform the customers about the data processing involving these comparisons. The DPA then concluded that the data controller had violated the company’s transparency policies and information obligations, since over 500,000 people had been affected in this data breach.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined Dixons South East Europe ΑΕΒΕ-ΚΩΤΣΟΒΟΛΟΣ with EUR 20,000. A data subject had previously filed a complaint against the data controller after it failed to comply with his right to information. The data subject tried returning a product, and proceeded to ask the data controller through Facebook Messenger to inform him about his request to cancel the credit card statement that was sent electronically to the bank. Despite this justified request, the data controller refused to comply, so the data subject demanded the bank to do the same. The bank, however, did not reply.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined the National Bank of Greence with EUR 20,000. A data subject had previously filed a complaint against the bank and a company after the data controllers failed to comply with his right to information. The data subject tried returning a product, and proceeded to ask the data controller through Facebook Messenger to inform him about his request to cancel the credit card statement that was sent electronically to the bank. Despite this justified request, the data controller refused to comply, so the data subject demanded the bank to do the same. The bank, however, did not reply.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.controller: NOW DOCTOR – Εταιρία Παροχής Ηλεκτρονικών Υπηρεσιών Αναζήτησης και Προβολής Ιατρών Ε.Π.Ε.
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), e) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 12 (2), (3) GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined the operator of the nowdoctor.gr medical platform that enables the online booking of medical appointments. A doctor had previously filed a complaint with the DPA. At the same time, she had also repeatedly stated that she didn’t wish to work with the data controller, while requesting the deletion of her data on the platform. The data controller failed to comply with the request of the data subject on the spot. Instead, the data deletion took place 18 months later, after the DPA had requested to data controller to proceed with the deletion. The DPA concluded that this was a clear breach of the data controller’s accountability obligations. It was further found that the data controller had been storing the data of the data subject for longer that was necessary for the intended processing purposes (providing online display services). These display services would stop existing at the moment the data subject used her right to stop working with the data controller. Additionally, the DPA found out that the data controller failed to facilitate the data subject’s access to her rights as per Art. 12 GDPR. Finally, while the data controller provided a public email address on its website through which the data subject could maintain communication, the controller was understaffed and there was no one to process this communication.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 12 (3) GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Greek DPA fined the Rhodes Municipal Transport Company with a fine of EUR 8,000. One of the former employees of the transport company filed a complaint against it with the DPA. At that time, the employee was engaged in a legal dispute with the transport company after the employer had reported him for alleged embezzlement. In this context, the employee had requested from the employer a copy of the video recordings taken by the bus’s video surveillance system during the data that the alleged embezzlement occurred. This video recording was necessary for this defense. However, the data controller failed to respond to this request. The DPA concluded that this was a clear violation of the data subject’s right to information, as per Art. 12 (3) GDPR and Art. 15 GDPR. Moreover, the data controller provided the former employee with a certificate of his former employment. Among others, the certificate contained the duration and type of the employment, as well as a notice of dismissal on charges of criminal offenses. This was a violation of the principle of proportionality as per Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR, according to the GDPR. The issued fine consists of EUR 3,000 for violating Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR and EUR 5,000 for violating Art. 12 (3) and Art. 15 GDPR.

allItems.name: Ireland
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Irish DPA has fined Vodafone Ireland Limited with a fine of EUR 1,400. Apparently, Vodafone had repeatedly sent marketing emails and SMS messages, as well as telephone calls to data subjects without obtaining their consent. Despite the data subjects’ attempts to stop this, the company kept sending them unsolicited marketing. At one time, a former customer of the company contacted Vodafone seven times and repeatedly requested them to stop with the marketing material. However, the company did not stop sending him marketing emails and SMS messages. Another customer had been receiving advertising calls on his telephone number, at which point he informed Vodafone during such a call that he did not want to receive further advertising calls. Against this request, the company made another twelve calls to his phone number. Yet another data subject filed outa form where he clearly stated that he did not want to receive more marketing calls from Vodafone. Despite this, the company employees that had processed this request failed to register the marketing preferences of the customer. This resulted in the customer receiving seven other emails and seven text messages.

allItems.name: Norway
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 28 (3) GDPR, Art. 32 (2) GDPR, Art. 44 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Norwegian DPA has fined Ferde AS, which is a Norwegian toll company, with EUR 496,000. After receiving a report from NRK, state-owned broadcasting company, the Norwegian DPA started investigating Ferde AS, discovering that the company had been transferring information on passages in various toll rings to a data processor in China. In this context, the DPA started a large-scale investigation into the company, with the purpose of finding out whether the company had implemented measures and routines that could ensure the information security of this information transfer to China. It should be noted that Ferde AS was also responsible for registering passages at toll booths through a chip in the car. If a car had no chip or if the chip wasn’t properly registered, a photo of the car’s license plate would be taken. These images would then be sent to an automatic optical character recognition system that would digitally read the license plate. If the image wasn’t clear enough, it would go through manual processing. Ferde AS had contracted Unitel Bratseth Services (UBS) to do this job. During the investigation, the DPA found out that the subcontractor also had employees in China. Moreover, Ferde AS had violated many obligations under the GDPR for 1-2 years. In on instance, Ferde failed to conduct a risk management assessment before the processing of personal data and the processing of manual images. This risk assessment was necessary to assess any underlying risks associated with the data transfer, and to also determine whether further security measures should be taken. Additionally, the DPA discovered that Ferde did not enter an official processor contract with UBS. Therefore, the transfer of personal data to China occurred without a legal basis. When determining the value of the fine, the DPA also considered the large amount of the affected personal data as an aggravating factor. However, the implicated data subjects received no material or immaterial damage, which had a mitigating effect on this whole affair.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined GESTIONES AUTO LOW COST S.L. with EUR 1,000 because the company’s website did not contain a privacy policy.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a hairdressing salon with EUR 1,000 because the data controller had installed a video surveillance system in its premises without properly informing the data subjects about the data processing.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a website operator with EUR 9,000. A data subject had complained to the DPA that the data controller had publicly published his first and last name and a screenshot of his LinkedIn profile on his website. The data controller hadn’t previously obtained the consent of the data subject for this, and it also did not inform the data subject about the imminent data processing. The DPA considered this to be a violation of Art. 6 GDPR and Art. 13 GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Vodafone Espana, S.A.U. with EUR 40,000 on charges of insufficient legal basis for data processing. A data subject claimed that multiple telephone lines had been registered in his name, despite never signing any contract with the company for these telephone lines. These contracts had been concluded by fraudsters on behalf of the data subject. However, Vodafone never verified the data subject’s personal data when entering it into its information systems. They did not check whether the contracts are lawful and if they’d actually been concluded by the data subject. The original fine of EUR 50,000 was reduced to EUR 40,000 because of voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Vodafone Espana, S.A.U. with EUR 40,000 on charges of insufficient legal basis for data processing. A data subject claimed that multiple telephone lines had been registered in his name, despite never signing any contract with the company for these telephone lines. These contracts had been concluded by fraudsters on behalf of the data subject. However, Vodafone never verified the data subject’s personal data when entering it into its information systems. They did not check whether the contracts are lawful and if they’d actually been concluded by the data subject. The original fine of EUR 70,000 was reduced to EUR 56,000 because of voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (AEPD) imposed a fine on Vodafone España, S.A.U. due to insufficient legal basis for data processing. The data subject stated that, unauthorized third parties had gained access to her Vodafone account and had booked the Vodafone Unlimited package in her name, as well as purchased an iPhone 11 Pro Max in installments. The DPA notes that the controller had not adequately verified whether the contracts had been lawfully and actually concluded by the data subject. The original fine of EUR 70,000 was reduced to EUR 56,000 due to the voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPNA (AEPD) has fined Vodafone Espana, S.A.U. with EUR 56,000 because of insufficient legal basis for data processing. A data subject claimed that unauthorized third parties hijacked his Vodafone account and signed three mobile phone contracts in his name. The DPA also found out that Vodafone did not verify whether these contracts were lawful and whether the data subject had actually concluded them. In this context, the contracts weren’t even signed and the information inputted by the fraudsters (date of birth, address) weren’t those of the data subject. The original fine of EUR 70,000 was reduced to EUR 56,000 because of voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) fined Vodafone España, S.A.U. with EUR 56,000 for insufficient legal basis for data processing. A data subject claimed that Vodafone had requested that he pay for three telephone lines. During the call, the data subject explained that he had not ordered or authorized those telephone lines, and he requested that they sent the invoices to him. The data subject said that the telephone and account numbers on the invoices weren’t his. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the contracts had been concluded by an unauthorized third party. Additionally, the DPA also found that Vodafone failed to verify the identity of the third party who had concluded the contracts, and also failed to take security measures to prevent these incidents from occurring. The original fine of EUR 70,000 was reduced to EUR 56,000 because of voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Frigorifica Botana S.L. with EUR 4,000. The company’s main activity is freezing, processing, and storing seafood. A data subject issued a complaint with the AEPD against the data controller, which prompted the DPA to begin investigations. Apparently, the data controller had installed an audio and video surveillance system that captured certain parts of the conference room. The DPA stated that the data controller had violated the principle of data minimization by processing this data without having a legal basis. It also failed to inform the data subjects about the data processing.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (AEPD) has fined CEDICO, CENTRO DE DIAGNOSTICO POR LA IMAGEN, S.L. A data subject complained to the AEPD against the data controller. He had previously gone to get an MRI scan of his knee because of a work-related accident. He had also contacted his insurance company for a sick leave. After the insurance company contacted the data controller, the latter transmitted the medical records of the data subject to the insurance company. But by doing so, the data controller offered the insurer a report of another MRI scan of the knew that the data subject had received for an event outside of work. While assessing the need for a sick leave, the insurer considered the MRI report in the medical records outside working hours, attributing the data subject’s incapacity to work to this event. So, they granted no sic leave to the data subject. The DPA considered that the data controller unlawfully disclosed the MRI report to the insurer, violating the principle of integrity and confidentiality. The original fine of EUR 30,000 was briefly reduced to EUR 18,000 because of voluntary payment and admission of guilt.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a company with EUR 3,000. The company in question had requested personal data from customers for appointment bookings. However, the DPA discovered that the data controller did not properly inform the data subjects about the data processing, as per Art. 13 GDPR.

allItems.name: Austria
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Austrian DPA fined the Austrian Post with EUR 9.5 million on September the 28th, 2021. The post was accused that, besides the contact options in use by the Austrian Post via email, customer service and customer service, the data protection-related inquiries should be allowed via email as well. But according to the “Der Standard” newspaper, the Austrian Post only introduced a contact form regarding the data protection inquiries. This would automate the inquiries process as well as obtaining the necessary information for processing these inquiries.

allItems.name: Denmark
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Danish DPA has fined the Danish Cancer Society with EUR 107,000 for not complying with the requirements of the GDPR related to the appropriate security measures. The Danish Cancer Society had previously reported a total of four data breaches according to Art. 33 GDPR to the DPA. Two of these data breaches involved computer thefts and two phishing attacks – all four were caused by the Danish Cancer Foundation’s failure to implement organizational and technical measures that would ensure a level of security appropriate to the risk to data subjects. A similar personal data breach had already occurred in August 2018, when the Foundation encountered spoofing and phishing hacking attacks. The Danish Cancer Society claimed that it should increase protection via multifactor authentication. However, the society did not implement this. The data of at least 1,448 individuals was compromised, and in several cases, it involved sensitive personal health data, including medical history.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined the real estate portal La Prima S.r.l. with EUR 5,000. A data subject had complained against the controller with the DPA, saying that she had received a contact request on LinkedIn by one of the La Prima employees. The employee wanted to offer real estate services regarding a specific property owned by the data subject in question. The data controller had apparently obtained the contact data of the data subject as well as information about the ownership of the property from a public register. But the data subject had not consented to this contact request. During the DPA investigation, the data controller argued that it doesn’t need consent in this case because the data subject had a public profile. However, the DPA stated that the exchange of information on a social network should only be carried out within the relevant terms of use. The DPA further claimed that the social media platform is in its right to enable the exchange of contact information to make job offers. However, social media platforms aren’t meant to be used to send messages to other users to sell services. Moreover, it doesn’t matter if the profile was public or not. So, the DPA concluded that the data controller had processed this data unlawfully.

allItems.name: Luxembourg
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) a), b) GDPR, Art. 33 (1), (5) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Luxembourg DPA has fined an insurance company with EUR 135,000. On the 19th of October, 2018, an employee of the data controller had sent an e-mail to a foreign third party instead of the data subject. This took place because of an error committed by the employee who had incorrectly inputted the e-mail address of the data subject. Aside from the name and gender of the data subject, the e-mail also talked in great detail about the data subject’s illnesses. Additionally, the attachment contained three forms regarding the illnesses that the data subject had previously reported in connection with a life insurance policy the subject had concluded. On the 29th of November, the same incident took place. The second misdirected e-mail contained, aside from the data subject’s name, specific questions about a particular pathology, the last name of the data subject’s life insurance doctor, the address of the doctor, and two blank forms related to this pathology that should be filed out by the data subject or his doctor. The DPA further stated that the data controller had failed to notify the data breach in due time, as per Art. 33 GDPR. Moreover, the insurance company failed to comply with its documentation obligation as per Art. 33 (5) GDPR. The DPA also concluded that the data controller did not implement the necessary organizational and technical measures that would ensure the protect of the data subjects’ private information.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a bar owner with EUR 3,000 because of a data subject’s complaint to the DPA. The data subject had been the victim of an accident in the bar, and the whole event was recorded by the surveillance system. The data controller claims that the security cameras had been installed for security reasons. Later on, this video had been distributed through WhatsApp and then published on a digital newspaper online. The data subject states that this event had personally affected his reputation. The DPA concludes that the data controller unlawfully publicized these images, as it was not done for the purpose of the video surveillance, violating Art. 5 (1) b) GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined CYNGASA, S.L. with EUR 5,000. When a data subject requested a work report from the company, he found out that the data controller had disclosed his personal data to an unauthorized third party company without obtaining his consent first. This data involved his first and last name, as well as his social security number.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: No data protection officer appointed
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined ACONCAGUA JUEGOS, S.A. with EUR 10,000 because the data controller failed to appoint a data protection officer, violating Art. 37 GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined the owner of a store with EUR 2,000. The data controller had previously installed a video surveillance system that covered the public street, among other areas. The DPA concluded that the data controller had violated the principle of data minimization by filming the public street.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined the owner of a store with EUR 2,000. The data controller failed to place signs informing the public about the installation of a video surveillance system in the store.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.controller: Caldereria Y Soldadura De Estructuras Metalicas, SL
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined CALDERERIA Y SOLDADURA DE ESTRUCTURAS METALICAS, S.L. with EUR 5,000 because of an unlawful processing of a data subject’s data. CYNGASA S.L, another company, had disclosed the data subject’s private information to the data controller without obtaining consent of the data subject. This data included, among others, the first and last name of the data subject, as well as his social security number. CYNGASA, S.L. was fined separately for the same offence.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) e) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b), d) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined CLUB DEPORTIVO SANSUENA, S.L. with EUR 4,000 because it unlawfully added the phone number of a data subject to a WhatsApp group without obtaining the consent of the data subject.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined ORANGE ESPAGNE, S.A.U. with EUR 30,000 because a data subject complained to the DPA about receiving 30 calls and SMS messages between 03/01/2021 and 03/03/2021 from Jazztel employees, which is a subsidiary of Orange Espagne, S.A.U. These phone calls and SMS messages were sent to the data subject despite the fact that the data subject hadn’t ever been a customer of the company. The data subject requested that the company delete her data, but she kept receiving phone calls and SMS messages, despite the fact that the data controller confirmed the deletion of her data. The original fine of EUR 50,000 was reduced to EUR 30,000 because the data controller admitted his guilt and voluntarily paid the fine.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined MAF.COM ESQUI CLUB with EUR 10,000. The mother of an underaged girl who attended ski lessons with the data controller complained to the DPA that the data controller had published videos of her daughter on its official website and social media without obtaining the mother’s consent. The data controller had obtained the consent of the father, but at the time, the two parents were divorced, and the DPA claimed that the data controller should have obtained consent from both parents. This means that the data controller processed the images without a valid legal basis, so the Spanish DPA issued a fine of EUR 10,000 for this offence.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Vodafone Espana, S.A.U with EUR 40,000. This fined was issued because a woman complained against the data controller to the DPA on account of receiving telephone bills on her email address from the data controller, which belonged to a third party. Even though she informed the data controller about this, no response was issued. So, the contacted the data controller by phone. However, no one was able to help her with this problem. The DPA concludes that the data controller had violated the principles of confidentiality and integrity outlined in Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR. Moreover, the data controller failed to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures that would ensure the proper security appropriate to the risk incurred by the data subjects. The original fine of 50,000 was reduced to EUR 40,000 due to voluntary payment from the data controller.

allItems.name: Ireland
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 12 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 (1) c) GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: An organization called None of your business (NOYB) published a draft decision of the Irish DPA on the 13th of October, 2021, indicating that the DPA wants to fine Facebook between EUR 28 million and EUR 36 million. Apparently, the draft addresses the fact that Facebook had included specific details on data processing in its terms of service, following the provisions of Art. 6 (1) b) rather than Art. 6 (1) a) GDPR. Some critics call this a loophole that Facebook intelligently uses to bypass the strict GDPR requirements of consent, those of Art. 6 (1) a). On the other hand, the DPC clearly states that the GDPR doesn’t establish any hierarchy of specific legal bases that a company can use to process personal data. However, the DPC further noted that Facebook did not provide any clear information regarding the legal basis it used for the data processing, further emphasizing that Facebook provides discontinuous information. The company also sends users to various texts and documents of the terms of services and data policy. The DPC thus concludes on its draft that Facebook had violated Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, art. 12 (1) GDPR, and Art. 13 (1) c). This draft decision has been forwarded to other European data protection authorities.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 12 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined the Ciechi Ardizzone Gioeni di Catania residential home for blind people with EUR 5,000 because of a complaint of a visitor to the residence. Apparently, the data subject saw that a video surveillance system had been installed in the accommodation. This video surveillance system recorded, among others, the connecting corridor  between the accommodation and the communal showers. This footage was recorded and displayed in real time on the staff’s monitors, thus creating a risk that the footage could be seen by suppliers or the visitors. During the DPA’s investigation, the administration of the institution argued that they had installed the video surveillance system to combat theft and provide adequate safety to the residents by preventing unauthorized access during the pandemic. However, the DPA stated that the institute had violated the principles of transparency, lawfulness, and data minimization. Even though the institution claimed that the quality of the footage showing the passage of the residents to the shower room was not clear enough and also of a short duration, the DPA states it was still unlawful. The DPA also claims that the institute could have ensured the safety of its residents in other, less invasive ways that would not restrict the freedoms of the data subjects, referring to a temporary switch-off of the cameras when filming the corridor to the shower rooms, or ensuring the security of these locations through other measures aside from video surveillance. Moreover, the DPA states that the institute failed in properly informing its residents about the video surveillance. They only provided information about the surveillance system to their residents after the DPA investigation had formally begun. Ironically, the information they offered wasn’t suitable for blind or visually impaired people. Instead, the institute should have provided its residents with pre-recorded audio-messages that the residents could listen to.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c), e) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR, Art. 44 GDPR, Art. 46 GDPR, Art. Art. 2-sexies Codice della Privacy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Bocconi University with EUR 200,000 after a student had filed a complaint with the DPA regarding alleged GDPR violations related to the use of a surveillance system during written exams. During the emergency situation of the Covid-19 pandemic where students couldn’t take live exams and in person, the university acquired a remote monitoring software called Respondus, from the American company called Respondus Inc. This software would monitor the students’ behavior via video recordings and snapshots taken at random intervals. Additionally, the exam was also audio-visually recorded, and the students had their photographs taken at the beginning of the exam. When the exam finished, the system would process the video and insert warning signals attached to each video, regarding potential indications of incorrect behavior (foul play). Among others, the system assigned “review priorities” to various videos so the examiner could further analyze whether there was any foul play in the video. During an investigation, the DPA discovered that the students hadn’t been informed about the processing of their personal data via Respondus. For instance, the students hadn’t been informed that they would be audio-visually recorded, and that these images would then be processed. Moreover, the students weren’t provided with any information regarding the retention period of this data. They also weren’t given enough information about whether or not their data would be transferred to the United States. Instead, they were only told that their data would be processed both inside and outside the European Union. Moreover, the DPA also found that even the information provided to the students had been chaotic and disorganized, placed in multiple documents in a fragmented form. This is a clear violation of the principles of fairness, transparency, and lawfulness, according to the DPA. The DPA also found that the university had processed this personal data without a proper legal basis. They needed to obtain the consent of the students regarding this personal data, before they participated in the exams. Alternatively, the university proposed in-person exams but the pandemic meant that this option presented certain health risks. The students also thought that refusing to take the online exams would clearly impact their grades. So, the DPA concluded that the students had not voluntarily given their consent. Moreover, the DPA also discovered that the university had retained the data for 12 months, despite this not being necessary for the purpose of making sure that the exams were valid. Finally, the DPA also discovered several violations regarding the transfer of data to Respondus. Namely, the processing agreement between Respondus and the university relied on the data protection agreement between the USA and the EU, the Privacy Shield agreement, which had previously been invalidated by the Schrems II ruling of the Court of Justice of the European Union. Thus, the DPA concluded that the university unlawfully transferred the personal data of the students to a third country, despite this not being compliant with the conditions stipulated in Chapter V of the GDPR.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 7 GDPR, Art. 12 (2) GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 28 GDPR, Art. 29 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) fined Sky Italia S.r.l. with EUR 3,296,326 for illegal telemarketing. The DPA received numerous complaints from people claiming that they’d received unsolicited telemarketing calls and SMS messages from Sky Italia directly and via various call centers of other companies. So, the DPA started investigating the phenomenon. They found out that Sky Italia had made the calls without properly informing the users how they got their hands on the data subject’s personal data. If Sky Italia had done this, the data subjects could have opposed to the data processing by contacting the company who had their data and objecting to the data processing. If the data subjects gave their consent, only then would Sky Italia be allowed to send them commercial offers. Instead, the company used the personal data obtained from various companies for these promotional purposes. However, despite the fact that the data subjects had given their consent to the disclosure of their data to said third party companies, Sky Italia had no right to acquire these lists of personal information and use them for its own promotional purposes. Additionally, Sky Italia also failed to check the list of individuals who had objected to the data processing regarding the advertising messages. Instead, the company proceeded with the marketing calls without taking this into account. Several data subjects who had objected to the data processing ended up receiving advertising calls. Moreover, the DPA discovered that Sky Italia did not appoint its data suppliers as data processors. When calculating the fine, the DPA considered the fact that Sky Italia’s violations implicated a “systemic” conduct that was integral to the company’s other operations, as well as the fact that the company should have made better decisions considering its experience and competence. Given its long-term presence in the market and constant contact with the authorities, Sky Italia should have known better.

allItems.name: Norway
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Norwegian DPA has fined the Østre Toten municipality with EUR 412,000 because the municipality had previously suffered a cyberattack in January 2021. As a result, the hackers encrypted much of the municipality’s data and deleted the backups. Then, about 30,000 documents were published on the dark web. The documents contained various data such as health status, sexual orientations, religious beliefs, ethnic origin, political opinions, union memberships, and banking data of the municipality’s employees and residents. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the municipality had various security deficiencies regarding the personal data and other internal security controls. For instance, the municipality did not use two-factor authentication during the log-in procedure into the system, and also lacked proper backup systems.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) a) GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA (also known as ANSPDCP) fined Glove Technology SRL with EUR 5,000 because the data controller had installed a video surveillance system using audiovisual monitoring at the employees’ workplace, recording various conversations between them. The DPA discovered that the data controller had also violated Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, and Art. 6 (1) GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Vodafone Espana, S.A.U. with EUR 70,000. A data subject had previously complained to the DPA that he had received multiple promotional emails from Vodafone even though he had not consented to the data processing, and he also did not have a contractual relationship with Vodafone Espana. The data subject made it clear that he did not want to receive further emails, objecting to the data processing, and Vodafone confirmed this. Still, the data subject received four more advertising emails a couple of months later. This fine is made up for EUR 50,000 for a violation of Art. 21 GDPR, and EUR 20,000 for a violation of Art. 21 LSSI.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Vodafone Espana, S.A.U. with EUR 40,000. A data subject had previously filed a complaint against Vodafone Espana saying that the company had debited his account in May 2020 for a telephone line that was on his ex-partner’s name. Apparently, the data subject’s ex-partner had concluded a contract with Vodafone on his name. When asked, the partner said that she was authorized to do this but provided no evidence of this. The DPA concluded that Vodafone had unlawfully processed the data subject’s data without checking whether the partner was authorized to conclude a contract in his name. The company needed to prove the lawfulness of the action if they were to abide to the principle of lawfulness when processing a third party’s data.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined BEEPING FULFILMENT S.L. with EUR 2,000. The data controller had failed to provide the adequate information regarding the purpose and characteristics of the data processing on the website’s privacy policy. The DPA concluded this was a violation of Art. 13 GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.controller: Caixabank Payments & Consumer EFC, EP, S.A.U.
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined CAIXABANK PAYMENTS & CONSUMER EFC, EP, S.A.U. with EUR 3,000,000. A data subject had complained against the data controller because it had formally requested his information from a third-party company, even though the data subject had not been a customer of Caixabank ever since 2014. The data subject was also included in an advertising campaign for a pre-grant credit. Caixabank had not obtained the data subject’s consent when assessing their credit worthiness using personal data. The data controller used this data to create financial profiles of the data subjects, as well as for advertising specific financial services like credit loans. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller did not obtain the consent of its data subjects, at least not specifically for this. The data subjects had given their consent to CaixaBank for the data processing, but the data controller did not properly inform them about the details of the data processing. The data controller only offered the data subjects general information about the profiling processing operations, so the data subjects did not clearly know what they had consented to.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined MERCEDES GERENCIA, S.L. with EUR 3,000 because the data controller did not respond to a request for information from the DPA in a timely manner.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Vodafone Espana, S.A.U. with EUR 64,000. A data subject had previously complained to the DPA that the data controller had registered several telephone lines under his name, and there were also outstanding payments to be made. However, the data subject says he had never concluded contracts for these telephone lines. Instead, they had been concluded by fraudsters with the data subject’s personal data. But the company did not properly verify the validity of the personal data once it was entered into its systems. It should have checked whether the contracts were valid and if they had actually been concluded by the data subject. The original fine of EUR 80,000 was reduced to EUR 64,000 because of voluntary payment from the data controller.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.controller: Servicios Logisticos Martorell Siglo XXL, S.L.
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined SERVICIOS LOGISTICOS MARTORELL SIGLO XXL, S.L. with EUR 16,000. The data controller had installed a total of five terminals with fingerprint control systems that would record the employees’ working hours. As such, the company did not conduct an protection impact assessment. The AEPD then discovered a violation of Art. 35 GDPR, which prompted it to issue a fine of EUR 20,000 that was reduced to EUR 16,000 due to voluntary payment.

allItems.name: United Kingdom
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The British DPA (also known as ICO) has fined the non-profit organization HIV Scotland with EUR 11,800. The data controller had previously sent an email to 105 people containing all the data subject’s email addresses in the mailing list. A total of 65 email addresses also contained the data subject’s names. So, it was possible to draw conclusions regarding the data subject’s HIV status based on its personal data provided. The DPA concluded that the organization did not implement the proper organizational and technical measures that would ensure sufficient security appropriate to the risk. For instance, the organization did not conduct efficient employee training and also used the inadequate methods to send bulk emails via blind copy.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) c), e) GDPR, Art. 6 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (3) b) GDPR, Art. 9 (1), (2), (4) GDPR, Art. 2-ter (1), (3) Codice della privacy, Art. 2-septies (8) Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined the municipality of Montalbano Jonico with EUR 5,000. Previously, a data subject had filed a complaint against the municipality with the DPA. He had complained that the municipality had publicized a document on its official website. The document contained personal data about the data subject and his father. Moreover, the document could be freely accessed in the “Documents and Data” section of the municipality’s website. Therefore, anyone could access a decision regarding a settlement for the overcoming and removal of architectural barriers in their home by simply filing out a search form. This decision contained the personal data and private information of the data subject in the text and subject line, information such as the name of the complainant and his dependent father, referencing him as a disabled person. Furthermore, the decision also contained the complainant’s date of birth and place of residence, and information about the settlement sum. The DPA concluded that the publication of this data was a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Luxembourg
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The DPA from Luxembourg fined a company with EUR 5,300. The company had apparently installed 75 surveillance cameras on its premises, as well as tracking devices in some of the vehicles used by employees to go to customers. Some of these cameras covered parts of the public street and a private property in the neighborhood. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that these cameras also covered the employee cafeteria, and they monitored the employees outside the working hours. The DPA found that his was a violation of the principle of data minimization, and the data controller had insufficiently complied with its information obligations as per Art. 13 GDPR.

allItems.name: Luxembourg
allItems.type: Insufficient involvement of data protection officer
allItems.summary: The DPA from Luxembourg fined a company with EUR 13,200. As per the DPA’s investigation, the data controller refused to involve the data protection officer in all matters regarding the protection of personal data. Moreover, the data controller did not have a data protection plan in place that would demonstrate that the data protection officers was carrying out his duties correctly.

allItems.name: Luxembourg
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 37 (7) GDPR, Art. 38 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 39 (1) b) GDPR
allItems.type: Insufficient involvement of data protection officer
allItems.summary: The DPA from Luxembourg fined a company with EUR 13,200. As per the DPA’s investigation, the data controller refused to involve the data protection officer in all matters regarding the protection of personal data. Moreover, the data controller did not have a data protection plan in place that would demonstrate that the data protection officers was carrying out his duties correctly. The data controller also failed to provide the data protection officer with the required information to perform his duties accordingly. The DPA also concluded that the data controller’s website did not contain a section referring to data protection. Moreover, the information notice about data protection was only available in English instead of one of Luxembourg’s official languages.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA (also known as ANSPDCP) has fined IKEA ROMÂNIA SA with EUR 1,000. The data controller had notified the DPA regarding a personal data breach under Art. 33 GDPR. Apparently, the data controller had organized a drawing contest involving the children of many of IKEA’s employees. Participants were supposed to upload their drawings in an online platform along with their entry forms that contained the personal data of the children and their parents, including the parents’ consent. However, to vote for the best drawing, the company posted the children’s drawings on the online platform, but they also posted the personal data in the participation forms by accident. During the investigation, the Romanian DPA concluded that this security incident had resulted in the unauthorized disclosure of personal data of IKEA family members (first name, surname, and age of minors, and the first name, surname, country, city, email address, IKEA family membership number, and the signature of the parents) on the company’s online platform that was accessible only to IKEA family members in Romania. This incident affected a total of 114 people, half of which were minors. The DPA determined that the data controller had breached its obligation as per Art. 32 (1) b), (2) GDPR that required it to implement organization and technical measures that would ensure a level of security appropriate to the risk for the data subjects.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA (ANSPDCP) has fined S.P.E.E.H. Hidroelectrica S.A. with EUR 5,000. The data controller notified the DPA of numerous breaches of personal data protection as per Art. 33 GDPR. The data controller breach ended with the data of 325 data subjects being unlawfully accessed or passed on to the wrong recipients. The DPA determined that this was a breach of data protection by the controller as per Art. 32 (1) b), (2) GDPR regarding the implementation of appropriate organizational and technical measures that would ensure adequate security appropriate to the risk incurred by the data subjects during the data processing. Additionally, the DPA discovered that the data controller had processed various amounts of personal data from three customers after they had clearly exercised the rights to delete their data and revoke their consent to the data processing. This data processing had been carried out without a legal basis. The DPA fined the company with EUR 5,000 for breaching Art. 32 (1) b), (2) GDPR. As for the violation of Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR and Art. 6 (1) a) GDPR, the DPA only issued a warning.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined VODAFONE SERVICIOS, S.L.U. with EUR 40,000. The DPA received a complaint against the data controller from a data subject who was a client of the controller. Upon checking his bills on the official MY VODAFONE website during last December, the discovered that he had four outstanding bills that were inaccessible. He had also received various requests to pay them. He was then informed that there was a parallel account registered with Vodafone using details that partly corresponded to him. Apparently, fraudsters had concluded a mobile phone contract using the personal data of the data subject. But then, this personal data that had been entered into the company’s information systems was not verified, and the lawfulness of the contract concluded in the data subject’s name was not assessed. The original fine of EUR 50,000 was reduced to EUR 40,000 because of voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined VODAFONE SERVICIOS, S.L.U. with EUR 40,000. The DPA received a complaint against the data controller from a data subject who was a client of the controller, saying that she had received multiple invoices and debits on her bank account regarding the payment of Vodafone services that she had not booked. She further claimed that she had been receiving calls from the collection company Bureau Veritas in which she was asked to pay for these services. Apparently, fraudsters had used her personal data to conclude these service contracts. However, the company did not verify the validity of the information provided and the lawfulness of the contract made in the data subject’s name, even though this information was entered into the company’s information systems. The original fine of EUR 50,000 was reduced to EUR 40,000 because of voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Bulgaria
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Bulgarian DPA fined a bank with EUR 380 for unlawfully transferring personal data to third parties.

allItems.name: Cyprus
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Cypriot DPA has fined WS WiSpear Systems LTD with EUR 925,000 because the company had previously collected data from individuals (data like International Mobile Subscriber Identity data and Media Access Control addresses) without obtaining their consent. This data was collected as part of presentations of technologies and tests. The DPA found that the company had violated the principles of objectivity, legality, and transparency.

allItems.name: France
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 5 (1) e) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The French DPA (also known as CNIL) fined the Régie autonome des transports parisiens (operator of public transport system in Paris) with EUR 400,000. Back in May 2020, the CNIL received a complaint from a trade union alleging that promotion decision files included the number of strike days exercised by staff. The CNIL then investigated several RATP bus centers. This way, the CNIL confirmed that this was true in three of the RATP bus centers. The French DPA further confirmed that files referring to performance evaluations and prospects should only even contain data that was necessary for evaluating employees during work hours. More specifically, it would have been sufficient that these files indicated the total number of days of absence without detailing and distinguishing between days of absence and days where the workers exercised their right to strike. The CNIL discovered that the data related to the number of days the staff members were on strike haven’t been used for the right purpose, so the RATP had violated the principle of data minimization as per Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR. Furthermore, the DPA also found that the RATP has excessively retained some of the employees’ data. More specifically, the RAPT had retained files regarding the evaluation of staff members for more than three years after the promotion commission had taken place. The data retention term was 18 months after the commissions were held, so the RATP also violated this principle. The CNIL discovered that the RATP hadn’t differentiated between staff authorization levels properly either, allowing more staff members than necessary to retain certain data. In conclusion, the CNIL considered that the RATP failed to implement the appropriate organizational and technical measures to ensure a proper level of protection appropriate for the risk at hand.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.controller: PREMIUMMEDIA ΠΑΡΑΓΩΓΗ ΟΠΤΙΚΟ-ΑΚΟΥΣΤΙΚΩΝ ΕΡΓΩΝ ΙΔΙΩΤΙΚΗ ΚΕΦΑΛΑΙΟΥΧΙΚΗ ΕΤΑΙΡΙΑ
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined the company PREMIUMMEDIA ΠΑΡΑΓΩΓΗ ΟΠΤΙΚΟ-ΑΚΟΥΣΤΙΚΩΝ ΕΡΓΩΝ ΙΔΙΩΤΙΚΗ ΚΕΦΑΛΑΙΟΥΧΙΚΗ ΕΤΑΙΡΙΑ with EUR 5,000. A client of the company had tried to unsubscribe from the official newsletter mailing list of the company but didn’t succeed. This failure to unsubscribe was caused by an internal technical error of the company.

allItems.name: Isle of Man
allItems.authority: Information Commissioner of Isle of Man
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The DPA of the Isle of Man fined Cosmetic Medical Limited with EUR 3,250. A data subject had previously filed a complaint to the DPA regarding the data controller’s failure to comply with her request of access to personal data. During the investigation, the DPA requested for information that would clarify this case from the data controller. However, the data controller failed to respond the DPA in due time. Since the data controller did not properly cooperate with the authorities, the DPA concluded the company had violated Art. 31 of the GDPR.

allItems.name: Poland
allItems.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItems.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItems.summary: The Polish DPA (also known as UODO) has fined Bank Millennium S.A with Eur 78,000. The UODO has previously become aware of a data protection breach that followed a complaint against the bank. As it turned out, the correspondence that the bank had sent through a courier service containing personal data (first names, last names, PESEL numbers, account numbers, home addresses, and identification numbers of customers) had been lost. Therefore, the UODO concluded that the bank did not report the incident to the DPA and failed to provide adequate notice to the affected data subjects.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 32 (1) b) GDPR, Art. 32 (2) GDPR, Art. 3 (1) Law No. 506/2004, Art. 3 (3) a), b) Law No. 506/2004
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA (ANSPDCP) has fined VODAFONE România SA with EUR 2,900 because it had suffered a data breach in accordance with Art. 33 GDPR. In the period between November 2020 and June 2021, unauthorized third parties had accessed personal data of over 70 data subjects (as part of mailing of service contracts to wrong email addresses, and unauthorized access by employees of the data controller to personal data of Vodafone customers without their consent). The DPA concluded that the data controller had failed to take appropriate organizational and technical measures the ensure the proper security of the personal data processing.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The company had used a CCTV camera without proper information notices.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The company failed to provide the requested information to the Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) with the required timeframe, violating Art. 58 (1) GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The supermarket used a CCTV camera without proper information notices.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) fined a private individual with EUR 1,000 for the unauthorized installation of a video surveillance camera on their car. The car had been parked on a public street, so the camera could also record the public space. The AEPD found out that the video surveillance of the public space was a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Vodafone ESPANA SAU with EUR 30,000.
