A data subject had complained to the AEPD that the data controller had sent him invoices and debits on his bank account regarding the payment of Vodafone services that he hadn’t booked. The data subject claims that he had been asked to pay for these services by a debt collection company called I.S.G.F. Informes Comerciales S.L. Apparently, several fraudsters had used the data subject’s credentials and personal information to conclude a service contract. Vodafone had apparently canceled this contract for the booked services. However, due to a system error, the outstanding invoices hadn’t been canceled, so they were forwarded to a collection agency. The AEPD concluded that this transmission had been unlawful due to the non-existence of a valid contract. The original fine of EUR 50,000 had been reduced to EUR 30,000 because of voluntary payment and admission of guilt.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA ((also known as AEPD) has fined Vodafone ESPANA SAU with EUR 40,000. A data subject had filed a complaint to the DPA against the data controller. He claims that he’s received text messages from Vodafone on September 2020 informing him of his debts to the services he had ordered from Vodafone. The billing address is that of an old house where the data subject had lived with his ex-partner in the past. Vodafone states that this mistake was due to a system error, however this resulted in the data subject appearing as the holder of his former partner’s customer account. The original account of EUR 50,000 was reduced to EUR 40,000 because of voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined a neighborhood community with EUR 1,000. This happened because the information sign of the video surveillance system installed in the community did not contain enough information as required by Art. 13 GDPR. This sign didn’t contain any reference to the data controller nor any address to contact if they wanted to exercise their data subject rights.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a company with EUR 3,000. The company had previously requested personal data from customers regarding appointment bookings. The DPA concluded that the data controller had failed to properly inform the data subjects about the processing of this personal data in accordance with Art. 13 GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined ANIVERSALIA NETWORKS, S.L. with EUR 2,000 because the privacy policy posted on the company’s website did not comply with the requirements of Art. 13 GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The data controller did not provide information requested by the Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) for investigative purposes.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Vodafone ESPANA SAU with EUR 40,000. A data client had complained to the DPA against Vodafone because the data controller had transferred her cell phone line to a third party without obtaining her consent, and she was also charged additional amounts from the third-party phone line. This happened due to a technical error in Vodafone’s systems, apparently.

allItems.name: Netherlands
allItems.authority: Dutch Supervisory Authority for Data Protection (AP)
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Dutch DPA has fined the airline Transavia with EUR 400,000. In 2019, the airline had suffered a data breach in which a hacker gained access to the company’s systems via two accounts held by the IT department of the company. This may have potentially allowed the hacker to gain access the personal data such as dates of birth, names, email addresses, genders, phone numbers, flight information, and booking numbers of more than 25 million passengers. The DPA discovered that the hacker downloaded the personal information of 83,000 people. In 367 cases, this personal data also included medical information of people who had requested wheelchair transportation or additional services due to being deaf or blind. The DPA further noted that the lack of security measures allowed the hacker to access the company’s systems. Apparently, accessing the airline systems could be done simply by entering the required password. That’s because the systems did not have any multi-factor authentication measures in place. Moreover, the accounts themselves didn’t only have access to the necessary systems but also to other systems as well, which allowed the hacker to gain access to multiple systems of Transavia. The DPA concluded that the airline company Transavia had breached its duty to implement proper technical and organizational measures that would ensure a level of security appropriate to the perceived risk of the data subjects.

allItems.name: Belgium
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 12 (3) GDPR, Art. 14 (1), (2), (3) GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 17 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 21 (2) GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Belgian DPA has fined a company with EUR 10,000. Apparently, the data subject had repeatedly received email advertising from the company despite having objected to the processing of his personal data and requested the deletion of his data. The company did not respond to the inquiries made by the data protection authority either. Moreover, the company also did not sufficiently inform the data subject about the processing of his personal data.

allItems.name: Denmark
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Danish DPA has fined the municipality of Frederiksberg with EUR 13,450. Back on March 1st, 2021, the municipality reported to the DPA a data breach as per Art. 33 GDPR. The dental care service of the municipality was operated by a system through which the parents could access the dental care letters of the children online. Then, this system was made available to parents with joint custody. Therefore, in many cases, parents could gain information about the other parent and the child’s address despite the fact that the other parent and the child were under name and address protection. The DPA concluded that the municipality breached its duty to implement adequate organizational and technical measures that would ensure a proper level of security adequate to the risk to the data subjects.

allItems.name: Finland
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 33 (1) GDPR, Art. 34 (1) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Finnish DPA has fined the Vastaamo psychotherapy center with EUR 608,000. Back in September 2020, the psychotherapy center reported a data breach on its patient database. Apparently, an unauthorized third party had gained access to the medical database of Vastaamo on two occasions (that we know of), one in December 2018 and the other in March 2019. The attacked had stolen data and left a ransom note on the database servers. Because of insufficient data logging, the DPA couldn’t identify the exact date of the breach nor the network addresses that the attacker used. As for the cause of this data breach, it was most likely an unprotected port on the database where the root user account was not protected by a password. The patient database server was left open to the Internet without firewall protection between November 26th, 2017, and March 13th, 2019. In these circumstances, the DPA concluded that the personal data of the patients wasn’t properly protected against unauthorized and unlawful access, processing, destruction, accidental loss, or damage. The data controller also failed to implement the proper measures that would secure the processing of the personal data. During its investigation, the DPA determined that the data controller had known about the data breach of its patient medical data and about the unauthorized access of the attacker ever since March 2019. The Vastaamo psychotherapy center should have reported the security breach to the patients involved and the DPA as soon as it happened. However, the data controller was very late in meeting this obligation. The fine is composed of EUR 145,600 for breaching Art. 33 (1) GDPR, EUR 145,600 for breaching Art. 34 (1) GDPR, and EUR 316,800 for breaching Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.controller: ΚΑΠΑ ΛΑΜΔΑ ΩΜΕΓΑ ΔΙΑΦΗΜΙΣΤΙΚΗ ΕΜΠΟΡΙΚΗ ΜΟΝΟΠΡΟΣΩΠΗ ΕΤΑΙΡΕΙΑ ΠΕΡΙΟΡΙΣΜΕΝΗΣ ΕΥΘΥΝΗΣ
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 12 (2) GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA fined ΚΑΠΑ ΛΑΜΔΑ ΩΜΕΓΑ ΔΙΑΦΗΜΙΣΤΙΚΗ ΕΜΠΟΡΙΚΗ ΜΟΝΟΠΡΟΣΩΠΗ ΕΤΑΙΡΕΙΑ ΠΕΡΙΟΡΙΣΜΕΝΗΣ ΕΥΘΥΝΗΣ with EUR 20,000 because the company had carried out marketing calls without the consent of the data subjects on several occasions. Even though the data subjects notified the data controller that they didn’t want to keep receiving marketing calls, the company kept sending them advertising.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 28 (3) c) GDPR, Art. 32 (2), (4) GDPR, Art. 11 (1) Νόμος 3471/2006
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined One Way Private Company with EUR 30,000. The DPA received a total of 17 complaints about illegal telephone calls made to data subjects regarding advertising. The DPA discovered that these telephone calls were made to subscribers because of an error in the application. Some of the subscribers were in the list of protection against unsolicited advertising calls. The DPA concluded that the data controller failed to implement the proper organizational and technical measures that would ensure a level of security appropriate to the risk of the data subjects.

allItems.name: Hungary
allItems.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 12 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Hungarian DPA fined a car importer with EUR 13,500. A customer of the one of the data controller’s authorized repair shops complained to the DPA about receiving unsolicited emails about customer surveys from the company after a car inspection. The Hungarian DPA discovered that the data controller didn’t have a valid legal basis to contact the data subject. Moreover, the data controller didn’t comply with its duty to inform as per Art. 13 GDPR and Art. 13 GDPR. These emails didn’t contain any contact information of the data controller.

allItems.name: Iceland
allItems.controller: Icelandic Ministry of Industry and Innovation
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 7 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 28 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Icelandic DPA has fined the Ministry of Industry and Inovation with EUR 51,000 and YAY ehf with EUR 27,200. The fines are related to the ministry’s campaign to encourage Icelanders to travel domestically in the summer of 2020. This involved a digital gift voucher obtainable through the app of the company YAY ehf. The DPA received several complaints from data subjects regarding the fact that using these travel gifts required too much personal information and access to the user’s phones. Therefore, the DPA launched an investigation against the YAY ehf company and the ministry. Apparently, the ministry had violated the principles of transparency and legality. The participating individuals could participate in then voucher promotion by only agreeing to the General Terms of Use of the YAY app. However, by doing so, the data subjects expressly consented to the processing of their personal data as well. The DPA found out that that the information provided about the data processing wasn’t sufficient to warrant it. Moreover, YAY ehf and the ministry didn’t implement proper organizational and technical measures that would ensure the appropriate security of the personal data processing. Because of a configuration error of the YAY company, the amount of processed data was more than needed, so the DPA also determined this to be a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Iceland
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 28 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Icelandic DPA has fined the Ministry of Industry and Inovation with EUR 51,000 and YAY ehf with EUR 27,200. The fines are related to the ministry’s campaign to encourage Icelanders to travel domestically in the summer of 2020. This involved a digital gift voucher obtainable through the app of the company YAY ehf. The DPA received several complaints from data subjects regarding the fact that using these travel gifts required too much personal information and access to the user’s phones. Therefore, the DPA launched an investigation against the YAY ehf company and the ministry. Apparently, the ministry had violated the principles of transparency and legality. The participating individuals could participate in then voucher promotion by only agreeing to the General Terms of Use of the YAY app. However, by doing so, the data subjects expressly consented to the processing of their personal data as well. The DPA found out that that the information provided about the data processing wasn’t sufficient to warrant it. Moreover, YAY ehf and the ministry didn’t implement proper organizational and technical measures that would ensure the appropriate security of the personal data processing. Because of a configuration error of the YAY company, the amount of processed data was more than needed, so the DPA also determined this to be a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined a physician with EUR 2,000. A patient had previously complained to the DPA that the doctor had disclosed some of his personal data to third parties without obtaining his consent first. The doctor had recommended medical products to the data subject as part of his treatment. However, a few days later, the data subject received a telephone call from a marketing consultant that was behind the products the medic had recommended. The data subject told the marketing consultant that he hadn’t consented to the disclosure of his personal data. Garante discovered that, generally, when it comes to the processing of personal data required for medical treatments, no specific consent of the patient is needed. However, this case is different because the data was processed for product promotion, so explicit consent of the patient was needed as per Art. 9 GDPR. The physician had processed the patient’s data unlawfully.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined the Health Protection Agency of Sardinia (ATS) with EUR 8,000. Apparently, a patient had received in his medical file the medical records and clinical documentation of another patient, by mistake.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined OTTO s.r.l. with EUR 2,000. As part of an administrative inspection of a store managed by OTTO, law enforcement agents found a video surveillance system with three security cameras installed in the store. However, the data controller didn’t provide enough information about the presence of the CCTV. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of Art. 13 GDPR.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Anfiteatro s.r.l. with EUR 2,000. As part of an administrative inspection of a hotel managed by Anfiteatro, law enforcement agents found a video surveillance system with three security cameras installed in the hotel. However, the data controller didn’t provide enough information about the presence of the CCTV. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of Art. 13 GDPR.

allItems.name: Lithuania
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Lithuanian DPA has fined UAB Prime Leasing, an operator of a short-term car rental platform called CityBee, with EUR 110,000. The DPA carried out an investigation on its own initiative after it received information about a potential personal data breach (Art. 33 GDPR) that became public in February 2021. According to company records and claims, they only learned about the security breach from a cybersecurity provider who informed them that customer data of about 110,302 CityBee users had been unlawfully published on the hacking forum RaidForums.com. The personal data included names, phone numbers, addresses, personal identification numbers, email addresses, type of payment cards, the last four digits of the data subject’s card numbers, and diver’s license numbers. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the published personal data came from an unsecured backup copy of a database of the company. The DPA further discovered that this data breach had taken place because of the company’s failure to comply with its obligation to implement the required organizational and technical measures that would ensure adequate security appropriate to the risk of the data subjects. For instance, the company didn’t appoint a person competent enough to oversee the security and risk management. It also didn’t ensure that accesses to database files were logged and evaluated. Moreover, the company hadn’t encrypted the stored databases. A person with enough technical knowledge could gain full access to the data contained in the file after downloading it. As for the personal codes stored in the database, they were unprotected. The passwords in the database were only encrypted with an algorithm that was determined to be insecure.

allItems.name: Luxembourg
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 38 (1), (3) GDPR, Art. 39 (1) a), b) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to appoint data protection officer
allItems.summary: The Luxembourg DPA has fined a company with EUR 15,400. During the DPA’s investigations, it was determined that the data controller failed to involve its data protection officer in matters related to the protection of personal data. Moreover, going against the requirements of the GDPR, the data protection officer didn’t report directly to the highest management level. Instead, the officer reported to two levels of hierarchy in between. Moreover, the data controller didn’t have a data protection plan in place that would demonstrate that the data protection officer was performing its duties correctly.

allItems.name: Norway
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c), e) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 9 (2) GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Norwegian DPA has fined the Norwegian State Pension Fund (SPK) with EUR 98,000 after the data controller notified the DPA about a data breach as per Art. 33 GDPR. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller had unlawfully collected income information since 2016. For instance, the controller had collected health-related information about disability pensions despite not being required. About 24,000 individuals had been affected by these incidents. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the Norwegian State Pension Fund didn’t implement routines to review and delete excessive information collected until 2019.

allItems.name: Norway
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Norwegian DPA has fined Grindr LLC with EUR 6,300,000. Grindr is a location-based social networking app that was designed for bi, gay, trans, and queer people. Back in 2020, the Norwegian Consumer Protection Authority had filed a complaint against Grindr to the Norwegian DPA, alleging that the platform had shared information about its users’ GPS location, IP address, cell phone advertising ID, age and gender to other third parties for marketing, without obtaining the consent of the data subjects. As per GDPR, that personal data should have only been shared with consent from the data subjects. However, the DPA discovered during its investigation that the consent collected by Grindr was invalid. Users had to accept a privacy policy when using the app but the policy didn’t explicitly ask them whether they consented to their data being shared to third parties for marketing purposes. Moreover, information about the disclosure of personal data wasn’t immediately clear or accessible to users. The DPA shows that the type of data disclosed could identify a Grindr user as a member of a sexual minority. The users would sometimes use this app anonymously without inputting their full name or uploading a photo of them. As for the sexual orientation of the users, it was made part of a special category of personal data that is subject to a special, high level of protection. The DPA concludes that this infringement was particularly serious and it justifies a high fine as a deterrent. GDPR considers that this type of fine should act as a strong deterrent for business models based on behavior-based marketing, which are widespread in the digital economy today.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 29 GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b) GDPR, Art. 32 (4) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA (also known as ANSPDCP) has fined Valoris Center S.R.L. with EUR 2,000. The data controller notified the DPA about a data breach as per Art. 33 GDPR. One of the call center employees of the data controller had accidentally sent to one of the customers an Excel file containing data from various other customers of the data controller. During the investigation, the DPA found out that this data breach resulted in the unauthorized disclosure of personal data like user ID, email address, username, customer code, customer name, and customer PIN of a total of 11,169 natural persons. The DPA further concluded that the data controller didn’t successfully implement the necessary organizational and technical measures that would ensure a level of security appropriate to the risk of the data subjects.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The company was fined by the DPA because it failed to provide the requested information within the required timeframe to the DPA, as per Art. 58 GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Vodafone Espana, S.A.U. with EUR 40,000. A data subject complained to the data about the data controller. Apparently, several telephone lines had been registered under his name despite having never concluded any contracts with Vodafone for these lines. The data controller had accidentally assigned the data subject’s personal data to the contracts of another Vodafone client, and that’s why the data subject had the telephone lines on his name. The DPA concluded that Vodafone’s processing of the data subject’s personal data was unlawful. The original fine of EUR 50,000 was reduced to EUR 40,000 because of voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Vodafone Espana, S.A.U. with EUR 40,000. A data subject complained to the DPA that the data controller had transferred her cell phone lines to someone else with her consent because of a technical error. Moreover, the account of the data subject was debited with several amounts that belonged to the third party’s phone line. The DPA also discovered that the Vodafone had unlawfully processed the data subject’s personal data. The original fine of EUR 50,000 was reduced to EUR 40,000 because of voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined UNION FINANCIERA ASTURIANA S.A. E.F.C. with EUR 9,000. The data controller had performed a credit check on the data subject without a contractual basis for doing so. The original fine of 15,000 was reduced to 9,000 because of voluntary payment and admission of guilt.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 48 (1) b) LGT, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 23 LOPDGDD
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined TIGERS MARKET, S.L. with EUR 4,000 because a data subject had received advertising calls from the data controller even though the data subject was included in the Robinson advertising exclusion list.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.source: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a restaurant owner with EUR 1,000 because the data controller failed to provide any information signs about the CCTV surveillance system it had installed in its establishment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a neighborhood community because the data controller had installed a video camera system on their private property. The CCTV system captured images of the public space and the neighbor’s private property as well. The AEPD concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.controller: ASOCIACIÓN ESPAÑOLA PARA LA ENSEÑANZA ONLINE
allItems.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined ASOCIACIÓN ESPAÑOLA PARA LA ENSEÑANZA ONLINE with EUR 5,000 because a data subject showed that he kept receiving advertisements from the data controller even though he had objected to receiving such newsletter subscriptions and even requested the data controller to delete all his data.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined DAVISER SERVICIOS, S.L. with EUR 20,000. The company was processing biometric data (fingerprints) of all its employees who accessed certain rooms, even though it could use less intrusive means (key cards). This way, the privacy of the data subjects could have been retained better. The AEPD discovered that the data controller had violated the principle of data minimization, as well.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.controller: ASOCIACIÓN ESPAÑOLA PARA LA ENSEÑANZA ONLINE
allItems.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) fined ASOCIACIÓN ESPAÑOLA PARA LA ENSEÑANZA ONLINE with EUR 5,000. A data subject had apparently objected to receiving newsletter subscriptions from the data controller and even requested that his personal data be deleted from the controller’s database. However, the data controller kept sending him newsletter subscriptions.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 48 (1) b) LGT, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 23 LOPDGDD
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects’ rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined INTRODUCTION BUSINESS CAPITAL MEDIA, S.L. with EUR 5,000. A data subject received advertising calls from the data controller even though the data subject was registered in the Robinson advertising exclusion list.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) fined IMAGINA FRANT SPORT, S.L. with EUR 2,000 because the company’s privacy policy didn’t comply with the requirements of Art. 13 GDPR. In one case, the website contained outdated information that wasn’t actualized.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) fined a store owner with EUR 1,000 because he failed to provide information signs about the CCTV surveillance system in its establishment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined NBQ Technology S.A.U. with EUR 24,000. A data subject complained to the DPA against the data controller after he was denied a financial transaction because of an alleged outstanding payment on a loan. However, as it turned out, a third party had stolen the data subject’s identity and obtained his personal information without authorization. He proceeded to apply for a loan from the data controller on behalf of the data subject. The data controller approved this loan. However, the AEPD determined that the data processed during this operation of granting the loan didn’t belong to the loan beneficiary but the data subject. So, the AEPD determined that the data controller had no legal basis for the data processing. The data processing was unlawful and it went against Art. 6 (1) GDPR. The original fine of EUR 40,000 was reduced to EUR 24,000 because of admission of guilt and immediate payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined IZA OBRAS Y PROMOCIONES, S.A. with EUR 50,000. One of the data controller’s employees filed a complaint with the DPA against his employer, alleging that the data controller had disclosed his personal data to a third-party company from which it had received a construction order. The data controller did this without authorization. The data subject had been working as a construction manager on the project but had been absent from work for some time on account of an illness. The data controller informed its client about this and further disclosed the data subject’s email address and certain health information. The DPA concluded that this disclosure of data wasn’t necessary and the data controller clearly violated the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 1,200 for failing to provide enough information about a video surveillance system that the data controller installed at their property.

allItems.name: Netherlands
allItems.authority: Dutch Supervisory Authority for Data Protection (AP)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) e) GDPR, Art. 8 Wbp
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Dutch DPA (also known as AP) has fined the Minister of Finance with EUR 2,75 million. Regarding the context of childcare benefit applications, several tax offices had processed data about the dual nationality of applications for many years. However, the DPA discovered that this data on the dual nationality of Dutch citizens wasn’t necessary to assess the applications for childcare benefits. This data was also processed for combating organized fraud and to automate the classifications in the authority’s risk system. That being said, even if these were reasons, the data processing still wasn’t necessary. To this end, the tax and customs administration were supposed to delete the data on dual nationality ever since January 2014. However, as of May 2018, data about the dual citizenship of about 1,4 million people was still registered in the systems of the customs and tax administration. The DPA determined that this data had been unlawfully processed because of a lack of valid legal basis. Moreover, the DPA claims that the data subjects had been discriminated against because of their nationality.

allItems.name: United Kingdom
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The UK DPA (also known as ICO) has fined the Cabinet Office with EUR 585,000. Back on December 27th, 2019, the Cabinet Office had published a file on GOV.UK that contained the uncensored names and addresses of more than 1,000 individuals who had received New Year’s honors. Among the affected individuals were people ranging from various profession across the United Kingdom, even individuals with high public profiles. After the Cabinet Office learned of this data breach, it removed the web link to the file hosted on the internet. However, the file was still contained within the cache and was accessible online to people who had access to the same exact website address. This personal data was disclosed online for two hours and 21 minutes and had been accessed a total of 3,872 times. This data breach occurred because of an error in the setup of the Cabinet Office’s new IT system, apparently. The United Kingdom ICO discovered that the Cabinet Office didn’t take the appropriate organizational and technical measures that would ensure a proper level of protection appropriate to the risk of the data subjects.

allItems.name: Austria
allItems.type: Various offences
allItems.summary: The Austrian DPA has fined REWE International AG with EUR 8 million. Back in the summer of 2021, a subsidiary of the company, Unser Ö-Bonus Club GmbH, received a fine of EUR 2 million. The Salzburger Nachrichten newspaper said that the fined is based on various violations of the GDPR. Other details aren’t known yet.

allItems.name: Belgium
allItems.type: Insufficient involvement of data protection officer
allItems.summary: The Belgian DPA has fined a bank with EUR 75,000. The DPA discovered a conflict of interest involving the data protection officer. The officer was also the head of the department to which he had been reporting as a data protection officer, aside from his work as a DPO. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of Art. 38 (6) GDPR

allItems.name: France
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 28 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 34 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The French DPA (also known as CNIL) has fined the payment institution SLIMPAY with EUR 180,000. Back in 2015, SLIMPAY carried out an internal research project where it processed personal data in its databases. Back when the research project had ended in July 2016, the data remained stored on an unencrypted server and it was freely accessible on the internet. This data breach affected approximately 12 million people. During the investigation, the CNIL discovered that the company failed to implement the adequate technical and organizational measures that would ensure a proper level of security appropriate to the risk of the data subjects. Therefore, the server wasn’t secured in any way, so anyone could access it on the internet between November 2015 and February 2020. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the company did not inform the data subjects about the data breach. In several cases, company-concluded contracts with processes were inadequately drafted because they didn’t include envisaged clauses that would force the process the personal data of data subjects in accordance with the GDPR requirements.

allItems.name: France
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The French DPA (also known as CNIL) has fined FREE MOBILE with EUR 300,000. The CNIL had received several complaints about the company’s failure to comply with the rights of the data subjects. During the investigation, the CNIL discovered that the company did not respond to the data subjects’ requests in a timely manner. Additionally, the company didn’t comply with the rights of objection of the data subjects, since it kept sending advertisements to the data subjects despite them having expressly mentioned that they don’t want to receive ads anymore. Moreover, the CNIL found out that the company didn’t implement the necessary organizational and technical measures that would ensure a level of security appropriate to the risk of the data subjects. For instance, the company sent user passwords via email in clear text.

allItems.name: France
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: Back on the 31st of December, 2021, the French DPA (also known as CNIL) fined Google LLC with EUR 90,000,000. The CNIL received several complaints about the manner in which google.fr and youtube.com approached the manner in which users could refuse cookies on these websites. The CNIL did an online review of these websites and discovered that, despite there being a button to accept the cookies instantly, there was no such button to reject them. To reject the cookies, you had to go through several options, as opposed to one option for accepting the cookies. The CNIL concluded that, in most cases, users accepted the cookies out of convenience rather than because they agreed to it. It also concluded that the way these cookie deposits were designed is an interference with the freedom of consent of internet users, violating Art. 82 of the French Law on Informatics and Freedoms. When determining the fine, the CNIL took into consideration the large number of people who were affected in such an aggravating manner. Additionally, the CNIL also considered the significant profits that the companies could make from advertisements generated indirectly from the data collected through these cookies. The CNIL also pointed out the fact that the authority had previously notified the Google companies of this breach in February 2021. Aside from the fine, the CNIL also issued an order that required the companies to provide all internet users in France with a simple way of rejecting cookies, just as simple as accepting them, within three months of receiving this notification. Otherwise, both companies would have to pay a fine of EUR 100,000 per day of delay.

allItems.name: France
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: Back on the 31st of December, 2021, the French DPA (also known as CNIL) fined Google Ireland Ltd. with EUR 60,000,000. The CNIL received several complaints about the manner in which google.fr and youtube.com approached the manner in which users could refuse cookies on these websites. The CNIL did an online review of these websites and discovered that, despite there being a button to accept the cookies instantly, there was no such button to reject them. The CNIL also pointed out the fact that the authority had previously notified the Google companies of this breach in February 2021. Aside from the fine, the CNIL also issued an order that required the companies to provide all internet users in France with a simple way of rejecting cookies, just as simple as accepting them, within three months of receiving this notification. Otherwise, both companies would have to pay a fine of EUR 100,000 per day of delay.

allItems.name: France
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: Back on the 31st of December, 2021, the French DPA (also known as CNIL) fined Facebook Ireland Ltd. with EUR 60,000,000. The CNIL received several complaints about the manner in which google.fr and youtube.com approached the manner in which users could refuse cookies on these websites. The CNIL did an online review of these websites and discovered that, despite there being a button to accept the cookies instantly, there was no such button to reject them. The CNIL also pointed out the fact that the authority had previously notified the Google companies of this breach in February 2021. Aside from the fine, the CNIL also issued an order that required the companies to provide all internet users in France with a simple way of rejecting cookies, just as simple as accepting them, within three months of receiving this notification. Otherwise, both companies would have to pay a fine of EUR 100,000 per day of delay.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined Εγνατία Οδός Α.Ε. with EUR 1,000. The company operated a video surveillance system that monitored the payment of tolls. One car owner received a fine for not paying the toll and then exercised his right to information as defined by the GDPR. He requested photographic material that was captured in the context of the fine. He also requested a copy of the documentation of the incident. However, the company didn’t provide this information to the data subject. After the DPA intervened, the company did offer this information but didn’t disclose any photographic material. For this reason, the DPA concluded that the company had violated Art. 13 (3) GDPR.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 11 Law 3471/2006
allItems.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined PLUS REAL Advertisement with EUR 25,000. The data controller had previously conducted several advertising calls without the data subjects’ consent. Additionally, it didn’t adequately inform the data subjects about the processing of their personal data. Therefore, it violated its information obligations.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 11 Law 3471/2006
allItems.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined INFO COMMUNICATION SERVICES with EUR 30,000. The data controller had previously conducted several advertising calls without the data subjects’ consent. Additionally, it didn’t adequately inform the data subjects about the processing of their personal data. Therefore, it violated its information obligations.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 33 GDPR, Art. 37 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined the Greek Ministry of Tourism with EUR 75,000. There was a data breach which, according to the DPA, involved the attempt of a citizen to enter his/her credentials on the online platform of the Ministry. This resulted in the displaying of another person’s credentials, including full name, social security number, tax number, phone number, postal address, email address, and other fields that indicated their disability. The DPA discovered that the Ministry did not implement the required organizational and technical measures that would ensure the proper security of the personal data. It also did not report this incident to the DPA. So, the DPA concluded that this was a violation of Art. 33 of the GDPR. During the investigation, it was found that the Ministry of Tourism hadn’t appointed a data protection officer even though the authority’s platform mentioned an email address of a supposed data protection officer. However, this email address was inactive, as it was later found out.

allItems.name: Ireland
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) GDPR, Art. 33 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Irish DPA has fined the Irish Teaching Council with EUR 60,000 after the Council notified the DPA about a data breach under Art. 33 GDPR. Apparently, two Council employees had accessed a phishing email that allowed them to establish an automatic forwarding system from their personal email accounts to a malicious email account. As a result of this, a total of 323 email were forwarded to this unauthorized email address between the 17th of February, 2020, and the 6th of March 2020. These emails contained personal details of 9,735 data subjects as well as the sensitive personal data of one data subject. The DPA concluded that the Council did not implement the required organizational and technical measures that would ensure a proper level of security for the personal data of the data subjects. Additionally, the DPA discovered that the Council did not report this data breach in a timely manner.

allItems.name: Ireland
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Irish DPA has fined Limerick City and County Council with EUR 110,000. During the investigation, the DPA carried out a complete audit of the processing of personal data done by the council or on the council’s behalf using video surveillance systems, body-worn cameras, automatic license plate recognition software, and other technologies that may have been used to monitor individuals. The DPA discovered that the Council had violated a number of data protection laws when using these technologies. The DPA issued a fine for these GDPR violations. More specifically, the DPA found out that the Council had violated Art. 13 GDPR regarding its relation to the processing of data using traffic cameras. The Council did not provide any information on the identity of the data controller, the contact details of the data protection officer, the purposes for the data processing, or the authorities from which further information could be obtained, as required by Art. 13 GDPR. Additionally, the Council did not provide any information in an easily accessible manner such as signs near the video surveillance cameras. Furthermore, the DPA discovered that the Council did not post a video surveillance policy in a plan and understandable language, in an easily-accessible place on the Council’s website. Therefore, the DPA concluded that the Council had infringed on Art. 12 GDPR. The Council further denied requests for personal data access that was processed by surveillance cameras during traffic management. As a result, the DPA concluded that the Council had also violated Art. 15 GDPR.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined the mobile operator TIM S.p.A with EUR 150,000 because it denied a data subject access to his phone data required to defend himself in a criminal case. The data subject hadn’t received a response to his requests in a timely manner, so he asked the DPA to obtain the data in time for the hearing of the criminal proceedings.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.controller: Società H San Raffaele Resnati s.r.l.
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Società H San Raffaele Resnati s.r.l. with EUR 6,000. The DPA started an investigation against the healthcare provider after the latter had reported a data breach to the DPA. Apparently, a patient had mistakenly received medical records and clinical documentation from two patients because of an employee error.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined ICA s.r.l. with EUR 30,000. The municipality of Collegno had previously implemented a system that allowed citizens to pay fines for traffic violations. The system was designed and developed by ICA s.r.l. Apparently, because of a lack of security precautions, it was possible for unauthorized individuals to access the personal data stored in the program. The DPA concluded that ICA did not implement the proper organizational and technical measures that would provide a level of security sufficient for the protection of the data subjects’ personal data.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Società Med Store Saronno s.r.l. with EUR 7,000. The nursing home had notified the DPA about a data breach as per Art. 33 GDPR. The facility had gone through a cyber attack done by a hacker who gained access to personal data and published it online. The personal data included radiological images of patients. He published them on his Twitter account. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the nursing home had secured the data with simple passwords only. So, the DPA concluded that the nursing home failed to implement adequate organizational and technical measures to protect the data subjects’ personal data.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.controller: Casa di cura Fondazione Gaetano e Piera Borghi s.r.l.
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Casa di cura Fondazione Gaetano e Piera Borghi s.r.l. with EUR 30,000. The nursing home had notified the DPA about a data breach as per Art. 33 GDPR. The facility had gone through a cyber attack done by a hacker who gained access to personal data and published it online. The personal data included radiological images of patients. He published them on his Twitter account. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the nursing home had secured the data with simple passwords only. So, the DPA concluded that the nursing home failed to implement adequate organizational and technical measures to protect the data subjects’ personal data.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Azienda USL di Parma with EUR 5,000. A patient had filed a complaint to the DPA because she was mistakenly sent two reports of diagnostic tests that belonged to two other patients.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), d) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR, Art. 25 (1) GDPR, Art. 30 GDPR, Art. 31 GDPR, Art. 130 (1), (2), (4) Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Various offences
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Enel Energia S.p.A. with EUR 26,5 million for several data breaches and violations of the GDPR. After a thorough preliminary investigation launched after the DPA received hundreds of reports from users, the DPA discovered that the data controller had been illegally processing the personal data of millions of users for telemarketing purposes. The DPA also discovered that the data subjects had been receiving unsolicited promotional calls made in the name of Enel Energia. In some cases, the calls were also recorded. Several data subjects were still receiving advertising calls even though the had objected to them and asked Enel Energia to delete their personal data a couple of times. More specifically, the DPA discovered that Enel Energia did not provide the data subjects with timely feedback on the requests of the data subjects to exercise their rights of access and opposition. Additionally, the DPA discovered that the company had insufficiently cooperated with the DPA during the investigation. For instance, Enel Energia did not respond to several inquiries made by the DPA. In assessing the issued fine, the DPA took into consideration the following aggravating factors: the seriousness of the violation, the large number of individuals affected, the duration and repetition of the violations, and the negligence of the conduct.

allItems.name: Luxembourg
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Luxembourg DPA (also known as CNPD) has fined a company with EUR 1,500. Apparently, the company had installed a video surveillance system that make sure that their customers did not wait too long when the front desk staff wasn’t present. However, these cameras also captured two employees’ work areas. The DPA concluded that the data controller had violated the principle of data minimization as per Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR. Moreover, the DPA discovered a violation of the information obligations established in Art. 13 GDPR because it didn’t properly inform its employees and other third parties about the video surveillance.

allItems.name: Luxembourg
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Luxembourg DPA (also known as CNPD) as fined a company with EUR 6,800. Apparently, the company had installed a video surveillance system to safeguard the company’s assets and prevent any unauthorized intrusions and accidents from third parties. However, these cameras also captured parts of the one employee’s work space, the smoking area frequented by the employees, and parts of the public space. The DPA concluded that the data controller had violated the principle of data minimization as per Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR. Moreover, the DPA discovered a violation of its information obligations as per Art. 13 GDPR because it didn’t properly inform employees and other third parties about the video surveillance.

allItems.name: Malta
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 9 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 33 GDPR, Art. 34 GDPR
allItems.type: Many
allItems.summary: The DPA has fined C-Planet (IT Solutions) Limited with EUR 65,000. The DPA has carried out an investigation on C-Planet in April 2020 after being informed of a data breach. The DPA found out that C-Planet had violated Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 9 (1), (2) GDPR, Art 14 GDPR, and Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR regarding data processing. The DPA discovered that C-Planet did not implement adequate organizational and technical measures that would ensure the proper security commensurate to the risk of the data subjects. This is a violation of Art. 32 GDPR. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the data controller did not notify the DPA in a timely manner and did not inform data subjects about the personal data breach. This is a violation of Art. 33 GDPR and Art. 34 GDPR.

allItems.name: Norway
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Norwegian DPA (also known as Datatilsynet) has fined Elektro & Automasjon Systemer AS with EUR 20,000 because it had implemented credit checks on an individual even though there was no legal base to do so.

allItems.name: Norway
allItems.type: Unknown
allItems.summary: The Norwegian DPA (also known as Datatilsynet) as fined T. Stene Transport AS with EUR 3,900 because of an unfair credit check on a data subject.

allItems.name: Poland
allItems.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 24 (1) GDPR, Art. 25 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 (1), (2) GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Polish DPA (also known as UODO) has fined the Warsaw University of Technology with EUR 10,000. The university had previously reported a data breach to the authority as per Art. 33 GDPR. An organizational unit of the university had used an application created by the staff of the university to register for courses and access assessments of exam results, teaching history, and billing of fees. Back in January 2020, an unauthorized third party had downloaded a database from this application that contained the personal data of students and faculty staff (more than 5,000 individuals). During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the Warsaw University of Technology did not implement the required organizational and technical measures that would ensure a proper level of security of the personal data. The DPA also discovered that the university did not conduct a formal risk assessment of the program.

allItems.name: Portugal
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c), e) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 13 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 35 (3) GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Portuguese DPA has fined the Lisbon City Council with EUR 1.25 million. This fine is the sum of 225 fines issued because of several violations committed by the municipality since 2018. The municipality had previously sent 111 notifications regarding the demonstrations to various departments and offices in the municipality and to third parties, to ensure that they could perform their public duties accordingly. These notices contained sensitive data of the organizer of the demonstrations and the demonstrators themselves. This data revealed the political opinions, philosophical beliefs, religious beliefs, and sexual orientations of the data subjects. The DPA discovered that the transfer of this data wouldn’t have been necessary for the involved entities to properly perform their public tasks. Therefore, the processing of the personal data was illegal. Additionally, the DPA discovered that the municipality had undergone the data processing without informing the data subjects, without establishing a policy regarding the retention of their personal data, and without conducting a preliminary data protection impact assessment.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA (also known as ANSPDCP) has fined Kaufland România SCS with EUR 3,000. The DPA carried out an investigation based on a complaint from an individual who stated that the data controller did not provide them with the complete copy of the video recordings of when they had been in the store premises. The DPA argues that the data controller is obliged to disclose the video images of the data subjects after they exercise their right of access. Furthermore, the data controller may choose to blur the images that, if shown, would violate the rights and freedoms of other natural persons.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria S.A. with EUR 60,000. A data subject had previously filed a complaint with the DPA against the data controller because he kept receiving SMS messages about non-payment from the data controller, even though he had no contractual relationship with the data controller. Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria argued that these unsolicited SMS messages had been sent because of a human error from its employees. The original fine of EUR 100,000 was reduced to EUR 60,000 because of admission of guilt and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 2,000. The data controller had previously installed several video cameras that recorded images of the public space and the entrance to a residential building. The AEPD concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined an online retailer with EUR 2,000. A data subject purchased a product from the online store of the data controller through eBay, and paid the purchase using PayPal. However, he received his order via Amazon. The data subject hadn’t consented to the transfer of his data to Amazon, so the DPA concluded that the data controller had processed his data unlawfully.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined CLUB DEPORTIVO RITMO DE ANDALUCIA with EUR 4,000. The DPA claimed that the data protection notice of the data controller didn’t comply with the requirements of the GDPR regulations. The information notice breached Art. 13 GDPR because not enough information was provided. Additionally, the data protection notice also didn’t provide an adequate opportunity for people to consent to the data processing.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.controller: FUNDACION ESPANOLA DE MEDICINA ESTETICA Y LONGEVIDAD
allItems.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined FUNDACION ESPANOLA DE MEDICINA ESTETICA Y LONGEVIDAD with EUR 2,000. The DPA claimed that the data protection notice of the data controller didn’t comply with the requirements of the GDPR regulations. The information notice breached Art. 13 GDPR because not enough information was provided. Additionally, the data protection notice also didn’t provide an adequate opportunity for people to consent to the data processing.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 6,000. This person had shared a video on Twitter that showed explicit images of a sexual assault by a man on a woman. Even though the private individual had a good reason to share the video to raise public awareness about violence against women, the DPA considers that sharing the video was unlawful. Despite having a legitimate interest to share the video, the victim’s right to privacy is more important.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Sfam Espana General s.l. with EUR 5,000 because a data subject had complained that the data controller charged her for several services that she hadn’t ordered.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined HUBSIDE IBERICA, S.L. with EUR 5,000 because a data subject had complained that the data controller charged her for several services that she hadn’t ordered.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined LA OFICINA BAR with EUR 1,500. The bar was operating a video surveillance system that captured the public traffic area. The DPA considered that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItems.summary: This corporate website didn’t have a privacy policy on its main page.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined REAL CLUB NAUTICO DE RIBADEO with EUR 6,000. The data controller had uploaded on its Facebook page and website several links to court decisions that contained personal data of data subjects.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined the manager of a call shop with EUR 2,000. Regarding a job vacancy at the call shop, the manager had set up a stand where applicants could submit their applications if they paid a fee of one euro. However, the manager didn’t properly inform the data subjects that their personal data would be processed, as per Art. 13 GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: Violation of the principle of data minimization because of a usage of CCTV cameras that captured public roads outside.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined EDUCANDO JUNTOS SL with EURO 9,000. The data controller had previously published several photos of an employee on various social network channels and on its website. However, the data controller hadn’t obtained the consent of the data subject before publishing these photos. As a result, the data subject asked the data controller repeatedly that the photos be taken down from the website and the social networks. However, the data controller didn’t comply with this request. As a result, the GDPR fined the data controller with EUR 6,000 for violating Art. 6 (1) GDPR and EUR 3,000 for violating Art. 17 GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 1,500. The data controller had installed several video surveillance cameras that also captured the public space. The DPA considered this to be a violation of the principle of data minimization. Moreover, the data controller didn’t properly inform the data subjects about the processing of the data via the video surveillance, and this violated its duty to inform. The fine contains EUR 1,000 for violating Art. (1) c) GDPR, and EUR 500 for violating Art. 13 GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: Usage of CCTV cameras that captured the foreign private space of a neighbor.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined PHARMA TALENTS, S.L.U. with EUR 2,400. A data subject had complained against the company after he discovered that there was personal data about himself and hundreds of other health sector professionals on a database of the company. This data contained email addresses and telephone numbers. The website and this particular database were freely accessible to anyone. The DPA discovered that the company didn’t implement the proper organizational and technical measures that would ensure adequate security commensurate to the risk of the data subjects. There were no password or username required to access the database. The original fine of EUR 4,000 was reduced to EUR 2,400 because of admission of guilt and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fiend MEETING PUERTO C.B. with EUR 2,000. The data controller had unlawfully published a picture of the data subject next to his partner on Facebook and Instagram. This picture was accompanied by insulting comments.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 1,500. The person had installed several video cameras in the apartment building where he resides. These cameras also recorded common areas used by all residents. The DPA considers that this is a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined VODAFONE ESPANA, S.A.U. with EUR 56,000 because the data controller had an insufficient legal basis for data processing. The data subject claims that two telephone connections had been registered under his/her name. However, the data subject had never signed any contracts with the company for these connections. Actually, the contracts had been concluded by fraudsters using the personal data of the data subject. Still, the personal data had been entered into the company’s systems without being verified if the contracts had been concluded lawfully and by the data subject in person, or whether he/he had given consent to the collection and processing of the personal data. The original fine of EUR 70,000 was reduced to EUR 56,000 because of immediate payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined GARLEX SOLUTIONS, S.L. with EUR 15,000. A data subject had received a call from the company regarding the renewal of the electricity supply contract. Then, the data subject received an SMS with a link leading to an electricity supply contract that had their personal data already entered. The data subject didn’t know how the company had entered his/her personal data into the contract since they had never provided it nor consented to its processing.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a website operator because it lacked a privacy policy on its website, violating Art. 13 GDPR

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a property owners’ community with EUR 1,200. The property manager had sent a copy of the general meeting minutes to the director of the security company CMM Seguridad. This document contained names and addresses of the residents, a list of defaulters, and the accounts of the income and expenses of the community. The data controller claims that they had sent these minutes to the security company in order to inform them about the appointment of the members of the Board of Directors. In other words, the data controller should have only sent the minutes and associated information after the document had been anonymized. Therefore, the DPA concludes that the transmission of the full minutes wasn’t necessary, so there was a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Sweden
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Swedish DPA has fined the Uppsala regional board with EUR 28,500. As a result of the investigation of Uppsala region, this fine was applied for various reasons. The DPA had previously received two reports of incidents regarding personal data from the Uppsala region. These incidents involved sensitive personal health data that was transferred unencrypted to recipients both in and out of Sweden. The regional board had sent this sensitive personal data and identity numbers via email. The transmission itself was encrypted, but the information inside the emails wasn’t. The emails contained patient data that was automatically directed to health administrators in the region. Some patient data was manually sent to physicians and researchers in the region. Therefore, the DPA concluded that the regional board had taken insufficient organizational and technical measures to protect the data from any unauthorized access.

allItems.name: Sweden
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Swedish DPA has fined the Uppsala hospital board with EUR 152,000. As a result of the investigation of Uppsala region, this fine was applied for various reasons. The DPA had previously received two reports of incidents regarding personal data from the Uppsala region. These incidents involved sensitive personal health data that was transferred unencrypted to recipients both in and out of Sweden. Uppsala University Hospital had also sent emails that contained patient data to senders in three countries without encrypting them. Additionally, the hospital administration had stored this sensitive personal data in the Outlook email service. Therefore, the DPA concluded that the hospital board had taken insufficient organizational and technical measures to protect the data from any unauthorized access.

allItems.name: Belgium
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c), f) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Belgian DPA has fined a researcher with EUR 1,200. The fine had been issued regarding another fine issued to the NGO EU Disinfolab. The researcher had been an employee at this NGO. Back in 2018, the NGO had published an analysis to help identify the political origins of tweets that were circulating on a heated controversy in France, the “Benalla affair”. During the analysis, the NGO had processed the data of 55,000 Twitter individuals. 3,300 of these had been classified as political. The information obtained from these accounts was published without taking minimal security precautions (anonymizing the data). The DPA noticed that the publication of this data could expose the data subjects to discrimination or discreditation because of the non-anonymous political profiling. Additionally, these files contained information about the data subjects’ sexual orientations, religious beliefs, and ethnic origins. As a result, the DPA concluded that several principles of the GDPR like the transparency to data subjects or the lawfulness of processing and data security, had been violated.

allItems.name: Belgium
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c), f) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 30 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Belgian DPA has fined the NGO EU Disinfolab with EUR 2,700. Back in 2018, the NGO had published an analysis to help identify the political origins of tweets that were circulating on a heated controversy in France, the “Benalla affair”. During the analysis, the NGO had processed the data of 55,000 Twitter individuals. 3,300 of these had been classified as political. The information obtained from these accounts was published without taking minimal security precautions (anonymizing the data). The DPA noticed that the publication of this data could expose the data subjects to discrimination or discreditation because of the non-anonymous political profiling. Additionally, these files contained information about the data subjects’ sexual orientations, religious beliefs, and ethnic origins. As a result, the DPA concluded that several principles of the GDPR like the transparency to data subjects or the lawfulness of processing and data security, had been violated.

allItems.name: Belgium
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 9 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 12 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 24 (1) GDPR, Art. 30 GDPR, Art. 31 GDPR, Art. 32 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 37 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Belgian DPA has fined IAB Europe with EUR 250,000. The DPA had previously received many complaints against IAB Europe ever since 2019. Regarding this complaint, the DPA questioned the compliance of IAB Europe with the “Transparency & Consent Framework (TCF). The TCF had been developed by IAB to promote compliance with the GDPR through organizations that used the OpenRTB protocol. This protocol is used for “real-time bidding” like the automated online auctions of user profiles regarding the purchase and sale of advertising space on the web. Users would visit websites that contain ad space that technology companies can bid for in real time through automated auction systems. This was done to display personalized advertising to users. Upon visiting a website for the first time, an interface would appear asking users for consent to the collection, sharing, and other types of processing of their personal information. During this process, the TCF employs a specific consent management tool that allows users to reject certain types of data processing. This TCF remembers the users’ preferences via the consent management tool by generating a TC string and sending it to everyone that participates in the OpenRTB system. This TC string allows user profiles to be compiled and sent to advertisers. The advertisers will see the types of data processing that the users have agreed to. The DPA noticed that the IAB had violated several of the GDPR regulations during the investigation. It discovered that these TC strings already contained personal data, which required a legal basis for its processing, which IAB did not have. IAB couldn’t prove that it had any legal basis to process these TC strings, though. For instance, when users were informed about the data processing, the information provided to them was far too generic and vague to properly understand the purpose of the data processing. Moreover, IAB did not maintain any register of its data processing activities and had also failed to appoint a data protection officer. It also did not conduct any data protection impact assessment.

allItems.name: Finland
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Finnish DPA has fined a travel agency with EUR 6,500. One of the customers of the travel agency informed the DPA about the company being suspicious because it may not process customer personal data in a GDPR-compliant manner. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the travel agency did not ensure a secure processing of personal data. For instance, the visa application forms that customers filled out were publicly available on the web server of the travel agency. This form contained, among other things, the data subjects’ names, passport numbers, and contact details. Additionally, the travel agency did not comply with the data subjects’ requests to delete their personal data from the systems.

allItems.name: Finland
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 25 (2) GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Finnish DPA has fined a motor insurance center with EUR 52,000. The data controller had requested too much patient data from the healthcare system for the purpose of processing claims. Most of the requested data wasn’t required to process the claims, though. For instance, the DPA discovered that the motor vehicle insurance center had collected patient visit notes that would determine whether the healthcare provider had been billing visits unrelated to examinations or treatments caused by moto accidents. The DPA also noted that the Finnish Motor Insurance Act doesn’t justify such direct and free access to patient data. Moreover, the information requested must be required for the processing of the claims. As such, the DPA noted that the motor insurance center had violated the principles of egality, minimization of data processing, and transparency.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 25 (1) GDPR, Art. 26 GDPR, Art. 28 GDPR, Art. 35 (7) GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined Cosmote Mobile Telecommunications S.A. with EUR 6 million. Cosmote had previously reported to the DPA a data breach as per Art. 33 of the GDPR.
