The that that was stolen included sensitive information from subscribers of Cosmote, such as age, contract information, and gender. About 10 million people were affected by this incident. As such, the DPA concluded that Cosmote did not implement the adequate technical and organizational measures to ensure a proper execution of the data anonymization procedure. Additionally, Cosmote didn’t conduct a sufficient data protection impact assessment and also didn’t properly inform the data subjects about the processing of their personal data. Moreover, the DPA also discovered that Cosmote didn’t explicitly regulate the allocation of roles within the data processing of its subsidiary, the OTE Group. When calculating the fine, the DPA took into account the aggravating factor of the long duration of these breaches (6 years), the large number of affected data subjects, and the lack of pseudonymization measures of the data that hadn’t been implemented for such a long time.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined the Cosmote subsidiary OTE Group with EUR 3,2 million. OTE group had contributed to the security infrastructure of Cosmote, which had reported a data breach as per Art. 33 of the GDPR. A hacker was able to penetrate Cosmote’s systems because of a lack of security measures. The hacker obtained and leaked vital customer data in the aftermath of the attack. This data included sensitive information about Cosmote customers, such as age, gender, and contract information. About 10 million people had been affected by this incident. Consequently, the DPA discovered that OTE Group didn’t implement the adequate organizational and technical measures that would ensure a proper level of security proportional to the risk of the data subjects.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined ΛΙΜΕΝΟΣ ΗΡΑΚΛΕΙΟΥ Α.Ε. with EUR 30,000. A data subject who had gone through a car accident on the premises of the organization had filed a complaint against ΛΙΜΕΝΟΣ ΗΡΑΚΛΕΙΟΥ Α.Ε. to the DPA. The organization operated a video surveillance system that recorded the car accident. Regarding this accident, the data subject requested the organization to give them access to the recordings. However, the organization didn’t comply with their request, which led to the fine.

allItems.name: Hungary
allItems.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 9 (1) GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Hungarian DPA fined a lawyer with EUR 843 because they’d disclosed documents containing the person data of their client during criminal proceedings without any legal basis.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 37 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Centro di Medicina preventive s.r.l. with EUR 10,000. The data controller had previously reported a database breach that suffered a cyberattack by a hacker group. During this attack, the hacker gained access to the list of patient data which was then published on Twitter. This list contained sensitive personal data of the patients such as radio-diagnostic tests. The DPA discovered that the data controller didn’t implement the appropriate organizational and technical measures that could ensure the proper security of the personal data. For instance, the servers of the medical center disclosed the requested personal data without verifying the credentials and identity of the person who requested it. This allowed unauthorized people to gain access to the data.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c), e) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 157 Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The company had left the email account of the data subject active after the termination of the data subject’s employment. The account automatically forwarded incoming emails to the data subject’s email. The company didn’t offer enough information about this.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Ubi Banca Spa with EUR 100,000. A data subject had previously filed a complaint to the DPA for having received a letter about an “anomalous credit Chieti” from the data controller. However, this letter didn’t contain any payment reminders. It only contained information about the transparency of the bank and financial services. Consequently, the DPA noted that the data controller had violated the principles of transparency, lawfulness, and data minimization. Moreover, the term on the envelope could potentially enable third parties to get information about the financial situation of the recipient, and this doesn’t take into account the contents of the envelope.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined FCA Italy s.p.a. with EUR 20,000. A former customer of the data controller had requested from the data controller the transcripts of telephone conversations between him and the company’s customer service regarding a previous communication about the malfunction of the instruments of his vehicle. He also requested the documents regarding this case. However, the data controller didn’t comply to the data subject’s request.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined UNiversita Teleamtica Internazionale Uninettuno. A professor had complained to the DPA against the education institution. Apparently, the professor had applied for a position at the university and provided his CV to this end. The university published it online without blurring or blacking out personal data that regarded his personal life. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined ASL Latina with EUR 10,000. The data controller had sent documents containing health data of the data subjects to unauthorized third parties by mistake.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Azienda Sanitaria Locale Frosinone with EUR 7,500. During the investigation against this medical facility, the Italian DPA has discovered that their privacy policy was deficient and incomplete. For instance, the facility indicated that the data processing had several purposes, but the legal bases for them weren’t clear and visible all the time. Moreover, the legal bases that were stated were contradictory or incorrect. Additionally, the facility didn’t provide enough information about the storage periods of the collected data.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The data controller didn’t respond to the data subject’s request for access to their data in a timely manner.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Azienda sanitaria unica regionale Marche with EUR 14,000. The DPA launched an investigation against the health department after media reports showcased deficiencies in the system that collected and managed Covid 19 screening data. The health department used an app that generated QR codes for people who received tests for Covid 19. These QR codes were generated based on progressive criteria and not randomly. So, each person received a number. Therefore, it was possible for unauthorized individuals to gain access to another person’s profile by changing a digit. The DPA discovered that the health authority didn’t implement the adequate technical and organizational measures that would ensure a proper level of security that’s appropriate to the risk of the data subjects.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The nursing care facility didn’t signal its use of CCTV systems within its premises.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined A.S.L. Napoli 1 Centro with EUR 1,000. One of the employees at the health authority had previously filed a complaint against the authority to the DPA. The health authority had previously published a press release on its website that contained data about the data subject and information regarding a disciplinary procedure. The health authority thought that the publication as lawful since the data subject had willingly provided this information to the press, and the press had published a report on the topic. However, the DPA noted that the health authority still needed a legal basis to publish the information, even if the same information had been used by other media.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined the private club “Ruian” with EUR 2,000. The data controller had previously installed video surveillance cameras that, among other things, covered the public space as well. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. Additionally, the data controller didn’t properly inform about the processing of the data through the video surveillance system, violating its duty to inform.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 157 Codice della privacy, Art. 166 (2) Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined T.S.M. s.r.l. with EUR 40,000. A data subject had previously filed a complaint to the Dpa against the company because the latter failed to comply with the data subject’s request to delete their data and to object to the future processing of their personal data.

allItems.name: Norway
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Norwegian DPA (also known as Datatilsynet) has fined Etterforsker1 Gruppen AS with EUR 5,000. The data controller didn’t have a legal basis for carrying out a credit check on a data subject.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA (also known as ANSPDCP) has fined SC Grupex 2000 SRL with EUR 1,000. The data controller didn’t have a legal basis to upload videos of patients on its website.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b), c), f) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined the civil law firm “Sabou, Burz & Cuc” with EUR 1,000. The DPA launched an investigation when a client complained that the data controller had published some of their personal data on a WhatsApp group used by lawyers of a bar association. This was done without the consent of the data subject. The DPA discovered that the data subject had processed the personal data of the data subject without obtaining their consent and without a legal basis. They had published the data for a purpose that was different from the originally agreed-upon purpose.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined IAMSAT Muntenia SA with EUR 3,000. A former employee complained to the DPA that their former employer had continued to process their personal data even after the employment contract had been terminated in 2020. The data subject had stated that they wouldn’t agree to the continued use of their email address and that they also objected to the use of their personal data by the data controller and other related third parties after the employment contract was terminated. During the investigation, the DPA found out that the data controller didn’t inform its employees, even the data subjects, about the processing of their personal data through a video surveillance system installed at the workplace.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The property owner association used CCTV cameras in the building complex without properly informing the property owners and obtaining their consent.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Cyrana Espana General S.L. with EUR 5,000. The data controller had previously sent an invoice to the data subject even though there was no contractual relationship between them.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined INCOPROSOL, S.L. with EUR 5,000. The data controller had recorded a telephone conversation with a customer without the data subject’s consent.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined Vodafone Espana, S.A.U. with EUR 3.94 million. A total of 9 Vodafone customers had complained to the DPA against Vodafone. During its investigation, the DPA discovered that several fraudsters had pretended to be the data subjects and demanded a copy of their SIM cards. Then, they concluded contracts in the name of the data subjects and carried out several transfers. According to the DPA, Vodafone didn’t properly verify the identity of the fraudsters before issuing the SIM cards. They also didn’t ensure that the fraudsters were really the SIM card holders. A lack of proper security measures led to this.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined ORANGE ESPANA VIRTUAL, S.L. with EUR 70,000. Two Orange Espana Virtual customers had complained to the DPA against Orange. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that several fraudsters had pretended to be the data subjects and demanded a copy of their SIM cards. Then, they concluded contracts in the name of the data subjects and carried out several transfers. According to the DPA, Vodafone didn’t properly verify the identity of the fraudsters before issuing the SIM cards. They also didn’t ensure that the fraudsters were really the SIM card holders. A lack of proper security measures led to this.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Orange Espagne, S.A.U. with EUR 700,000. Two Orange Espagne customers had complained to the DPA against Orange. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that several fraudsters had pretended to be the data subjects and demanded a copy of their SIM cards. Then, they concluded contracts in the name of the data subjects and carried out several transfers. According to the DPA, Vodafone didn’t properly verify the identity of the fraudsters before issuing the SIM cards. They also didn’t ensure that the fraudsters were really the SIM card holders. A lack of proper security measures led to this.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined XFERA MOVILES S.A. with EUR 200,000. Two Xfera customers had complained to the DPA against Orange. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that several fraudsters had pretended to be the data subjects and demanded a copy of their SIM cards. Then, they concluded contracts in the name of the data subjects and carried out several transfers. According to the DPA, Vodafone didn’t properly verify the identity of the fraudsters before issuing the SIM cards. They also didn’t ensure that the fraudsters were really the SIM card holders. A lack of proper security measures led to this.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined TELEFONICA MOVILES ESPANIA, S.A.U. with EUR 900,000. Four TELEFONICA customers had filed a complained to the DPA against the company. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that several fraudsters had pretended to be the data subjects and demanded a copy of their SIM cards. Then, they concluded contracts in the name of the data subjects and carried out several transfers. According to the DPA, Vodafone didn’t properly verify the identity of the fraudsters before issuing the SIM cards. They also didn’t ensure that the fraudsters were really the SIM card holders. A lack of proper security measures led to this.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The café several CCTV cameras that captures, among other things, the public space outside of the business. This resulted in a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined a private individual with EUR 2,000. The individual had previously published audiovisual material of a court trial to Twitter. However, he did not obtain the consent of the witnesses and other parties involved in the trial that could be seen in the audiovisual material.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined PINTODIS, S.L. with EUR 10,000. The data controller had previously installed several video cameras that covered food areas and changing rooms where employees changed. The Spanish DPA claimed that the data controller violated the principle of data minimization because this much surveillance was unnecessary.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined RECLAMADOR, S.L. with EUR 1,600. Apparently, a data subject filed a complaint against the data controller, claiming that the latter continuously sent him SMS advertisements even though he’d previously requested the deletion of his data. The data controller even confirmed the data deletion. The fine is composed of EUR 1,000 for a breach of Art. 17 GDPR, and EUR 1,000 for a breach of Art. 21 LSSI. The original fine of EUR 2,000 was reduced to EUR 1,800 because of voluntary and immediate payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 10 GDPR, Art. 10 LOPDGDD
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Amazon Road Transport Spain S.L. with EUR 2,000,000. The AEPD had previously received a complaint from a certain trade union against the Amazon Road Transport Spain company. The company quired certificates that confirmed the absence of criminal records when it hired drivers. Amazon Road though that these certifications weren’t under the umbrella of Art. 10 GDPR. However, that wasn’t the case. The AEPD concluded that this data does fall under Art. 10 GDPR. During the investigation, the AEPD concluded that the processing of this data wasn’t compliant with the requirements of Art. 10 GDPR. Therefore, the DPA came to the conclusion that Amazon Road had processed the data regarding the absence of criminal record without a valid legal basis.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 6,000. The data subject had previously filed a complaint against the data controller because the latter published images of her in a bikini on a website without obtaining her consent. The data subject had initially posted images of herself in a bikini to a second-hand platform named Vinted, with the purpose of selling the bikini.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 2,500. The data controller has installed video surveillance cameras at his house. These cameras also covered the public space and neighboring properties outside. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. Additionally, the information signs that he had posted about the cameras were blurred and couldn’t be read well enough. The DPA claimed that this was a breach of the duty to inform as per Art. 13 GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined RESTAURANTE FUENTEBRO, S.C. with EUR 1,500 because it failed to provide information signs about the CCTV surveillance in the establishment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a store owner with EUR 1,000 because it failed to provide information signs about the CCTV surveillance in the establishment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined MALAGATROM S.L.U. with EUR 1,000 because the company failed to comply with an order issued by the DPA.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a hotel operator with EUR 3,000. The data controller had previously installed video surveillance cameras that, among other things, covered the public space and parts of the hotels pool area. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. Moreover, the data controller also didn’t comply with its duty to properly inform data subjects about the CCTV system.

allItems.name: Belgium
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR, Art. 18 GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 28 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Belgian DPA has fined a company with EUR 7,500. The former managing director of the company filed a complaint against the company, claiming that, when he was dismissed, he deleted all the private data on the work laptop before he handed over the equipment. However, the company claims that he not only deleted private data but also work-relate data from the laptop. The company had to restore the delete work data from the laptop. As such, the data subject exercised their right to delete and restrict the processing of their personal data. However, the company didn’t agree to this request. During the investigation, the DPA concluded that the company had breached its obligation to grant the former managing director a way to exercise these rights. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the company had unlawfully processed the data due to not having a valid legal basis at the time of the data restoration.

allItems.name: Belgium
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) e) GDPR, Art. 9 (2) g) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 13 (2) e) GDPR, Art. 35 (1), (3), (7) b) GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Belgian DPA has fined the Brussels Airport Zaventem with EUR 200,000. An investigation was launched against the airport after several media reports about temperature monitoring of persons in the airport surfaced. Because of the Covid-19 pandemic, the airport used these thermal imaging cameras to filter out individuals who had body temperatures above 38 degrees. The people who were filtered had to answer several questions about potential coronavirus symptoms. The DPA noticed that the airport did not have a legal basis to process this health data. Essentially, health data is sensitive data as per Art. 9 GDPR, and it can only be processed in exceptional cases as per Art. 9 (2) GDPR. For instance, an exceptional case would be to process the data in the public interest. But if this is the case, the data processing should proceed on a clear legal norm. As for the airport case, the data processing was based solely on a protocol that didn’t meet the necessary requirements. Additionally, the DPA discovered deficiencies in the data protection impact assessment. Moreover, the airport also did not properly inform the data subjects about the data processing.

allItems.name: Belgium
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 6 (3) GDPR, Art. 9 (2) i) GDPR, Art. 12 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 13 (2) e) GDPR, Art. 35 (1), (7) GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Belgian DPA has fined the Brussels Airport Charleroi with EUR 100,000. An investigation was launched against the airport after several media reports about temperature monitoring of persons in the airport surfaced. Because of the Covid-19 pandemic, the airport used these thermal imaging cameras to filter out individuals who had body temperatures above 38 degrees. The people who were filtered had to answer several questions about potential coronavirus symptoms. The DPA noticed that the airport did not have a legal basis to process this health data. Essentially, health data is sensitive data as per Art. 9 GDPR, and it can only be processed in exceptional cases as per Art. 9 (2) GDPR. For instance, an exceptional case would be to process the data in the public interest. But if this is the case, the data processing should proceed on a clear legal norm. As for the airport case, the data processing was based solely on a protocol that didn’t meet the necessary requirements. Additionally, the DPA discovered deficiencies in the data protection impact assessment. Moreover, the airport also did not properly inform the data subjects about the data processing.

allItems.name: Belgium
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Belgian DPA has fined Ambuce Rescue Team with EUR 20,000. This fine is closely related to the fines issued for the Brussels Airports Zaventem and Charleroi for using thermal imaging cameras to filter out people who may have coronavirus symptoms. In the context of the Covid-19 pandemic, the two airports used thermal imaging cameras to filter out people with body temperatures above 38 degrees. Then, they were provided a questionnaire to complete. This questionnaire was made by Ambuce Rescue Team. The DPA discovered that the processing of this medical data was done illegally since there was no valid legal basis for it. Health data as sensitive as this can only be processed in exceptional cases as per Art. 9 (2) GDPR. For instance, an exceptional case would be to process the data in the public interest. But if this is the case, the data processing should proceed on a clear legal norm. In this case, the data processing was based solely on a protocol that didn’t meet the necessary requirements.

allItems.name: Croatia
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Croatian DPA has fined this energy company who own petrol stations and sells fuel to its customers. One data subject who is a customer of the energy company has filed a consumer complaint regarding the inaccurate measuring and charging of fueled petrol at one of the petrol stations owned by the energy company. The data subject also requested a copy of the personal data of the company, including a copy of the video surveillance footage narrowed to a specific time and area. However, the energy company denied this request, justifying by: (i) a lack of a written request by the competent authorities to deliver this footage, (ii) the lack of a justified purpose for the request, and (iii) the claim that offering a copy of this footage would negatively affect the rights and freedoms of the petrol station’s customers and personnel. After the DPA issued its general opinion and claimed that the energy company is under legal obligation to provide the surveillance footage to the data subject, the energy company informed the customer that this wasn’t possible. The energy company claimed that the video surveillance footage archives are being erased after seven days. The DPA concluded that the energy company had violated the fundamental rights of the data subject and issued a fine of HRK 940,000,000. The DPA also took note of the indirect damage incurred by the customer and also the potential financial gains of the company due to indirectly avoiding a customer dispute. Moreover, the DPA also considered that, by deleting the video footage, the company has eliminated importance evidence.

allItems.name: Croatia
allItems.articleViolated: Art 32 (1) b) and d) GDPR, Art 32 (2) GDPR, Art 32 (4) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: A retail company has reported a breach of personal data to the DPA. The company claimed that its employees have recorded video surveillance footage with mobile phones. This was unauthorized and against the company’s instructions and internal acts. This recording was made public by leaking it to social media and various media outlets. The DPA concluded that the data controller failed to take the adequate actions to prevent employees from recording the company footage. The company did undertake specific measures like adopting internal acts regarding the access to video surveillance footage, and also educated the employees by implementing confidentiality statements. However, the DPA noted that the retail company did not ensure the appropriate technical and organizational security measures that would minimize the risk of such data breaches. Additionally, the data controller didn’t regularly inspect the efficiency of the organizational and technical measures that were implement to maintain the integrity, confidentiality, and accessibility of the personal data. The DPA fined the retail company with HRK 675,000,000 for failing to take the appropriate organizational and technical measures. It also clarified that this fine should have preventive effects and raise the awareness for all data controllers and processors on the obligations regarding correct data processing.

allItems.name: Cyprus
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Cypriot DPA has fined the English School Staff Union (ESSA) with EUR 5,000. The school notified the DPA about a data breach as per Art. 33 GDPR. A teacher, who was also a member of the staff union, had used the email addresses of the students’ parents for another purpose than the one originally intended with the data collection process. The DPA noted that the staff union failed to take the appropriate organizational and technical measures that would ensure the protection of person data and preventing such incidents from happening.

allItems.name: Cyprus
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Cypriot DPA has fined the English School Cyprus with EUR 4,000. The school notified the DPA about a data breach as per Art. 33 GDPR. A teacher used the email addresses of the students’ parents for another purpose than the one originally intended with the data collection process. The DPA noted that the school failed to take the appropriate organizational and technical measures that would ensure the protection of person data and preventing such incidents from happening.

allItems.name: Denmark
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Danish DPA has fined the Danish National Genome Center with EUR 6,700. The center had previously conducted a data protection impact assessment that revealed certain circumstances which, if exposed, could pose a high risk to the rights of the data subjects. The DPA fined the Genome Center because it had unlawfully processed the personal data of the data subjects without consulting the DPA, despite the fact that the impact assessment had a high risk to the data subjects. The Danish National Genome Center did comply with all the DPA’s requests and has been very cooperative throughout the investigation.

allItems.name: Denmark
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Danish DPA has fined Danske Bank with EUR 1.3 million. The DPA has opened an investigation against the bank after it was informed that the bank had an issue with the personal data deletion. During the investigation the DPA discovered that the bank did not document the rules for the storage and deletion of personal data in more than 400 systems. As a result, the bank could not prove that these regulations even existed in the first place. The DPA concluded that this was a breach of the bank’s accountability obligation as per Art. 5 (2) GDPR.

allItems.name: Finland
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 12 (1), (2), (3), (4) GDPR, Art. 13 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 15 (1), (3) GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Finnish DPA has fiend a medical clinic with EUR 5,000. One of the customers of the clinic had previously complained to the DPA that he hadn’t received access to his medical records from the clinic even after he requested this information. Additionally, the clinic didn’t adequately inform its clients about the data processing. More specifically, the DPA noted that the clinic didn’t inform its clients about the extent of the data processing activities.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The DPA of Bremen has fined the housing association BREBAU GmbH with EUR 1.9 million. BREBAU GmbH has processed about 9,500+ datasets related to potential tenants without a valid legal basis. More specifically, the DPA discovered that the data controller had also processed very sensitive data as per Art. 9 GDPR. For instance, the data controller unlawfully processed information regarding the ethnic origin, skin color, sexual orientation, religious affiliation, and health status of the data subjects. BREBAU GmbH has also deliberately ignored several requests from data subjects for transparency regarding the processing of their personal data. When issuing the fine, the DPA also took into consideration, as an aggravating factor, the depth of the violation of fundamental rights to data protection. However, the company also cooperated fully during the investigation which led to some of the damage being mitigated. The company also clarified the facts on its own and made sure that such violations wouldn’t be repeated in the future.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined an employer with EUR 2,000. An employee had previously filed a complaint against the employer due to the latter’s failure to comply with the data subject’s right to object. The data subject had objected to various monitoring activities of his online courses via Zoom. However, the employer continued to monitor the data subject. Moreover, the DPA also discovered that the employer didn’t provide a valid legal basis for processing this data.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fiend an employer with EUR 2,000. One of the school’s employee who worked there as a language teacher, has filed a complaint to the DPA against the school. Apparently, the data controller kept monitoring the employee during the Zoom online courses despite them objecting to this. The DPA noted that the data controller had violated its duty to comply with the data subjects right to object. Moreover, the DPA also discovered that the data controller didn’t properly inform the data subject about the processing of his personal data, as per Art. 13 GDPR.

allItems.name: Iceland
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Iceland DPA has fined Hörpu tónlistar- og ráðstefnuhúss ohf. With EUR 7,000. The DPA had received a complaint about the concert hall’s collection of ID numbers and date of birth information regarding an electronic ticket purchase. This incident took place before the start of the Covid-19 pandemic, and the registration of personal data for contact tracking wasn’t yet required at that time. The DPA concluded that the data controller had no real reason to collect this data for issuing a ticket. The purchase could have been completed with this data being collected. For this reason, the DPA noted that the concert hall had violated the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Ireland
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Irish DPA (also known as DPC) has fined Meta Platforms Ireland Limited with EUR 17 million. This decision is based on 12 notifications of data breaches that took place between June 7, 2018, and December 4, 2018. The DPC’s investigations ended with Meta being charged with a violation of Art. 5 (2) GDPR and Art. 24 (1) GDPR. During the investigation, the DPC found out that Meta could not prove that it had taken the necessary organizational and technical measures that would protect the data of EUR users. The fine proceedings were carried out with cross-border data processing, and that’s why a decision was only met through the co-decision procedure under Art. 60 GDPR, involving all the European advisory authorities. Although two other European DPAs objected to the draft decision of the DPC, a consensus was reached in the end. As it stands, the DPC’s decision to fine Meta with EUR 17,000,000 is the collective decision of all the other European DPAs.

allItems.name: Ireland
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 33 GDPR, Art. 34 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Irish DPA has fined the Bank of Ireland with EUR 463,000. The Bank has reported a total of 22 data breaches to the DPA, as per Art. 33 GDPR. During the investigation, then DPA discovered that the bank had provided false information to the Central Credit Register because of a mix-up of bank customers’ account data. This error could have impacted the creditworthiness of many data subjects. The DPA also found that the personal data breach had taken place due to the lack of appropriate organizational and technical measures from the bank. Additionally, the bank didn’t immediately inform the data subjects and the DPA about the data breach.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The company has left the email account of the data subject active even after the termination of the subject’s employment and also failed to provide information about this.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b), e) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 27 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the US-based Clearview Al with EUR 20 million after it was found that the company had been using biometric surveillance on Italian territory. The company owns a database of over 10 billion facial images from all over the world. In the context of the fine, the company offers a search service that allows profiles to be created based on the biometric data from the images. These profiles can be further improved using information such as geolocation or image tags. The DPA investigated this company after it was revealed that it also enables the search of Italian national and residents, despite having denied this initially. The DPA discovered that the personal data held in the company’s databases were processed unlawfully and without a valid legal basis. Additionally, the DPA also discovered that the company had violated several GDPR principles. For instance, the company had clearly violated the principle of transparency when it failed to properly inform users about the data processing. Clearview had also violated the principle of purpose limitation when it processed the users’ data for purposes other than the ones it had revealed online. Finally, the company also violated the principle of storage limitation because it did not specify a time period for the data storage.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.controller: Azienda socio sanitaria territoriale Melegnano e della Martesana
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Azienda socio sanitaria territorial Melegnano e della Martesana with EUR 3,500. The DPA started investigating the data controller after receiving a report about a data breach. A patient had received by mistake the medical records and clinical documentation of another patient, apparently.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Region of Tuscany with EUR 10,000. The region had previously notified the DPA about a data breach as per Art. 33 GDPR. The region further stated that it had published the personal data of 3,548 applications for administrative assistant positions by mistake. The data information that the region had shared was part of a pre-selection test for the application. The region had mistakenly published a URL that people could access to see the results of these tests.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Scanshare S.r.l. with EUR 10,000. This fine is related to another fine imposed on the Region of Tuscany. The region claimed that it had published the personal data of 3,548 applications for administrative assistant positions by mistake. The data information that the region had shared was part of a pre-selection test for the application. Apparently, Scanshare was entrusted with organizing these pre-selection tests. Because of an error on the part of Scanshare, a URL was published by mistake through which the personal data and tests results of all data subjects could be accessed.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The community published on its website information about a court case. This information included the name and professional information of the data subject.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR, Art. 157 Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Arte del vivere S.r.l. with EUR 5,000. A data subject had previously filed a complaint against the data controller because his personal data had been published on the website www.mondoshiatsu.com operated by the data controller. The data subject was also included in the Shiatsu Portal after he had participated in a one-year Shiatsu training. However, the data subject requested the deletion of his persona data since he had never worked in this field. However, the data controller did not fulfill their obligation despite saying that they would delete the data subject’s personal data.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 12 (3) GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Studio Colli Aniene Verderocca S.r.l. with EUR 1,500. A data subject had filed a complaint against the data controller for sending unsolicited telephone advertising to him. Additionally, the data subject stated that he didn’t receive any response to his request for information and deletion of his personal data.

allItems.name: Poland
allItems.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItems.type: Insufficient fulfilment of data breach notification obligations
allItems.summary: The Polish DPA has fined Santander Bank Polska with EUR 118,000 because it did not notify the data subjects about a data breach. One of the former employees of the bank managed to gain unauthorized access to one of the databases used for electronic services. This led to numerous Santander customer’s data becoming accessible to the former employee. Because of the high risk for this data, the bank was obliged to inform the data subjects about the data breach. However, the bank did not do this and instead continued to state that it wouldn’t comply with this obligation in the future. The DPA took note of this and concluded that it was a major intrusion for the data subjects because they couldn’t take the necessary steps to protect their rights.

allItems.name: Poland
allItems.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItems.controller: Fortum Marketing and Sales Polska S.A.
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art 24 (1) GDPR, Art. 25 (1) GDPR, Art. 28 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 (1), (2) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Polish DPA has fined Fortum Marketing and Sales Polska S.A. with EUR 1,000,000. The company had previously reported a data breach to the DPA in accordance with Art. 33 GDPR. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that unauthorized individuals had managed to access and steal customer data. This data breach had taken place during the introduction of a modification in the IT system of the company. This modification was introduced by a processing agent who created another customer database as part of the IT modification. However, the database was stored on a sever that was insufficiently protected, and that’s why unauthorized individuals managed to gain access to it. The DPA also discovered that the data processor did not pseudonymize and encrypt the data. Additionally, the processing agent was using real customer data instead of test data to test the IT modification to the system. As such, the DPA concluded that the data controller did not take the appropriate organizational and technical measures that would ensure the protection of the personal data. Moreover, the DPA found that the data controller should have monitored the work of the data processor to make sure that the personal data of the data subjects is constantly protected.

allItems.name: Poland
allItems.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 28 (3) c), f) GDPR, Art. 32 (1), (2) GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Polish DPA has fined PIKA Sp. z o.o. with EUR 53,000. The fine relates to the fines issued to Fortum Marketing and Sales Polska S.A. Pika was the data processor for Fortum. . During the investigation, the DPA discovered that unauthorized individuals had managed to access and steal customer data. This data breach had taken place during the introduction of a modification in the IT system of the company. This modification was introduced by a processing agent who created another customer database as part of the IT modification. However, the database was stored on a sever that was insufficiently protected, and that’s why unauthorized individuals managed to gain access to it. The DPA also discovered that the data processor did not pseudonymize and encrypt the data. Additionally, the processing agent was using real customer data instead of test data to test the IT modification to the system. As such, the DPA noted that PIKA did not take the appropriate organizational and technical measures to ensure the protection of the personal data.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA (also known as ANSPDCP) has fined Operatorul Briza Land S.R.L. with EUR 2,000 because the data controller did not respond properly to a request for information.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Kaufland Romania SCS with EUR 2,000. A data subject had complained to the DPA that the data controller has failed to comply with their request to provide copies of video surveillance recordings where the data subject could be seen. During the investigation, the DPA concluded that the data controller had violated its duty to offer information, especially since the information requested (video surveillance recordings) was available.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Condor SA with EUR 2,000. The data controller had suffered a data breach where unauthorized individuals managed to access a couple of documents that contained the personal data of employees and former employees (first name, surname, position, salary, bank details, place of work). During the investigation, the DPA noted that the data controller did not take the appropriate organizational and technical measures to ensure the proper protection of the personal data.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA (also known as ANSPDCP) has fined a property owner’s association with EUR 500 because it failed to provide the information requested by the DPA during an investigation.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.controller: FRUTAS Y VERDURAS LOS CAMPEONES, S.L.
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined FRUTAS Y VERDURAS LOS CAMPEONES, S.L with EUR 1,200. The data controller had installed a video surveillance system but it did not place any signs informing about the presence and use of this system.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined WORLDWIDE CLASSIC CARS NETWORK, S.L. with EUR 1,500. The data controller several video surveillance cameras that covered the public space, among others. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. Moreover, the data controller failed to comply with its duty to inform about the CCTV system.

allItems.name: Sweden
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 12 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 (2) f) GDPR, Art. 14 (2) g) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Swedish DPA has fined Klarna Bank AB with EUR 720,000. Klarna is a bank, a financial company that processes large numbers of personal data for various reasons. During the investigation, the DPA found that Klarna did not comply with its information obligations. In one case, the data controller did not provide enough information on its website about the purpose and the legal basis for the processing of personal data. Moreover, regarding the transfer of data to various Swedish and international credit agencies, Klarna provided incomplete information regarding the recipients of the personal data. The data controller also did not provide information about third countries where the personal data was going to. In the end, the DPA concluded that Klarna did not sufficiently inform its data subjects about their rights as per the GDPR regulations.

allItems.name: Netherlands
allItems.authority: Dutch Supervisory Authority for Data Protection (AP)
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Dutch DPA has fined DPG Media Magazines B.V. with EUR 525,000. The DPA had previously received many complaints about the manner in which the data controller was handling requests from customers. Clients who wanted to know what type of personal data the data controller stores or to have their data deleted, had to upload and send proof of their identity first. The DPA concluded that it was not necessary to send proof of one’s identity to process these requests. Additionally, the mailing process made it extremely difficult for data subjects to exercise their rights.

allItems.name: Netherlands
allItems.authority: Dutch Supervisory Authority for Data Protection (AP)
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Dutch DPA has fined the Dutch Foreign Ministry with EUR 565,000. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the National Visa Information System (NVIS) had major security deficiencies. This is a serious matter seeing as though the Foreign Ministry processed around 530,000 visa applications per year over the last 3 years. The personal data processed during those applications was, as it seems, insufficiently protected. This data included sensitive information like name, address, fingerprints, place of residence, country of birth, nationality, and purpose of travel. Because of these inadequate security measures, unauthorized individuals could have accessed the data at any time. The DPA noted that the Foreign Ministry had been aware of this security weakness for quite some time. However, they didn’t do anything to adjust the security system. This is why DPA concludes that the ministry was negligent. It was also found that the Foreign Ministry didn’t adequately inform individuals who applied for visas that their personal data would be shared with third parties. This resulted in a fine of EUR 565,000 being issued to the Dutch Foreign Ministry.

allItems.name: Belgium
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 12 (2) GDPR, Art. 21 (2), (3), (4) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Belgian DPA has fined the Belgian National Railroad Company (Nationale Maatschappj der Belgische Spoorwegen) with EUR 10,000. The Belgian DPA has received a complaint from a Twitter user who had received an email newsletter from the railroad company. Apparently, this newsletter didn’t have an option to unsubscribe. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the railroad company had no valid legal basis to process the personal data of the Twitter user through the newsletter. The railroad company claimed that the newsletter was essential for the performance of the contracts established between the company and the passengers, but the DPA disagreed. This performance interest wasn’t a valid legal basis to process the personal data of the Twitter user. Moreover, the DPA found that that the data subject’s right to object wasn’t sufficiently considered since there was no option to unsubscribe from the newsletter through the email received.

allItems.name: Denmark
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Danish DPA has fined the Danish Agency Civilstyrelsen with EUR 13,400. The DPA discovered that a USB containing more than 800 pages of sensitive and confidential information belonging to the Civilstyrelsen company was lost. During the investigation, the DPA found out that this USB stick was not encrypted. Moreover, the agency didn’t have policies in place that instructed its employees on how to use removable and portable media. The DPA also discovered that the agency did not report the data breach even though it was aware of it. This is a breach of Art. 33 GDPR. The DPA concluded that the agency did not take the necessary organizational and technical measures to ensure the proper protection of the personal data. For instance, the USB stick should have been encrypted since it contained such sensitive information and personal data.

allItems.name: France
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 28 GDPR, Art. 29 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The French DPA (also known as CNIL) has fined DEDALUS BIOLOGIE with EUR 1.5 million. The company is a distributor of software solutions for medical analysis laboratories. Back in February 2022, the press revealed a massive data leak involving DEDALUS, and which resulted in the leak of personal data belonging to more than 500,000 individuals. This data included information about the first names, surnames, data on medical examinations and illnesses, social security numbers, and the names of the physicians. During the investigation the CNIL discovered that DEDALUS BIOLOGIE had violated several GDPR regulations. For instance, DEDALUS had violated Art. 29 GDPR by processing more data than was necessary during the processing of two laboratories’ patient data. Moreover, the DPA also discovered that DEDALUS did not implement the necessary organizational and technical measures that would ensure the proper protection of the personal data. This is a clear violation of Art. 32 GDPR by itself. The company did not implement any specific security procedures during the data migration operations. Moreover, the data that was leaked was not stored on an encrypted server either. The DPA also discovered that DEDALUS had not implement authentication for access in the public area of the server. This is the main reason why the data leak took place, in fact. Furthermore, the DPA discovered that none of the contracts established between DEDALUS and its clients complied with the requirements set by the GDPR in Art. 28. The DPA took into consideration the aggravating factors and the seriousness of the violations, as well as the large number of data subjects who had been affected, when imposing the fine.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 33 GDPR, Art. 34 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined Piraeus Bank with EUR 10,000. Apparently, the bank had sent by mistake a document containing the personal data of the data subject to a third party. This error took place because a co-owner of the account entered a wrong email address. Even though the bank was aware of this error, they didn’t stop communicating with the third party. Instead, they told the data subject that they can request a correction of the inaccurate data that was sent to the third party. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the bank had violated the principle of confidentiality because it did not take any actions to stop the communications with the third party. The DPA also noticed that the bank did not report the data breach to the DPA and the data subject in a timely manner.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined a mayor with EUR 5,000. Apparently, the mayor had sent documents of an employee to the municipality without the data subject’s consent. The DPA stated that this was a violation of Art. 5 (1) 1) GDPR.

allItems.name: Hungary
allItems.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 12 (2) GDPR, Art. 17 (1) b) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Hungarian DPA has fined a company with EUR 13,500. An individual had complained to the DPA that the company had published their personal data, including their name, telephone number, and address without obtaining their consent first. Moreover, the company did not respond to the deletion request that the data subject filed.

allItems.name: Iceland
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Icelandic DPA has fined the City of Reykjavik with EUR 36,000. The city had been using the digital education system “Seesaw” in different schools. This system processed, among other things, the personal data of minor students, including the teacher feedback and information about the private affairs of the students. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the City of Reykjavik had not sufficiently defined the purpose for the processing of the children’s data. As such, the DPA stated that this was a breach of the principle of data minimization and data proportionality. Additionally, the DPA concluded that the city did not implement the required organizational and technical measures that would have protected the personal data of the children adequately. This was necessary, especially given the high risk that the data could have been processed and transferred in the United States. When assessing the fine, the DPA took into consideration that no damage had been caused by the data breaches.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), f) GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Azienda USL Toscana Centro with EUR 10,000. The DPA started an investigation against the data controller after it received a report of a data breach as per Art. 33 GDPR. The data controller had send patient medical records to the wrong patients by mistake. The DPA concluded that the Azienda USL Toscana Centro did not take the necessary organizational and technical measures to properly protect the personal data of the patients.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 37 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Azienda sanitaria provincial di Caltanissetta with EUR 6,000. In the context of legal proceedings, a data subject had asked the data controller to send all communications related to this matter only to the data subject’s personal email inbox. However, the data controller sent this communication to the data subject’s business email address. Moreover, the data subject had also requested access to their data. The data controller did not comply with this request either. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the health care facility did not report this to the DPA. Moreover, it also did not communicate the name and contact details of the new data protection officer, and did not update this information on its website either.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.controller: Agenzia Regionale per la Tutella dell’Ambiente dell’Abruzzo
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 10 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy, Art. 2-octies Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Agenzia Regionale per la Tutella dell’Ambiente dell’Abruzzo with EUR 8,000. One of the former employees of the environmental agency had complained to the data about the fact that the agency had published documents containing his personal data on its official website. These documents could be accessed freely by anyone and contained, among other things, information about the data subject’s criminal information and previous employment.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Brav s.r.l. with EUR 10,000. An operator of the online platform Brav s.r.l. reported a data breach to the DPA as per Art. 33 GDPR. Apparently, unauthorized third parties had gained access to the platform that the Genoa Police used to manage traffic violations, also coming into the possession of the personal data contained within these documents. According to the City of Genoa, several employees of Brav s.r.l. had disclosed the access passwords to the platform, violating official regulations, and this led to the data breach. As such, the DPA discovered that the data controller did not take the necessary organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data. The data controller should changed the passwords regularly in order to prevent such unauthorized access exploits by third parties.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), f) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 30 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Azienda ospedaliera di Perugia with EUR 40,000. During the investigation on the healthcare facility, the DPA discovered multiple violations of the GDPR. This investigation took place in the context of several inspections that dealt with the processing of data and several whistleblower systems at the employers. Azienda ospedaliera di Perugia the healthcare facility had been using an open-sourced whistleblowing web application when the data breach took place. The app was accessed through several systems that hadn’t been properly configured. As such, the users’ browsing data could be recorded and stored, which led to the identification of these users, who could have been whistleblowers. Regarding the processing of the personal data, the healthcare facility did not inform its employees prior to it. Additionally, the DPA discovered that the healthcare facility did not conduct a data protection impact assessment and also did not register the data processing in the register of processing activities. So, the company did not carry out the required risk assessments regarding the rights and freedoms of the data subjects.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined ISWEB S.p.A. with EUR 40,000. This fine was issued in regard to another fine against the healthcare facility Azienda ospedaliera di Perugia. ISWEB was the company that provided the whistleblower application for the healthcare system. During the investigation at the healthcare facility, the DPA discovered multiple GDPR violations regarding the whistleblower system. This investigation took place as part of a series of several inspections aimed at the whistleblower system data processing on the employers’ systems. Regarding ISWEB, the DPA discovered that they had been using an external provider to host the whistleblower systems. Moreover, ISWEB did not provide the external provider nor the healthcare facility with specific instructions about the processing of the data subject’s data.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined ASST di Lodi with EUR 1,000. The healthcare facility had previously reported a data breach as per Art. 33 GDPR. A patient had offered two contacts that the healthcare facility could contact regarding the data subject’s medical affairs. In the case of an emergency, the facility could obtain medical information about the patient from these two persons. During an important diagnostic examination of the data subjects, a healthcare facility employee tried contacting the two authorized contacts but could not reach them. Instead, they contacted a family member that they personally knew for this information. During the investigation the DPA discovered that the healthcare facility had processed the data subject’s information without the data subject’s consent. Therefore, this action had no valid legal basis. Additionally, the DPA concluded that the healthcare facility did not take the appropriate organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data of the data subject.

allItems.name: Luxembourg
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The DPA from Luxembourg has fined a café operator with EUR 1,000. The operator had previously installed two video surveillance cameras in the café to protect the company assets and the safety of employees and customers. However, these cameras also captured parts of the employee’s work areas. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization, and the data controller also did not comply with its information obligations as per Art. 13 GDPR.

allItems.name: Norway
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Norwegian DPA has fined Lillestrøm Municipality with EUR 30,000. The municipality had previously published (by accident) a document containing a total of 21 attachments. 10 of these attachments contained personal data of the students, such as names, test results, dates of birth, and assessments of the students’ challenges and behaviors. The error hadn’t been detected by the responsible administrator and went through several manual quality checks at the documentation center. The error wasn’t detected there either. A journalist noticed the data breach and brought it to the municipality’s attention. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the municipality had not taken the necessary organizational and technical measures to protect the personal data of the data subjects. Moreover, the DPA also considers it a clear lack of security rigorousness that the incident wasn’t discovered by the municipality.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined IKEA România S.R.L. with EUR 1,000. A data subjects had filed a complaint to the DPA, stating that IKEA did not comply in a timely manner with their request to delete their personal data from the company’s user account. The DPA concluded that IKEA Romania had violated Art. 12 (3) GDPR.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The company failed to provide the necessary information to the Romanian DPA in a timely manner, breaching Art. 58 GDPR.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Concordia Capital IFN S.A. with EUR 4,000. The data controller had unlawfully installed several video and audio cameras in its employees’ offices. This video surveillance system was meant to protect the goods and the employees of the company. However, the DPA discovered that the data controller had violated Articles 5 and 6 GDPR because such extensive surveillance was uncalled for and unnecessary.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined the gas station operator LORIS FUEL SOP SRL with EUR 1,000. A person had previously filed a complaint to the DPA because pictures of him had been published on Facebook by the gas station. These images were taken by the video surveillance system installed in the controller’s gas stations. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller had not taken the required organizational and technical measures that would ensure the confidentiality and anonymity of the personal data generated by the CCTV system installed in the gas stations. This led to third partiers accessing these images, filming them, and then posting them online on social networks.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined BASER COMERCIALIZADORA DE REFERENCIA, S.A. with EUR 150,000. A customer of this company had previously filed a complaint to the DPA because their electricity supply contract had been modified without their consent. This had resulted in an increase in the electricity supply. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that a fraudster had been pretending to be the data subject. They provided the data subject’s name and ID number, which led them to be able to modify the contract of the data subject. The DPA stated that the data controller had not properly verified the identity of the fraudster before modifying the contract. This lack of security measures led to the fraudster being mistaken for the data subject, which led to the data breach.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined a homeowners association with EUR 500. The executive board of the association had publicly posted a list of defaulting owners. The DPA considers that this is a violation of the principle of integrity and confidentiality, as set out by Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined RAMONA FILMS, S.L. with EUR 8,000 because the data controller did not ensure that their privacy policy complied with the requirements of Art. 13 GDPR. More specifically, the website contained outdated information and was referring to laws that weren’t in effect anymore. Moreover, the DPA discovered deficiencies in the cookie use of the company’s website. The original fine was reduced from EUR 10,000 to EUR 8,000 because the company paid the fine immediately and acknowledged its guilt.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined FLORAQUEEN FLOWERING THE WORLD S.L. with EUR 1,800 because it failed to provide the information requested by the DPA during one of its investigations. The original fine of EUR 3,000 was reduced to EUR 1,800 because the company paid the fine immediately and acknowledged its guilt.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 22 (2) LSSI
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined JIMBO NETWORKS, S.L. with EUR 9,000. During the investigation, the DPA discovered several security deficiencies on the data controller’s website. For instance, the data controller was processing data of visitors on the website without obtaining their consent. Additionally, the privacy policy of the website did not comply with the requirements of Art. 13 GDPR. The privacy policy contained outdated information and also referred to laws that were not in effect anymore. Moreover, the DPA also found deficiencies in the cookie use of the website. The original fine of EUR 15,000 was reduced to EUR 9,000 due to immediate acknowledgement of guilt and payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 22 (2) LSSI
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a website operator with EUR 1,800. During the investigation, the DPA discovered multiple security deficiencies on the website of the operator. For instance, the data controller was processing the personal data of visitors on the website without obtaining their explicit consent. Moreover, the website had no privacy policy. As such, the DPA considered that the data controller had violated its duties as expressed by Art. 13 GDPR. Moreover, the DPA also discovered several deficiencies in the use of cookies on the website. The original fine of EUR 3,000 was reduced to EUR 1,800 due to immediate acknowledgment of guilt and payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined DOOR2DOOR SPAIN, S.L. with EUR 600. The data controller had failed to implement in due time the required measures that the DPA ordered several times. Moreover, the data controller also did not provide the DPA with the requested information. The original fine of EUR 1,000 was reduced to EUR 600 due to immediate acknowledgment of guilt and payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a physician because they had used recordings of a patient’s treatment for advertising purposes. The patient did not consent to this either. As such, the DPA has stated that the doctor had processed the personal data of the patient without a valid legal basis. The original fine of EUR 7,000 was reduced to EUR 5,600 because of immediate payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined MOVALIA TRASLADOS, S.L.U. with EUR 1,200.
