During the investigation, the DPA discovered several security deficiencies in the data controller’s website. For instance, the data controller was processing the personal data of visitors to the website without obtaining their explicit consent. Moreover, the data controller also did not have a privacy policy, contrary to its obligation under Art. 13 GDPR. The original fine of EUR 2,000 was reduced to EUR 1,200 because of immediate payment and acknowledgment of guilt.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 1,500. The data controller had previously installed video surveillance cameras which captured the public space, among other things. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. Moreover, the data controller also did not properly inform the data subjects about the processing of their personal data through the surveillance systems, violating its duty to inform. The fine consists of EUR 1,000 for violating Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR and EUR 500 for violating Art. 13 GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) a) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined CAFFE VECCHIO, S.L. with EUR 1,500. One of the former employees of the café had filed a complaint to the DPA, stating that the operator of the café had replied to several negative online reviews, while disclosing the personal data of the former employee. Additionally, the operator had published information regarding the future employment termination of the contractual relationship between the data subject and the café.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined MEDEROS MOVITEN, S.L. with EUR 15,000. A data subject had signed a mobile service contract with the company but the company had invoiced the data subject for services that the data subject did not consent to. These contracts had the data subject’s name on them but no personal signature. Because the contracts were not valid, the DPA concluded that the company had illegally processed the personal data of the data subjects, violating Art. 6 (1) GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined the credit information agency Working Capital Management Espana, S.L. with EUR 40,000. A data subject had complained to the AEPD that the several fraudsters had taken a loan with NBQ Technology S.A.U. in the name of the data subject without there being a valid contractual relationship in place. After the data subject refused to make the payments, NBQ disclosed the data subject’s information to Working Capital Management. The AEPD concluded that Working Capital Management had processed the data subject’s information illegally since the personal data was processed and entered into the company’s information systems without ensuring that the data subject had given their consent to this.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined CLINICA DENTAL SAN FRANCISCO, S.L. with EUR 4,200. A data subject had complained to the DPA that the data controller kept sending him advertisements via WhatsApp after sending several data deletion requests to the data controller. The original fine of EUR 7,000 was reduced to EUR 4,200 because of immediate payment and acknowledgement of guilt.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined LABORATORIOS GONAZALEZ, S.L. with EUR 16,000. The laboratory had apparently sent results of a Covid-19 test that the data subject had taken to them and also their boss (without consent. The original fine of EUR 20,000 was reduced to EUR 16,000 because of immediate payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined MISTORE CANARIAS, S.L. with EUR 5,000. A client who made a purchase from the company had filed a complaint to the DPA, stating that the company had collected her first name, surname, and bank account details during a purchase. During the purchase, she was offered products from three other companies, which she refused. However, it was still clear that the data controller had sent her data to the three companies without obtaining her consent first.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined CONTIMAG INVEST, S.L. with EUR 1,200 because the company failed to provide enough information about the video surveillance systems that it operated in its restaurants.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a store owner with EUR 300. The data controller had previously requested various personal data from its customers for its appointment bookings. The DPA discovered that the data controller had failed to properly inform the data subjects about the processing of their personal data, as per Art. 13 GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a bar owner with EUR 600. The bar was operating a video surveillance system where the observation angle of the cameras captured the public space too. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization and issued a fine of EUR 600 to the bar owner.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a homeowners’ association with EUR 6,000. An apartment owner who had been a resident of the apartment complex for over 15 years filed a complaint to the DPA because he was forced to show his ID before being allowed to use the communal pool. This requested for personal data was based on several measures taken to fight against the Covid-19 pandemic. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the collection of personal data through the ID verification was not necessary given that data subject had lived in the apartment complex for over 15 years. The homeowners association had violated the principle of data minimization as per Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the data subject wasn’t properly informed about the processing of their personal data.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 500. The data controller had previously installed a surveillance cameras on his property that recorded the neighboring properties too. The AEPD has concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined a private individual with EUR 2,000. Apparently, the private individual had shared a video on WhatsApp that showed a violent attack perpetrated against the data subject, without obtaining the latter’s consent first.

allItems.name: Netherlands
allItems.authority: Dutch Supervisory Authority for Data Protection (AP)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b), d), e) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) GDPR, Art. 35 (2) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Dutch DPA has fined the Dutch Tax and Customs Administration with EUR 3,7 million. This marks the largest fine ever issued by the Dutch DPA after an investigation. During the investigation, the DPA discovered several violations of the GDPR but the Dutch Tax and Customs Administration. The data controller had been keeping a list of indications of fraud for several years. This list contained information on more than 270,000 data subjects, including minors. The administration had processed the personal data, which included citizenship, health, and criminal personal data, as part of the list maintenance. The DPA initially discovered that the administration had no valid legal basis to process this personal data. As such, the data gathered had been processed unlawfully. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the information in this list was also incorrect at times, where many individuals had been falsely registered as possible fraudsters. Additionally, the investigation also revealed that the maintenance of this list resulted in the discrimination against several data subjects. The risk of fraud was also determined based on the nationality and appearance of some of the data subjects. For instance, donations to mosques were considered a risk factor for fraud in the administration’s list. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the administration had violated its obligations to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures that would properly protect the collected personal data. As such, the administration had not adequately secured the personal data of the data subjects. The DPA found out that the administration had also violated the principle of storage limitation by keeping this data for longer than was necessary and contrary to the retention period set by the administration itself. The DPA also found out that the processing of this personal data was not necessary for the administration to perform its duties, so the data processing was disproportionate to the claimed purpose. Also, the administration hadn’t clearly defined the posers for the data processing, violating the principle of data limitation as a result. The fine consists of: EUR 1 million for breaching Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR and Art. 6 (1) GDPR; EUR 750,000 for a breach of Art. 5 (1) b) GDPR; EUR 750,000 for a breach of Art. 5 (1) d) GDPR; EUR 250,000 for a breach of Art. 5 (1) e) GDPR; EUR 500,000 for a breach of Art. 32 (1) GDPR EUR 450,000 for a breach of Art. 35 (2) GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined the supermarket chain Mercadona S.A. with EUR 170,000. A data subject had filed a complaint with the DPA, claiming that, at one time, he had suffered an accident in one of the Mercadona supermarkets. At that time, he wanted to claim damaged, so he had asked Mercadona to provide the recordings of the accident from the video surveillance system. However, the supermarket chain Mercadona did not comply with this request. The data subject hired lawyers who demanded these images from Mercadona, but the supermarket chain replied that the images had already been deleted.

allItems.name: Hungary
allItems.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) b), c), GDPR, Art. 6 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 13 (1), (2) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Hungarian DPA has fined a workshop with EUR 1,300. Apparently, the workshop had previously installed a video surveillance system to protect its assets. However, these cameras also captured parts of the employees’ work areas. The DPA discovered that it wasn’t necessary for the CCTV to record the employees in order to protect the assets of the company, so the surveillance was disproportionate to the declared purpose. The DPA also discovered that the workshop had not sufficiently complied the its information obligations as per Art. 13 GDPR. The workshop claimed that its legal basis for using the CCTV system was the consent given by the employees. However, the DPA declared that the workshop could not use this consent as the legal basis for the video surveillance because the voluntary consent in an employer-employee relationship is questionable to begin with. The workshop should have used a legitimate interest to use the video surveillance instead.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 33 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA (also known as ANSPDCP) has fined Kredyt Inkaso Investments RO S.A. with EUR 5,000. A data subject had filed a complained to the DPA against the data controller because the former had disclosed their personal data and the personal data of their minor child to several medical institutions without their content. The data subject also had no relationship to these medical institutions. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller had disclosed sensitive information such as professional status, home address, and data from the data subject’s employment contract. Additionally, the DPA found that the data controller did not notify the DPA about this data breach in a timely manner, as demanded by Art. 33 GDPR.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) b), c) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA (also known as ANSPDCP) has fined MAYR MELNHOF PACKAGING ROMANIA S.R.L. with EUR 1,500. The data controller had installed a video surveillance system on its premises for protecting the company assets and ensuring the safety of its employees. However, during an investigation, the DPA discovered that these cameras also covered the employee cafeteria and smoking area, which means the employees were monitored outside the working areas. The DPA states that these recordings of the employees are not necessary to ensure the purposes of the surveillance system, so the recordings are disproportionate. The DPA concluded this to be a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 1,500. The data controller had previously installed several video surveillance cameras on his property. However, these cameras also covered the public space. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 48 (1) b) LGT, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 23 (4) LOPDGDD
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects’ rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined TIGERS MARKET, S.L. with EUR 8,000 because a data subject kept receiving advertising calls from the data controller even though the data subject had been registered in the Robinson advertising exclusion list.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined RAMONA FILMS, S.L. with EUR 18,000 because data controller had failed to provide the information requested during a DPA investigation. The original fine of EUR 30,000 was reduced to EUR 18,000 because of immediate payment and acknowledgment of guilt.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined INSEKT FOODS, S.L. with EUR 4,000. A data subject had filed a complaint to the DPA against the data controller because the former had published the personal data of the data subject on three WhatsApp groups. This led to a total of 541 members of these WhatsApp groups gaining unauthorized access to key personal data of the data subject, such as first name, surname address.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Google LLC with EUR 10 million. Two data subjects had filed complaints to the DPA that Google had previously disclosed their personal data to several third parties without their consent. During the lengthy investigation, the DPA discovered that Google had sent the personal data of the data subjects to the Lumen Project. Lumen is a project that’s managed and run by the Berkman Klein Center for Internet & Society of the Harvard University. This project began in 2002 for the official purpose of collecting requests related to the removal of content from websites both within and outside of the US. Researchers and other interested parties may then access this data for studies. However, users of the YouTube, Google Drive and other Google-operated platforms could request that the content related to themselves be deleted from these platforms. To this end, Google has provided several complaint and contact forms. However, the data of the people who filed out these forms was automatically transferred to the Lumen Project. The users were not given the chance to object to this data transmission because the process was automatic, and it was a hardwired condition for completing the forms. Consequently, the DPA concluded that Google had no valid legal basis to process the data subjects’ data because of this lack of consent regarding the transfer of data to Lumen. In this context, the DPA also discovered that Google did not sufficiently enable the data subjects to exercise their rights of erasure of their data. When analyzing the fine, the DPA took into consideration several aggravating factors: the data was disclosed and transferred to a third-party country without giving the data subjects a chance to object to the transfer. Moreover, this deprived the data subjects of control over their personal data and its transfer. Additionally, the DPA discovered that this transfer had taken place over a long period of time. Another aggravating factor was that a very large number of individuals were affected by this data transfer, and in some cases, sensitive data had been processed.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Alfa Shipyard s.r.l. with EUR 10,000 because the data controller failed to implement the measures ordered by the DPA in due time.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined SCF ZHU, S.L. with EUR 600 because the data subject did not have enough data processing information regarding a video surveillance on the business premises. The original fine was reduced to EUR 600 from EUR 1,000 because of acknowledgment of debt and immediate payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Vodafone Espana, S.A.U. with EUR 42,000. A data subject had filed a complaint to the AEPD against the data controller. The data subject complained that he received several invoices even though he had no contractual relationship with the data controller. However, even though the data subject had previously objected to receiving messages because there were no existing outstanding invoices and the data controller confirmed this, the messages kept coming. The DPA concluded that the data controller had processed the data subject’s data without a valid legal basis. The original fine of EUR 70,000 had been reduced to EUR 42,000 because of admission of guilt and immediate payment.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined MED LIFE S.A. The company had previously disposed of several documents that contained sensitive patient data by disposing of them in a publicly accessible garbage can. Someone found these documents and filed a complaint to the DPA. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that MED LIFE did not take the adequate organizational and technical measures to protect the personal data and to avoid such incidents.

allItems.name: Norway
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Norwegian DPA has fined a company with EUR 9,700. The DPA had received a complaint from one of the former employees of the company. Apparently, after the termination of the employee’s work contract, both the private and professional emails of the employee’s mailbox were automatically forwarded to an email address administrated by the managing director. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that that the data controller had no valid legal basis to automatically forward the emails. Moreover, the data controller also did not inform the former employee about this processing of his data through the forwarded emails. This is contrary to the data controller’s obligation under Art. 13 GDPR. Consequently, the DPA established that the data controller did not properly comply with a request of objection to the processing that was submitted by the former employee.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined a private individual with EUR 2,000. The individual had taken several photos of a group of minors and police officers without obtaining their consent. Later, he uploaded them to Facebook.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 1,500. The data controller had previously installed several video surveillance cameras in his car which also covered parts of the community garage. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual who operated three websites with EUR 2,000. During the investigation, the DPA found that the three websites lacked a field for giving consent to the processing of the personal data. Additionally, the DPA discovered that the privacy policies on the websites lacked any references to the identity of the data controller and the rights of the data subjects to withdraw their consent from the data processing.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), e) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 12 (3) GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 157 Codice della privacy, Art. 166 (2) Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Palumbo Superyacht Ancona s.r.l. with EUR 5,000. The company had previously blocked an employee’s company email account without obtaining the subject’s consent first. The employee had reported this incident to the company and asked that his email inbox be restored since it contained both business and private emails. However, the company did not comply with his request. During the investigation, the DPA discovered further violations such as the company’s failure to respond to a request of information from the DPA, violating the principle of limiting data retention.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 7 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 130 (3) Codice della privacy, Art. 157 Codice della privacy, Art. 166 (2) Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Made in Italy s.r.l.s. with EUR 20,000. A data subject had previously filed a complaint with the DPA after he kept receiving promotional calls from the data controller, even though he had not consented to them. The data controller did not stop these calls even after the data subject had objected to them. The data subject also requested the information about the origin of the data, as well as the deletion of the data. However, the data controller did not respond to this request. Moreover, the data controller did not sufficiently cooperate with the DPA during the investigation.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Findomestic Banca spa with EUR 10,000. A customer had previously filed a complaint to the DPA regarding a breach of confidentiality regarding a financial institution. The data controller had unauthorizedly sent over several payment reminders to the wife of the data subject regarding a loan that he had taken out in the past. The wife had guaranteed one of the loans taken by the data subject but not the one in question.

allItems.name: United Kingdom
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The UK DPA (also known as ICO) has fined the law firm Tuckers Solicitors LLP with EUR 115,000. The law firm suffered a ransomware attack on its systems which led to a personal data breach. During the investigation, the DPA concluded that the law firm had failed to take the proper organizational and technical measures to protect this personal data. This failure had left its systems vulnerable to malware attacks. The attackers encrypted a total of 972,191 files, out of which 24,712 were related to court proceedings. The attacker also siphoned off 60 files and published them in underground data marketplaces. The files contained both personal and special category data such as witness statements, medical records, the names, addresses of the witnesses and victims, and the alleged crimes of the data subjects.

allItems.name: Finland
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The Finnish DPA has fined a telemarketing company with EUR 8,300 for failing to comply with a DPA order. One of the customers of the company had requested access to the recording of a sales call. The company, however, did not comply with this request. So, the DPA formally ordered the company to provide the customer with access to the recordings. Later on, the customer reported that the telemarketing company did not comply with the DPA’s order and failed to provide the recordings call.

allItems.name: United Kingdom
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), e) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 16 GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 22 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The UK DPA has fined Clearview AI Inc. with EUR 9 million. The company manages a database of more than 20 billion facial images, including those of UK residents and nationals, from all over the world. This data is collected online from platforms that are publicly accessible, such as social networks. The company has a search service that allows individuals to be identified based on the biometric data that is extracted from these images. The profiles of these individuals can be further improved with information associated with these images, like image tags and geolocation. Clearview AI doesn’t offer these services in the UK but it does offer them in other countries, so the personal data of UK residents is still used. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the personal data contained within the company’s databases was processed unlawfully without a valid legal basis. Moreover, when the data subjects wanted to exercise their rights under the GDPR, such as the right governed by Art. 15 GDPR, they had to submit more personal data in the form of a photograph that may be matched with the Clearview database. According to the DPA, this is a significant obstacle and deterrent in the exercise of the rights. Additionally, the DPA discovered that the company had violated several of the GDPR principles. For instance, the company had clearly violated the principle of transparency because it failed to adequately inform users about the data processing of their personal data. Clearview also violated the principle of storage limitation because it did not provide a data retention policy, failing to ensure that the data was held for longer than necessary. Finally, Clearview AI did not conduct a privacy impact assessment despite the obvious high risk to the data subjects’ data.

allItems.name: Belgium
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) e) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 7 (1), (3) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Belgian DPA has fined Roularta Media Group with EUR 50,000. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the cookie managed used on two websites operated by Roularta failed to comply with the GDPR. To use these cookies, the data controller should have obtained prior consent from its users, except in the cases where the cookies are obligatory for the functionality of the website. The DPA discovered that the consent for the processing of the personal data on Roularta’s websites was not valid because not all conditions were met. Consequently, approximately 60 cookies that were not required were placed on the devices of the users without obtaining their consent first. Roularta also failed to sufficiently inform its users about these cookies. Additionally, the boxes for the consent in placing the third-party cookies were checked in advance even though the users hadn’t checked them (consented to them). Moreover, the DPA discovered that the users could not revoke their consent regarding the cookie placement as easily as they had offered it.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The company failed to respond in a timely manner to the data subject’s request to access their data.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), e) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) b), c) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian has fined Educationest s.r.l. with EUR 1,000. The daycare center had previously sent an email to the families of the children under its care, informing them about the pregnancy and maternity leave of one of the educators. The daycare center had sent this email to prevent any rumor spreading about the teacher’s absence being motivated by covid illness, and to protect her. However, the educator did not consent to the disclosure of her pregnancy status. The DPA concluded that the daycare center Educationest had unlawfully processed the educator’s personal data and violated Art. 5 GDPR and Art. 6 GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain

allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined CORON ISLAND SLU with EUR 1,600. A customer had previously filed a complaint with the DPA against the restaurant. The customer had asked for a bill in her name after getting a meal at the restaurant. However, the manager said that he could only issue an invoice if the customer provided her telephone number. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Spain

allItems.summary: The private individual used a CCTV camera that captured the foreign private space of a neighbor and the public space.

allItems.name: Italy

allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), f) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) e) GDPR, Art. 9 (2) g) GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy, Art. 2-sexies Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Istituto Nazionale Assicurazione Infortuni sul Lavoro (Public Accident Insurance for Workers) with EUR 50,000. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that on three occasions, both the accident and the occupational illnesses of various employees could be publicly viewed on an online system of the insurance carrier. This data breach had occurred because of an outdated version of the system. The DPA claimed that the insurance carrier did not sufficiently fulfill its duty to take the appropriate organizational and technical measures to prevent the personal data breaches. The insurance carrier should have clearly ensured that the online systems were updated and secured.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 10 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy, Art. 2-sexies Codice della privacy, Art. 2-octies Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles

During the investigation, the DPA discovered that two emails containing sensitive information about the health status of the data subject and various legal proceedings, had ben forwarded without authorization.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 29 GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b) GDPR, Art. 32 (2), (4) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Kaufland Romania SCS with EUR 2,000. The data controller had reported two data breaches to the DPA as per Art. 33 GDPR. One of the employees who processed a complaint did not follow the internal procedures for handling complaints, and allowed a security guard to view and misuse the complainant’s data. Additionally, the data controller had mistakenly forwarded the personal data in one of the customer order forms to an unauthorized third part. This led to the disclosure of the personal data (first name, last name, telephone number, and email address) of the affected Kaufland customer to unauthorized sources. In this sense, the DPA discovered that the data controller did not take the appropriate technical and organizational measures that would ensure the protection and security of the personal data.

allItems.name: Spain

allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a store owner with EUR 1,000 because it failed to provide information signs about the CCTV surveillance in his establishment.

The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. Additionally, the data controller did not properly inform the data subjects about the processing of the data through the video surveillance system, violating its duty to inform.

During the investigation, the DPA discovered that Wens Experience, while it acted as the processor of the data controller, engaged another processor to process the employee data without obtaining prior authorization from the data controller. This is a violation of Art. 28 (2) GDPR.

This document contained information about the benefits linked to the health status of the teachers who were entitled to receive such benefits. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the school had published this data without having a valid legal basis, and so, this was unlawful.

The seller did not agree to the negotiations about the method of payment, so the officer used a police information system to obtain information about the seller. The police officer then sent several messages to the seller, mentioning the information he had obtained from the police database through his research. The goal was to force the seller to agree to the payment method suggested by the police officer.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: To identify a guest who had not paid his bill, several visitors were contacted by the employees of the restaurant. To this end, the employees used the telephone numbers provided by the guests as part of the Covid contact tracing. However, the guests had provided their data only for the infection control purposes, so the DPA concluded that contacting them for the purpose of identifying another guest is a violation of the principle of purpose limitation (Art. 5 (1) b) GDPR).

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Unknown
allItems.summary: To combat the Covid 19 pandemic, a restaurant had created an open list where visitors had to enter their contact data. One of the restaurant employees obtained the first names last names, and phone numbers of all the woman on the contacts list in order to contact them privately and ask them about their relationship status. The DPA concluded that using the personal data from the contact lists for infection control documentation for other purposes aside from contact tracing was unlawful.

The employee wanted to prove that two of her colleagues had a relationship with each other, and she proceeded to check the registration addresses of both of them.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: A job center employee had previously accessed the data in the social database systems and in the civil register for private research purposes.

allItems.name: Germany

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The DPA from Berlin has imposed a fine on a medical clinic. Apparently, the clinic had installed 21 cameras on its premises for the purpose of protecting against crime and property damage. This led to the monitoring of the employees and patients around the clock. The clinic relied on the consent given by the employees and the information signs as the legal basis for the video surveillance. However, the DPA concluded that the clinic had no right to base the video surveillance on consent because voluntary consent in the employee-employer relationship is questionable. Moreover, the visible notices of the video surveillance did not allow the conclusion that the patients legally expressed their consent to the observation by simply entering the monitored premises. The DPA could also not find any other evidence that justified this extensive video surveillance of the clinic.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Unknown
allItems.summary: The DPA form Berlin has imposed a fine against a beverage retailer. Apparently, the retailer operated a video surveillance system where the observation angle of the cameras extended into the public space.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The DPA from Berlin has imposed a fine on an attorney. The Attorney had been in a legal dispute with a client for several years over a monetary claim. For the last two years, he had published the first and last names, the residential addresses of the client and his family members, and various unredacted parts of the files on his blog. He also invoked the press privilege. However, his was not a journalistic publication. The attorney was clearly concerned with the acceleration of the payment of the monetary amount to which he was allegedly entitled to. The attorney could not refer to the press privilege for the legal basis of the data processing, and the DPA discovered that he had unlawfully processed the data of the data subjects.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Unknown
allItems.summary: The DPA form Berlin has imposed a fine on a clinic. Apparently, the clinic had previously appointed the clinic managed, who was also a shareholder of the clinic, as the data protection officer. Regarding the data protection officer’s tasks and duties, the company must ensure that they do not create a conflict of interest. In this case, however, a conflict of interest had arisen because the clinic manager had to make economic decisions in his executive position. But he also had to monitor the clinic’s compliance with the data protection laws. The DPA concluded that this duality of his roles carried the extensive risk that the patients and employees would be hesitant to ask assistance from the data protection officer, who was also the hospital director, about various questions about the processing of personal data. So, the clinic was fined because it allowed this conflict of interest to exist.

allItems.name: Norway

allItems.summary: The Norwegian DPA (also known as Datatilsynet) has fined Krokatjønnvegen 15 AS with EUR 30,200. The data controller had run credit checks on two of its data subjects without any contractual basis for doing this.

allItems.name: Romania

allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Sephora Cosmetics România SA with EUR 2,000. One of the company’s data subjects had received promotional SMS texts from Sephora even though they’d objected several times to the processing of their personal data for marketing purposes. Sephora had also confirmed the termination of the SMS sending. However, this continued until the data subject complained to the DPA.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined JAÉN SENTIDO Y COMÚN with EUR 2,000. Apparently, the data controller had sent an email to 241 people in an email open distribution list, thus making the email addresses of all recipients visible to one another.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.controller: ESTUDIOS EUROPEOS DE POSTGRADO Y EMPRESA, S.L.
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined ESTUDIOS EUROPEOS Y EMPRESA, S.L. with EUR 3,000. One of the company’s employees had filed a complaint to the DPA. Apparently, she had received access to the company’s email account upon being hired. However, when she accessed the email account given to her, she found out that it was the email account of another employee. So, she was able to access all of the emails received and sent by that employee. During the investigation, the DPA determined that the data controller did not properly configure the email accounts and had thus breached its duty to implement the appropriate organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined LAST LAP, S.L. with EUR 9,600. This company organizes the San Silvestre road running race. During one of the shows, the race participants were required to show their vaccination certificates or offer a PCR or antigen test before participating in the race. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the company did not have any reasonable legal basis for processing this health data. The original fine of EUR 16,000 was reduced to EUR 9,600 due to admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), e) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR, Art. 38 (6) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: Art. 5 (1) a), e) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR, Art. 38 (6) GDPR Description: The Italian DPA has fined the Policoro Municipality with EUR 26,000. The Italian municipality had previously installed a video surveillance system without offering sufficient information about this. Additionally, the DPA discovered that the municipality had not established a data retention period for the video surveillance recordings, keeping them for an unjustified period of time. Moreover, the DPA also found that the municipality had not fulfilled its obligations in naming a data protection officer. The municipality had instead appointed its attorney as the data protection officer, but this is a conflict of interest, the DPA concluded.

allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined CDI Transport Intern și Internațional SRL with EUR 7,000. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the company’s website did not offer any information about the rights of the data subject regarding the GDPR laws, and how they can exercise those rights. Moreover, the company also failed to provide the DPA with the requested information in a timely manner.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a restaurant owner with EUR 600. The data controller had previously installed several video surveillance cameras. These cameras filmed, among other things, the public space. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. Additionally, the data controller also failed to comply with its duty to properly inform the public about the CCTV system.

allItems.name: Denmark
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information
allItems.summary: The Danish DPA has fined the Lolland municipality with EUR 6,700. The municipality had apparently reported a data breach to the DPA in accordance with Art. 33 GDPR. One of the employees of the municipality had their work phone stolen. This phone was used by the employee to access the work email account, which included the names of citizens, social security numbers, and their health data. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that this phone wasn’t protected by a password. This made it possible for anyone to access the information on the phone. The DPA concluded that this incident had clearly occurred due to the municipality’s failure to implement the required organizational and technical measures that would protect the data subjects’ personal data. At the very least, the municipality should have made sure that each employee has secured their phone with a password.

For instance, the completed guest registration forms had been kept in an adjoining room that was accessible to all employees without any special security measures in place.

As such, the DPA concluded that the data controller had violated its information obligations, as per Art. 13 GDPR.

allItems.name: Isle of Man
allItems.authority: Information Commissioner of Isle of Man
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c), f) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 34 GDPR, Art. 58 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The DPA of the Isle of Man has imposed a fine of EUR 202,000 on Manx Care Ltd. Apparently, the company had sent an unsecured attachment via email that contained a patient’s health information to more than 1870 recipients. The DPA issued an enforcement notice against Manx Care as a result. However, the company did not comply with the DPA’s orders. As such, the DPA concluded that the company should be fined. The DPA discovered that the company had not implemented the appropriate organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data. Moreover, the DPA found that the company had also violated the principle of data minimization as per Art. 5 (1) C) GDPR, by sending the patient’s data to individuals who weren’t related to the patient’s care. Finally, the DPA discovered that the company did not inform the data subject about the data breach.

The DPA then discovered that this video surveillance system had various features other than the approved ones, and it had been installing them in a different position than approved. Moreover, the DPA found that the company did not offer sufficient information to the data subjects about this video surveillance.

However, this data was then used to contract various individuals for advertising purposes. This fine was reduced from EUR 6,000 to EUR 3,600 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined JOYPAZAR, S.A. with EUR 1,600. This company had previously installed video surveillance cameras that also covered the public playground, among other things. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Slovakia
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The Slovak DPA has fined a data controller with EUR 500 for failing to cooperate with the DPA.

allItems.name: Slovakia
allItems.type: Unknown
allItems.summary: Unlawful video surveillance in a garden community.

allItems.name: Slovakia
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 28 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Slovak DPA has fined a data controller with EUR 40,000. The data controller had previously violated the principle of accountability (lack of proof that a data protection officer had implemented a data protection impact assessment) and the principle of transparency and fairness. Moreover, the data controller had not concluded a contract with the data processor.

allItems.name: France
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, L. 34-5 CPCE
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information
allItems.summary: The French DPA (also known as CNIL( has fined ACCOR SA with EUR 600,000. Both the CNIL and other European DPAS institutions have received various complaints against ACCOR from several data subjects. During the investigation, the CNIL discovered that the hotel guests who had made a booking directly through the hotel or one of its websites were automatically sent advertising newsletters because the consent box was automatically ticked in advance. Moreover, the CNIL found that many data subjects were unable to opt-out of these promotional emails because of technical errors. The CNIL also discovered that ACCOR had not provided sufficient data to the data subjects about the processing of their personal data regarding the promotional messages, violating Art. 12 GDPR and Art. 13 GDPR. Moreover, ACCOR failed to respond to the data subjects’ requests for access to their personal data in a timely manner, violating Art. 12 and 15 GDPR. The company also failed to comply with the data subjects’ right to object because of technical problems. The CNIL found a violation of Art. 12 and 21 GDPR. There was also a violation of Art. 32 GDPR because ACCOR allowed the use of passwords that were deemed unsecure. When imposing the fine, the CNIL considered it aggravating that the violations had affected several fundamental principles of personal data protection and involved a fundamental infringement of the rights of the data subjects.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.controller: Private Polyclinic and Diagnostic Centre of Pyle Axiou
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined the Private Polyclinic and Diagnostic Centre of Pyle Axiou with EUR 30,000. One of the patients had requested access to their personal data from an imagining examination. Due to a lack of availability of these images, the clinic was unable to grant the request for access. The DPA discovered that the clinic had failed to offer adequate storage facilities for these images, violating Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.controller: DO VALUE GREECE LOANS & CREDITS CLAIM MANAGEMENT S.A.
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 12 (2) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined DO VALUE GREECE LOANS & CREDITS CLAIM MANAGEMENT S.A. with EUR 30,000. A data subject had previously filed a complaint to the DPA for receiving various calls from the company regarding debts that had already been settled. The data subject had objected to the processing of this personal data and then demanded that the calls are stopped immediately, as well as the deletion of their personal data from the company’s database. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the company had unlawfully obstructed the exercising of the data subject’s rights.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined UNONO NET 3.0., S.L. with EUR 900. This company had previously forwarded an email to various recipients without using the blind copy function. This made it possible for all recipients to see the email addresses of all the other recipients. The original fine of EUR 1,500 was reduced to EUR 900 because of admission of guilt and voluntary responsibility.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 600. The data controller had previously installed several video surveillance cameras that, among other things, covered the public space and a neighboring property. The DPA considered this to be a violation of the principle of data minimization. Moreover, the data controller hadn’t properly informed the data subjects about the processing of this personal data by the video surveillance, violating its duty to inform.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fiend SMART ELECTRIC SOLUTIONS, S.L. with EUR 800. The data controller had previously installed several video surveillance cameras that, among other things, covered the public space and a neighboring property. The DPA considered this to be a violation of the principle of data minimization. Moreover, the data controller hadn’t properly informed the data subjects about the processing of this personal data by the video surveillance, violating its duty to inform.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined FINCAS ARENYS SL with EUR 1,800. A data subject had filed a complaint to the DPA. This data subject had previously contacted the real estate agency to rent a property. During the renting process, the company requested certain documents from the data subject, not informing them about the processing of their personal data as part of the rental process. The original fine of EUR 3,000 was reduced to EUR 1,800 because of voluntary payment and admission of responsibility.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Cribis Credit Management s.r.l. with EUR 10,000. This company had inadvertently sent an email regarding late payments on a subscription to the head of the data subjects. By doing this, the head gained access to their employees’ personal data (name, surname, and payment status information).

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Unicredit S.p.A. with EUR 70,000. An employee has filed a complaint with the DPA where he claimed that his right to access his personal data wasn’t sufficiently respected. The company required him to file out a specific form to gain access to that personal data. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the requirement to fill out this form was disproportionately difficult to exercising the right of access.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Enel Energie Muntenia S.A. with EUR 10,000. One of the customers had mistakenly received an email that was addressed to another customer. This email contained documents with personal data belonging to the other customer. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that this incident had occurred because of the company’s failure to implement adequate organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 32 (1) b), (2) GDPR, Art. 58 (1) a), e) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined E Software Concept SRL with EUR 4,000. This company had previously uploaded certain documents on its website that were publicly accessible. Among other things, these documents included transport documents and invoices. The documents included various personal data such as names, surnames, sender and recipient address, usernames, passwords, telephone numbers, and email addresses. During the investigation, the DPA found that the public disclosure had occurred as a result of the company’s failure to implement efficient organizational and technical measures to protect the personal data. The DPA also discovered that the company hadn’t complied with the requests for information from the DPA during their investigation.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined Sindicato Intersectorial Trabajadores/as Provincia de Alicante with EUR 2,000. The union had previously published the protocols of a work council on their bulletin board and in a WhatsApp group. However, the handwritten signatures of all union representatives were visible both in the bulleting board and in the WhatsApp group.

allItems.name: Ireland
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 12 (1) GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR, Art. 25 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Irish DPA (also known as DPC) has fined Meta Platforms, Inc. with EUR 405,000,000. After a previous investigation, the DPC submitted a draft decision as per Art. 60 GDPR to other European supervisory authorities that had been affected. The initial draft included a fine of EUR 30-50 million. However, the DPC received objections from six of the supervisory authorities, leading to a dispute resolution procedure at the European Data Protection Board (EDPB) in Brussels. In the ensuing decision, the EDPB requested the DPC to increase the fine. After the DPC’s investigation, it was revealed that several Instagram business accounts of minors had displayed their phone numbers and emails to the public. Additionally, the settings of these accounts had been set to “public” by default, which made their social media content publicly available unless they specifically changed these settings. This breach has potentially affected millions of teenagers.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined the SERVICIOS PROFESIONALES LA PARADA S.L. with EUR 480. Apparently, the company had installed several video surveillance cameras that covered the public space, among other things. The DPA stated that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. Additionally, the data controller hadn’t properly informed the data subjects about the processing of this data by the video surveillance cameras, violating its duty to perform as a result. The original fine of EUR 800 was reduced to EUR 480 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined COLEGIO VILLAEUROPA, S.C.L. with EUR 3,000. The school didn’t provide sufficient information about the video surveillance system it had in place, as required by Art. 13 GDPR. The information signed did not contain a reference to the data controller nor an address to contact the data controller if anyone wanted to exercise their data subjects rights. The original fine of EUR 5,000 was reduced to EUR 3,000 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined DIGITECNIA SOLUTIONS, S.L. with EUR 1,200. A data subject had filed a complaint to the DPA against the company because the former had published a picture of themselves without their permission. The original fine of EUR 2,000 was reduced to EUR 1,200 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 29 GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b) GDPR, Art. 32 (2), (4) GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Alpha Bank Romania SA with EUR 1,000. The bank had accidentally transferred a document to the wrong recipient through WhatsApp. This document contained the personal data of four data subjects (first and last names and information about contracts and loans). During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the bank hadn’t implement sufficient organizational and technical measures to protect the personal data.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined MH VILASECA S.L. with EUR 240. The data controller did not provide an information notice about the video surveillance system on its premises. The original fine of EUR 400 was reduced to EUR 240 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Bazar Pekin with EUR 1,700. The data controller did not provide an information notice about the video surveillance system on its premises. Moreover, the data controller did not keep a proper register of its processing activities.

allItems.name: Norway
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Norwegian DPA (also known as Datatilsynet) has fined Recover AS with EUR 20,000. The data controller had carried out a credit check on the data subject without having a valid legal basis for it.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined a private individual with EUR 300. The individual had installed three video surveillance cameras on his property that also covered the access road of a neighbor, among other things.

allItems.name: France
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information
allItems.summary: The French DPA has fined GIE INFOGREFFE with EUR 250,000. The company operates a website where people can access legal information about other companies and order documents that are certified by the commercial courts. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the personal data of 25% of its members and subscribers (first names, surnames, bank details, telephone numbers, addresses) had been retained for a longer period than intended (36 months). The DPA concludes that this was a violation of Art. 5 (1) e) GDPR. Additionally, the DPA also discovered that the portal did not require the user of a secure password to create an account, which resulted in 3.7 million accounts having an insufficiently secure password. Moreover, the portal also transmitted passwords that allowed access to accounts, unencrypted via email. Lastly, the portal stored passwords and secret questions/answers that were used during the process to reset passwords by users in a database that did not use encryption. For this reason, the DPA stated that the portal had failed to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data of its users.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 2,000 because he had installed several video surveillance cameras that also covered the public space, among other things. The DPA stated that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 300 because he had installed several video surveillance cameras that, among other things, also filmed the neighbor’s property and public space. The DPA stated that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined SC Raiffeisen Bank SA with EUR 2,000. One of their clients had filed a complaint to the DPA because he kept receiving text messages about money transfers to certain individuals that they hadn’t done or validated. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the bank had accidentally used the data subject’s phone number in 44 transactions. The data subject was also not a customer of the bank and had not requested these transactions.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined EURO DONER KEBAB with EUR 180. The data controller had previously installed several video surveillance cameras that also covered the public space, among other things. The DPA stated that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. Moreover, the data controller did not properly inform the data subjects about the processing of their personal data by the video surveillance cameras, thus violating its duty to inform. The original fine of EUR 300 was reduced to EUR 180 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined MUXERS CONCEPT, S.L. with EUR 20,000. The company had previously installed several video surveillance cameras and microphones in the employee changing room in one of its restaurants. The DPA concluded that there was no legal basis for such an extensive data processing of the employees’ personal data, making it unlawful.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a store owner with EUR 360 because the data controller had installed several video surveillance cameras that also covered the public space, among other things. The DPA stated that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. Moreover, the data controller did not properly inform the data subjects about the processing of their personal data via the video surveillance system, violating its duty to inform. The original fine of EUR 600 was reduced to EUR 360 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.controller: Federazione Italiana Sommelier, Albergatori e Ristoratori
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Federazione Italiana Sommelier, Albergatori e Ristoratori with EUR 5,000 because the data controller had sent a protocol that contained personal data of a member to all other members. This protocol revealed personal information about a disciplinary measure that was taken against the member, even though the measure wasn’t legally binding and was later revoked. Additionally, the disciplinary measure was still published on a cloud platform even after the measures had been revoked.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined the Federazione Italiana Nuoto with EUR 2,000 because it failed to respond to the data subjects’ requests to access their data in a timely manner.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 480. The data controller had previously installed several video surveillance cameras that also covered the public space, among other things. The DPA stated that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. The original fine of EUR 600 was reduced to EUR 480 because of voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined SOPHIE ET VOILA, S.L. with EUR 10,000. The wedding dress company had previously published on its Instagram account a picture of a customer wearing a wedding dress without the customer’s consent. As such, the DPA concluded that the processing of the customer’s personal data was unlawful.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Realmedia Network SA with EUR 8,000. The company had previously suffered security breaches on the website it operates. This made it possible for third-parties to access unauthorized data that was leaked. This data included surnames, first names, email addresses, telephone numbers, signatures, postal addresses, copies of ID cards, bank data, and information from land register extracts of the data subjects. There were 194,309 people affected by this security incident, in total. The DPA discovered that the company had failed to take the adequate organizational and technical measures that would ensure a level of data security appropriate to the processing risk.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined NATURGY ENERGY GROUP, S.A. with EUR 48,000. An individual had contacted the energy company pretending to be a relative of a customer. This person then requested to receive the electricity bills of the data subject using a new email address. To verify their identity, the individual had to provide the name, address, contract number, ID number, and the last 4 digits of the bank account details of the customer. However, the DPA discovered that this verification wasn’t compliant with the GDPR requirements for identity verification. They stated that it was a violation of Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR and Art. 32 GDPR. The original fine of EUR 80,000 was reduced to EUR 48,000 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined SOLIVESA MASTER FRNACHISE S.L. with EUR 5,600. The data subject had previously received an advertising call from the data controller that was made on behalf of Vodafone Espana, S.A.U., even though the data subject had been registered in the Robinson Advertising Exclusion list.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined a private individual with EUR 1,500. The data subject had previously filed a complaint to the DPA against his ex-wife. The ex-wife had installed several video surveillance camaras in the jointly occupied house. These cameras also recorded his living areas and interfered with his privacy. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 600. The data controller had previously installed several video surveillance cameras that also covered the neighbor’s shared access road, among other things. The DPA stated that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. Additionally, the data controller did not properly inform the data subjects about the processing of this data through the video surveillance system, and this violated its duty to inform.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The DPA of Berlin has fined a subsidiary of a Berlin-based e-commerce group with EUR 525,000. The company had previously appointed a data protection officer who was also the managing officer of two service companies that provided personal data processing services to the same company for which they acted as a data protection officer. These service companies were also involved in a group to which the parent e-commerce company belonged. The DPA concluded that this was a conflict of interest and discovered a violation of Art. 38 (6) GDPR. The DPA had already issued such a warning to the company in 2021. However, an inspection this year revealed that the company hadn’t named a new data protection officer, prompting the DPA to impose the fine.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The DPA of Baden- Württemberg has fined a property development company with EUR 50,000. This company had previously sent a letter to a property owner where it made a purchase price offer for their property. This letter did not contain any information about the origin of the contact data, however. Even after the owner asked the company to clarify where it had obtained his contact data, the company did not reply. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that a surveyor had used his authority to look at the electronic land register recordings and identify several hundred property owners without their knowledge. Afterward, the surveyor would pass this information over to the company which then contacted the property owners with proposals. The DPA stated that this was a violation of Art. 6 (1) GDP and Art. 14 GDPR due to the lack of information on the origin of the data.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined MARIELI GABRIELA, S.L. with EUR 3,000. An individual had previously filed a complaint with the DPA because the company that had debited their bank account despite being no contractual relationship between them.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined the real estate agency BARCELONA DREAM HOUSE AGENCY with EUR 2,000. An individual had filed a complaint to the DPA because the real estate agency hadn’t sufficiently informed him about the processing of their personal data in the context of the conclusion of a rental agreement. For instance, the data controller did not include information about the purpose of the processing and data about the controller itself.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined the trade union Union Sindical Obrera with EUR 1,800. A data subject had filed a complaint to the DPA about receiving constant emails from the data controller despite having requested that their data be deleted. The original fine of EUR 3,000 was reduced to EUR 1,800 because of admission of guilt and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 25 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b), d), e) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Banca Comercială Română SA with EUR 2,000. The bank had previously notified the DPA about a data breach as per Art. 33 GDPR. Because of an error in the IT application of the data controller, several emails containing the personal data of customers were sent to the wrong recipients. The data breach resulted in the unauthorized access and disclosure of personal data (first and last name, home address, email address, phone number, financial information) of 564 individuals. The DPA discovered that the bank had failed to take the appropriate organizational and technical measures the ensure the proper level of security appropriate to the risk.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 3,000. The data controller had previously installed several video surveillance cameras that also covered the public space, among other things. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. Moreover, the data controller hadn’t properly informed the data subjects about the processing of their personal data through the video surveillance system, thus violating its duty to inform.

allItems.name: Poland
allItems.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Polish DPA has fined the Sulkowice Cultural Center with EUR 530. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller had transferred the processing of personal data to another processor without concluding any written concession agreement. Moreover, the data controller failed to verify the processor and also did not check whether the processor provided sufficient guarantees that would ensure the appropriate organizational and technical measures to protect the personal data.

allItems.name: Hungary
allItems.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) b), c) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 (1), (2) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Hungarian DPA has fined a company with EUR 735 because an individual had complained to the DPA that an employee of the company had made sound recordings with a mobile phone during the repair work done at the complainant’s home without informing the complainant.

allItems.name: Hungary
allItems.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 12 (3), (4) GDPR, Art. 31 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Hungarian DPA has fined a health insurance provider with EUR 1,200. The insurer had previously published the result of the data subject’s Covid-19 test on its website. This would have technically allowed unauthorized individuals to access the personal data of the data subject. Moreover, the insurer did not adequately cooperate with the agency during the DPA investigation.
