allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The DPA of Baden- Württemberg has fined a surveyor with EUR 5,000. The surveyor had used his authority to inspect several electronic land registers to identify a few hundred property owners without their knowledge. He then passed this information to a property developer who would call the data subjects to make them offers. The DPA concluded that the developer and the surveyor had unlawfully processed the data of these property owners.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Bitfactor SRL with EUR 2,000. The data controller had previously notified the DPA about a data breach as per Art. 33 GDPR. Because of a malfunction of an application belonging to the data controller, several marketing messages were sent to users of the site. This resulted in a breach of confidentiality of the personal data of 1757 data subjects. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller didn’t take the adequate organizational and technical measures to protect the personal data of the data subjects.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined Y OTRO MAS C.B. with EUR 180. Apparently, the data controller had previously installed a video surveillance system in a residential complex. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the information sign about the video surveillance system did not contain enough information about the processing of the personal data, the exercise of data subjects’ rights, and the data controller. The DPA noted that this was a violation of Art. 13 GDPR. The original fine of EUR 300 was reduced to EUR 180 because of voluntary payment and admission of responsibility.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined CLUB NATACIO LLEDIA with EUR 720. The data controller had installed several video surveillance cameras that recorded the cashier areas of the premises. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization, and the original fine of EUR 1,200 was reduced to EUR 720 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Denmark
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information
allItems.summary: The Danish DPA has fined Hørsholm municipality with EUR 6,700. The municipality had previously reported a data breach to the DPA as per Art. 33 GDPR. An employee’s work computer that contained confidential information about 1,600 municipality employees had been stolen. During the investigation, the DPA noted that the data on the computer wasn’t adequately secured and the municipality had failed to take the appropriate organizational and technical measures to protect the personal data.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Auto Hi-Fi System S.n.c. with EUR 2,000. The data controller had previously installed a video surveillance system that covered the public road and a private property, among other things. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. Moreover, the data controller hadn’t posted a sign with any information about the video surveillance. The DPA noted that this was also a violation of Art. 13 GDPR.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Global Service s.r.l. with EUR 2,000. The data controller had previously installed several video surveillance cameras on its premises but failed to inform the data subjects about the processing of the data. The DPA discovered that the data controller had violated its duty to inform as per the GDPR.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 114 Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Stay Over s.r.l. with EUR 10,000. One of the former employees of the company had filed a complaint to the DPA. The company had apparenyl failed to respond to the data subjects request for data access to their personal data. Additionally, the company had further continued to process the data from the email inbox of the employee after the termination of the contractual relationship, without the employee’s consent.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Azienda Socio Sanitaria Territoriale Rhodense with EUR 3,000. The healthcare facility had previously reported the loss of a patient’s medical records. This file contained personal data like the surname, first name, date and place of birth, gender, place of residence, phone number, and tax number of the data subject. The DPA concluded that this incident was caused by a lack of organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data during data processing.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 33 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined the BAYARD REVISTAS, S.A. with EUR 31,200. Apparently, unauthorized individuals had accessed the Bayard database and had syphoned off the contact and location data from users in the database. About 470,000 users were affected by this incident, and the DPA’s investigation also found out that a vulnerability in the data controller’s systems was to blame. The original fine of EUR 52,000 was reduced to EUR 31,200 because of admission of guilt and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Austria
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Austrian DPA has fined a private individual with EUR 600. The individual in question had contacted a public institution to notify them about the fact that the statement of a kindergarten teacher about being 50% disabled was not true. To this end, the person had submitted a court report that contained the health-related data of the data subject. During the investigation, the DPA noted that the transmission of the court report was an unlawful processing of the kindergarten teacher’s personal data.

allItems.name: Austria
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Austrian DPA has fined a private individual because he had installed a video surveillance system that also captured the public space, among other things. He also retained the images for longer than necessary.

allItems.name: Denmark
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information
allItems.summary: The Danish DPA has fined the Danish Immigration Agency with EUR 20,100. Apparently, several media reports brought the DPA’s attention to potential logging errors in one of the IT systems of the agency. These errors may have impacted the right and freedoms of several Danish residents. The DPA then started an investigation at the agency. In spring and summer of 202, several security incidents had occurred in the agency’s systems, leading to the loss of data records. These losses led to several proceedings being initiated against several residents regarding the reduction of their cash benefits. A few residents were also reported for non-compliance with the provisions of the Foreigners act. The DPA also discovered that a lack of organizational and technical measures was at fault for allowing these incidents to occur. For example, the agency had not made sufficient backups of data processed data even though it would have been necessary, considering the potential legal consequences of a loss of data.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined the Club Nautico el Estacio with EUR 6,000. A data subject had filed a complaint to the AEPD against the data controller, claiming that the controller had published an announcement and record of the club’s ordinary meeting on its website. By doing this, the data controller disclosed the data subject’s personal information without access restrictions.

allItems.name: United Kingdom
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 13 (1) c) GDPR, Regulation 21 PECR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The UK DPA has fined Easylife Ltd. with EUR 1,547,000. Easylife is in the retailing business and sells household items and services/products under the motor, health, supercard, and garden clubs. When clients purchase certain products, the company would make assumptions about the customer’s health condition, and it would offer further products for purchase via phone or SMS that were related to their assumed health condition. From the 122 products in the Health Club catalog of Easylife, 80 of them were classified as “trigger products”. Once the clients would purchase these products, Easylife would create their profiles to target them with additional health-related items. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the company had collected and used the personal data (health data) of about 145,500 data subjects without obtaining their consent. The DPA further noted that the “invisible” data processing of the personal data was a serious violation of the data subjects’ rights because they could not exercise their privacy and data protection rights since they did not know about the data processing. Moreover, the company had made a total of 1,345,732 unsolicited marketing calls to individuals without obtaining their consent for the calls. The DPA also noted that this was a violation of the PECR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined the OES GLOBAL ENERGY S.L. with EUR 35,000. One of the customers of the data controller had complained to the DPA that he received an email from the data controller that contained documents related to the termination of electricity contracts of other customers. These documents also contained the personal data of these customers, like the ID numbers and their names. The DPA concluded that this was an unlawful disclosure of personal data, and a violation of the principle of confidentiality and integrity, as well as a lack of sufficient organizational and technical measures that would protect their personal data.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.controller: ACKERMANN & SCHWARTZ ATTORNEYS AT LAW SLP
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined ACKERMANN & SCHWARTZ ATTORNEYS AT LAW SLP with EUR 10,000. The law firm had previously collected the personal data of website users without their consent. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the privacy policy on their website did not contain enough information. For instance, the information about the data controller’s contact details and information about the exercising of the data subjects’ rights were missing.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.controller: EL RACO DEL PIS INVERSIONES S.L.
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined EL RACO DEL PIS INVERSIONES S.L. with EUR 9,000. The data controller had sent an email in an open distribution list, which made all the email addresses of the recipients visible to other recipients.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The data controller failed to respond to the data subject’s request for access to their data in a timely manner.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined URBANO DIVERTIA, S.L. with EUR 1,200. One of the customers had filed a complaint to the DPA, saying that they’d received a document from the data controller with data related to the previous tenant of the apartment they were renting from the data controller. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of confidentiality and integrity. The original fine of EUR 2,000 was reduced to EUR 1,200 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined a private individual with EUR 10,000. The Individual had previously published the personal data of another person on a blog without obtaining their consent, and did it in a defamatory manner.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a member of the staff council with EUR 2,000. The data controller had sent minutes of staff council minutes to several unauthorized third parties that weren’t members of the staff council. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the individual did not have any effective legal basis for sending these emails.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) b) GDPR, Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined BANCO BILBAO VIZCAYA ARGENTARIA, S.A. with EUR 70,000. One of the bank’s customers had complained to the DPA, saying that in the past, in his capacity as an attorney, he had filed a statement of claim against the bank by their client, who was also a customer of the bank. The bank had sent a reply to the client where it included the private addresses of the data subject and the attorney, instead of their professional addresses. The DPA discovered that the bank had processed the attorney’s personal data in a manner that was incompatible with the purpose for which the data was collected (to manage their private account). Moreover, the DPA also found that the unauthorized disclosure of the attorney’s personal data happened because of inadequate organizational and technical measures.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined CAIXABANK S.A. with EUR 25,000. The data subject had previously (unsuccessfully) requested that the bank update their address on file. The DPA considered that this was a violation of Art. 16 GDPR.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined the Romanian Post with EUR 2,000. The Post had suffered a data breach where the staff lost multiple mailings that contained pension statements, death certificates, and employment certificates. This incident affected 35 individuals, and the DPA discovered that the Post had failed to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data, which would have prevented this incident.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined the Vodafone Espana, S.A.U. with EUR 56,000. A data subject had filed a complaint to the DPA after unsuccessfully requesting a copy of their phone contract from Vodafone a couple of times. Eventually, the data subject received an email but it contained the phone contract of another customer. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of confidentiality and integrity as per Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR. Moreover, the DPA also found out that Vodafone had failed to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data, which could have prevented this incident. The original fine of EUR 70,000 was reduced to EUR 56,000 because of voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA (also known as ANSPDCP) has fined SC Das Sense Society SRL with EUR 1,000 after it failed to provide the information requested by the DPA during an investigation.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 12 (3) GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR
allItems.type: Several
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Colosseo S.r.l. with EUR 1,000. A data subject had complained to the DPA after the data controller had sent him an unsolicited commercial email. After that, the data subject requested the data controller that they provide access to his personal data, to delete the personal data, and to stop from sending future promotional emails. However, the data controller failed to reply to the data subject’s requests.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined CITRICOS TANTA, S.L. with EUR 5,000. The data controller had previously entered the personal data of an employee in the Social Security General Employee Register without making sure that the employee every actually worked. As such, the data controller would have been forced the cancel the entry of the data subject in the register within 72 hours. However, this did not happen. Moreover, in the absence of the data subject’s work performance, the data controller had no legal basis to upload the data to the register. Therefore, the DPA concluded that this failure to delete the data was an unlawful processing of the data subject’s personal data.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined Rapido Finance, S.L. with EUR 2,000. The data subject had previously received a message from a company on behalf of Rapid Finance, where they requested the payment of outstanding debts. However, the data subject had already paid those debts in the past, which was also confirmed in a court ruling. For this reason, the DPA concluded that the disclosure of the data subject’s personal data regarding the settlement of the debt was unlawful.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b), e) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 8 GDPR, Art. 12 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 30 (1) GDPR, Art. 22 (2) LSSI
allItems.type: Several
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined Techpump Solutions S.L. with EUR 525,000. The company operate several websites with adult content. The Spanish DPA discovered several violations of data protection law during its investigation on the company. To start, the DPA found that Techpump shared the users’ personal data with the companies that belonged to the same group, contradicting its privacy policy. Moreover, the DPA also discovered that Techpump did not specify a retention period for their users’ personal data, keeping it indefinitely until the users requested to withdraw their consent. Techpump was also processing the users’ personal data without obtaining their consent first. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the company did not have the sufficient parental controls to prevent minors under 14 to access its contents. Techpump’s privacy policy was also only available in English rather than Spanish, and the information was unclear at best. Techpump also required that data subjects who wished to exercise their data subject rights would submit their ID card information to verify their identity. The DPA concluded that this was an unacceptable impediment to exercise the data subject’s rights. In the end, Techpump collected various data like WiFi data and IP addresses without having defined a processing purpose for it.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.controller: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE ESPANA LTD Y COMPANIA SRC
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined the UNITED PARCEL SERVICE ESPANA LTD Y COMPANIA SRC with EUR 70,000. A data subject has complained to the DPA that the UPS had delivered a package from them to their neighbor without obtaining their consent. The DPA concluded that this was an unauthorized disclosure of their personal data. This was a result of a lack of organizational and technical measures to protect the personal data. The DPA also discovered that this unauthorized disclosure of personal data was a violation of the principle of confidentiality and integrity.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 300. The data controller had previously installed video surveillance cameras that also covered the public space, among other things. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fiend a Homeowners Association. This association had installed several video surveillance cameras across their residential area, covering the public space, among other things. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. However, the original fine of EUR 1,500 was reduced to EUR 900 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined the Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria, S.A. with EUR 48,000. A data subject had previously complained to the DPA after requesting information on their account and receiving the contract information from a third party. The DPA concluded that the unauthorized disclosure of third-party data was because of inadequate organizational and technical measures at the bank. The original fine of EUR 80,000 was reduced to EUR 48,000 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined XASTRE DO PETO, S.L. with EUR 3,600. A data subject had complained to the DPA that the data controller required them to fill out a form with their personal information regarding contact tracing during the Covid-19 pandemic. However, during the investigation, the DPA discovered that the legal basis for the collection of this contact information had expired and the data controller had been processing the data unlawfully. The DPA also discovered that the data controller failed to provide the data subjects with enough information about the data processing. The DPA then determined that the data controller did not provide the data subjects with an easy way of objecting to the processing of the personal data.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined BANKINTER, S.A. with EUR 80,000. A data subject had complained to the DPA because the personal data of a third party was displayed to them when accessing their bank account. The DPA discovered that the unauthorized disclosure of the third-party data was caused because of inadequate organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data at the bank. The original fine of EUR 100,000 was reduced to EUR 80,000 because of voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Hungary
allItems.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItems.controller: AMPLIFION Hungary Trade and Service Provider LLC
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) b) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 12 (1) GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Hungarian DPA has fined AMPLIFION Hungary Trade and Service Provider LLC. With EUR 197,000. The DPA had previously received a complaint from multiple data subjects who said that they’d received unsolicited invitations to a hearing screening. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the company in question had contacted the data subjects without obtaining their consent first. The company had also received the data from the Ministry of the Interior for market research purposes. The DPA discovered that the company had processes this data unlawfully and opposed to the original purpose of the market research. Moreover, the DPA found that the company failed to provide the data subjects with enough information about the data processing.

allItems.name: Poland
allItems.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 25 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 (1), (2) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Polish DPA has fined the mayor of the Dobrzyniewo Duze municipality with EUR 1,700. The mayor had previously reported a data breach to the DPA as per Art. 33 GDPR. One of the employee’s work computers that contained personal data was stolen. During the investigation, the DPA concluded that the data on the computer had not been adequately secured and the municipality had failed to take the necessary organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Raiffeisen Bank SA with EUR 28,000. The bank had previously reported multiple data breaches as per Art. 33 GDPR to the DPA. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the bank had conducted several queries in a credit agency without obtaining the data subjects’ consent first. Moreover, the DPA also discovered that the bank had granted credit to several customers even though the affected customers had not applied for it. Moreover, the bank had mistakenly sent the personal data of several data subjects to the wrong recipients, which allowed them to access this data. The DPA discovered that the bank had not implemented the adequate organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data. This clearly led to the unauthorized access and the disclosure of the personal data.

allItems.name: France
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) e) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 25 (2) GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The French DPA (also known as CNIL) has fined DISCORD INC. with EUR 800,000. Discord is an online communication service that users can use to chat and make video calls. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the company had failed to establish and comply with the data retention period necessary for the purpose of the processing. For instance, more than two million accounts in the DISCORD database (French users) had not used their accounts for more than three years and more than 50,000 accounts had not used their accounts for more than five years. Moreover, the DPA noted that DISCORD did not have the complete information about the retention periods. The DPA also found that the company had failed to ensure the proper data protection by default, contrary to its obligation as per Art. 25 (2) GDPR. Therefore, it was possible for user data to be transmitted after the communication app was closed. The DPA also discovered that the company did not sufficiently ensure the security of the personal data by accepting insecure passwords from users. The company was accepting user passwords that consisted of six characters that contained only letters and numbers. In the end, the DPA discovered that the company also failed to conduct a data protection assessment.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA (also known as ANSPDCP) has fined the Homeowners Association Bld. Pipra 1-2E with EUR 300 after failing to provide the information requested by the DPA during an investigation.

allItems.name: Portugal
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) e), f) GDPR, Art. 13 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 37 (1), (7) GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Portuguese DPA has fined the Setubal Municipality with EUR 170,000. The DPA discovered data protection violations about the collection of personal data from the Ukrainian refugees. The municipality had asked these refugees to fill out a form at the time of their arrival and offer various details such as names, dates of birth, marital status, and so on. The DPA stated that the municipality hadn’t sufficiently informed the data subjects about this data processing. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the municipality did not implement the required organizational and technical measures to protect the personal data and toe define a retention period for this data. The municipality also failed to appoint a data protection officer.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 300. The data controller had previously installed a video surveillance system that also covered the public space, among other things.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.controller: ING BANK NV Amsterdam Sucursala București
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined ING Bank NV Amsterdam Sucursala București with EUR 20,000. The bank had previously reported a data breach to the DPA as per Art. 33 GDPR. Personal data of customers (bank data, ID card data, bank card data, etc) was accessed and disclosed without any authorization. This resulted in payment transactions being carried out by unauthorized third parties who did not have the consent of the data subjects. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the bank had failed to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data, allowing the unauthorized access to occur, prompting the DPA to issue a fine.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 32 (1) b) GDPR, Art. 32 (2) GDPR, Art. 32 (4) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Medicover S.R.L. with EUR 1,000. Apparently, the data controller had previously reported a data breach to the DPA as per Art. 33 GDPR. The data controller had mistakenly sent various documents that contained personal data to the wrong recipient. As a result of this, the personal data (information like name, email address, correspondence address and health data) was disclosed without valid authorization to a third party. The DPA concluded that these incidents took place because the data controller failed to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures that would protect the processing of the personal data.

allItems.name: Ireland
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Irish DPA has fined Meta Platforms Ireland Limited with EUR 265 million. The DPA had previously launched an investigation against Meta back in 2021 after several media reports indicated that a dataset that contained personal data from Facebook was made available on a public hacking platform. This data leak had affected up to 533 million users, disclosing their personal data (phone numbers and email addresses) to third parties without authorization. During the investigation, the DPA reviewed and analyzed the Facebook Search, Messenger Contact Importer, and the Instagram Contact Importer Tools. The DPA’s main goal was to assess the implementation of organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data, and they found a breach of Art. 25 GDPR.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 25 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b) GDPR, Art. 32 (2) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined the company OTP LEASING ROMANIA IFN SA with EUR 3,000. Apparently, an individual had previously informed the data controller that they had obtained unauthorized access to an IT platform that was operated by the data controller by changing the URL address and then creating an administrator account. This let the person obtain unauthorized access to personal data. The DPA discovered that the data controller had not taken the appropriate organizational and technical measures to protect the personal data, which resulted in the unauthorized access to personal data.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 500. Apparently, the data controller had installed several video surveillance cameras which, among others, also covered the public space. The data controller also published some of these recorded images on Facebook, publicly. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization and issued a fine of EUR 500.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 7 GDPR, Art. 12 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 130 (1), (2), (3) Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Vodafone Italia S.p.A. with EUR 500,000. A customer of the company had filed a complaint to the DPA against Vodafone, the data controller. The 80-year-old Vodafone customer had been contacted by an external call center that was commissioned by Vodafone. During this conversation, the call center concluded a new contract with the data subject without their consent. During the investigation, the Italian DPA discovered that the customer had not received enough information about the processing of her personal data. Moreover, the call center had read the information so quickly that the data subject did not understand most of it, making the transmission of information useless. When calculating the fine, the DPA also took into consideration the aggravating factor of Vodafone having already committed such violations in the past. However, Vodafone immediately terminated the contract, which acts as a mitigating factor.

allItems.name: France
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 7 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. L. 34-5 CPCE
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The French DPA has fined ÉLECTRICITÉ DE FRANCE, France’s largest electricity supplier, with EUR 600,000.  The DPA had received multiple complaints from individuals who said that they were experiencing issues in exercising their rights from EDF. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the company’s privacy policy did not provide enough information on several aspects related to data processing, such as the data retention period of the data subjects’ personal data. Furthermore, the DPA also discovered that ÉLECTRICITÉ DE FRANCE had failed to respond to several data subject requests in a timely manner. Moreover, ÉLECTRICITÉ DE FRANCE also failed to respect the data subjects’ right to object to advertising requests, in several cases. The DPA also noted that EDF could not demonstrate that it had obtained the data subjects’ valid consent regarding a commercial solicitation campaign. Finally, the DPA also noted that EDF did not implement enough organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data. EDF had also stored the passwords of more than 25,000 customers in an insecure manner. Additionally, the company had not salted the passwords of 2.4 million accounts, instead opting to hash them out.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined a company with EUR 3,000. The data controller had previously installed a video surveillance system that also recorded the voices of customers and employees. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller did not have a valid legal basis for processing the information related to the voices as part of its video surveillance system. Additionally, the DPA discovered that the data controller had failed to provide enough information about the video surveillance system, which included information about the data processing, identity of the data controller, and the exercise of the data subject rights.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined INDECEMI, S.L. with EUR 3,000. A person had filed a complaint to the DPA against the data controller after they’d received an email from the data controller that contained personal data (first and last name, address, telephone number, and more) of another data subject in the context of a complaint. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of confidentiality and integrity.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined LORENT 2013, S.L. with EUR 600. The data controller had previously installed several video surveillance cameras that, among other things, also covered the public space. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined the Homeowners Association with EUR 300. The association had previously installed several video surveillance cameras across the residential areas that, among other things, also covered the common area. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), e), f) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 7 GDPR, Art. 12 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 27 (4) GDPR, Art. 28 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Alpha Exploration with EUR 2 million. Alpha Exploration is a company that operates the network Clubhouse. During the investigation, the DPA discovered several violations of the GDPR. For instance, the DPA discovered that there was a lack of transparency related to the use of the users’ data and their chat contacts. Moreover, users of this network were able to store and share the audio messages from other users without obtaining their consent. Moreover, the account information was shared with various unauthorized third parties without a valid legal basis. Moreover, the company also did not define retention periods for the personal data. The company also failed to provide its users with enough information about several aspects of the processing of their personal data, failing to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data. In the end, the DPA discovered that the company failed to conduct a data protection impact assessment, as well. When the investigation was over, the DPA imposed a fine and ordered the company to take several measures. For instance, the company was forced to define retention periods and introduce a function that could inform users that their chats are being recorded.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Codess Sociale, Soc. Coop. sociale. With EUR 10,000. A former voluntary member of the institution had filed a complaint to the DPA. Apparently, the data subject claims that when they resigned, they had requested the deletion of their personal data from the data controller’s archives. However, the data controller did not comply with this request in due time.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined FCA Italy S.p.A. with EUR 40,000. One of the data controller’s employees requested access to personal data that was processed in the context of their employment relationship. However, the data controller did not comply with this request in a timely manner, violating the requirements of Art. 12 GDPR and Art. 15 GDPR.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), f) GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Azienda Usl Valle d’Aosta with EUR 40,000. An employee and patient of the health department had previously filed a complaint to the DPA because one of their colleagues who had never treated them had accessed their medical files numerous times, despite the fact that the data subject had explicitly refused their consent to the data processing. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the health department had simplified the medical record system in order to simplify the patient management during the Covid 19 pandemic. This led to the patient medical records becoming accessible to any employee whether or not the patient actually gave their consent to the data processing. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the obligation to implement the appropriate organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined CASA 7 PERSONAL SHOPPER, S.L. with EUR 3,500. The data controller had sent an email containing personal data to several recipients in an open distribution list. This resulted in the recipients seeing all the email addresses of the rest of the recipients.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.controller: Federation of Sports for People with Intellectual Disabilities of Castilla la Mancha-FECAM
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined the Federation of Sports for People with Intellectual Disabilities of Castilla la Mancha-FECAM with EUR 3,600. The data controller had processed the medical data of Covid-19 antigent tests of participants in sports competitions without obtaining their consent for the data processing. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the data controller had failed to inform the data subjects about the data retention period. The original fine of EUR 6,000 was reduced to EUR 3,600 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined ALPA 57 PRODUCCIONES, S.L. with EUR 1,800 because the company failed to provide information requested by the DPA during one of its investigations. The original fine of EUR 3,000 was reduced to EUR 1,800 because of admission of guilty and immediate payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined the Association for the prevention and study of crimes, abuses and negligence in information technology and advanced communications (APEDANICA) with EUR 5,000. The employees of the company LEGAL ERASER SL had complained to the DPA against the association. Apparently, the data controller had requested information about LEGAL ERASER from the DPA as part of the right to information based on the Spanish Transparency Act. The data controller then published these documents, some of which contained the personal data of LEGAL ERASER’s customers and employees, to 58 links on the internet.

allItems.name: Ireland
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR, Art. 28 (1), (3) GDPR, Art. 30 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Irish DPA has fined Slane Credit Union Ltd. with EUR 5,000. The data controller had notified the DPA about the data breach in 2018. Because of an error in the search engine optimization tool installed on the website of the data controller, four reports of member inquiries that contained personal member data were unintentionally published online. The incident affected 76 members, including minors, and their personal data (names, addresses, birth dates, genders, account numbers, etc). The DPA discovered that the data controller did not implement sufficient organizational and technical measures to protect the personal data. Moreover, the DPA concluded that the data controller did not conduct due diligence on the data processor and also did not conclude a GDPR-compliant contract with the processor.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 25 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b) GDPR, Art. 32 (2) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Casa Rusu S.R.L. with EUR 2,000. The data controller had reported a data breach to the DPA as per Art. 33 GDPR. The data controller had used an unauthorized form during the payment process on its website that allowed the bank data of the customer cards to be collected. This allowed anauthorized access to personal data (first and last names of the affected cardholders, card numbers, expiration dates and years, CVC codes). During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller did not take the appropriate organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined a private individual with EUR 480. The individual in question had installed several video surveillance cameras in a residential complex that also covered common areas. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the individual did not have permission to install these cameras and there did not have any legal basis for the data processing. Moreover, the individual did not provide information about the video surveillance to the data subjects. The original fine was reduced to EUR 480 from EUR 600 because of voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined a notary with EUR 8,000. The data controller had consulted the land register of a property that belonged to the data subject without an order that required the consultation of this data or the consent of the data subject. The original fine of EUR 10,000 was reduced to EUR 8,000 because of voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 120. The data controller had previously installed a video surveillance system in a multi-party building that they owned. However, the information sign about the video surveillance system lacked necessary information about the data controller and the exercise of the data subjects’ rights. The original fine of EUR 150 was reduced to EUR 120 because of voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Portugal
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 9 (1) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 28 (1), (6), (7) GDPR, Art. 35 (1), (2), (3) b) GDPR, Art. 44 GDPR, Art. 46 (2) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Portuguese DPA has fined the Portuguese National Statistical Institute with EUR 4,300,000. The DPA discovered several violations of the GDPR regarding the 2021 census in Portugal. The DPA first discovered that the data controller did not inform the data subjects that the provisions of the health and religious data was purely voluntary. The DPA considered that this was an interference with the data subjects’ ability to freely express their will regarding the data processing. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the data controller did not exercise due diligence when selecting its data processing, contrary to its obligation per Art. 28 GDPR. Moreover, the order processing contract permitted the transfer of all personal data outside the EEA without providing additional security measures besides the SCCS that was approved by the European Commission, as required under the Schrems II Ruling. The DPA considered that this was a breach of Art. 44 GDPR and Art. 46 (2) GDPR. In the end, the DPA discovered that the data controller did not conduct a data protection impact assessment regarding this census.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined Vodafone Espana, S.A.U. with EUR 56,000. A person had filed a complaint to the DPA against the company because the former had given a duplicate of their SIM card to another unauthorized fraudulent third party without obtaining their consent. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that Vodafone Espana failed to verify the identity of the third party or obtain the data subject’s consent to share their data. This allowed the fraudsters to gain access to the data subject’s bank accounts and make unauthorized payments. The original fine of EUR 70,000 was reduced to EUR 56,000 because of voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Finland
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), d) GDPR, Art. 12 (3) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 15 (1) GDPR, Art. 25 (1) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Finnish DPA has fined Viking Line Oy Abp with EUR 230,000. A former employee of the company had filed a complaint to the DPA. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller had not complied with the data subject’s request for access to their health data. Moreover, some of the medical data had been stored incorrectly. The DPA also found that the medical data was stored alongside other personal data, despite this being unlawful. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the data controller had not properly informed its employees about the data processing of their personal data, as per its obligation under Art. 13 GDPR.

allItems.name: France
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 33 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The French DPA has fined FREE SAS with EUR 300,000. The DPA had received several complaints from various individual who experienced issues in exercising their rights to access and delete their personal data at FREE. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the company did not process the requests for access and deletion of its personal data in a timely manner. The DPA also discovered that the company had failed to ensure the security of its personal data. For instance, the company allowed users to use insecure passwords. Moreover, the user passwords were stored without encryption in the company’s databases. Finally, the DPA discovered that the company had inadequately documented a data breach.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined I.S.P.R.O., an oncology health care facility, with EUR 7,000. An individual had mistakenly received the medical records of someone else via email.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined Vodafone Espana, S.A.U. with EUR 56,000. A person had filed a complaint to the DPA against the company because the former had given a duplicate of their SIM card to another unauthorized fraudulent third party without obtaining their consent. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that Vodafone Espana failed to verify the identity of the third party or obtain the data subject’s consent to share their data. This allowed the fraudsters to gain access to the data subject’s bank accounts and make unauthorized payments. The original fine of EUR 70,000 was reduced to EUR 56,000 because of voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined Vodafone Espana, S.A.U. with EUR 56,000. A person had filed a complaint to the DPA against the company because the former had given a duplicate of their SIM card to another unauthorized fraudulent third party without obtaining their consent. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that Vodafone Espana failed to verify the identity of the third party or obtain the data subject’s consent to share their data. This allowed the fraudsters to gain access to the data subject’s bank accounts and make unauthorized payments. The original fine of EUR 70,000 was reduced to EUR 56,000 because of voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Societatea Energetică Electrica S.A. with EUR 50,000 for violating Art. 28 (3) a) GDPR

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined the HOPSITAL RECOLETAS PONFERRADA, S.L. with EUR 16,000. A patient had filed a complaint to the DPA against the hospital, saying that he’d filed out a consent form during a medical examination in which certain items had already been pre-ticked. The DPA also discovered that the data controller had not complied with the patient’s request for access to their personal data in a timely manner. The original fine of EUR 20,000 was reduced to EUR 16,000 because of voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined the company ORANGE ESPAGNE, S.A.U with EUR 30,000. Apparently, a data subject had filed a complaint to the DPA against the data controller because the former had registered a telephone line in the data subject’s name without obtaining their consent and without having any contractual relationship. Instead, the contracts in question had been concluded by fraudsters that used the personal data of the data subject. However, the personal data was also entered into the company’s information systems without any verification whether the contracts were actually lawful and concluded by the data subject. The original fine of EUR 60,000 was reduced to EUR 30,000 because of admission of guilt and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), d) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Lazio Region with EUR 100,000. An individual had previously filed a complaint to the DPA after having received an invitation from the regional health authority, asking her to participate in a cervical cancer screening program addressed to her daughter who died in 1995. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the daughter’s personal data was still in the region’s database even though she had died a long time ago. As such, the DPA concluded that the Region had violated the principles of correctness and accuracy. Being the owner of the data, the Region should have also ensured that the personal information was accurate and updated. The Region should have also taken all the steps to delete and correct the information in a timely manner. Moreover, the Garante also discovered that the Region hadn’t properly provided the data subjects with the required information about the processing of their personal data when they sent the invitation letters for the cervical cancer screening campaign. When imposing the fine, the DPA also considered an aggravating factor the fact that the Region already had a fine.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b), f) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 7 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 27 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Sensoenics Inc. with EUR 45,000. The company had previously reported a data breach to the DPA as per Art. 33 GDPR. This involved an employee accidentally sending an information campaign through email to several recipients in an open distribution list. This led to the disclosure of all the email addresses of the recipients to each other. The recipients of the emails were diabetic patients, which made it possible for them to obtain information about the health status of other data subjects included in the emails. During the investigation, the DPA also identified other privacy violations that involved the glucose monitoring system that was produced by the company. When downloading the monitoring app, the users had to accept the contractual terms of use and give their consent of the privacy policy with a single click. This made it impossible for them to give their consent separately to the individual processing operations, which also included the processing of health data. Moreover, the DPA also discovered that the company had violated the principles of transparency and fairness by providing its users with confusing and (sometimes) erroneous information about the processing of their personal data. Lastly, the company did not designate a representative in the European Union as a contact person for all data protection issues.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined the real estate agency PUNTO BADAL-BCN S.L. The data controller had previously sent marketing emails to several individuals in an open distribution list. This made the email addresses of all the recipients visible to everyone else. The original fine of EUR 5,000 was reduced to EUR 4,000 because of voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.controller: CAJA DE SEGUROS REUNIDOS, COMPAÑÍA DE SEGUROS Y REASEGUROS, S.A.
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined the CAJA DE SEGUROS REUNIDOS, COMPANIA DE SEGUROS Y REASEGUROS, S.A. with EUR 24,000. A data subject had previously filed a complaint with the DPA. Apparently, the data subject had taken out an insurance policy with the data controller. The beneficiary was the ex-life partner at that time. After the separation, the ex-life partner asked the data controller to change the debit entry for the premium from the data subject’s account to her account. The data controller carried out this change without obtaining the consent of the data subject. The DPA concluded that this was an unlawful change to the personal data of the data subject. The original fine of EUR 40,000 was reduced to EUR 24,000 because of voluntary payment and admission of responsibility.

allItems.name: Estonia
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Icelandic DPA has fined HEI – Medical Travel with EUR 10,600. A data subject had previously filed a complaint to the DPA against the data controller. The data controller had apparently gained access to the email of the data subject via the Icelandic Medical Association’s internal website and then sent the data subject unsolicited emails. The DPA discovered that this type of access was unlawful because of a lack of a valid legal basis. Moreover, the data subject had asked the data controller for information regarding the processing of their personal data (the origin of the email address). The data controller did not properly comply with this request, however.

allItems.name: Iceland
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Icelandic DPA has fined HEI – Medical Travel with EUR 10,600. A data subject had previously filed a complaint to the DPA against the data controller. The data controller had apparently gained access to the email of the data subject via the Icelandic Medical Association’s internal website and then sent the data subject unsolicited emails. The DPA discovered that this type of access was unlawful because of a lack of a valid legal basis. Moreover, the data subject had asked the data controller for information regarding the processing of their personal data (the origin of the email address). The data controller did not properly comply with this request, however.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined a private individual with EUR 900. The data subject unauthorizedly sent emails containing personal data to multiple recipients in an open distribution list. This made it possible for the recipients to view the email addresses of all the other recipients. The original fine of EUR 1,200 was reduced to EUR 900 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined a company with EUR 800. The data controller had previously installed video surveillance cameras without obtaining the authorization for the installation. Moreover, the data controller failed to provide warning signs regarding the CCTV system with the contact details of the data controller.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.controller: UNION DE OFICIALES DE LA GUARDA CIVIL PROFESIONAL
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined the UNION DE OFICIALES DE LA GUARDIA CIVIL PROFESIONAL with EUR 6,000. A person had previously complained to the DPA that the data controller had contacted them without them being a member of the association. They hadn’t even given their permission to be contacted.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined EVERIS SPAIN S.L. with EUR 64,000. The company had published information about sold data of several users of an insurance company and records with personal data of Spanish customers of the same insurance company. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the confidentiality of the data. The publication of the unlawful data was made possible because of a lack of organizational and technical measures that would protect the data at the time of the data breach. The original fine of EUR 80,000 was reduced to EUR 64,000 because of voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined the homeowners’ association with EUR 600. The data controller had previously installed a video surveillance system that recorded both image and sound. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the video surveillance system had recorded parts of the common area, among other things. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. Moreover, the DPA also discovered that the data controller hadn’t sufficiently complied with its information obligations as per Art. 13 GDPR regarding the video surveillance.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) a) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined a website operator with EUR 150. The data controller had previously published unauthorized personal data such as the ID number and series, telephone number, bank details, email address, and marital status of 383 natural persons.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy, Art. 2-sexies Codice della privacy, Art. 2-septies (8) Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the school Eduardo Amaldi with EUR 4,000. The school had apparently published a circular on the school website regarding the summer vacations which also contained the exact vacation dates of the school staff.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 32 (1) b), c) GDPR, Art. 32 (2) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Curtea Veche Publishing SRL with EUR 5,000. The data controller had previously reported two data breaches to the DPA as per Art. 33 GDPR. During the first data breach, the data controller had inadvertently published a file that contained the customer database in a public forum. This resulted in the unauthorized disclosure of personal data (first name, last name, email, phone number, encrypted password, IP address) of 10,793 customers. The secondary data breach concerned a ransomware attach that led to the unauthorized access and loss of integrity and the availability of personal data of approximately 100 data subjects. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller had failed to implement adequate organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data. This failure to implement protective measures was what caused the data breaches.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined EDYTE S.A. with EUR 5,000. The data processor had unlawfully disclosed the personal data to third parties without obtaining the authorization of the data controller.

allItems.name: Belgium
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 35 (1), (3) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Belgian DPA has fined a medical laboratory with EUR 20,000. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the laboratory had failed to conduct a data protection impact assessment and had thus violated Art. 35 GDPR. Moreover, the laboratory also violated Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR and Art. 32 GDPR because it was possible for physicians to view the personal data of patients on the website without proper encryption. Lastly, the DPA discovered that the laboratory had failed to publish a privacy statement on its website, violating Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, and Art. 14 GDPR.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined IDIKA SA with EUR 10,000. IDIKA, as the data controller, operated in the context of providing free COVID-10 tests. The DPA discovered that IDIKA, during the processing activities, failed to sufficiently inform the data subjects about the processing of their personal data. Moreover, IDIKA had stored personal data for longer than was necessary, failing to implement sufficient organizational and technical measures to protect the personal data.

allItems.name: Hungary
allItems.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 12 (1) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Hungarian DPA has fined a complaint with the DPA. The bank had previously conducted a credit check on the individual based on a credit application. However, the bank conducted a second credit check later on, even though the data subject had not requested it. The DPA then found that this second credit was carried out illegally because it lacked a legal basis.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined SEAN SERIOS S.L. with EUR 12,000. The data controller had previously published the results of a selection procedure on a website. This included the personal data of the participants (surname, first name, and score in the selection process). During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller didn’t have a sufficient legal basis for publishing the data.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Cosmopol S.p.A. with EUR 20,000. An individual had previously filed a complaint with the DPA against the data controller. This individual had received invoices without having a contractual relationship with the company. So, the data subject then requested information about the origin of their personal data. However, the data controller failed to respond to the data subject’s request for information in a timely manner.

allItems.name: Hungary
allItems.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) GDPR, Art. 12 (2) GDPR, Art. 13 (1) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Hungarian DPA has fined a physician with EUR 1,500. A patient had previously asked the doctor to send her complete medical records (including the imaging records and the consent forms about her maternity care). However, the physician failed to comply with this request.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined INMUR JOYEROS, S.L. with EUR 180. The data controller failed to provide a notice with information regarding the video surveillance on its premises. The original fine of EUR 300 was reduced to EUR 180 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Intesa Sanpaolo Vita S.p.a. with EUR 20,000. The data subject had taken out a life insurance with the data controller and filed a complaint to the DPA against the data controller for the unauthorized disclosure of their personal data. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller had disclosed the data subject’s personal data (first name, last name, and information regarding the policy) to third parties without authorization. This unauthorized data disclosure had occurred because of an employee’s error.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined RESTEXPERIENCE, S.L. with EUR 5,000. The data controller had accidentally sent an email that contained the tax information of 36 individuals to 11 unauthorized individuals. The DPA claims that this was a breach of the principle of confidentiality and integrity. The DPA also discovered that the company had previously failed to implement the appropriate organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 500. The private individual had installed a video surveillance camera on their property that also covered the public space and the neighboring property. The AEPD has discovered that such extensive video surveillance was a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: France
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR, Art. 31 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The French DPA has fined Clearview AI Inc. with EUR 20,000,000. The company has a database of more than 20 billion facial images, including those of French nationals and residents from around the world. This data is collected online from publicly accessible platforms like social networks. The data controller offers a search service that lets individuals to be identified based on the biometric data that’s extracted from these images. Individuals’ profiles can be further enriched with information associated with those images like image tags and geolocation. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the personal data contained in the company’s database had been processed unlawfully and without a valid legal basis. Moreover, the DPA discovered that Clearview AI had restricted the exercise of data subjects’ rights. For instance, it limited the exercise of then data subjects’ rights to twice a year without any justification. Also, data subjects had to submit several requests before even one was answered. Moreover, requests were often not answered at all or were only answered inadequately. Finally, the DPA criticized the cooperation of Clearview AI since the company did not respond to investigation forms at all or only very incompletely.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA (also known as ANSPDCP) has fined SC Materiale Constructii Online SRL with EUR 2,000 because the company failed to provide information requested by the DPA during an investigation.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined a private individual with EUR 150. The individual had previously made unauthorized use of another person’s personal data without obtaining their consent first.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined a company with EUR 6,000 because the data controller had previously installed several video surveillance cameras that also recorded sound. However, the DPA discovered that the data controller did not have a sufficient legal basis for this surveillance, and that the recordings were obtained unlawfully.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Immobiliare Riscostruzione Meloria s.r.l. with EUR 2,000. The data controller had installed a video surveillance system at its office that also covered parts of the common entrance to the building, recording residents of the building. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the information signs regarding the video surveillance contained neither sufficient information about the purpose of the data processing, nor the contact details of the data controller.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined the gas station operator with EUR 3,000. A person had previously filed a complaint to the DPA against the data controller because the latter failed to grant them access to the images of their minor child recorded by the video surveillance system in the gas station. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of Art. 12 GDPR. Moreover, the operator shared these images with the police during the investigation without informing the parent first. The DPA also discovered that the failure to inform the parent was a violation of Art. 14 GDPR.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 30 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined a school with EUR 15,000. The school had previously installed several video surveillance cameras on the building that permanently recorded the teachers, students, and visitors. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the school didn’t have a sufficient legal basis for the video surveillance. Regarding the extensive video surveillance and the restriction of the personal rights of the data subjects, the school couldn’t rely on a legitimate interest to do this. Moreover, the DPA also discovered that the data controller had violated its duty to inform by only informing teachers and parents verbally and incompletely about the video surveillance system.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined ALFA BANK S.A. with EUR 20,000. Regarding the use of certain debit/credit cards, information about the last 10 transactions were stored on the chip of the card without the explicit consent of the customers. This information could be read later by anyone. The DPA discovered that the bank had failed to inform the affected customers about the storage of this transaction information and violated Art. 13 GDPR.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined the EUROBANK ERGASIAS S.A. with EUR 20,000. The Hellenic DPA has fined EUROBANK ERGASIAS S.A. with EUR 20,000. Regarding the use of certain debit/credit cards, information about the last 10 transactions were stored on the chip of the card without the explicit consent of the customers. This information could be read later by anyone. The DPA discovered that the bank had failed to inform the affected customers about the storage of this transaction information and violated Art. 13 GDPR.

allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined PIRAEUS BANK S.A. with EUR 20,000. allItems.name: Greece
