allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined NATIONAL BANK OF GREECE S.A. with EUR 20,000. Regarding the use of certain debit/credit cards, information about the last 10 transactions were stored on the chip of the card without the explicit consent of the customers. This information could be read later by anyone. The DPA discovered that the bank had failed to inform the affected customers about the storage of this transaction information and violated Art. 13 GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 1,000. The data controller had previously installed several video surveillance cameras that also covered the public space, among other things. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Bper Banca S.p.A. with EUR 10,000. An individual had previously filed a complaint to the DPA about the failure of the data controller to fulfill their right to erasure of personal data. The individual had requested the bank to delete their personal data that had been processed by the institutions. However, the bank asked the data subject to send their identification documents so they can verify his identity and fulfill the request. The data subject submitted this data but did not receive any response to their request. This is why the DPA concluded that the bank had violated Art. 12 GDPR by failing to respond to the request in a timely manner.

allItems.name: United Kingdom
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The British DPA has fined the construction group Interserve Group Limited with EUR 5,033,000. The data controller had previously notified the DPA about a data breach as per Art. 33 GDPR. Interserve had suffered a cyber attack in the past where the attackers had sent a phishing email to the mailbox of the company’s accounting team. The email had been opened by an employee who also downloaded and opened the zip file contained in the attachment. This made it possible for the attackers to install malware and steal personal data of 113,000 employees. The stolen data contained the social security numbers, bank account information, sexual orientation, ethnicity, and religion of the data subjects. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the attack was made possible because of inadequate security measures. Interserve employees had not been adequately trained on data privacy and the company processes personal data on unsupported operating systems that did not receive security updates anymore, so new system vulnerabilities weren’t covered. Moreover, Interserve had not conducted the adequate vulnerability scans and the information security team did not sufficiently investigate the attack because the antivirus software installed on the systems reported that the malware had been removed.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Servicio Idrico Integrato S.c.p.a. with EUR 15,000. The data controller had previously operated a website where the personal data was being processes without the use of SSL forms. The DPA discovered that the use of an SSL form was necessary to thoroughly protect the data. So, the DPA concluded that the data controller failed to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 30 (2) GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della Privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Clio S.r.l. with EUR 10,000. The company manages a whistleblowing reporting application for publica and private entities. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that Clio had not sufficiently regulated its relationship to the customers. Moreover, the company provided data on whistleblowing reports to customer without having a legal basis to do so. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR and Art. 6 GDPR. Lastly, the DPA found that the company had failed to maintain a register of its activities carried out in the role of data processor. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of Art. 30 (2) GDPR.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 28 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Acqua Novara.VCO S.p.a. with EUR 20,000. This fine is related to the fine issued to Clio S.r.l. which provided and managed a whistleblowing reporting application for public and private entities. Acqua Novara was one of its clients. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that Acqua Novara offered personal data to Clio in connection to several whistleblowing reports, which allowed Clio to collect and store the data without a valid legal basis. Lastly, the DPA concluded that Acqua Novara had not adequately regulated its relationship with Clio.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (AEPD) has fined a company with EUR 240. The data controller had installed video surveillance cameras which, among other things, also covered the public space. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. The original fine of EUR 300 was reduced to EUR 240 because of voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 400. The data controller had previously installed several video surveillance cameras which, among other things, also covered the public space. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 48 (1) b) LGT, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 23 (4) LOPDGDD
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) fined ADSL HOUSE, S.L. with EUR 8,000. The data subject had received advertising calls from the data controller, although the data subject was registered in the Robinson advertising exclusion list

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Thiene Municipality with EUR 3,000. One of the municipality’s former employees filed a complaint to the DPA because a document that contained their personal data was published on the municipality’s website. This document contained information about the termination of their employment relationship. The Italian DPA concluded that this was a violation of Art. 5 (1) a), c), GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, and Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy.

allItems.name: France
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 28 (3) GDPR, Art. 82 Loi informatique et libertés
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The French DPA has fined CITYSCOOT with EUR 125,000. The company apparently rents motor scooters for short periods of time. During the investigation, the DPA found out that CITYSCOOT had been collecting vehicle geolocation data every 30 seconds while renting the scooters, and was also storing the history of the trips. The company had claimed that they were collecting this data for the purpose of handling traffic violations, complaint inquiries, and helping users in the case of a crash, as well as handling theft cases. However, the DPA discovered that these reasons did not justify the permanent geolocation of the data subjects, and the company had violated the principle of data minimization by doing this. Moreover, the DPA found out that the contracts concluded by the company with its data processors did not contain all the necessary information.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c), e) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Tehnoplus Industry SRL with EUR 5,000. One of the company’s employees had complained to the DPA against the data controller because the latter had installed a GPS system in their company vehicle for monitoring the vehicle without offering them enough information about this installation. During the investigation, the DPA also discovered that the data controller had been processing the GPS data outside working hours and for other purposes than those originally stated. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. Moreover, the data controller was not able to prove that it did not store data for longer than legally permitted.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fiend a private individual with EUR 450. This individual in question had published personal data of several people on a social media network without obtaining their consent first.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined Orange Espagne S.A.U. with EUR 70,000 after an individual had complained to the DPA because the company in question had given a duplicate of their SIM card to an unauthorized fraudulent third party without their consent. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the company had failed to verify the identity of this third party or obtain the consent of the data subject when sharing their personal data. This let the fraudsters gain access to the data subject’s bank account and make unauthorized transactions.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.controller: CAIXABANK PAYMENTS & CONSUMER EFC, EP, S.A.U.
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined CAIXABANK PAYMENTS & CONSUMER EFC, EP, S.A.U. with EUR 70,000. The data subject had previously received a message from a debt collection company on behalf of Caixabank where it requested the payment of outstanding debts. However, the debt in question had previously been annulled which had been confirmed in a court ruling. For this reason, the DPA concluded that the disclosure of the data subject’s personal data for the purpose of being contacted regarding the debt settlement was unlawful.

allItems.name: Luxembourg
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The DPA of Luxembourg has fined a company with EUR 1,000. This company provides online services to citizens, and during the investigation, the DPA found that the company in question had not offered enough information about the data processing in an intelligible, transparent, concise and easily accessible form. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of Art. 12 (1) GDPR.

allItems.name: Luxembourg
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The DPA of Luxembourg has fined a company with EUR 2,500. This company provides online services to citizens, and during the investigation, the DPA found that the company in question had not offered enough information about the data processing in an intelligible, transparent, concise and easily accessible form. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of Art. 12 (1) GDPR.

allItems.name: Luxembourg
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The DPA of Luxembourg has fined a company with EUR 2,100. This company provides online services to citizens, and during the investigation, the DPA found that the company in question had not offered enough information about the data processing in an intelligible, transparent, concise and easily accessible form. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of Art. 12 (1) GDPR. Moreover, the DPA also concluded that the data controller had failed to offer the data subjects enough information about the processing of their personal data, violating Art. 13 GDPR as well.

allItems.name: Luxembourg
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The DPA of Luxembourg has fined a company with EUR 700. This company provides online services to citizens, and during the investigation, the DPA found that the company in question had not offered enough information about the data processing in an intelligible, transparent, concise and easily accessible form. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of Art. 12 (1) GDPR. Moreover, the DPA also concluded that the data controller had failed to offer the data subjects sufficient information about the transfer of their personal data to a third country or international organization, violating Art. 13 GDPR as a result.

allItems.name: Luxembourg
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The DPA of Luxembourg has fined a company with EUR 1,400. This company provides online services to citizens, and during the investigation, the DPA found that the company in question had not offered enough information about the data processing in an intelligible, transparent, concise and easily accessible form. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of Art. 12 (1) GDPR. Moreover, the DPA also concluded that the data controller had failed to offer the data subjects enough information about the processing of their personal data, violating Art. 13 GDPR as well.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined the SOCIEDAD ESPANOLA DE RADIODIFUSION, S.L. with EUR 50,000. Multiple media outlets, including the data controller in question, had published an audio recording of a rape victim’s testimony in court on their official websites as a way to report on the case. This case had attracted a lot of media attention at the time. During the investigation, the DPA concluded that the right to privacy of the rape victim outweighed the data controller’s freedom of information. Moreover, the audio recordings of the victim added no significant value to the reporting but rather compromised the victim’s privacy. This is why the DPA concluded that the data controller violated the principle of data minimization.

allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined the LA VANGUARDIA EDICIONES, S.L. with EUR 50,000. allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The DPA of Bremen fined a physician because he failed to respond to a data subject’s request for data access in a timely manner.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The DPA of Bremen imposed a fine on a physician for failing to respond to a data subject’s request for access to their data within a given timeline.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The DPA of Bremen imposed a fine on a physician because he used a patient’s contact details to contact them in private without their consent.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The DPA of Bremen fined a physician for transmitting the patient’s data to a billing office without their consent.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The DPA of Bremen fined a private individual who worked in a restaurant and had contacted a restaurant visitor in private using the contact information that they had provided during a restaurant visit in the Covid 19 pandemic.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The DPA of Bremen fined a private individual. The person in question was working a Covid 19 testing center and had contacted a patient privately using the contact details they had provided for their Covid test.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The DPA of Bremen has fined a company with a five-digit amount because the data controller had been unlawfully using GDS software in its company vehicles. This allowed for the unrestricted monitoring of its employees ever long periods of time. The DPA claimed that such an extensive monitoring was not needed and was unlawful as a result.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The DPA of Bremen has imposed a five-digit fine on a company. The company had apparently sent an unredacted and unencrypted social plan to all the affected employees regarding the dismissals caused by operational reasons. This resulted in the disclosure of the personal data contained inside the social plan, including age, date of birth, number of dependent children, marital status, severe disability, function in the company, and other details of all the employees. The DPA discovered that this extensive disclosure of personal data was unlawful because of a lack of legal basis. The DPA also concluded that special categories of personal data (information about severe disabilities, for instance), had been disclosed and this was an aggravating factor.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The DPA of Bremen has fined a company with a five-digit amount because the company had transferred the pay slips of all its employees to another company without their consent. This company would continue to employ the employees in the future. The DPA concluded it to be an aggravating factor that there was a high double-digit number of employees who had been affected by this.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Failure to notify DPA of a data breach
allItems.summary: The DPA from Bremen has fined a company because it failed to inform the DPA (as per Art. 33 GDPR) about a hack that had occurred on an employee’s business email account.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The DPA of Bremen has fined a company with a three-digit amount because it had offered its applications an online application process on its website without ever informing the users about the processing of their personal data.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Unknown
allItems.summary: The DPA of Bremen has fined a medical care center because the latter had scanned a customer’s ID card against their will and stored the copy for themselves. After the customer issued a complaint, they were threatened with the termination of their customer relationship. When assessing the fine, the DPA took into consideration that fact that the ID card had been scanned even though the data subject had explicitly objected to this.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Unknown
allItems.summary: The DPA of Bremen has fined a supermarket because a store detective had taken a photo of the data subject regarding an alleged theft and had transmitted it via WhatsApp to the manager, two closing staff members, and the store manager. This was allegedly done to enforce the house rules but it did not have a sufficient legal basis.

allItems.name: United Kingdom
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The UK DPA (also known as ICO) has fined TikTok with EUR 14.5 million. The ICO had previously discovered that more than one million British children under 13 had been using TikTok without the consent of their parents. The ICO criticized TikTok because it had failed to implement the necessary measures that would identify and remove the underage children from the platform. Moreover, the ICO discovered that TikTok had not provided the users of the platform with sufficient and easily-understandable information about the data collection, use and disclosure. This is why the ICO concluded that TikTok had not ensured the lawfulness, fairness, and transparency of the data processing of its users.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Tensa Art Design SRL with EUR 3,000. An individual had previously complained to the DPA about receiving promotional messages even though he had filed an objection to receiving marketing messages and having their data processed for marketing purposes. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of Art. 21 (3) GDPR.

allItems.name: Poland
allItems.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 28 (1), (3), (9) GDPR, Art. 33 (1) GDPR, Art. 34 (1), (2) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Polish DPA has fined a housing association with EUR 321. The data controller had gone through a data breach that involved the theft of some documents, including a copy of a notarial deed. During the investigation the DPA discovered that the data controller had failed to report the data breach to the DPA in a given timeframe and to notify the data subjects who were affected by the data breach. Moreover, the DPA found out that the data controller had not comprehensively verified that the data processor was offering sufficient guarantees to implement the required organizational and technical measures to ensure data protection.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.controller: ATRESMEDIA CORPORACION DE MEDIOS DE COMUNICACION, S.A.
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined the ATRESMEDIA CORPORACION DE MEDIOS DE COMUNICACION, S.A. with EUR 50,000. Multiple media outlets, including the data controller in question, had published an audio recording of a rape victim’s testimony in court on their official websites as a way to report on the case. This case had attracted a lot of media attention at the time. During the investigation, the DPA concluded that the right to privacy of the rape victim outweighed the data controller’s freedom of information. Moreover, the audio recordings of the victim added no significant value to the reporting but rather compromised the victim’s privacy. This is why the DPA concluded that the data controller violated the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined ENFOKA SISTEMAS GLOBALES, S.L. with EUR 18,000. A customer had previously complained to the DPA that the data controller had carried out a change of their electricity supply company without getting their consent first. The original fine of EUR 30,000 was reduced to EUR 18,000 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 300 because he had failed to offer sufficient information about a video surveillance system that was installed on their property.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined 20 MINUTOS EDITORA, S.L. with EUR 50,000. Multiple media outlets, including the data controller in question, had published an audio recording of a rape victim’s testimony in court on their official websites as a way to report on the case. This case had attracted a lot of media attention at the time. During the investigation, the DPA concluded that the right to privacy of the rape victim outweighed the data controller’s freedom of information. Moreover, the audio recordings of the victim added no significant value to the reporting but rather compromised the victim’s privacy. This is why the DPA concluded that the data controller violated the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 300 because he had failed to offer sufficient information about a video surveillance system that was installed on their property.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined INMARAN ASESORES S.L. with EUR 1,000 because it had failed to comply with an order issued by the DPA.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 114 Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined a store owner with EUR 3,000. The data controller had operated several video surveillance cameras on its premises without obtaining the required authorization first. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the information signs about the processing of the personal data through the cameras were also missing.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.controller: Azienda socio-sanitaria locale nr. 1 di Sassari
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Azienda socio-sanitaria locale nr. 1 di Sassari with EUR 4,000. The data controller had sent a document that contained health data of the data subject to the wrong recipient by mistake. The DPA discovered that the healthcare facility had not taken enough organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The unlawful use of a dashcam

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 32 (1) GDPR, Art. 33 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: A logistics company had disposed of the delivery lists in a public waste paper container. This list contained a large amount of detailed information like the first and last names of subscribers, their addresses, subscribed newspapers, and special delivery information like the location of their mailboxes and complaints from recipients. The DPA also noticed that the company had failed to inform the data subjects or the DPA about the data breach in a timely manner.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The DPA of Hamburg has fined a Covid-19 test center with EUR 1,000 because it did not comply with the right of the data subjects to have their personal data deleted.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: A physician’s office had disposed of several records of positive and negative Covid-19 Antigen Rapid tests from patients in a public waste disposal site.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The DPA of Hamburg has fined a Covid-19 Test Center with EUR 2,700. The Test Center had sent the data subjects an unencrypted e-mail that contained a URL which allowed them to access the test results without ever taking any other security measure. In some cases, the download link was even structured in such a way that it led to the download of a PDF file where the file name corresponded to the last name of the person tested. With enough knowledge about the directory path, it was possible for others to view third-party test results.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 180. The data controller had failed to offer any notice with information about the video surveillance on its premises. The original fine of EUR 300 was reduced to EUR 180 because of voluntary payment and admission of responsibility.

allItems.name: Luxembourg
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 37 (7) GDPR, Art. 38 (1), (3) GDPR, Art. 39 (1) b) GDPR
allItems.type: No data protection officer appointed
allItems.summary: The DPA of Luxembourg has fined a company with EUR 18,700. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the public website of the data controller did not include the contact details for the DPO. Moreover, the DPO was not sufficiently involved in all the data protection matters. For instance, the DPO had only participated in internal meetings by invitation alone. There were also multiple hierarchical intermediaries between the highest management level of the data controller and the DPO, which did not grant the DPO enough autonomy. Lastly, because of the absence of formalized procedures, the DPO could not sufficiently monitor the consistency of the data processing practices.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined ALI MARKET with EUR 360. The data controller had failed to offer a notice with information about the video surveillance on its premises. Moreover, the data controller had also failed to make a proper register of the processing activities.

allItems.name: Ireland
allItems.controller: A&G Couriers Limited T/A Fastway Couriers (Ireland)
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Irish DPA (also known as DPC) has fined the A&G Couriers Limited T/A Fastway Couriers (Ireland) with EUR 15,000. Apparently, during of the changeovers of the IT systems, the data controller had suffered a cyberattack that allowed unauthorized third parties access to personal data. The DPA discovered that the data controller had failed to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data, thus facilitating the attack.

allItems.name: Finland
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The Finnish DPA has fined Suomen Asiakastieto Oy with EUR 440,000. Apparently, the company failed to comply with an order issued by the DPA. During an investigation, the DPA discovered that the company had unlawfully stored financial data of multiple data subjects. The DPA then ordered the company to remove this data but the company refused to comply.

allItems.name: Croatia
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Croatian DPA (also known as azop) has fined a telecommunications company with EUR 20,000. One of the data subjects had filed a complaint to the DPA saying that the company was processing their personal data even though they had not been a customer of the company for more than ten years. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the company was still storing the data because of an alleged debt. This debt was not longer outstanding, though, but the company did not delete the data of the data subject because of a lack of measures required to verify that the stored data was up to date and accurate. The DPA then concluded that the company had been unlawfully processing the data of the data subject, acting in violation with Art. 6 (1) GDPR and Art. 5 (1) d) GDPR.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 32 (1) b), c) GDPR, Art. 32 (2) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Finopro IFN SA with EUR 2,250 after the data controller had suffered a ransomware attack where unauthorized third parties had gained access to the personal data (addresses, credit card details, telephone numbers, bank account information, etc.) of multiple data subjects. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller had not implemented the required organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 32 (1) b), c) GDPR, Art. 32 (2) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Integral Collection SRL with EUR 3,000 after the data controller had suffered a ransomware attack where unauthorized third parties had gained access to the personal data (addresses, credit card details, telephone numbers, bank account information, etc.) of multiple data subjects. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller had not implemented the required organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Mondaone SRL with EUR 2,000 after an individual had filed a complaint with the DPA saying that they were receiving messages through email from the data controller even though they had objected to receiving such messages and this was confirmed by the data controller. During the investigation, the DPA also discovered that the data controller had not offered the data subjects with the sufficient, accurate, and up-to-date information about the processing of their personal data. Moreover, the DPA concluded that the requirements for exercising these data subject rights were inadequate.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Alianța pentru Unirea Românilor with EUR 10,000. During the investigation, the DPA concluded that the data controller was collecting personal data on tis website without informing the data subjects and without acting in a lawful manner concerning the data processing laws. The DPA also discovered that the data controller has been collecting data such as surname, last name, address, ID card number, and more not only on the official lwebsite but also on various forms that users could fill. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Partidul Uniunea Salvați România with EUR 4,000. The data controller had suffered a phishing attack where the attackers gained unauthorized access to personal data of data subjects, including first name, last name, phone number, email address, and the political affiliation of the data subjects. The DPA discovered that the data controller had failed to implement the required organizational measures like data encryption to protect this personal data, thus facilitating this type of attack on the organization.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Tinmar Energy SA with EUR 3,000. The data controller had suffered a data breach where numerous third parties had gained unauthorized access to the personal data of data subjects, including first and last name, address, phone number, and more. The DPA discovered that the data controller had failed to implement the required organizational measures like data encryption to protect this personal data, thus facilitating this type of attack on the organization.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Centrul Medical Dr. Furtună Dan with EUR 1,000 after the data controller had sent the results to a medical test through WhatsApp to the wrong recipient. As a result, the personal data of the data subject (first and last name, medical data and telephone number) was disclosed to third parties without authorization. The DPA discovered that the data controller had not implemented the required organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 32 (1) b) GDPR, Art. 32 (2) GDPR, Art. 32 (4) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: Art. 32 (1) b) GDPR, Art. 32 (2) GDPR, Art. 32 (4) GDPR

allItems.name: Poland
allItems.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 24 (1) GDPR, Art. 25 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 32 (1), (2) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Polish DPA has fined the Szczecin-Centrum District Court with EUR 6,400. Apparently, the court had reported a data breach to the DPA that involved the loss of three data carriers. One of the data carriers was an encrypted official one, while the other two ones were private and unencrypted that contained drafts of court rulings and statements with personal data. During the course of the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data carriers had not been verified and secured by the court’s IT department and had been used on unencrypted computers for many years. Moreover, the DPA discovered that, despite being regulations that prohibited the use of private data carriers, the court did not check whether employees actually complied with these regulations. Lastly, the court also failed to implement the necessary technical measures that would prevent the use of such private data carriers.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined a private individual with EUR 5,000. The data controller had sent an email that contained personal data to several recipients in an open distribution list. This made it possible for all the recipients to view the email and the addresses of the other recipients.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 480 because the data controller had installed a video surveillance camera that also covered the public space and a neighboring property. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. Moreover, the data controller had also failed to inform any data subjects about the processing of the data through the video surveillance system, violating its duty to inform. The original fine of EUR 600 was reduced to EUR 480 because of voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined an attorney with EUR 4,000. The attorney had sent a court ruling that contained the personal data of a data subject to various individuals on WhatsApp without the consent of the data subject.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined a private individual because he had filed a complaint against their ex-partner to the DPA. The ex-partner had installed several video surveillance cameras in the jointly occupied residency that also recorded various parts of their private living areas and the jointly used parts of the residency. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. The original fine of EUR 300 was also reduced to EUR 240 because of voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Azienda ULSS n.5 Polesana with EUR 5,000. The healthcare facility had mistakenly sent a patient medical record to the wrong, and unauthorized patient. The DPA discovered that the healthcare facility had failed to take the necessary organizational and technical measures that would protect this personal data, allowing such incidents to occur.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.controller: Ufficio Scolastico Regionale per la Lombardia, Ufficio IV – Ambio Territoriale di Brescia
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy, Art. 2-septies (8) Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Ufficio Scolastico Regionale per la Lombardia, Ufficio IV – Ambio Territoriale di Brescia with EUR 6,000. Apparently, the school board had published a document that also contained the personal health data of a teacher on its official website. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that that school had published this personal data without a valid legal basis and had acted unlawfully while doing this.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Vodafone Espana, S.A.U. with EUR 136,000. One of the company’s data subjects had filed a complaint to the DPA claiming that unauthorized fraudsters had managed to access their Vodafone account and made changes to their contract. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that Vodafone had carried out these changes without verifying the actual identity of the person who was requesting them and without determining that the requests were made by the data subject in question. The original fine of EUR 170,000 was reduced to EUR 136,000 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Ireland
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Irish DPA has fined the Bank of Ireland 365 with EUR 750,000. The bank had then notified the DPA of 10 data breaches related to the bank’s app. Unauthorized individuals had managed to gain access to the app and various individuals’ accounts. The DPA concluded that these data breaches were facilitated by the fact that the bank failed to implement the required organizational and technical measures to protect the personal data.

allItems.name: Norway
allItems.type: Failure to notify DPA of a data breach
allItems.summary: The Norwegian DPA has fined Argon Medical Devices with EUR 220,000 when the data controller had failed to notify the DPA about a data breach that involved the personal data of all its European employees within 72 hours.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The DPA of Baden-Wurttemberg has fined a pharmacy with EUR 6,500 because the latter had improperly disposed of a large number of personal documents. These documents included medical prescriptions and diagnoses of data subjects, and were disposed of in trash containers that were accessible to other people.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Unknown
allItems.summary: The DPA from Baden-Wurttemberg has fined a company with EUR 20,000. Apparently, the company in question had developed a new office plan that looked at the vaccination status of its employees. For information purposes, this office place that showed the new occupancy was then sent to the employees. Every employee had been assigned wit ha color (yellow, red, green) depending on their vaccination status. The DPA concluded that this color system allowed the disclosure of the vaccination status of all the company’s employees, making it unlawful as a result.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Unknown
allItems.summary: The DPA from Baden-Wurttemberg has fined a restaurant with EUR 500 because the owner of the establishment had disposed of a large quantity of COVID contact forms in a nearby forest.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The DPA from Baden-Wurttemberg has fiend a debt collection company with an unknown fine. The company in question had received various investor information from one of the employees of an insolvent company which it had previously used to offer its services to assist the affected investors that had insolvency claims. However, the DPA concluded that the company had unlawfully processed the personal data without a legal basis. Moreover, the debt collection company had failed to provide the data subjects with the necessary information like the origin of their personal data.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) b), e) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 7 GDPR, Art. 12 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 (2) a) GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR, Art. 25 (1) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Douglas Italia S.p.a. with EUR 1,400,000 for various GDPR violations. During its investigation, the Italian DPA initially discovered that the customers were forced to give their consent to the privacy notices, the GTC and the cookie policy at the same time. However, the DPA claimed that this was a breach of Art. 6 GDPR and Art. 7 GDPR because the data subjects’ consent to the processing of their personal data could not have been given freely and voluntarily because of the lack of separate options for consenting to different notices. In the meantime, Douglas had also merged with other companies and also acquired additional personal data as a result. The DPA concluded that after it had acquired this personal data, Douglas had kept it for an excessive period of time without obtaining any consent from the data subjects regarding the use of their personal data for its own purposes. The DPA also discovered that Douglas had kept the personal data of customers who had not renewed their loyalty cards for an excessive period of time. Moreover, Douglas had not provided with customers with accurate nor sufficient information about the data processing. For instance, many of these customers were receiving SMS marketing messages even though they had only consented to telemarketing. In the end, the DPA concluded that Douglas had breached its accountability obligations regarding the processing of the clients’ personal data.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Societa Lombarda Sport s.r.l. with EUR 4,000 because an individual had filed a complaint to the DPA against the company. Apparently, the data subject had undergone a sports fitness examination at this company for the purpose of attending sports courses. However, the company had then sent the result of this examination without a valid legal basis.

allItems.name: Belgium
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) d) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 24 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 (1), (2) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Belgian DPA has fined a company with EUR 2,500. Apparently, the company in question was operating a digital management platform where customers and suppliers could communicate and upload administrative documents. One particular individual who is not a member of this platform had complained to the DPA. As it stands, the complainant’s roommate is a member of this platform and the complainant had asked them to upload the joint water bill, and this bill was in the complainant’s name. The platform then recognized the complainant’s name and sent the roommate an invitation to connect to additional companies through the platform where the complainant was a customer. Even though the roommate had not accepted this invitation, they could view specific data regarding the complainant. The DPA also discovered that the company had not implemented the appropriate organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal in order to prevent easy access from third parties.

allItems.name: Norway
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), e) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 12 (1), (3) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Norwegian DPA has fined a fitness chain named Sats with EUR 900,000. The DPA had received several complaints from numerous customers who had submitted requests for information and the deletion of their personal data, but Sats had not complied with these requests. The DPA also discovered that Sats had processed a lot of customer data without a valid legal basis.

allItems.name: Luxembourg
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The DPA of Luxembourg (also known as CNPD) has fined a company with EUR 10,000. The company in question had installed a video surveillance system in order to protect the company staff and property. However, these cameras also constantly captured parts of the break room, employee’s work areas, a meeting room, and even a neighboring property. The DPA claims that the data controller had violated the principle of data minimization as per Art. 5 (1) c GDPR because of excessive CCTV. Moreover, the DPA also discovered a violation of the principle of information obligations as set by Art. 13 GDPR because the company had not properly informed the data subjects about the video surveillance.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 600. Apparently, the individual in question (data controller) had installed several video surveillance cameras that also captured the public space, among other things. The DPA concluded that this was a severe violation of the principle of data minimization. Moreover, the data controller had also violated its information obligations by not properly informing the data subjects about the processing of their personal data via the video surveillance cameras.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined COMANDANCIA DE LLEIDA with EUR 300. The data controller had not provided a notice with information regarding the video surveillance system on its premises.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 300 because he had failed to provide sufficient information about a video surveillance system posted on his property.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 300. Apparently, the individual in question (data controller) had installed several video surveillance cameras that also captured a neighboring property, among other things. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization and issued a fine.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 300. Apparently, the individual in question (data controller) had installed several video surveillance cameras that also captured the public space, among other things. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization and issued a fine.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined SUPER 24H LOS ROSALES, S.L. with EUR 180 because the data controller had not provided any notice with information about the video surveillance on its premises. The original fine of EUR 300 was reduced to EUR 180 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 1,200. The data controller had apparently installed several video surveillance cameras that also captured the public space, among other areas. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. Moreover, the data controller had also not properly informed the data subjects about the video surveillance system.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined PLANET COSTA DORADA SOCIEDAD LIMITADA with EUR 300. Apparently, the company had not provided any information notice about the video surveillance system installed on its premises.

allItems.name: Ireland
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Irish DPA has fined Centric Health Ltd. with EUR 460,000. The data controller had suffered a ransomware attack where the personal data such as the name, date of birth and contact details had been accessed, altered and destroyed without express authorization. The data records of more than 70,000 people had been affected, and 2,500 of them had been permanently affected. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the healthcare facility had not implement the proper organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data, thus facilitating such an attack.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 28 GDPR, Art. 37 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Amiu S.p.A. with EUR 200,000. Apparently, the company in question operates a waste collection service for the city of Tarento, and has acted as a processor for this service. The company had also installed several video surveillance cameras for the express purpose of monitoring any illegal waste disposal. However, the DPA discovered that Amiu had posted these images on Facebook, showing some individuals who were sufficient visible that they could be identified. During this investigation, the DPA discovered that Amiu did not have any valid legal basis to publish these images. They also found out that the data processing was not sufficiently regulated, as Art. 28 of the GDPR required in these cases. In the end, the DPA stated that Amiu had not even appointed a data protection officer.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 28 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Tarento municipality with EUR 150,000. Apparently, the company Amiu S.p.A. had operated the local waste collection service for the municipality in question. The company had also installed several video surveillance cameras for the express purpose of monitoring any illegal waste disposal. However, the DPA discovered that Amiu had posted these images on Facebook, showing some individuals who were sufficient visible that they could be identified. During the investigation, the DPA found that the municipality had improperly regulated the processing of data with Amiu S.p.A. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the municipality had not properly offered sufficient information about the video surveillance cameras installed by Amiu. The municipality also failed to conduct a data protection impact assessment concerning the installation of these video surveillance cameras. This would have been necessary considering the scope of such a large-scale systematic surveillance.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Veneto region with EUR 100,000. The DPA had received a complaint from several nursing and medical staff. Once the investigation started, the DPA discovered that, in the context of Covid-19 containment measures, the Region had offered lists of information about unvaccinated employees to various healthcare facilities as well as the physicians in charge there. The DPA discovered that the Region had no valid legal basis for such a systematic disclosure of these lists to the physicians. Only the disclosure of the lists to the relevant health authorities was covered by the legal degree imposed at that time.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 28 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Verizon Connect Italy S.p.A. with EUR 30,000. Apparently, an individual who had worked for a Verizon customer had complained to the DPA. Verizon had installed GPS systems in the delivery vehicles for their customers and was acting as a processor for them. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the relationship between the customer and Verizon was not sufficient regulated as requested by Art. 28 GDPR. As a result, the DPA found that the data that was processed as part of this commissioned data processing was done so without a valid legal basis for a long period of time.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 7 GDPR, Art. 12 (1), (2), (3) GDPR, Art. 21 (2) GDPR, Art. 24 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 25 (1) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Edison Energia with EUR 4.9 million. Several individuals had filed complaints against the company to the DPA for unlawful marketing activities. During their subsequent investigation, the DPA discovered that the company had contacted the data subjects by telephone for marketing purposes without obtaining their consent first. To this end, the company had used the contacts lists for certain third parties that, in many cases, had not contained any free, specific, informed, or documented consent taken from these users regarding the disclosure of their personal data. The DPA also found that Edison Energia had not provided the data subjects with an easy and direct method of objecting to the processing of their personal data. Moreover, Edison Energia had not responded the data subjects’ requests in a timely manner. What’s more, the DPA also found that the users of the company’s app and website had simultaneously consented to the user of their personal data for profiling and marketing purposes. This type of consent, according to the DPA, does not correspond to a specific or voluntary consent for both purposes simultaneously. In the end, the DPA discovered that Edison Energia had not provided its data subjects with transparent information about the processing of their personal data.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish (also known as AEPD) DPA has fined a private individual with EUR 1,500. Apparently, the data controller had sent an email that contained personal data to several recipients in an open distribution list. Obviously, this provided access to every member of that list to see the email addresses of all the other members.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined HERON CITY VALENCIA MANAGEMENT, S.L. with EUR 10,000. One of the data subjects had complained to the DPA that the data controller had not complied with their request for data access to the recordings of the video surveillance system where the data subjects was also captured.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual. The individual in question had apparently shared a document that contained the personal data of the data subject in a WhatsApp group without obtaining the consent of the data subject first. The original fine of EUR 500 was reduced to EUR 300 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined GRUPO NORCONSULTING, S.L. with EUR 15,000. Apparently, a data subject had complained to the DPA that the data controller had not properly complied with their request for the access and deletion of their personal data, which prompted the DPA to issue a fine.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined EUROPYMES SERVICIONS INTERGRALES, S.L. with EUR 800. The data controller had not properly complied with a data subject’s request for the erasure of their personal data. The original fine of EUR 1,000 was reduced to EUR 800 because of voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Vodafone Espana, S.A.U. with EUR 56,000. Apparently, someone had filed a complaint to the DPA saying that the company had given a duplicate of their SIM card to an unauthorized third party (fraudulent one) without their consent. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the company had not verified the identity of this third party and had not obtained the data subjects consent to share the data. This allowed the fraudsters to obtain access to the data subject’s bank account and also to make unauthorized transactions. The original of EUR 70,000 was reduced to EUR 56,000 because of voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 114 Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the owner of the store “Woolen” with EUR 3,000. The data controller had operated several video surveillance cameras on its premises without the required authorization. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the information signs about the processing of personal data by the cameras were not where they should be (missing).

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy, Art. 2-septies (8) Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined A.R.N.A.S. Civico with EUR 6,000 because two employees of the data controller had filed a complaint to the DPA. After the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller had previously published two documents that contained personal health data of the data subjects online without obtaining their consent, making that data public in the process.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Amazon Italia Logistics s.r.l. with EUR 20,000. One of the former employees of the company had requested documents from the data controller, however they did not receive them in due time. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller had not properly fulfilled its obligation to comply with the data subject’s request for data access.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Insufficient fulfilment of information obligations
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined Thomas International Systems. S.A. with EUR 40,000. The company performs psychological tests for other companies. In this particular instance, the company had conducted such a test for the company Agroxarxa, S.L. One of the participants to the test had complained to the data controller that they had to provide sensitive personal data (disability, ethnicity). However, Agroxarxa had clearly stated that the test did not request nor process such sensitive data. During the investigation the DPA discovered that that Thomas International had processed this sensitive personal data without obtaining the data subject’s and without it being necessary for the fulfillment of the contract between Agroxarxa and Thomas International. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of Art. 9 GDPR. The original fine of EUR 50,000 was reduced to EUR 40,000 because of voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Dante Internațional SA with EUR 1,000. One of the data subjects had filed a complaint to the DPA against the data controller because the data controller kept sending them advertisements even though the data subject had requested the deletion of their data.

allItems.name: Ireland
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 (1) c) GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Irish DPA (also known as DPC) has fined WhatsApp Ireland with EUR 5.5 million. The Austrian Organization “None of Your Business” (NOYB) had complained to the DPA on behalf of a data subject. WhatsApp had recently updated its terms of service shortly after the GDPR came into force. In the ToS, WhatsApp informed its users to click “Agree and Continue” to show that they agree with the new terms of service. This was also required for further access to the messaging service. WhatsApp assumed that this consent to the updated Terms of Service constituted a contract between the user and WhatsApp Ireland because the data processing would have been necessary for the provision and the improvements of the messaging service. The data processing was, therefore, lawful according to Art. 6 (1) b) GDPR. However, the complainant claimed that WhatsApp was trying to process the users’ data by relying on the fact that this consent was lawful. WhatsApp Ireland actually forced users to consent to the processing of their personal data by making access to its services conditional on the users’ consent to the updated Terms of Service. After the investigation, the DPC submitted a draft decision under Art. 60 GDPR to the other European supervisory authorities implicated. The DPC discovered that WhatsApp had not relied on user content as a legal basis, which further means that “coerced consent” did not apply in this case. Though, this also did not rule out the possibility that WhatsApp had relied on a contractual basis. As a response, the DPC received objections from 6 supervisory authorities. On the other hand, the DPC discovered that Meta had breached its transparency obligations as per the GDPR. Apparently, Meta had not clearly explained to its users for what purpose and on what legal basis would their personal data be processed. Since they couldn’t reach an agreement on these disputed points, the DPC initiated a dispute resolution procedure as per Art. 65 GDPR. When making its decision, the EDPB confirmed the violation of transparency obligations by WhatsApp. Apparently, the EPDB had a different perception than the DPC regarding WhatsApp’s entitlement to rely on the contractual legal basis to process the users’ personal data. The EPDB concluded that WhatsApp had violated Art. 6 (1) GDPR. So, the DPC agreed in its final decision and imposed a fine of EUR 5.5 million, as well as required WhatsApp to bring its data processing into compliance within 6 months.

allItems.name: Sweden
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Swedish DPA has fined Dalarna Region with EUR 17,900. The region had apparently sent out invitations for patient visits where the healthcare facility (children’s hospital) could be seen on the envelope window. The DPA discovered that this type of visibility granted access to unauthorized individuals to the patients’ personal data. The DPA concluded that the region had not implemented the proper organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 300. The data controller had installed several video surveillance cameras that, among other things, also recorded the neighbor’s property. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined TECNO MOTOR LA MUELA, S.L.L. with EUR 360. The data controller had previously installed several video surveillance cameras that, among other things, also covered the public space. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. Moreover, the data controller had not properly informed the data subjects about the video surveillance and had thus violated its duty to inform as per Art. 13 GDPR. The original fine of EUR 600 was reduced to EUR 3660 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Insufficient fulfilment of information obligations
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined a private investigator with EUR 2,000. And individual who had previously hired this investigator filed a complaint to the DPA. The claimed that the data controller had failed to inform them sufficiently about the processing of their personal data which was conducted during the investigation. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the data controller had a contact form on its website that offered no reference to the privacy policy.

allItems.name: Finland
allItems.type: Insufficient fulfilment of information obligations
allItems.summary: The Finnish DPA has fined a company with EUR 122,000. This company sold products that process health data such as heart rate, and so on. The DPA had received many complaints about the processing of health data from the data subjects, regarding this company. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the company did not have a sufficient legal basis to process the various types of health data. Though the company had informed its users about the products and the processing of personal health data in general, it did not provide any information for each of the different types of health data processed (oxygen capacity, body mass index, etc), or the purpose of the data processing. As a result, the DPA discovered that the users’ consent was not valid because it was not given on an individual basis and without knowing the full facts.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Vodafone Espana, S.A.U. with EUR 100,000  because of data processing without a sufficient legal basis. A data subject claimed that a prepaid line where charges were made had been registered in their name. However, no contract between the data subject and the company had ever been concluded in this sense. In fact, the contract in question had been concluded by fraudsters who used the data subject’s personal data. Nonetheless, the personal data had been entered into the company’s information systems without any verification as to whether the contract had been actually concluded by the data subject and in a lawful manner.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a homeowners’ association with EUR 2,000. The person who did the cleaning work in the residential complex had complained to the DPA that several members of the association had added them to a WhatsApp group without obtaining their consent. The data subject had to upload pictures of the cleaning they did for documentation purposes. The DPA concluded that adding the data subject’s phone number to the WhatsApp group without their consent was a violation of Art. 6 GDPR and was unlawful. The DPA also discovered that the data controller had failed to comply with the data subject’s request for access to the personal data in a timely manner, violating Art. 15 GDPR in the meantime.

allItems.name: Croatia
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 27 (2) Croatian Act on the Implementation of the GDPR
allItems.type: Insufficient fulfilment of information obligations
allItems.summary: The Croatian DPA (also known as azop) has fined a company in the hospitality industry with EUR 1,991. The data controller had installed several video surveillance systems on its premises, though the DPA discovered that the video surveillance notice did not contain all the relevant information. So, the DPA concluded that the data controller had violated Art. 27 (2) of the Croatian Act on the Implementation of the GDPR.

allItems.type: Insufficient fulfilment of information obligations

The data controller had installed several video surveillance systems on its premises, though the DPA discovered that the video surveillance notice did not contain all the relevant information. So, the DPA concluded that the data controller had violated Art. 27 (2) of the Croatian Act on the Implementation of the GDPR.

allItems.name: Croatia
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 27 (1), (2) Croatian Act on the Implementation of the GDPR
allItems.type: Insufficient fulfilment of information obligations
allItems.summary: The Croatian DPA (also known as azop) has fined a betting place with EUR 1,991. The data controller had previously installed a video surveillance system on its premises, though the DPA discovered that the video surveillance notice was not visible for the data subjects who entered the video perimeter. Moreover, the video surveillance notice did not contain all the relevant information on the CCTV. The DPA concluded that the data controller had violated Art. 27 (1) and (2) of the Croatian Act on the Implementation of the GDPR.

allItems.name: Croatia
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 27 (1) Croatian act on the Implementation of the GDPR
allItems.type: Insufficient fulfilment of information obligations
allItems.summary: The Croatian DPA (also known as azop) has fined a retailer with EUR 3,583. The data controller had previously installed a video surveillance system on its premises, though the DPA discovered that the data controller failed to inform the data subjects about the fact that they’d be recorded by the CCTV. The DPA concluded that the data controller had violated Art. 27 (1) of the Croatian Act on the Implementation of the GDPR.
