allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 300. The data controller had previously installed several video surveillance cameras that, among other things, recorded a neighbor’s property and the public space. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined a data controller with EUR 180. Apparently, the data controller had not provided a notice with information regarding the video surveillance system on its premises. The original fine of EUR 300 was reduced to EUR 180 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined CASAL DE L’ESPLUGA DE FRANCOLI with EUR 3,000. A club that was managed by the data controller had uploaded several pictures of the competition that contained minors on social media. The mother of one of the children had complained to the DPA because she was not asked for permission for these pictures to be published. The DPA then concluded that the data controller, not having a valid legal basis, has unlawfully processed these images. The original fine of EUR 5,000 was reduced to EUR 3,000 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.controller: Istituto Comprensivo – IC Cosenza III “V. Negroni”
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy, Art. 2-septies (8) Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Istituto Comprensivo – IC Cosenza III “V. Negroni” with EUR 2,000. The educational institution had previously published a document that also contained the personal health of some of the teachers, on an online platform for the teaching staff. This document contained various information about benefits which were linked to the health status of the teachers who were entitled to receive them. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the school had publishe this data without a valid legal basis, so it acted unlawfully.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Failure to notify DPA of a data breach
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA fined Dent Estet Clinic SA (a dental practice) with EUR 1,000. One of the employed dentists had published medical information of a patient (photos and x-rays) in an article on a medical blog. However, the dentist did not obtain the patient’s consent before publishing the medical data. Although the patient had informed the clinic, it failed to notify the DPA about this data breach in a timely manner.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 6 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 9 (2) a) GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA fined a dentist with EUR 1,000. The data controller had published medical information of a patient (photos and x-rays) in an article on a medical blog. However, the dentist did not obtain the patient’s consent before publishing the medical data. So, the DPA concluded that the data controller had unlawfully processed this data.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Insufficient fulfilment of information obligations
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined a data controller with EUR 180. Apparently, the data controller had failed to provide a notice with information regarding the video surveillance on its premises. The original fine of EUR 300 was reduced to EUR 180 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 600. The data controller had installed several video surveillance cameras that, among other things, also covered the public space. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. Moreover, the data controller had not properly informed the data subjects about the processing of this data by the video surveillance, violating its duty to inform by not doing this.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined a private individual with EUR 600. The individual in question installed several video surveillance cameras at their home that, among other things, recorded common areas of the residential complex. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Insufficient fulfilment of data subjects rights
allItems.summary: The Romanian data protection authority (AEPD) has fined the company Tensa Art Design SA with EUR 1,000. A data subject had previously objected to a further newsletter subscription but the company had kept sending him advertisements.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR, Art. 2-sexies Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Azienda Universitaria Friuli Occidentale with EUR 55,000. The health authority had previously created several patient profiles using algorithms and personal patient data that would indicate the risk of having complications regarding the even of a Covid 19 infection. This was implemented to better identify appropriate diagnostics and therapeutic solutions in a time manner, if complications ever occurred. However, the DPA discovered that the health authority had no valid legal basis to process the personal data of the patients through profiling. Moreover, the DPA also found out that the health authority had not conducted a data protection impact assessment. When calculating the fine, the DPA took into consideration the aggravating factor of there being a large number of individuals who were affected.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR, Art. 2-sexies Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Azienda Universitaria Friuli Centrale with EUR 55,000. The health authority had previously created several patient profiles using algorithms and personal patient data that would indicate the risk of having complications regarding the even of a Covid 19 infection. Moreover, the DPA also found out that the health authority had not conducted a data protection impact assessment. When calculating the fine, the DPA took into consideration the aggravating factor of there being a large number of individuals who were affected.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined FACTOR ENERGIA, S.A. with EUR 24,000. One of the data subjects had complained to the DPA that they had received several advertising messages from the data controller even though there was no contractual relationship between them. According to the DPA, the data controller had processed the data unlawfully because it had no valid legal basis. The original fine of EUR 40,000 was reduced to EUR 24,000 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined STS Di Prisinzano s.r.l. with EUR 1,000 because the company had previously processed the data of a customer regarding a breakdown service without sufficiently informing the customer about the processing of their personal data.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Insufficient fulfilment of data subjects rights
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Associazione Rescue Drones Network ODV with EUR 3,000. One of the founding members of the association had filed a complaint to the DPA, saying that he had learned of disciplinary actions taken against them. The founding member then wanted to use documents from their email account for their defense. However, the data controller had blocked access to that email account, preventing them from accessing the documents they needed. In this context, the data subject had asked the data controller to grant them access to that email account. However, the data controller never responded to this request. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the data subject’s right to information as per Art. 12 GDPR and Art. 15 (3) GDPR.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Insufficient fulfilment of data subjects rights
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Poste Italiane S.p.a. with EUR 10,000 after it failed to respond to the data subject’s request for access to their data in a timely manner.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 2-septies (8) Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Fondazione Regio di Torino with EUR 5,000. One of the foundation members had filed a complaint to the DPA, saying that the foundation had published a document on their website that contained personal data health of the data subject. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the foundation had published this data without a valid legal basis and the process was therefore unlawful.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Azienda Ospedaliero-Universitaria Careggi di Firenze with EUR 9,000. The data controller had mistakenly sent a patient medical record to the wrong patient, and the DPA discovered that the healthcare facility had not implement the appropriate organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data, allowing such an incident to occur.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 37 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Cisterna di Latina municipality with EUR 5,000. An individual had complained to the DPA, saying that the municipality had not replied to their request for access to their personal data in a timely manner. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the municipality had mistakenly sent the data requested by the data subject to another third party instead of the data subject. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the municipality failed to appoint a new data protection officer multiple months after the initially appointed data protection officer had resigned.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.controller: Conservatorio di Musica S. Cecilia di Roma
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 38 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Conservatorio di Musica S. Cecilia di Roma with EUR 6,000. One of the students of the educational institution had complained to the DPA, claiming that he had received a disciplinary sanction for a statement he had made during a student assembly. Although it shouldn’t have happened, the assembly was recorded and the institution used these recordings to base the disciplinary actions on it. During the investigation, the DPA concluded that the data controller had no valid legal basis to use the assembly recordings and process the personal data the student, making the procedure unlawful. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the data protection officer of the educational institution was also the institution’s director. The DPA rightly found this to be an unlawful conflict of interest.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Failure to notify DPA of a data breach
allItems.summary: The DPA of Sachsen-Anhalt has fined the Magdeburg University Hospital with EUR 9,000. The clinic had previously failed to report to the DPA a data breach that involved one of the former employees having unlawfully disclosed personal data from the clinic’s systems to third parties.

allItems.name: Cyprus
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Cypriot DPA has fined the Hermes Airport Ltd. with EUR 6,000. The data controller had previously suffered a cyber attack that, according to the DPA had been clearly caused by the lack of organizational and technical measures required for the protection of the personal data, as well as a supervision of a processor.

allItems.name: Cyprus
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Cypriot DPA has fined DW Dynamic Works LIMITED with EUR 5,000. The data controller was a processor for Hermes Airport Ltd. When Hermes went through a cyber-attack, one of the guilty parties, according to the DPA, was Dynamic Works. Their lack of organizational and technical measures failed to protect the personal data.

allItems.name: Cyprus
allItems.controller: Universal Life Insurance Public Co Ltd.
allItems.type: Insufficient data processing agreement
allItems.summary: The Cypriot DPA has fined Universal Life Insurance Public Co Ltd. with EUR 3,500. The processor of this data controller had went through a data breach where the personal data of several customers were mistakenly disclosed to other customers. During their investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller had not contractually regulated their relationship with the data processor. The DPA stated that the data controller had contracted this data processor without making sure that the data processor offered enough guarantees for the implementation of proper organizational and technical measures to protect the personal data.

allItems.name: Cyprus
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Cypriot DPA has fined PRINTAFORM Ltd. with EUR 3,750 because the data controller, which was a processor for Universal Insurance Public Co Ltd., had went through a data breach where the personal data of multiple customers were mistakenly disclosed to other customers. According to the DPA, this data breach was clearly caused by PRINTAFORM’s lack of proper organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data.

allItems.name: Cyprus
allItems.controller: Bank of Cyprus Public Company Ltd.
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 24 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Cypriot DPA has fined the Bank of Cyprus Public Company Ltd. with EUR 17,000. In the context of a sales of credit facilities, the Cypriot bank had mistakenly transferred the data of multiple customers whose credit facilities had not yet been sold to the buyer. These incidents had affected about 11,673 records and over 5,500 individuals. The DPA concluded that it was the bank’s failure to implement proper organizational and technical measures that led to the data breach.

allItems.name: Cyprus
allItems.type: Insufficient data processing agreement
allItems.summary: The Cypriot DPA has fined the Cypriot Ministry of Defense with EUR 5,000. The data controller had previously suffered a cyber attack that (the DPA states) had been caused by the lack of proper organizational and technical measures necessary to protect the personal data, as well as the lack of proper supervision of a processor.

allItems.name: Cyprus
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Cypriot DPA has fined DW Dynamic Works LIMITED with EUR 7,500. The data controller had operated as a processor for the Cypriot Ministry of Defense, as a context. When the ministry went through a cyberattack, the DPA concluded that Dynamic Work’s lack of proper organizational and technical measures required to protect the personal data was one of the causes for the attack.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.controller: Scuola Statale Secondaria di  I^ grado 'Bianco-Pascol'
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy, Art. 2-sexies Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the school “Scuola Statale Secondaria di  I^ grado ‘Bianco-Pascol’” with EUR 3,000. The educational institution had apparently published a document that contained personal health data of students in the school’s electronic register. During its investigation, the DPA discovered that the school had published this data without having a valid legal basis, acting in an unlawful way. Moreover, the school failed to respond to the several requests for information in a timely manner.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined MIRACLE IBIZA S.L. with EUR 500. The data controller had previously installed a video surveillance system that captured the front door of a data subject’s apartment. The DPA concluded that hits was a violation of the principle of data minimization as per Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined HOTEL VILLA SORO, S.L. with EUR 600. The data controller in question had apparently installed a video surveillance system without offering the required information as per Art. 13 GDPR. The original fine of EUR 1,000 was reduced to EUR 600 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.controller: Istituto di Istruzione Superior G. Renda di Polistena, Reggio Calabria
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the educational institution “Istituto di Istruzione Superior G. Renda di Polistena, Reggio Calabria” with EUR 900. One of the former employees of the municipality had filed a complaint to the DPA, claiming that a document containing their personal data had been unlawfully published on the institution’s website. This document contained information regarding the termination of the employment relationship between the data subject and the institution.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 10 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy, Art. 2-octies Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined the Italian Archery Federation (FITARCO) with EUR 10,000. One of the members of the of the federation had complained to the DPA that the federation had unlawfully published documents containing their personal data on its official website. These documents contained, among others, specific criminal information about the data subject.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art, 5 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 37 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Poliambulatorio Radiologico “il Sorriso” S.r.l. with EUR 15,000. One of the patients of the institution had complained to the DPA that they had not received enough information about the processing of their personal data. Among others, the data controller had not offered information about the data protection officer and the type of data that would be processed. The DPA also discovered that the data controller had not provided the contact details of their data protection officer to the DPA.

allItems.name: Poland
allItems.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1), a) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Polish DPA has fined the law firm PIONIER with EUR 9,600. Apparently, the law firm’s professional area of expertise were the victims of traffic accidents regarding proceedings against insurance companies and other entities. Keeping this in mind, the law firm supports its clients in claims for damages and claims for reimbursement of medical treatment costs. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the law firm had processed personal data (including health data) of its potential clients without having a valid legal basis. The law firm obtained the personal data of potential clients based on press releases and other social media reports. This allowed it contact the potential clients and offer them their services. During the initial conversation, the law firm asked their clients for verbal consent to process their personal data until the conclusion of a contract. However, the DPA stated that consent should have been given in such a way that it could be proven later on (for instance, in a register of consents).

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Insufficient fulfilment of data subjects rights
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Azienda Sanitaria Locale di Brindisi with EUR 2,500. A data subject had complained to the DPA, claiming that the health authority failed to respond to their request for access to their personal data.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 (2), (4) GDPR, Art. 37 (7) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined the Comune di Borgia with EUR 5,000. The municipality in question processed the biometric data of employees regarding the registering of their attendance. Garante discovered that this processing of data was not proportionate to its purpose, and therefore was an unjustified infringement of the data subjects’ rights. As a result, Garante stated that the processing of biometric data had occurred without a valid legal basis. Moreover, Garante also discovered that the municipality failed to provide the DPA with the contact data of their data protection officer.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 (2), (4) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined the Comune di Vicchio with EUR85,000. The municipality in question processed the biometric data of employees regarding the registering of their attendance. Garante discovered that this processing of data was not proportionate to its purpose, and therefore was an unjustified infringement of the data subjects’ rights. As a result, Garante stated that the processing of biometric data had occurred without a valid legal basis. Moreover, Garante also discovered that the municipality failed to provide the DPA with the contact data of their data protection officer.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy, Art. 2-septies (8) Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined the Comune di Bracciano with EUR 6,000. One of the institution’s former employees had complained to the DPA, stating that the municipality had published a document containing their personal health data on their website. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the municipality had published the persona health data without a valid legal basis, therefore acting in an unlawful manner.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 2-septies (8) Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined a private individual with EUR 1,000. Apparently, two data subjects had complained to the DPA because the data controller had published personal data of them and their families in their dissertation. The individuals had participated in various treatments conducted by the data controller but they had not consented to the publication of their data in the dissertation in an unanonymized form.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the owner of the store “Turkish City” with EUR 2,000 because they had installed several video surveillance cameras on its premises without properly informing the data subjects about the processing of their personal data through these cameras. The DPA discovered that the data controller had not carried out its duty to inform, as per the GDPR.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b), e) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 30 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Comune di Salento with EUR 12,000. A data subject had complained to the DPA after being recorded by a CCTV camera (the recording proved that he had ignored the curfew introduced during the COVID-19 pandemic countermeasures). During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the processing of the data subject’s personal data with the purpose of proving the curfew violation was unlawful since the cameras had originally been installed for another purpose, that of combatting street crime. Hence, the municipality was not processing the data subject’s personal data for the original purpose, which is a breach of the purpose limitation principle included in the GPDR. The DPA also discovered that the municipality had stored these recordings excessively long and failed to provide sufficient information about the CCTV to the data subject. Moreover, the DPA also found out that the municipality had not responded to the data subject’s request for information in a timely manner. Last but not least, the municipality did not maintain a register of processing activities for certain periods of time.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Ordine dei Medici Chirurghi e geli Odontoiatri della Provincia di Cagliari
allItems.type: Art. 5 (1) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Ordine dei Medici Chirurghi e geli Odontoiatri della Provincia di Cagliari (Board of Surgeons and Dentists of the Province of Cagliari) with EUR 3,000. Apparently, the data controller had disclosed the data of a doctor to several third parties without having a valid legal basis to do so.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) e) GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Comune di Monte Sant’Angelo with EUR 3,000. A data subject who had participated in a selection procedure had complained to the DPA because the municipality had published a list of candidates as well as their results in the selection procedure on its official website. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the municipality had no valid legal basis to publish the results and the personal data of the applications on its website. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the data controller had failed to comply with the data subjects’ requests for deletion of their personal data.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined the Medijobs Platform SRL with EUR 5,000. The data controller had previously informed the DPA about a data breach as per Art. 33 GDPR. Several unauthorized third parties had successfully accessed the IT infrastructure of the data controller and managed to download, delete, and transfer personal data of the applications (name, professional history, email address, marital status, etc). The DPA discovered that the data controller had not implemented the proper organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data, which then led to the data breach.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy, Art. 2-sexies Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the school Direzione Didattica Statale 1° Circolo-Eboli with EUR 1,500. The educational institution had previously sent several documents that contained the names of all students and teachers (including health data) to all the parents and teachers, without making sure that teachers and parents receive only the information about the students that concern them.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 114 Codice della privacy, Art. 157 Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Rebirth s.r.l. with EUR 15,000. The data controller had installed a total of 14 surveillance cameras in a café it operated without informing about the video surveillance.

allItems.name: Hungary
allItems.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 7 (2), 4) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Hungarian DPA has fined a news service with EUR 5,200. Apparently, one of the news service’s customers had complained to the DPA about subscribing to the newsletter in order to receive a daily news digest. However, they also started receiving direct marketing messages. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the processing of the data subject’s personal data for direct marketing purposes was unlawful. Because the data controller had failed to offer sufficient information to the data subject about their rights, the DPA concluded that the data subjects’ consent to receive the newsletter was not a valid legal basis to process their personal data for marketing purposes (due to insufficient information provided).

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 12 (3) GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Mister Brick S.a.s. with EUR 1,000. A data subject had complained to the DPA, claiming that the data controller had sent unsolicited marketing messages to them. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller did not have a legal basis to process the data subject’s data for marketing purposes. Moreover, the data controller did not respond in a timely manner to a request of the data subject who wanted to exercise their rights.

allItems.name: Luxembourg
allItems.controller: Manager of a real estate co-ownership
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 12 (3), (4) GDPR, Art. 15 (1) b), c) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The DPA of Luxembourg has fined the manager of a real estate co-ownership with EUR 1,500. The data controller had disclosed the personal data of a data subject to unauthorized third parties without having a valid legal basis to do so. Moreover, the data controller failed to respond in a timely manner to requests from the data subjects who wanted to exercise their rights.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 29 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 114 Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Tecnomed Trento s.r.l. with EUR 10,000. The data controller had operated several video surveillance cameras on its premises, and some of them had no authorization to be there. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the information signs about the processing of the personal data were missing. The DPA also found out that three individuals who shared credentials had authorized access to these recorded images. In conclusion, the DPA stated that this was not appropriate to guarantee the confidentiality of the information that was processed by the video surveillance system, as it did not allow anyone to check who carried out certain processing operations.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined a private individual with EUR 1,000. A data subject had complained to the DPA against the data controller, claiming that the data controller had published their personal data (name, surname ID car number, date of birth), without obtaining their consent, in a WhatsApp group with 31 members. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined a Property Owners Association with EUR 2,000. Two property owners had complained to the DPA. The two individuals had requested a copy of their financial documents to the board. However, the Association published the requests containing personal data of the two data subjects in question on the bulletin board, in a common area of that residential building. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of confidentiality.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined a private individual with EUR 3,000. The individual had previously posted videos of teachers and their underage students during physical education classes online in order to express his anger about the fact that the students were required to wear a mask during the physical education class. However, the DPA concluded that the individual had unlawfully processed the personal data of the data subjects because he did not have their consent, or any other legal basis.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 113 Codice della privacy, Art. 114 Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Lazio Region with EUR 100,000. A specific trade union had complained to the DPA, claiming that the Lazio Region had monitored the email accounts of the legal department’s employees. The region had started this monitoring operation because there was suspicion of possible disclosure of information that was protected by official secrecy to third parties. The Region had stored and assessed the employees’ data for a total of 180 days. This data did not only include information pertaining to work but also personal data of the data subjects, information that concerned their private lives. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the Region did not have a valid legal basis to conduct such a large-scale personal information gathering at that time.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined the Villafranca di Verona municipality with EUR 4,000. The municipality had previously published a document that contained the personal data of an employee on its website.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined SUBREZIDENȚIAL Broker S.R.L. with EUR 10,000. One of the data controller’s employees had unauthorizedly published an Excel spreadsheet that contained personal data (first and last name, telephone number, email address, ID number and bank details) of 509 customers online. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller had not implement the appropriate organizational and technical measures to protect this personal data.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 29 GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b) GDPR, Art. 32 (2), (4) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Kaufland Romania SCS with EUR 3,000. The Data controller had previously reported a data breach to the DPA according to Art. 33 GDPR. One of the company’s employees had taken pictures of the CCTV recordings using their cell phone and then transmitted the pictures to a third party. This third party then published the photos, in which two people and a license plate could be easily identified, on the website of a local newspaper. The DPA concluded that the data controller had not implemented the necessary organizational and technical measures to protect the personal data.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) d), e) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the electricity supplier Areti spa with EUR 1 million. One of the company’s customers had complained to the DPA that Areti spa had classified them as a defaulting customer which made it impossible for the customer to switch to another electricity supplier. This was caused by outdated data in Areti spa’s databases, which hadn’t been updated after a mismatch in the company’s internal systems. This incident affected approximately 47,000 customers. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that Areti spa had stored this data for an inordinate amount of time. Moreover, Areti spa had failed to properly respond to requests from the customers who wanted to exercise their data subject rights.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 30 (1) c) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Sportitalia with EUR 20,000. The data controller processed the biometric data (fingerprints) of the employees to register their attendance. However, Garante found that such an extensive procedure was not proportionate to its purpose, and as such constituted an unjustified infringement of the rights of the data subjects. Moreover, Garante concluded that the processing of this biometric data had happened without the company informing the data subjects about the data processing.

allItems.name: Ireland
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 (1) c) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Irish DPA (also known as DPC) has fined Meta Platforms Ireland Limited with EUR 390 million. The DPA has fined the company with EUR 210 million for violating the provisions of its Facebook services and another 180 million for violating the provisions of its Instagram service. The Austrian organization “None of Your Business” (NOYB) had complained to the DPA on behalf of two individuals. These complains were related to Meta’s updated Terms of Service. In the update, Meta had changed the legal basis necessary for the processing of personal data regarding the behavioral advertising and other personalized services. Before the change, Meta based the data processing on user content. After the change, Meta relies on the Terms and Conditions to condition its users to accept the processing of personal data for the purpose of personalized advertising. If they want continued access to the Facebook and Instagram services, users are required to accept the updated Terms of Service. Initially, the DPA discovered that Meta had violated its transparency obligations as per the GDPR. However, they also discovered that Meta had not clearly emphasized to users on what legal basis and for what purpose their personal data would be processed. Moreover, the DPA also discovered that Meta could not rely on the Terms and Conditions that both them and their users had contractually agreed to as the legal basis to process the data for behavioral advertising. The DPA claimed that the users would have been pressured into accepting the Terms and Conditions to continue using the services. In this context, the DPA said that the users should be able to explicitly consent or deny the processing of their data for the purpose of this personalized advertising with a simpler yes/no option. Other than imposing the fines, the DPA also required Meta to make its data processing operations comply with the GDPR within 3 months.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 37 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Cisterna di Latina Municipality with EUR 5,000. An individual had complained to the DPA, claiming that he has submitted a request to the municipality to their personal data. However, due to an error, the data was instead disclosed to a third party instead of the data subject in question. In this context, the data subject did not receive any response to his request. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the municipality had not appointed any data protection officer.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined a homeowners’ association with EUR 500. The data controller had publicly posted a list containing the first and last names of all the members of the association.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 32 (1) b) GDPR, Art. 32 (2) GDPR, Art. 32 (4) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Apă Canal Ilfov SA with EUR 3,000. The data controller had sent an email with personal data to several recipients in an open distribution list, making it possible for every recipient to view the email addresses of all the other recipients.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a homeowner’s association for failing to provide enough information about the video surveillance in the residential area.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined MAE WEST SYSTEMS, S.L. with EUR 400. The data controller had previously installed video surveillance in a bar it was operating without offering enough information about it.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined the Transport Workers’ Union of Aragon with EUR 3,000. The union had previously published a document with personal data (including the first and last name and identity card number) of all the members of a strike committee on various social networks. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that this incident could have happened because of the union’s failure to implement the required organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 600. The data controller had previously installed video surveillance cameras that also covered the public space and a neighbor’s property. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. Moreover, the data controller had not properly informed that data subjects about the processing of this data through the video surveillance, violating its duty to inform.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Insufficient data processing agreement
allItems.summary: The company failed to provide the requested information to the Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) within the required timeframe, violating Art. 58 GDPR.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined BRISTOL LOGISTICS SA with EUR 10,000. The DPA received a notification from BRISTOL LOGISTICS SA of a personal data breach as per Art. 33 GDPR. This notification stated that a binder that contained the personal files of 12 employees had been stolen by someone. This led to a third party gaining unauthorized access to the personal data. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of Art. 32 GDPR, since the municipality had failed to implement the appropriate organizational and technical measures that would have ensured a proper level of protection for the data.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined I-Model s.r.l. with EUR 10,000. Apparently, a data subject had complained to the DPA against the data controller, claiming that the data controller kept sending them SMS advertisements even though they had requested the deletion of the data and the data controller had confirmed the deletion.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined EDITORIAL RIBADEO S.L. with EUR 1,000 because it failed to comply with an order issued by the DPA.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.controller: SERVICIOS INTEGRALES DEL HOGAR TENERIFE, S.L.
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined SERVICIOS INTEGRALES DEL HOGAR TENERIFE, S.L. with EUR 3,000. One of the company’s former employees had complained to the DPA, claiming that the data controller had unauthorizedly disclosed their personal data through WhatsApp after the data subject left the company. The original fine of EUR 5,000 was reduced to EUR 3,000 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Insufficient fulfilment of information obligations
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined a homeowner’s association with EUR 120 because it failed to provide sufficient information about the video surveillance in the residential area. The original fine of EUR 150 was reduced to EUR 120 because of voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 300. This individual had installed several video surveillance cameras on their private property that also covered a neighboring property. The AEPD discovered that such extensive video surveillance was a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 300. This individual had installed several video surveillance cameras on their private property that also covered a neighboring property. The AEPD discovered that such extensive video surveillance was a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined a homeowners association with EUR 600. The data controller had previously installed an unauthorized CCTV system in the residential area. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the data controller had not provided the sufficient information about the data processing through the CCTV.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Insufficient fulfilment of information obligations
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a store owner with EUR 300 because he failed to provide information signs about the CCTV surveillance installed in their premises.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined SUMINISTRADOR IBERICO DE ENERGIA, S.L. with EUR 24,000. A customer had previously filed a complaint to the DPA after the data controller had carried out a change of their gas and electricity supply company without obtaining the data subject’s consent first. The original fine of EUR 30,000 was reduced to EUR 24,000 because of voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 114 Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the owner of the Joy Unique Collection store with EUR 6,000. The data controller had been operating video surveillance cameras on its premises without any authorization. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the information signs regarding the processing of personal data through the video surveillance system were missing.

allItems.name: Lithuania
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 9 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 30 (1), (3) GDPR, Art. 35 (1), (3) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Lithuanian DPA has fined Praktiškas UAB, which is the operator of the SportGates sports club, with EUR 6,000. The data controller had processed the biometric data of several customers in the context of their access to specific sports facilities. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the customers’ consent to the processing of their biometric data couldn’t be considered to be provided voluntary. That’s because the data controller had not offered the provision of any other type of information to gain access to the sports clubs. It also did not provide the data subjects with any information about potential alternatives to access the sports club. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the data controller had not provided the data subjects with enough information about the processing of the personal biometric data. The data controller also failed to conduct a data protection impact assessment before the personal data processing.

allItems.name: Ireland
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Irish DPA has fined the nursing home operator VIEC Limited with EUR 100,000. The data controller had notified the DPA about a data breach as per Art. 32 GDPR. This was a phishing attack where an unauthorized third party had gained access to the email account of a VIEC Limited manager. As a result of this, the third party managed to access the personal data (health and biometric data) of home residents. The DPA discovered that this was a breach of the principles of confidentiality and integrity. The DPA also stated that the data controller had failed to implement the appropriate organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data.

allItems.name: Finland
allItems.type: Insufficient fulfilment of data subjects rights
allItems.summary: The Finnish DPA has fined the debt collection company Alektum Oy with EUR 750,000. The DPA started an investigation against the data controller after three people had filed complaints against them. During this investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller did not respond at all or completely to requests from data subjects regarding their data protection rights. The DPA also discovered that the data controller had not sufficiently cooperated with the DPA.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined Intellexa SA with EUR 50,000. The data controller had not properly cooperated with the DPA during the investigation.

allItems.name: Poland
allItems.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 31 GDPR, Art. 58 (1) a), e) GDPR
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The Polish DPA (also known as UODO) has fined a data controller with EUR 1,450 because it failed to provide the information requested by the DPA during an investigation.

allItems.name: Poland
allItems.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The Polish DPA (also known as UODO) has fined a data controller with EUR 490 because it failed to provide the information requested by the DPA during an official investigation.

allItems.name: Poland
allItems.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItems.type: Insufficient cooperation with supervisory authority
allItems.summary: The Polish DPA (also known as UODO) has fined TIMSHELL Sp. z o.o. with EUR 6,800 because it failed to provide the information requested by the DPA during an official investigation.

allItems.name: Poland
allItems.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItems.type: Insufficient cooperation with supervisory authority
allItems.summary: The Polish DPA (also known as UODO) has fined a data controller with EUR 960 because it failed to provide the information requested by the DPA during an official investigation.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 600. Apparently, the data controller had installed several video surveillance cameras that also covered a neighbor’s property and the public space. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. Moreover, the data controller had not clearly informed the data subjects about the processing of this personal data through the video surveillance, which means he violated its duty to inform.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b), c) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA (also known as ANSPDCP) has fined REGENCY COMPANY SRL with EUR 3,000. Apparently, the data controller had installed several video surveillance cameras on its premises to monitor the access of people and the security of its premises and property. However, this made it possible for it to monitor its employees extensively. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the video surveillance had been partly carried out without the clear consent of the company employees. The purpose of the surveillance could have easily been achieved through less intrusive means that did not encroach on their employees’ privacy.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The DPA from Hamburg has fined a Covid-19 Test Center with EUR 1,400 because the data controller wanted to fulfill its statutory documentation obligations and scanned both the front and back of the ID cards of all tested individuals to accomplish this. However, such an extensive storage of personal data was not necessary to fulfill the documentation obligations. The data controller could and should have known this beforehand.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined BANCO BILBAO VIZCATA ARGENTARIA, S.A. with EUR 84,000. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller had registered the alleged debts of one of its former clients to the Spanish Central Bank’s risk information center without having a legal basis to do so. The DPA also discovered that the data controller had failed to comply with the former customer’s request for access to their personal data. The original fine of EUR 140,000 was reduced to EUR 84,000 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fiend INGENIERIA Y TELECOM JAEN, S.L. with EUR 10,000. The data controller had extended the data subject’s contract without obtaining their consent first.

allItems.name: Hungary
allItems.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 12 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Hungarian DPA has fined TV2 Media Csoport Zrt. with EUR 26,700. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller had operated two of its websites without offering the necessary information about the handling of the personal data. The DPA also discovered the fact that the data controller did not obtain the consent of its users in a clear and transparent manner on these websites.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 75 Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Azienda Ospedaliera Bianchi Melacrino Morelli. The data controller had mistakenly sent a document that contained health data of the data subject to the wrong recipient. The DPA discovered that the healthcare facility had failed to impose the required organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Azienda Ospedale-Universita Padova with EUR 5,000. The data controller had sent to several recipients an email that contained the consent forms for the participation in a clinical trial, and it was in an open distribution list. This made it possible for all recipients to view the email addresses of each other (19 in total).

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined WUNSCHURLAUB S.L. with EUR 1,800 because it stored passwords in plain text on its website (www.meine-auszeit-jetzt.de). The DPA concluded that this was a violation of Art. 32 GDPR. The original fine of EUR 3,000 was reduced to EUR 1,800 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined ECOMM MOVADGENCY S.L. with EUR 600 after sending out direct marketing agency, even though the data subjects

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Insufficient legal basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined CITIZENGO FONDATION with EUR 3,000. An individual had filed a complaint to the DPA that the data controller had sent them an email that contained election advertising without getting the individual’s consent first. The original fine of EUR 5,000 was reduced to EUR 3,000 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Poland
allItems.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItems.type: Insufficient fulfilment of data breach notification obligations
allItems.summary: The Polish DPA has fined a housing operative with EUR 11,100 because the data controller had disclosed specific personal data of a member of this cooperative to an unauthorized individual. The incident had been recorded in an internal register of violations but the data controller did not inform the DPA or the data subject about this incident in a timely manner.

allItems.name: Czech Republic
allItems.type: Unknown
allItems.summary: The Czech DPA fined a company with EUR 3,400. Apparently, the data subject had concluded an energy supply contract with this data controller in the past. However, he then terminated it not soon after. Nonetheless, the data controller assigned this previously terminated contracted to a data processor (sales representative) who contacted the data subject to conclude a new contract. The DPA discovered that the data controller had unlawfully transferred the data of the data subject to the sales agent, since it had no valid legal basis for the transfer in the absence of an existing contract.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Misterbianco municipality with EUR 5,000. One of its employees had issued a complained to the DPA because the municipality had published, on its website, a document that contained their personal data. During the investigation, the DPA noticed that the municipality had published this data without a valid legal basis, acting in an unlawful manner.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Eurosanita S.P.A. with EUR 120,000. The data controller controls various healthcare facilities and one individual in particular had issued a complaint to the DPA after mistakenly receiving a document that contained the medical records of another individual. The DPA discovered that the data controller had failed to take the necessary organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data and avoid such incidents.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined a store owner with EUR 2,000 because it had failed to offer the necessary information as per Art. 13 GDPR regarding the CCTV surveillance on its premises.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.controller: Real Federacion Espanola de Tenis de Mesa
allItems.type: Insufficient fulfilment of information obligations
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined the Real Federacion Espanola de Tenis de Mesa with EUR 10,000. One of the participants in the examination for a table tennis coach qualification had issued a complaint to the DPA because they were asked to provide a Covid test to access the examination premises. During the investigation, the DPA found that the data controller had no valid legal basis to process this data, since the legal provisions regarding hygiene concepts at that time did not require any proof of testing before accessing a business’ premises.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b) GDPR, Art. 6 (1), (4) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined Vodafone with EUR 10,000. Apparently, an individual had filed a complaint to the DPA because they had received a package that contained promotional gifts from a company that worked with Vodafone. This happened even though the data subject had expressly objected to the use of their data for any promotional purposes. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller had processed this data without having a valid legal basis, acting unlawfully. The DPA found that the data controller could also not offer any evidence that it had comprehensively informed the data subject about the processing of their personal data, as required by Art. 13 GDPR.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), f) GDPR, Art. 33 GDPR, Art. 34 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined Piraeus Bank with EUR 30,000. A customer had filed a complaint to the DPA because the bank had disclosed the account balance and transaction information from two bank accounts that they jointly owned to the heirs of the other joint owner during the legal proceedings. The DPA concluded that the disclosure of its joint account information was unlawful. Moreover, the bank failed to report this incident to the DPA and the data subject in a timely manner.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.type: Insufficient fulfilment of data breach notification obligations
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined Vodafone with EUR 40,000. An individual had filed a complaint to the DPA because Vodafone had sent them another customer’s conversations after the data subject had requested access to the records of their conversations with a Vodafone call center. Moreover, Vodafone did not report this incident to the DPA in a timely manner.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined ORANGE ESPAGNE S.A.U. with EUR 100,000. One of the company’s customers who had purchased a cell phone from ORANGE contacted the DPA with a complaint afterward. He claimed that ORANGE had issued a condition to deliver the cellphone: the delivery person had to photograph the front and back of the customer’s ID card. ORANGE had implemented these measures for security purposes, in order to prevent identity theft and fraud. Despite having these legitimate justifications, the DPA discovered that there were other methods, which far war less intrusive to the data subject’s privacy, to achieve this other than photographic the ID card and processing a variety of personal data in the process.

allItems.name: Hungary
allItems.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItems.type: Insufficient fulfilment of data subjects rights
allItems.summary: The Hungarian DPA has fined a company with EUR 13,300. One of its customers had complained to the DPA that a conversation that they had with a sales representative of the data controller had been recorded without their consent or any information whatsoever. The DPA concluded that this was a breach of the data controller’s information obligations under the GDPR.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Insufficient fulfilment of data subjects rights
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Deca s.r.l. with EUR 1,600 after several employees had complained to the DPA that the data controller had not complied with their requests for access to their personal data processing during the attendance check.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 31 GDPR
allItems.type: Insufficient fulfilment of data subjects rights
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined the company ΜΑΡΙΑ ΠΕΔΙΩΤΗ ΚΑΙ ΣΙΑ Ο.Ε. with EUR 7,000. The company had insufficiently complied with the request for information from an individual (the information was both late and incomplete). Moreover, the data controller had not sufficiently cooperated with the DPA.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 300. The data controller had installed several video surveillance cameras that, among other things, also covered the public space. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Vodafone Espana, S.A.U. with EUR 112,000. An individual had issued a complaint to the DPA because the company had given a duplicate of their SIM card to an unauthorized (and fraudulent) third party without getting their consent first. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the company had failed to verify the identity of the third party of get the data subject’s consent to share their data. This made it possible for the fraudsters to obtain access to the data subject’s bank account and make several unauthorized transactions. The original fine of EUR 140,000 was reduced to EUR 112,000 because of voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Insufficient fulfilment of data subjects rights
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined GUUDJOB WORLDWIDE S.L. with EUR 800. An individual had filed a complaint to the DPA where they claimed that the data controller had failed to comply with their request to delete their personal data. The individual in question had posted a review on the data controller’s site. After seeing that their name had been published, they asked for their data to be deleted immediately. However, the data controller failed to comply with this request on time. The original fine of EUR 1,000 was reduced to EUR 800 because of voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The DPA of Brandenburg has fined a bank with a five-digit fine. Apparently, the bank had previously installed a video surveillance system that also covered parts of the foyer of the branch with ATMs, which is the entrance area as well as the sidewalk and parking spaces in front of it. The commands to access this camera and the transmission of the images were carried out via the internet and were unencrypted. The bank then suffered a data breach where unknown third parties compromised the video cameras and posted the images online. They were also able to take control over the cameras to a limited extent. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the bank had hailed to implement the required organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data, which made the breach possible in the first place. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the bank had not entered into a processing agreement with its processors who had access to the images and cameras.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The DPA of Brandenburg has fined a restaurant operator with a five-digit fine. Apparently, during the Covid-19 pandemic, the operator in question had required its restaurant visitors to fill out forms that asked for their name, address, email address, and telephone number for the purpose of contact tracing as required by the law. However, the law didn’t require the collection of an email address back then. Visitors were also required to check a box that stated that they agreed to be contacted by the restaurant. However, the restaurant then used the email addresses of the subjects to send promotional newsletters. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the processing of the email addresses for advertising purposes was unlawful because of the fact that the requirements for giving reliable consent were not met. It was unclear to the data subjects that the restaurant would use the email addresses for advertising purposes. The restaurant operator also did not inform the data subjects about their right of withdrawal of consent.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The DPA of Brandenburg has fined the operator of an outdoor swimming pool with a five-digit fine. The data controller had processed more visitor data that it was legally required for contact tracing purposes during the Covid pandemic.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The DPA of Brandenburg has fined an aid organization with a five-digit fine. Apparently, the aid organization offered transportation for people with illnesses and it reported a data breach to the DPA where the data of the subjects had been published online after a hack. During the attack, the data controller’s database contained more than 80,000 records of data that included information about the health status of all the data subjects. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the bank had not taken the appropriate organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data. This allowed the breach to occur. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the bank had not concluded a processing agreement with its data processors.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fiend ALBERTO FORTE COMPSITE, S.L. with EUR 12,000. Apparently, the company had taken pictures of its employees at the entrance to record their working hours. However, the company did not conduct a data protection impact assessment. The original fine of EUR 20,000 was reduced to EUR 12,000 due to admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Insufficient fulfilment of information obligations
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined INFINITY ECOM S.L. with EUR 5,000 because it failed to ensure that the privacy policy on its official website met the requirements of Art. 13 GDPR.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b), c) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 7 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 130 Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Ediscom S.p.a. with EUR 300,000. The marketing company had apparently collected the data from over 21 million individuals through various online portals to use it for marketing activities. The company also used “dark patterns” to manipulate and mislead users into consenting to the processing of their data for marketing purposes and to transfer their data to various third parties. The DPA discovered several violations, including the fact that in some cases of data processing, the company could not prove that it had obtained the consent of the data subject.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b), e) GDPR, Art. 12 (2) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 30 (1) GDPR, Art. 22 (2) LSSI
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Burwebs S.L. with EUR 75,000. Apparently, Burwebs operates websites with adult content. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the company did not process its users’ data in a transparent manner. Moreover, the company also retained its users’ personal data for an indefinite period of time. The DPA also found out that Burwebs processed the data of its minor users without requiring parental consent. Burwebs also complicated the exercising of the data subjects’ rights as per the GDPR and did not sufficiently inform its users about the data processing and the storage of their personal data in its privacy policy. Lastly, the DPA discovered that the record of processing activities was not complete.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined DISPLAY CONNECTORS, S.L. with EUR 30,000. An individual had filed a complaint to the DPA about the data controller’s publication of information regarding a court case that also included that personal data of the complainant’s minor son. During the investigation, the DPA concluded that the minor’s right to privacy was more important than the controller’s freedom of information, and the publication violated the principle of data minimization as a result. The original fine of EUR 50,000 was reduced to EUR 30,000 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined BANQUETES SANTA ANA, S.L. with EUR 5,000. Apparently, the data controller had asked a couple who was celebrating the wedding on its premises to provide the personal data of their guests, including ID card numbers, for the purpose of contact tracing regarding the Covid-19 pandemic laws. The DPA claimed that such a broad request for personal information was unnecessary for contract tracing purposes and that the provision of names would have been more than sufficient.

allItems.name: Hungary
allItems.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItems.type: Unknown
allItems.summary: The Hungarian DPA has fined the supermarket chain Aldi with EUR 253,000. Apparently, Aldi had entered and then stored the date of birth of several of its customers during the checkout system when purchasing alcoholic beverages. This procedure was introduced to make the cashiers’ work easier since the software could easily calculate whether the person was over 18 or not. However, it was considered excessive by the DPA. Moreover, Aldi did not answer any questions regarding the legal basis of this data processing.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 7 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 130 Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Aesse S.r.l.s. with EUR 3,000. An individual had filed a complaint to the DPA about the fact that the data controller had made an unsolicited advertising call. The complainant claimed that they had never given their consent to receive such advertising communication. Moreover, the data controller did not quite comply with their request for information regarding the origin of the personal data.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined GSMA LTD. with EUR 200,000. Apparently, an individual had filed a complaint to the DPA because they wanted to transfer some special categories of personal data (the ID card data) to the data controller to register for an event. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller did not conduct a data protection impact assessment for these processing operations.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 130 Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
