allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined a private individual with EUR 5,000. The individual had sent promotional messages to several data subjects without getting their consent first.

allItems.name: Poland
allItems.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 24 (1) GDPR, Art. 25 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 32 (1), (2) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Polish DPA has fined a company with EUR 7,200. The data controller had previously suffered a data breach that led to the loss of personal data. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller had not implemented the required organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data, and this facilitated the data breach. The data controller had also failed to conduct various risk analyses. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the data controller did not review its data processor to ensure that it offered enough guarantees to protect the personal data.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined FUNDACIO PRIVADA UNIVERSITARIA EADA with EUR 1,200. Apparently, an individual who had participated in a training event filed a complaint against the aforementioned educational institution. The data controller had used various pictures of the training event that showed the data subject for promotional purposes, without getting their consent. The original fine of EUR 2,000 was reduced to EUR 1,200 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined a homeowners’ association with EUR 2,000. A property owner had complained to the DPA about the fact that various members of the association had previously accessed the community’s video surveillance footage and shared it via WhatsApp.

allItems.name: Hungary
allItems.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) e) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 31 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Hungarian DPA has fined a hotel with EUR 8,000. The data controller had previously installed various video surveillance cameras that covered the dining room and a whirlpool area and permanently recorded guests. The data controller had installed these cameras to protect the individuals and their property. However, during the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller’s purposes were not proportionate to the severe interferences with the guests’ privacy. The DPA also discovered that the data controller had not provided enough information about the video surveillance.

allItems.name: Hungary
allItems.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItems.type: Unknown
allItems.summary: The Hungarian DPA has fined a beauty salon with EUR 80,700. The data controller had installed various video cameras on all its premises that permanently recorded customers and employees. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller did not have the required permission to operate the video surveillance system. Moreover, the data controller processed the data of these customers for marketing purposes and did not have a valid legal basis. They did not inform the customers about it either.

allItems.name: Hungary
allItems.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 12 (2) GDPR, Art 13 (1) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Hungarian DPA has fined a physician with EUR 1,600. A patient had issued a complaint against the data controller to the DPA. The patient had asked the doctor to send all the medical records after the death of her unborn child, however the physician did not do that.

allItems.name: Hungary
allItems.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 12 (2), (3) GDPR, Art. 31 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Hungarian DPA has fined a website operator with EUR 1,300. An individual had previously filed a complaint to the DPA against the data controller because the data controller had published various personal data of them on their website. The data subject sent a request to access their data to the data controller but they did not receive a reply. Moreover, the data controller did not properly cooperate with the DPA during the ensuing investigation.

allItems.name: Hungary
allItems.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 7 (2) GDPR, Art. 12 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Hungarian DPA has fined a coin dealer with EUR 80,700. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the privacy policy did not have enough information about the data processing regarding the data of both new and prospective customers. The DPA also discovered that, because of a lack of information, the data subjects were not able to give their informed consent about the data processing, and the process was unlawful as a result.

allItems.name: Croatia
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 (1) GDPR, Art. 28 (3) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b), d) GDPR, Art. 32 (2) GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Croatian DPA (AZOP) has fined the debt collection agency “K2 Kapital d.o.o.” with EUR 2,265,000. This is the highest fine ever issued by AZOP as well as the first case where the data controller was publicly named. AZOP had received an anonymous complaint back in December 2022 claiming that a large number of the debtors’ personal data was processed by the collection agency without proper authorization. There was a USB stick attached to the complaint that contained personal data (name, date of birth and personal identification number) of 77,317 debtors. During the investigation, AZOP discovered that the data controller did not offer enough information about the processing of the personal data on its privacy policy. Furthermore, it did not provide information about the legal basis concerning the refund of overpaid funds. The breach affected around 132,652 individuals. Moreover, AZOP also found that the data controller had not entered into a data processing agreement with a data processor that monitored simple consumer bankruptcies. This put the data of around 88,896 individuals at risk. This breach persisted for over 2 years. In the end, AZOP discovered that the data controller had not implemented the required organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data. There were deficiencies in the security system which allowed the insecure processing of personal data on a very large scale, and this resulted in the unauthorized filtering of the data. AZOP also noticed that the breach had been ongoing ever since 2019 and was not addressed. AZOP also took into consideration various aggravating factors such as: the controller’s failure to reasonably cooperate with the DPA during the investigation. Moreover, the data controller had not even informed AZOP of additional measures it had taken to prevent any future risks of identified violations, and it had also not made its privacy policy compliant with the GDPR.

allItems.name: Cyprus
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) f) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Cypriot DPA has fined the newspaper Πολίτης with EUR 7,000. The data controller had unlawfully published the names and pictures of two police officers without their consent.

allItems.name: Cyprus
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 24 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Cypriot DPA has fined Epic Ltd. with EUR 3,250. The data controller had issued several unsolicited calls to 332 former customers without having a valid legal basis. The DPA also discovered that the data controller had not taken any appropriate technical and organizational measures to prove that the data processing was carried out in compliance with the GDPR.

allItems.name: Cyprus
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b), d) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Cypriot DPA has fined NAGA Markets Europe Ltd. with EUR 9,000. The data controller had suffered a data breach where an unknown person had accessed the company’s database, holding the data of more than 342,000 customers hostage. The DPA discovered that the data controller had not implemented the required organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data, and this made it possible for the breach to take place.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined ASSOCIACIO DE CAÇADORS D’ALZIRA with EUR 2,000. One of the members of the association had issued a complaint to the DPA because the chairman of the company had published a letter they had written to a WhatsApp group with 195 members without obtaining their consent.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Consorzio Concessioni Reti Gas S.c.a.r.l. with EUR 2,000. Apparently, the data controller had continued to leave the business email account of one of the interns active, even after the termination of the employment contract. The DPA also found that the data controller could not prove compliance with its information obligations as per the GPDR.

allItems.name: Hungary
allItems.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) a), b) GDPR, Art. 32 (2) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Hungarian DPA has fined a party with EUR 8,000. The party has issued a data protection breach that resulted in six Excel files which were made accessible on the internet. These files contained the personal data of the party members. However, this incident affected around 2,000 data subjects. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the party had failed to take the appropriate organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data, and this allowed such an incident to occur.

allItems.name: Hungary
allItems.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItems.type: Unknown
allItems.summary: The Hungarian DPA has fined a dentist with EUR 1,300. The data controller had installed several video surveillance cameras in their practice. These cameras recorded both the patients and the employees permanently. The data controller had installed these cameras for the purpose of protecting the individuals and the property. However, during the investigation, the DPA determined that such an extensive video surveillance interfered too much with the freedoms of the data subjects, which made the surveillance unlawful.

allItems.name: Hungary
allItems.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 9 (2) GDPR, Art. 13 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Hungarian DPA has fined the spa operator I&S Limited Kft with EUR 80,500. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller had installed various video surveillance cameras on its premises. These cameras permanently monitored the guests and employees. The DPA also found out that the data controller had no valid legal basis for such an extensive video surveillance. The data controller also failed to inform the data subjects about the data processing of their personal data. Moreover, the data controller had processed the data of its customers for marketing purposes without having a valid legal basis.

allItems.name: Hungary
allItems.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Hungarian DPA has fined a credit institution with EUR 2,700. Several individuals had issued a complaint to the DPA about the fact that the data controller had previously sent claims for their loan agreements to another bank without getting their consent first.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 180. The data controller had previously installed several video surveillance cameras that also covered a neighboring property and the public space. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. The original fine of EUR 300 was reduced to EUR 180 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined ESTUDIO INMOBILIARIO SAN ISIDRO with EUR 5,000. Apparently, an individual had complained to the DPA that employees of the data controller had visited their home in order to promote various rental services without obtaining their consent first.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 33 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined the Bolzano municipality with EUR 30,000. Apparently, the health authority of the Bolzano municipality had reported a data breach to the DPA where there was unauthorized access to the health records of multiple patients. This data breach was caused by a deficiency in the electronic health record services that a data processor had been delegated to operate. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the municipality should have taken the necessary organizational and technical measures to avoid such incidents, even though the data leak took place at the processor’s site.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Informatica Alto Adige Spa with EUR 10,000. The municipality of Bolzano had reported a data breach to the DPA where there was unauthorized access to the health records of multiple patients. This data breach was caused by a deficiency in the electronic health record services that a data processor had been delegated to operate. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that Alto Adige Spa had not taken the necessary organizational and technical measures that would prevent such incidents from happening.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 28 GDP
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Razmataz Live s.r.l. with EUR 1,000. The company had contracted a data processor to carry out various marketing campaigns, which the data processor did not execute in a privacy-compliant manner. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that Razmataz had not carried out the adequate controls at the data processor.

allItems.name: Bulgaria
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Bulgarian DPA has fined a political party with EUR 12,800. Several individuals had issued a complaint to the DPA because their personal data had been added to a voter list without their consent.

allItems.name: Bulgaria
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 32 (1) b), c), d) GDPR, Art. 32 (2) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Bulgarian DPA has fined the Bulgarian Posts EAD with EUR 500,000. The data controller had previously suffered a hacking attach where attackers had managed to access the controller’s databases. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller had not implemented the necessary organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data and prevent such events from happening.

allItems.name: Bulgaria
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Bulgarian DPA has fined a trucking company with EUR 5,000. The data controller had previously disclosed the personal data of several former employees to various third parties without a valid legal basis.

allItems.name: Malta
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 24 (2) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) (b) GDPR, Art. 32 (4) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The data controller had unlawfully disclosed the personal data of a data subject.

allItems.name: Malta
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The data controller had previously failed to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures to protect the personal data.

allItems.name: Malta
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, art. 32 (11) b) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The data controller had unlawfully disclosed the personal data of a data subject.

allItems.name: Malta
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The accidental loss of personal data.

allItems.name: Malta
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The data controller had disclosed the personal email addresses to all the recipients of an email.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined VODAFONE ONO, S.A.U. with EUR 40,000. The data controller had previously carried out a credit check on an individual without first making sure that there was a customer relationship or another affiliation between them. The personal data of the data subject was processed without a valid legal basis. However, the original fine of EUR 50,000 was reduced to EUR 40,000 because of voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Netherlands
allItems.authority: Dutch Supervisory Authority for Data Protection (AP)
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Dutch DPA has fined the Dutch Social Insurance Institution (SVB) with EUR 150,000. Apparently, the data controller had previously suffered a data breach where the client’s data had been leaked to various unauthorized third parties. An unknown third party had managed to request the benefit information through the data controller’s telephone helpdesk. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that this had happened because the data controller had not implemented the required organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data. For instance, the DPA discovered that the system which they used to verify the identity of the callers was not good, and the verification questions were too simple.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined the party “Partidul Uniunea Salvați România” with EUR 3,000. The data controller had apparently published the personal information of individuals with various degrees of disability on its official website without a valid legal basis.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Insufficient fulfilment of data subjects rights
allItems.summary: The failure to respond to the data subject’s request for access to their data within the required timeframe.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The DPA of Hessen has fined a Covid-19 test center with EUR 16,400. The data controller had apparently sent an e-mail that contained personal data to multiple recipients in an open distribution list. The DPA discovered that the data controller had also failed to document the data breach.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), f) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The DPA of Hessen fined a Covid-19 test center with EUR 1,800. Apparently, one of its employees had taken an adhesive label from the trash, wrote the test center’s email address on it, and then attached it to the center’s window. However, because of a lack of care, the employee did not notice that the label also contained the personal information of an individual. The data was visible to various third parties for 24 hours until it was removed from the premises.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Unknown
allItems.summary: A police officer had previously accessed data in police databases for his own private research purposes for a period of three years.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Unknown
allItems.summary: A police officer had been accessing data in police databases to get information about their ex-partner’s new partner.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Unknown
allItems.summary: A police officer had been accessing data in police databases to obtain information about a colleague.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Insufficient fulfilment of data subjects rights
allItems.summary: The Romanian GDPR has fined Tensa Art Design SA with EUR 1,000 because the data controller did not comply with the data subject’s right to object.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined KFC RESTAURANTS SPAIN, S.L. with EUR 25,000. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller has previously failed to appoint a data protection officer. Moreover, the DPA also found that the data controller had not offered all the necessary information as required by Art. 13 GDPR on its official website.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c), f) GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 25 (1), (2) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Azienda sanitaria locale di Bari with EUR 50,000. The healthcare facility had previously published several reviews of former patients online and offered access to hundreds of documents on which it was possible to identify these patients. The information about these patients had been insufficiently redacted so that data was disclosed. More specifically, information regarding the patient’s health, diagnoses and clinical data of operations were visible.

allItems.name: Sweden
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Swedish DPA has fined the Skåne region with EUR 17,600. One of the region’s employees had lost an unencrypted USB stick that contained the social security numbers as well as the sensitive personal data of more than 2,000 people. The DPA discovered that the region had not implemented the required organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data.

allItems.name: Austria
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Austrian DPA has fined the operator of a public toilet with EUR 25,000. Apparently, the data controller had installed a video surveillance camera on the restrooms and secretly recorded the people using the toilets. The DPA discovered that the data controller had no legal basis to install these cameras. When assessing the fine, they took into account the fact that the privacy of the data subjects had been significantly violated.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined SECURITAS DIREC ESPANA, S.A. with EUR 25,000 because it failed to comply with an order issued by the DPA.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined DIGI SPAIN TELECOM, S.A. with EUR 70,000. Apparently, someone had filed a complaint to the DPA because the company had issued a duplicate of their SIM card to an unauthorized third party without obtaining their consent. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the company had failed to verify the identity of this third party or get the data subject’s consent. This made it possible for the fraudsters to obtain access to the data subject’s bank account and make unauthorized transactions.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Telefonica Moviles Espana, S.A.U. with EUR 70,000. Apparently, someone had filed a complaint to the DPA because the company had issued a duplicate of their SIM card to an unauthorized third party without obtaining their consent. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the company had failed to verify the identity of this third party or get the data subject’s consent. This made it possible for the fraudsters to obtain access to the data subject’s bank account and make unauthorized transactions.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Insufficient fulfilment of data subjects rights
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a website operator with EUR 1,000 because it had failed to make sure that the privacy policy on its website complied with the requirements of Art. 13 GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined a private individual with EUR 300. The data controller had previously installed several video surveillance cameras that also recorded a neighboring property. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization and issued a fine of EUR 300.

allItems.name: Denmark
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Danish DPA has fined the law firm SIRIUS with EUR 67,200. The law firm had previously suffered a cyber-attack where the gathers had gained access to the firm’s servers and encrypted them. This allowed the hackers to access information about the firm’s clients and other business partners. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the law firm didn’t have basic security measures in place, and this increased the risk of unauthorized access to client data. The firm’s systems, for instance, had insufficient verification measures like multi-factor logins, in place.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the owner of the store “Turkish City” with EUR 2,000. The data controller had previously installed several video security cameras on its premises without properly informing the data subjects about the data processing of their data. The DPA discovered that the data controller had violated its duty to inform as per the GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 300 for installing a video surveillance camera on their property without authorization. These cameras recorded the public space as well as a neighboring property. The AEPD discovered that installing this video surveillance camera was a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Cyprus
allItems.type: Insufficient fulfilment of data subjects rights
allItems.summary: The Cypriot DPA has fined the Cyprus Judo Federation with EUR 5,000. The father of one of the members had complained to the DPA that the judo coach of his minor son had previously published photographic and audiovisual material on various social media platforms without obtaining his prior consent. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the trainer had not sufficiently cooperated with the DPA, so a fine of EUR 5,000 was issued for violating Art. 31 GDPR.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.controller: Azienda Socio Sanitaria Territoriale Dei Sette Laghi
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined the healthcare facility Azienda Socio Sanitaria Territoriale Dei Sette Laghi with EUR 7,000. One of the facility’s patients had received medical records and clinical documentation from another patient by mistake.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The DPA from Brandenburg had fined a company employee with a three-digit fine. This individual had sent an Excel spreadsheet containing employee data of 56 employees to her private email address from the official work computer, although this wasn’t necessary to complete her official activities. This is why the DPA concluded that the employee had unlawfully transferred the employee data. This spreadsheet included, among other things, the full names of the employees, and an overview of the sick days accrued, vacation days taken and remaining, wage data, overtime worked, and social security contributions.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The DPA from Brandenburg had fined a company employee with a three-digit fine. This employee had forwarded application documents from his employer to his private email address without having authorization to do this. Even though he did it to receive suggestions for the design of his applications, he hadn’t anonymized the resumes, so they included the personal and professional data of the applicants. Because sending these application documents to his private email address wasn’t a part of his duties, the DPA concluded that the forwarding was unlawful.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The DPA of Brandenburg has fined a children psychotherapist with a fine in four-digit amount. The doctor had created a WhatsApp group with 230 participants that would communicate their new office addresses. A mother of a former minor patient had complained to the DPA that the doctor had not obtained consent for this group. All of the group member phone numbers were disclosed to the other members. In some cases, some of the group members could draw conclusions that children from families they knew had been patients of that physician. In this sense, the DPA concluded that the doctor had unlawfully processed the data via the WhatsApp group by failing to obtain consent.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) c), e) Art. 6 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (3) b) GDPR GDPR, Art. 2-ter (1), (3) Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the City of Rome with EUR 10,000. The city had previously published a document on the municipal website about a mother who couldn’t pay her canteen fees. This document contained the personal data of both the mother and her minor child. The city claimed that, due to the absence of a permanent address of the mother to where the notice could be sent, it had published this document as a notification to the homeless mother of the debtor. However, the DPA discovered that this wasn’t considered a sufficient legal basis for processing the personal data, so the city had unlawfully processed the data.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Unknown
allItems.summary: A police officer had accessed the police database for private research purposes. This police officer had queried the investigation process of a friend regarding the background of a judicial hearing. Through WhatsApp, he had shared information that he had obtained through unauthorized retrievals. In this sense, the DPA of Brandenburg had imposed a fine for violating § 32 Absatz 1 BbgDSG. The Brandenburg Data Protection Act is clear about the supplementary regulations necessary to adapt the GDPR.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Unknown
allItems.summary: A police officer had unlawfully disclosed the personal data of a drunk driving incident to the mother of the offender during a random encounter. He thought that the mother, being his employer, could prevent such an offence from happening again by withdrawing his car. However, the mother was an unauthorized third party, which means that the police officer wasn’t allowed to disclose this information to her. In this sense, the DPA of Brandenburg had imposed a fine for the violation of. The Brandenburg Data Protection Act is clear about the supplementary regulations necessary to adapt the GDPR.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Unknown
allItems.summary: A police officer had unlawfully accessed data in the police database. According to the DPA, the police officer received a fine for violating § 32 Absatz 1 BbgDSG. The Brandenburg Data Protection Act is clear about the supplementary regulations necessary to adapt the GDPR.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The DPA of Hamburg has fined a company operating in the healthcare sector with a six-digit amount fine. This company had failed to take the appropriate organizational and technical measures to ensure the proper level of data security protection that was appropriate to the risk when sending the doctor’s letters. Consequently, the doctor’s letters were sent to a person who wasn’t the doctor providing further treatment to the affected patients. Instead, these letters should have arrived to a general practitioner with the same name as the recipient. The company had been informed about the incorrect mailing of letters several times in the past. However, it had constantly failed to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures to prevent these incidents from reoccurring. When calculating the fine, the DPA took into account the aggravating factors that this data involved health data, and this type of data is particularly sensitive.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 33 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined the DKV Seguros y Reaseguros, S.A.E. with EUR 132,000. An individual had complained to the DPA after he’d received multiple emails from the data controller. These emails contained information from an unknown person. In total, the data controller had sent 51 emails with medical certificates containing the names, surnames, and medical tests data of the data subjects to wrong recipients. The complainant had notified the data controller about the wrong mailing of this data. However, the data controller did not respond until it learned about the complaint to the DPA. The data controller hadn’t reported any data breach to the DPA either. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the company had constantly failed to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures to ensure a sufficient level of data protection security. The original fine of EUR 220,000 was reduced to EUR 132,000 due to admission of guilt and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 600 for failing to implement measures ordered by the DPA in due time.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a bar owner with EUR 5,000. Apparently, the bar owner had unlawfully shared the recordings from the CCTV in the bar on WhatsApp and various social media platforms.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fiend a private individual with EUR 2,000. The individual had previously installed several video cameras in the apartment building where he lived. These cameras also recorded common areas of all residents, which the DPA considered to be a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish Data Protection Agency has fined an employee of a bookstore with EUR 4,000. A data subject had complained to the DPA that he had received an invoice of another person containing that person’s personal data. The employee had mistakenly sent the invoice to the wrong recipient.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined BANKINTER, S.A. with EUR 56,000. The data controller had mistakenly sent a report about the data subject’s investment portfolio to a third party. The data controller claims the mis-sending happened because of a computer error. As such, the DPA determined that the data controller had violated the principle of integrity and confidentiality as set out by Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 12 (3), (4) GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Afragola Municipality with EUR 10,000. One of the former employees of the municipality had complained to the DPA that the municipality had published his resume with personal data on the municipality’s official website, even though their employment relationship had ended. Additionally, the former employee had previously filed a request to object to the disclosure of his personal data. However, the municipality had not replied to this request.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 37 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 37 (7) GDPR, Art. 38 (6) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Villabate Municipality with EUR 6,000. The municipality had previously disclosed the personal data of a former employee to unauthorized third parties without obtaining the data subject’s consent. The DPA also discovered that the municipality had failed to appoint a data protection officer.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.controller: Convitto Nazionale Statale 'Giordano Bruno' di Maddaloni (boarding school)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 2-ter (1), (3) Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Convitto Nazionale Statale ‘Giordano Bruno’ di Maddaloni (boarding school) with EUR 6,000 because the data controller had published a document on its website containing personal data of the data subject without consent.

allItems.name: Croatia
allItems.type: Non-compliance with general data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Croatian DPA has fined a car dealership with EUR 4,000. The data controller had installed several video surveillance cameras on its premises without properly informing the data subjects about the data processing done by the surveillance cameras.

allItems.name: Croatia
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 25 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b) GDPR, Art. 32 (2) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Croatian DPA has fined a telecommunications company with EUR 285,000. The company had previously suffered a data breach where attackers had managed to access the data of about 100,000 data subjects. During the investigation, the DPA had discovered that this breach was facilitated by the company’s failure to implement the adequate organizational and technical measures to process the personal data. For instance, the processing systems didn’t have any access restrictions in place. When calculating the fine, the DPA took into account the aggravating factor that the company is one of the leading telecommunications companies in Croatia. Due to the high volume of data processed on its premises, the risk of an attach was that much higher, so the company should have implemented the necessary security protection. As such, the company should have been more careful to ensure that the proper security measures were taken.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 6 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (3) b) GDPR, Art. 2-ter (1), (3) Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Region of Tuscany with EUR 16,000. The Region had previously published a document on its website that contained information on professionals from the tourism sector who had applied for the emergency aid during the covid-19 pandemic. This document showed, among other things, the name, address, and the amount of aid granted to each data subject.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Universita Agraria di Nettuno with EUR 4,000. One of the former employees of the university had previously filed a complaint with the DPA because the university published a document containing his personal data. The document showed information related to a legal dispute between the data subject and the university. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the publica was unlawful in the absence of a valid legal basis.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the owner of the store Singh Market with EUR 2,000. The data controller had previously installed video surveillance cameras on its premises without properly informing the data subjects about this processing of their data. The DPA concluded that the data controller had violated its duty to inform as per the GDPR regulations.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), f) GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the healthcare facility Azienda sanitaria universitaria Friuli Centrale with EUR 70,000. Several employees of the healthcare facility had accessed the patient’s health data despite not being involved in the treatment of these patients. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the healthcare facility’s IT platform had allowed any employee to access the personal data of patients despite not being in charge of treating those patients. Additionally, the DPA found out that the IT platform also did not install systems that identified the improper use of the personal data.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Unknown
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the healthcare facility Azienda sanitaria universitaria Friuli Occidentale with EUR 50,000. Several employees of the healthcare facility had accessed the patient’s health data despite not being involved in the treatment of these patients. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the healthcare facility’s IT platform had allowed any employee to access the personal data of patients despite not being in charge of treating those patients. Additionally, the DPA found out that the IT platform also did not install systems that identified the improper use of the personal data.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.controller: Comune di Napoli Corpo di Polizia Municipale
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 88 GDPR, Art. 113 Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the police authority Comune di Napoli Corpo di Polizia Municipale with EUR 12,000. The data controller had sent a list of names, tax numbers, addresses, contact details and appointments for covid-19 employee tests to various administrative units through email. The authority mentioned that employees had given consent to the data processing, and this was the legal basis for it. However, the DPA concluded that the data controller couldn’t rely on the consent because voluntary consent is questionable in the employee-employer relationship.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The DPA of Hamburg fined a private individual with EUR 5,000. The individual in question had fimed many young women in public. Some of these female persons are apparently younger than 14 years old. In many cases, this individual approached the filmed persons to within a few centimeters and filmed them for up to 38 minutes. During a search of the data subject’s backpack, the police officers discovered a digital camera and eight memory cards. These memory cards contained a 156 such video files. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the individual had processed the personal data of the young women without an effective consent in effect.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Unknown
allItems.summary: The DPA of Hamburg had fined an energy supplier with EUR 12,500. The company had previously outsourced and sold the heating energy division. However, customers affected by this transfer were informed about the transfer and were given the right to object. In such an event of a declared objection, no personal data of the customers could be transferred to the new company. However, despite some customers having declared their objection, their data was still transferred to the new company.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Unknown
allItems.summary: The DPA of Hamburg had fined an energy supplier with EUR 12,500. The company had previously outsourced and sold the heating energy division. However, customers affected by this transfer were informed about the transfer and were given the right to object. In such an event of a declared objection, no personal data of the customers could be transferred to the new company. However, despite some customers having declared their objection, their data was still transferred to the new company.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Unknown
allItems.summary: The DPA of Hamburg had fined a car trading group with EUR 10,110. The company had previously informed its customers that they were restructuring because of the absence of an employee due to illness. The company informed the 3,000 customers about the exact date on which the employee’s inability to work happened and that this situation would continue for an indefinite period of time. The DPA discovered that the company failed to present a valid legal basis for the transfer of this personal data, so the transfer was unlawful.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined ESVETEL, S.L. with EUR 40,000. The data subject had previously received an advertising call from the data controller made on behalf of Vodafone Espana, S.A.U., despite the subject having been registered in the Robinson advertising exclusion list.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 28 GDPR, Art. 30 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR
allItems.type: nsufficient fulfilment of information obligations
allItems.summary: The DPA of Lower Saxony has fined Volkswagen with EUR 1.1 million. The company had previously installed several cameras on a test vehicle. This vehicle was used to test and train the functionality of a driving assistance system that would prevent traffic accidents. To this end, the traffic around the vehicle was recorded with these cameras. However, Volkswagen did not provide any information about the data processed by the cameras attached to the vehicle, according to Art. 13 GDPR. The DPA discovered that, as opposed to its obligations under Art. 28 GDPR, Volkswagen did not conclude a processing a agreement with the company that carried out these journeys. Moreover, no data protect impact assessments as per Art. 35 DSGVO were carried out. Lastly, the organizational and technical protection measures hadn’t been outlined in the list of processing activities. Still, Volkswagen had cooperated extensively with the DPA.

allItems.name: Luxembourg
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The DPA of Luxembourg (also known as CNPD) has fined a company with EUR 1,400. The data controller had previously installed location sensors on various cars in its fleet. The purpose was to protect the company’s assets, optimize fleet management and the workflow, among other goals. Some of this location data was collected by the controller and stored for a year. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of storage limitation. Additionally, the DPA discovered that the data controller had insufficiently informed the data subjects about the processing of this location data, violating its information obligations as per Art. 13 GDPR.

allItems.name: Luxembourg
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The DPA of Luxembourg (also known as CNPD) has fined a company with EUR 3,000. The company had previously installed a video surveillance system for the purpose of protecting company property and staff. However, these cameras also captured part of the employee’s work areas. The DPA concluded that the data controller had violated the principle of the information obligations as per Art. 13 GDPR, that required them to properly inform the employees about the video surveillance.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined CINCON S.C. with EUR 500. The company had failed to provide any information required by Art. 13 GDPR on a form that allowed potential customers to access a free course.

allItems.name: Luxembourg
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 12 (1), (7) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The DPA of Luxembourg has fined a company with EUR 1,000. This company had previously installed a video surveillance system that recorded both the employees and other third parties. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the company had breached its information obligations as per Art. 12 GDPR and Art. 13 GDPR.

allItems.name: Luxembourg
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 12 (1), (7) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The DPA of Luxembourg has imposed a fine of EUR 1,000 on a company. The company had installed a video surveillance system that recorded both employees and third parties. During its investigation, the DPA found that the company had breached its information obligations under Art. 12 GDPR and Art. 13 GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The private person used a CCTV camera to capture the foreign private space of a neighbor and the public space.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: One of the company’s former customers had received emails that contained electronic bills after they’d terminated their contract with the company. This resulted in the processing of personal data of the data subject without sufficient legal basis.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The DPA of Lower Saxony has fined the Hannoversche Volksbank with EUR 900,000. The bank previously analyzed the data from active and former customers without obtaining their consent first. To this end, the bank analyzed the digital usage behavior and assessed, among other things, the purchases in app stores, the total number of transfers in online banking compared to the use of in-branch services, and the frequency of bank statement printers. Moreover, these results had been cross-checked with a credit agency. The goal was to find those customers with a greater willingness to use digital media and to focus on them intensively through electronic communication channels for promotional purposes. Most of the customers were given a notice beforehand. However, the DPA concluded that this did not replace the required consent. When determining the fine, the DPA took into account the fact that the bank did not use the results of these evaluations for anything else. Moreover, the bank cooperated with the DPA during the investigation.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a homeowners association with EUR 2,500 for publishing information (name, surname, apartments) about several owners on their website.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.controller: EFS MANTENIMIENTO Y SERVICIOS TECNICOS, S.L.
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined EFS MANTENIMIENTO Y SERVICIOS TECNICOS, S.L. with EUR 800. The trade union had previously complained to the DPA that the company in question had shared information about one of its employees with the works council without the proper authorization. The information shared caused this employee to be put in a disadvantageous position. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principles of confidentiality and integrity.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.controller: Territorial Administration of the Government of Genoa
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) c), e) Art. 6 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (3) b) GDPR GDPR, Art. 2-ter (1), (3) Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Territorial Administration of the Government of Genoa with EUR 11,000. The department had previously published a file on its website containing a table that listed information about the lawyers of two companies as well as their adult cohabiting family members. During the investigation, the DPA concluded that the department had published this information without a valid legal basis.

allItems.name: Poland
allItems.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItems.controller: University Hospital of the Medical University of Warsaw
allItems.type: Insufficient fulfilment of data breach notification obligations
allItems.summary: The Polish DPA has fined the University Hospital of the Medical University of Warsaw with EUR 2,120. The university hospital had previously suffered a data breach where the patient had received a referral from a doctor that contained, among other things, the personal data (name, address, etc) of another patient. The DPA concluded that no one had informed the DPA about the data breach, not the patient and not the doctor.

allItems.name: France
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The French DPA (also known as CNIL) has fined the UBEEQO INTERNATIONAL with EUR 175,000. The vehicle rental company had previously collected geolocation data about rented vehicles at every 500 meters. The company then stated that they collected this data to monitor the condition of their cars, locate it in case of theft, and assist the customer in case of an accident. However, the DPA discovered that the company still had no valid legal basis to collect the geolocation data in such detail. As such, the DPA found that the company violated the principle of data minimization as per Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR. The DPA also discovered that the company had stored the vehicle data for longer than it was necessary This data was kept during the duration of the business relationship with the customer and an additional three years after the termination of the vehicle rental. Additionally, the personal data of users who were inactive for more than eight years were still stored in the company’s databases. The CNIL found out that this long retention of data was a violation of Art. 5 (1) e) GDPR. The DPA also concluded that the users had not been adequately informed during the registration process on the company portal, and this was a violation of Art. 12 GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 600. The data controller had previously installed several video surveillance cameras that also captured the public space. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. Additionally, the data controller hadn’t properly informed the data subjects about the processing of their personal data by the surveillance cameras, failing its duty to inform.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria, S.A. with EUR 42,000. The company had been sending advertising messages to a data subject despite the data subject’s objection to the processing of their personal data. The original fine of EUR 70,000 was reduced to EUR 42,000 because of voluntary payment and admission of responsibility.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1), c) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 2 ter-Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The commune published information regarding a court case on its website. This information included personal data such as the name and professional information of a data subject.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Brandenburg DPA has fined a physician. Apparently, the father of a minor patient filed a complaint to the DPA against the physician because the former had transmitted specific data on his child to a central billing office. This data included the child’s name, date of birth, address, health insurance number, medical services rendered, and the diagnose made. The physician had passed this data without obtaining the parents’ consent and without a valid legal basis.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Unknown
allItems.summary: The Brandenburg DPA has fined a company because an individual had complained to the DPA that the company produced a video recording where the complainant could be seen. The complainant contacted the company and requested that the video be deleted and also to not publish it online. However, the company published the video on its website and other social media networks. Moreover, when the DPA asked the company to delete the video, not only did the company not delete the video from its website but it also did not remove it from its social media accounts. Only upon a secondary request from the DPA did the company remove the video from the social media networks.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: A private individual used a CCTV camera that captured the foreign private space of a neighbor and the public space.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the restaurant operator Ekss s.r.l. with EUR 2,000. The data controller had previously installed video surveillance cameras in its premises without properly informing the data subjects about the processing of this data. The DPA discovered that the data controller had violated its duty to inform as defined by the GDPR.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the newspaper Il Sole 24 Ore S.p.a. with EUR 40,000. The newspaper had previously published an article regarding the recognition by the Italian authorities of a U.S. judge’s decision regarding the adoption of a child by a same-sex couple. However, the newspaper also published personal data on the adopted child and the couple, by mistake. The couple demanded the deletion of the personal data and requested that the newspaper revoke access to the information made available to the public. The newspaper deleted this personal data but did not comply with the data subjects’ right of access.

allItems.name: Germany
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The DPA of Brandenburg has fined a real estate because she had contacted an individual to offer him to sell a property she owns. The data subject had not previously offered his personal data to the real estate agent, so he inquired how the real estate agent got a hold of his personal data. He also requested that his personal data be deleted. The real estate agent then informed the data subject that she had deleted his personal data, however she also did not comply with the data subject’s right to access the data. Sometime later, the data subject again received a message from the real estate agent even though the data deletion was confirmed by the agent. This is why the DPA concluded that the real estate agent had processed the data of the data subject without a valid legal basis and unlawfully.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined S.C. Wine Point S.R.L. with EUR 3,000. A data subject had previously filed a complaint with the DPA for receiving several advertising emails from the data controller. These emails contained a distribution list where the email addresses of 810 other people were visible to the other recipients. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller had failed to take the necessary organizational and technical measures to ensure the confidentially of the personal data processed.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined a private individual with EUR 10,000. This individual had previously created a humiliating and discriminatory video of three siblings disparaging their skin color. She then shared it on her Instagram profile and on WhatsApp.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 7 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Nos s.r.l.s. with EUR 20,000. Nos was the data processor for Vodafone and managed advertising tasks for the telecommunications company. In this sense, Nos had previously acquired and processed personal data from the companies Kdata ltd. and Dynamic Web Solution ltd. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data subjects hadn’t consented for the use of this personal data, and they hadn’t been informed about it by Nos either.

allItems.name: Belgium
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 6 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 7 (1) GDPR, Art. 12 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Belgian DPA has fined the media company SA Rossel & Cie with EUR 50,000. During the investigation, the DPA discovered several GDPR violations on three of the websites operated by this company. For example, the company had placed unrequired cookies on one of its websites without obtaining the consent of the website visitors. Moreover, the company considered that visiting other website was a given consent for further cookie placement on these pages. Moreover, the boxes for the consent on third-party cookies were already ticked. The cookie policy was also incomplete and difficult to access for the visitor. Finally, the DPA discovered that the company was always placing new cookies despite the users revoking their cookie consent.

allItems.name: Norway
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Norwegian DPA (also known as Datatilsynet) has fined the Norwegian Labor Inspectorate “Arbeidstilsynet” with EUR 14,500. The data controller had previously carried out a credit check on the data subject without obtaining any valid legal basis.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the healthcare facility Ospedale San Raffaele s.r.l. with EUR 70,000. The hospital had previously reported two data breaches to the DPA as per Art. 33 GDPR. In the first case, the neurology department of the hospital had distributed a newsletter in an open distribution list. This resulted in the email addresses of the recipients being visible to all other recipients. Out of the 499 email addresses affected, 321 were related to patients and 46 to family members or caregivers of the patients. This also allowed the individuals to be identified by name. In the second case, the surgical department had sent a newsletter in an open distribution list, so the same problem appeared. Out of the 90 email addresses affected, 75 were related to patients and/or family members or caregivers of the patients, so the recipients could be identified by name. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of integrity and confidentiality. This principle requires that the personal data is processed in a way that ensures the necessary security against unauthorized access. This includes protection against unlawful processing and accidental loss/ destruction or damage, through appropriate organizational and technical measures. Regarding the fine, the DPA took into account the aggravating fact that the hospital had introduced several measures to prevent these events specifically, but also the fact that the hospital was highly cooperative with the DPA during the investigation.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined the bar operator SCOTCH CORNER BAR with EUR 1,000. The data controller had previously installed a CCTV system that also covered parts of the public space. Moreover, the data controller had failed to provide the DPA with the necessary information.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a company with EUR 1,000 for failing to provide information signs about a CCTV system on its premises.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined SC Interactions Marketing SRL with EUR 1,000. The data controller had previously sent advertising messages through email to several people for another company. One of the recipients had filed a complaint with the DPA because the data controller had sent several advertising messages in an open distribution list, thus making the email addresses of all the recipients visible to the other recipients.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c), e) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Asociația de Proprietari Aviației Park, which was the operator of the residential facility, with EUR 7,000. The data controller had previously processed the personal data, which includes the surname, first name, ID number and series, arrival time, destination, departure time and remarks, of all delivery persons and couriers without a valid legal basis. Additionally, the DPA discovered that the data controller did not sufficiently inform the data subjects about the processing of this personal data. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the data controller did not establish a data retention period for this personal data that was processed by the video surveillance system, keeping it longer than was necessary.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a store owner with EUR 180 because he failed to provide information signs about a CCTV system in its establishment.

allItems.name: Denmark
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Danish DPA has fined the publisher Gyldendal A/S with EUR 134,000. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the company had kept most of the data (approximately 685,000 unsubscribed members of Gyldendal’s book clubs), for longer than was necessary. Instead of deleting this data of the deregistered book club members, Gyldendal had kept the data in a database. The data of 395,000 former members had been retained for more than 10 years. Moreover, the DPA discovered that Gyldendal did not have any guidelines in place regarding data deletion.

allItems.name: Italy
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 114 Codice della privacy
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the company Zito Auto di Gianfranco Zito with EUR 3,000. The company had previously installed several video surveillance cameras that monitored, among other things, the public spaces and employees. The DPA thought that this was a violation of the principles of data minimization (Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR).

allItems.name: Poland
allItems.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Polish DPA has fined Stołeczny Ośrodek dla Osób Nietrzeźwych with EUR 2,100. The data controller is a center of people suffering from alcoholism. During this investigation, the DPA discovered that several video surveillance cameras had been installed at the facility. This surveillance system recorded both the sound and images of the residents. The facility justified this video surveillance system based on the purposes related to the health and safety of the alcohol-impaired individuals. However, the DPA concluded that these official purposes did not constitute a sufficient legal basis and the center had, in fact, unlawfully processed the personal data of the residents.

allItems.name: Hungary
allItems.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItems.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b) GDPR, Art. 6 (1), (4) GDPR, Art. 12 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 21 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 24 (1) GDPR, Art. 25 (1), (2) GDPR
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Hungarian DPA (also known as NAIH) has fined the Budapest Bank Zrt. With EUR 634,000. The NAIH reports that the bank used an artificial intelligence-driven software solution to automate the evaluation of customers’ emotional states. This speech evaluation system assessed which of the customers needed to be recalled based on their mood. The bank used this application to prevent complaints and to keep customers happy. However, the bank did not inform the data subjects about the processing of their data, so the customers were not in a position where they could object to the data processing. Therefore, the rights of the data subjects regarding the adequate information and the right to object had not been observed and guaranteed. The DPA discovered that the bank did not have a substantiated legal basis for processing the personal data of the customers, and their interest in doing so was illegitimate. That’s because the bank had not sufficiently examined the interests of the data subjects. So, the bank had processed the personal data without a valid legal basis.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a company with EUR 1,000. The company had previously requested various personal data from its customers for the appointment bookings. The DPA discovered that the data controller had failed to properly inform the data subjects about the data processing, as per Art. 13 GDPR.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.controller: CORPORACION DE RADIO Y TELEVISION ESPANOLA, S.A.
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined the CORPORACION DE RADIO Y TELEVISION ESPANOLA, S.A. with EUR 30,000. Multiple media outlets, including the data controller, had published on their websites and on Twitter an audio recording of a multiple rape victim’s testimony in court. The case had attracted a lot of media attention back then, so the DPA started an investigation. It discovered that the rape victim’s right to privacy outweighed the data controller’s freedom of information. The audio recordings of the victim didn’t add any significant value to the reporting. Instead, they severely compromised the victim’s privacy. As such, the DPA concluded that the data controller had violated the principle of data minimization. The original fine of EUR 50,000 was reduced to EUR 30,000 because of admission of guilt and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined RADIO TELEVISION MADRID, S.A. with EUR 30,000. Multiple media outlets, including the data controller, had published on their websites and on Twitter an audio recording of a multiple rape victim’s testimony in court. The case had attracted a lot of media attention back then, so the DPA started an investigation. It discovered that the rape victim’s right to privacy outweighed the data controller’s freedom of information. The audio recordings of the victim didn’t add any significant value to the reporting. Instead, they severely compromised the victim’s privacy. As such, the DPA concluded that the data controller had violated the principle of data minimization. The original fine of EUR 50,000 was reduced to EUR 30,000 because of admission of guilt and voluntary payment.

allItems.name: Romania
allItems.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItems.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItems.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined the Continental Automotive Romania SRL with EUR 2,000. The data controller had previously reported a data breach to the DPA as per Art. 33 GDPR. The data controller had discovered 135 unauthorized and improperly configured cameras on its premises. These cameras captured images of employees in the production area, among other things. These cameras were connected to unprotected and unofficial camera systems. That’s why the DPA concluded that the data controller hadn’t taken the necessary organizational and technical measures to ensure the security of the employees’ personal data.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined FLY FUT, S.L. with EUR 3,000. FLY FUT, S.L. is a company specialized in drone footage at soccer matches. A father had filed a complaint to the DPA against the company, saying that the company had filmed his underaged daughter playing soccer during a match at a local club without obtaining his consent first. As such, the DPA discovered that the data controller had processed the daughter’s data without having a valid legal basis to do so.

allItems.name: United Kingdom
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The UK DPA (also known as ICO) has fined the Tavistock & Portmann NHS Foundation Trust with EUR 91,000. The foundation is a mental health specialist trust located in London. Back in September 2019, the trust wanted to run a contest where it asked patients at the adult gender identity clinic to provide artwork so they can renovate the clinic building. For this reasons, two emails were mistakenly sent with an open distribution list (one of them was sent to 912 recipients and another to 869 recipients). The emails made it clear that all of the recipients were patients of the clinic. The trust immediately acknowledged this error and tried to recall the emails without success. During the investigation, the ICO determined that the trust had no organizational or technical measures in place that would prevent or mitigate the predictable human errors. The ICO also rated as high the harm done to the affected individuals because the relationship of the affected individuals with the gender identity clinic is classified as very sensitive personal information.  Because of immediate implementation of security measures and extensive cooperation with the ICO, the fine was reduced from EUR 910,000 to EUR 91,000.

allItems.name: Greece
allItems.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItems.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined a pediatric psychologist with EUR 3,000 because he had improperly cooperated with the DPA during an investigation.

allItems.name: Spain
allItems.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItems.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 500 for the unauthorized installation of a video surveillance camera on their property.
