allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company had installed a CCTV system without the adequate information of doing so.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company had ported the telephone line of the data subject from his current company to Telefónica Móviles España without getting the data subject’s consent first. Personal data about the data subject was transferred from the former telephone company to Telefónica Móviles España without a sufficient legal basis.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Despite having made a request for erasure from the company’s records, the data subject received another newsletter. The company had confirmed the erasure prior to this event. Apparently, an external service provider of the company had committed an error.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: El Real Sporting de Gijon S.A.D.
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company was fined for sending direct marketing communications without obtaining the data subjects’ consent first. The form submitted by the company failed to comply with the GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data subject had made an erasure request, yet the company continued to use the client’s phone number for marketing purposes.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company made unsolicited marketing calls to data subjects, despite the fact that the data subjects had objected to the data processing. This was also a breach of Article 48 (1)(b) of General Law 9/2014.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Vodafone informed a data subject of the porting of a phone number which the data subject had not requested or confirmed.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Party of the Socialists of Catalonia
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The political party unlawfully used personal information provided by a doctor to contact the complainant’s relative, asking for political support. This wasn’t in accord with the express purpose of the data collection, and it is a violation of the principle of purpose limitation.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company had installed a cookie policy on the website, offering no information regarding the purpose of the cookies, their properties, or the time they would remain active in the user’s device.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The bank failed to erase the personal data of a past customer, allowing access to other bank employees. The Data Protection Authority deemed this to be a violation of the principle of purpose limitation.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Basketball Federation of Castilla and Leon
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Basketball Federation unlawfully disclosed personal information of the data subjects to third parties, which then published the data on the internet. Moreover, the Federation also disclosed the personal data to a newspaper, violating the principles of integrity and confidentiality.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: One of the AVASB security committee members sent WhatsApp messages containing personal information about employees, to private phone numbers. This constitutes a violation of the confidentiality principle which states that not only is the data controller obligated to respect it but everyone else involved in the data processing.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The owners community published a document containing personal data (such as information about the identity of the data subjects and related debts) to the public notice billboard.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: A CCTV system was being used to monitor the public area in front of a building, covering the public space. This situation was in violation with the principle of data minimization. The cameras should have been used in a way that didn’t monitor the public space.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data subject contacted Naturgy Energy Group S.A. to request professional services for the installation of an air conditioning system. The data subject was then contacted by two companies, one of which was GLP Instalaciones 86, who pretended to be a part of the Naturgy Energy Group. Naturgy denied this claim afterward, stating that the two companies weren’t their employees and they weren’t authorized installers of air conditioning systems either. Therefore, GLP Instalaciones 86 unlawfully processed the data subject’s personal data, including telephone number, name and surname, bank details, and e-mail.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Cyprus
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Bank of Cyprus Public Company Ltd
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Social Insurance Services of the Ministry of Labor, Welfare and Social Insurance
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 33 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: One of the bank’s clients requested access to personal information under Art. 15 GDPR. The bank could not answer this request in due time due to the fact that the client’s insurance contract was lost. The DPA considered this to be a violation of the data subject’s rights according to Art. 15 of the GDPR, and a violation of its obligations to protect personal data under Art. 15 (1) f) GDPR and Art. 32 GDPR. Additionally, the bank also violated the Data Breach Notification Obligations under Art. 33 f. GDPR by failing to inform the data subject of the security incident.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Cyprus
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company unlawfully sent emails to data subject despite not having a sufficient legal basis to do so.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Cyprus
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: A police officer had unauthorized access to one of the databases containing personal data about vehicle owners. The police officer then passed information from the database to a third party, outside his/her capacity of work, without a legal reason to do so. The DPA found that the police had insufficient organizational and technical measures put together to prevent any unauthorized access and disclose of personal information from the database.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: France
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 33 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Multiple
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The French DPA (CNIL) issued a fine of EUR 2,250,000 to Carrefour France due to several violations of data protection regulations, including those of the GDPR. The CNIL discovered that Carrefour France did not make it accessible or comprehensible for users of the carrefour.fr website and those wishing to join the loyalty program to access their personal data. Carrefour France also had insufficient and incomplete data regarding the data storage and transfer of data to countries outside the EU. The company also failed to comply with the storage time limits, and it stored the data of more than twenty-eight million customers who had been inactive for five to ten years, for the purpose of its loyalty program. The same happened to 750,000 users of the carrefour.fr site who were inactive for about five to ten years. The CNIL discovered that Carrefour France required almost every user to offer proof of identity when they requested a right. Though, the CNIL found out that this request for proof of identity was, most times, unjustified, because most affected users were clearly identifiable without the need for proof of identity. What’s more, Carrefour France failed to respond to a couple of requests from individuals who wanted to access their personal data. Moreover, the company did not erase the data requested by several individuals. Lastly, Carrefour France did not respond to several requests from individuals who did not agree to receiving e-mail and SMS advertising from Carrefour France.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: France
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Carrefour Banque was fined EUR 800,000 by the French DPA (CNIL) for violating its obligations to fairly process data (under Article 5 (1) GDPR). Carrefour Banque officially claimed that, when a client subscribed to the Pass card (which is attached to the loyalty account) and also wanted to participate in the Carrefour loyalty program, the client would have to check a box agreeing to Carrefour Banque forwarding his or her surname, first name, and email address to “Carrefour fidelite”. In this sense, Carrefour Banque expressly states that no other information other than the specific one would be transmitted. However, CNIL discovered that other data was transmitted, including postal address, number of children, and telephone number.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: H&M Hennes & Mauritz Online Shop A.B. & Co. KG
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: H&M operates in a service center in Nuremberg and is based in Hamburg. The Hamburg data protection officer discovered that, since 2014, specific details about the lives of some employees of H&M were comprehensively recorded and stored as information on a network drive. In one of these cases, the company devised a “Welcome Back Talk” after its employees had returned from a vacation or an illness. All the information that the company obtained during this time, including specific information about the illnesses and medical diagnoses of the employees, were retained and stored. The Hamburg data protection officer also found that the H&M supervisors obtained general information about its employees “through the grapevine”, such as religious beliefs and family problems. All the information stored on the network drive was made accessible to over 50 managers of H&M, and they used it to evaluate the work performance and efficiency of all employees, as well as make employment decisions. This fact became known when the H&M servers encountered a technical error, and the data on the network drive became accessible to all employees for a few hours. The management subsequently apologized to all affected employees and offered monetary compensation in return for this offence. The data protection authority established more robust protective measures to prevent such incidents from happening again.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The American College of Greece was fined EUR 1,000 by the Hellenic DPA (HDPA) for violating the right of access and the right to demand the erasure of personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Hungary
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information (NAIH)
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 18 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company denied a data subject’s access to video material recorded by a CCTV camera in a local store (stating that the data subject needed an official order for that). The data subject wanted to use the footage to prove that he or she did not receive change after paying in the store. The company denied access to the footage, this violating Art. 15 of the GDPR, but also deleted the footage after some time, despite the fact that the data subject requested the footage no to be deleted, under Art. 18 (1) c) GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Hungary
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information (NAIH)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hungarian DPA (NAIH) imposed a fine of HUF 50,000 (EUR 1,385) to the company for having taken inadequate technical and organizational measures to ensure the security of the personal data. Next Time Media Agency Ltd., a web agency, was contracted by the travel agency Robinson Tours Idegenforgalmi es Szolgaltato Kt. (Robinson Tours Ltd.) to devise and manage the agency’s online reservation system. However, the responsible party supplemented the system with real data of Robinson Tours’ customers, despite receiving no such instructions. Overall, the data of over 781 people was compromised between November 13, 2019, and February 4, 2020. Anyone could access the data with a simple Google search.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Hungary
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information (NAIH)
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 25 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b) GDPR, Art. 34 (1) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Robinson Tours Ltd. received a fine of HUF 20,500,000 (EUR 55,400) after the Hungarian DPA (NAIH) discovered that the company’s online reservation system contained unprotected customer data that could be access by anyone on Google. The data contained address and contact data, names, passport numbers, and copies of personal IDs. Apparently, the company in question had hired the web agency Next Time Media Agency Ltd. to create, manage, and test a database for the online reservation system. However, the web agency used not only test data but also real data of Robinson Tours’ clients. The total number of affected customers was 781, and personal data about them was made accessible to anyone in the period from November 13, 2019, to February 4, 2020. The NAIH deems that Robinson Tours failed to perform consistent security risk checkups and screenings, and neither did it notify the affected customers of the data breach.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Ireland
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Data Protection Authority of Ireland fined the Cork University Maternity Hospital after confirming that the personal data of 78 patients had been disposed of in a public recycling center. Part of the documents included special-category personal data of six patients, among which were future planned care programs and medical history.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Ireland
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to notify DPA of a data breach
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Twitter was issued a fine of EUR 450,000 by the Irish DPA for violating Art. 33 (1) and Art. 33 (5) GDPR, regarding the failure to notify the DPA of a data breach, and the inadequate documentation of the data breach. This data breach was linked to privacy settings of users on Twitter. Users would have the option to set a post as private, in which case only subscribers of that respective user would see the post, or public. A programming bug on the Twitter Android app resulted in posts marked as “private” to be publicly visible to the entire Twitter consumer base. This data breach should have been reported to the DPA in 72 hours and properly documented. Twitter International Company failed to do both these tasks. Their legal team found out about the data breach on January 2nd, 2019, and only notified the DPA about it on January 8th.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Data Protection Authority found out that personal data of several participants in a public competition had been disclosed online. This happened due to a configuration error, where a list of the codes assigned to all the candidates was publicly accessible on the platform for some time, which allowed unwarranted access to the participants’ personal data by other candidates. Scanshare violated the principle of protection of information security, despite being the data controller on behalf of “Azienda Ospedaliera di Rilievo Nazionale ‘Antonio Cardarelli” (private hospital), and was fined with EUR 60,000.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Azienda Ospedaliera di Rilievo Nazionale 'Antonio Cardarelli' (Private Hospital)
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 28 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data protection authority discovered that the hospital had not complied with the information obligations and did not provide adequate processing agreement with the data processor, under Art. 28 GDPR. The incident involved the unlawful disclosing of personal information about participants in a public competition. Because of a configuration error with the platform, the list of codes assigned to the participants was temporarily accessible on the platform, making it easy to access the personal data. The DPA deemed this to be a violation of the principle of protection of information security.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (2) a), f) GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Due to a human error in the integration of two IT systems, personal health data of over 74 patients were made accessible to other patients via the online medical reports on their smartphones. The data protection authority was notified of this breach in due time, under Art. 33 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 7 GDPR, Art. 15 (1) GDPR, Art. 16 GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR, Art. 25 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 33 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Multiple
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Vodafone Italia was fined EUR 12,251,601 for unlawful processing of personal data belonging to millions of customers, for telemarketing purposes. The legal proceedings were preceded by hundreds of complaints coming from data subjects about unsolicited phone calls, which made the data protection authority to start the investigations. During the investigation, several violations of the data protection law were discovered, such as a violation of the consent requirements and the violation of general data protection obligations (accountability, for instance). The data protection authority criticized the use of fake phone numbers by the Vodafone contracted call centers (in that the phone numbers had not been registered with the National Consolidated Registry of Communication Operators). Moreover, Vodafone was also found guilty of several violations regarding the handling of contact lists obtained from external providers. Lastly, the data protection authority considered the security measures used to manage the customer data to be inadequate and insufficient.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Ireland
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Irish DPA has fined Meta Inc with EUR 1.2 billion for unlawful data transfers to the US. The company was ordered to stop transferring the data of European users from Europe to the United States after failing to comply with the EU’s highest court’s 2020 decision that bemoaned the insufficient protection of the data shipped across the Atlantic from American spy agencies. The Irish DPA mentioned that this fine only applies to Facebook, and not Instagram or WhatsApp, which Meta also owns. Meta has 5-6 months to comply with this decision but the official statements claimed that they would appeal the fine and that there would be no service disruption to European users. Meta could also avoid the massive fine if the European Union and American officials close the new data-sharing pact (Data Privacy Framework) that harmonizes the GDPR legislation with US data collection. If Meta is to comply with the Irish DPA’s ruling, Facebook will have to delete vast amounts of user data or move it back in a legal space. Meta has become an easy target for GDPR regulations after several multi-million-dollar fines for data leaks and insufficient user consent.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Personal data belonging to persons who have claimed damage reports against the authority was published on the website of the authority without sufficient legal basis. The data included tax ID, first and last name, and address).

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company engaged in non-compliance practices when the personnel director of the company forwarded an email conversation to four people, regarding the physical and mental discomfort related to the data subject and a work colleague.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) b), c) GDPR, Art. 9 (1) b) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (garante) registered a complaint from the union UILCOM Sardegna toward the call center operator Concentrix Cvg Italy s.r.l. concerning one of the internal regulations of the responsible party. The call center company imposed a “clean desk policy”, where the employees were prohibited to keep specific items on their desks, including smartphones, for the purpose of maintain confidentiality during the processing of customers’ personal data. The company made an exception in the case of medication that certain employees would need to take. However, the medication had to be placed visibly on the desk, which also meant that the medication was visible to other co-workers, indirectly exposing the data subjects’ health status. While the data controller had obtained the consent of all employees regarding the rules of procedure, it did not inform them about the processing of health data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: During a documentary regarding the link between a local ceramics plant and health problems in the population, the television station did not sufficiently anonymize the person interviewed.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Latvia
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company’s website contained a privacy policy that was not easily understandable, which is a violation of Art. 13 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Lithuania
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) d) GDPR, Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: As part of the data synchronization of the Population Information System of the Municipal Administration with the databases of the State Centre for Business Registers, an applicant’s personal data who wanted to adopt a child was replaced, through an unfortunate error, with the personal information of the biological parents. This information was accessible in the Population Register of the Republic of Lithuania, which constituted a violation of the principles of accuracy, integrity, and confidentiality of personal data processing, according to Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Norway
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Municipality had published a student file on its website, which contained personal data about the student. The Data Protection Authority imposed a fine of NOK 200,000 (EUR 18,840) on the municipality.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f), (2) GDPR, Art. 25 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b), d), (2) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Data Protection Authority fined Virgin Mobile Polska EUR 443,000 because of a data leak that resulted in unauthorized third parties gaining access to personal data. The company had not taken the adequate and sufficient security measures to protect the data. Moreover, the DPA noticed that the company had not conducted consistent and extensive tests on the effectiveness of the security measures employed. The company would only test the security measures when a suspected security leak occurred.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Towarzystwo Ubezpieczeń i Reasekuracji WARTA S.A.
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to notify DPA of a data breach
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Polish Data Protection Authority (UODO) fined Towarzystwo Ubezpieczeń i Reasekuracji WARTA S.A EUR 18,930 for a breach under Art. 33 (1) GDPR and Art. 34 (1) GDPR. Back in May 2020, the Polish DPA was notified by a third party that a data breach occurred at Towarzystwo Ubezpieczeń i Reasekuracji WARTA S.A, regarding an insurance agent posing as a processing agent at the company. The insurance agent sent an insurance policy to an unauthorized third party via e-mail. The document contained personal data regarding the subject of the insurance policy, including first names, surnames, residential addresses, and other information. Then, the supervisory authority demanded that the company clarify whether it performed any risk analyses on the data security of natural persons, in connection to the electronic correspondence sent to an unauthorized third party, as this would make it evident that a data breach had occurred. If a data breach does occur, the company responsible is obligated to notify both the DPA and the affected parties. Despite being sent a letter by the supervisory authority asking for explanations on the data breach, the responsible party did nothing to report the data breach to the DPA or inform the affected data subjects about the data breach. Finally, the DPA initiated administrative proceedings, which eventually prompted the company to report the data breach and notify the two affected individuals about the incident.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with Data Processing Authority's orders
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Fined for failing to comply with an order of the supervisory authority.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with Data Processing Authority's orders
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Fined for failing to comply with an order of the supervisory authority.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company unlawfully disclosed personal data of employees on the company website due to inadequate organizational and technical measures to ensure information security.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Several clients complained to the Romanian DPA (ANSPDCP) that Vodafone refused to respond to their requests for access and erasure of data. Moreover, the data controller could not offer any evidence for exoneration.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company disclosed the delivery, order, and personal data of more than 1000 customers on its webstore, in a document that could be downloaded and accessed without access protection. This is a clear result of the inadequate organizational and technical measures taken. Moreover, the company also did not notify the data protection authority of this data breach.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Banca Transilvania was fined EUR 100,000 by the Romanian DPA (ANSPDCP) for violating Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art 32 (1) GDPR, and Art. 32 (2) GDPR. The DPA found out that the bank asked a customer to declare the intended purpose and use of a specific amount of money withdrawn from their personal account. The statement was submitted to the bank online, and it was forwarded to a couple of employees of the bank. One of the employees took a picture of the declaration and forwarded it via WhatsApp. Then, the document was also posted on Facebook and another website. Therefore, this resulted in the unauthorized disclosure and access of personal data concerning four data subjects, despite the bank’s commitment to observe the principles of integrity and confidentiality of personal data, under Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR. The Data Protection Authority also noticed that this data breach showcased how under-trained the Bank’s employees were with regard to the standards for data protection. The DPA obliged the Bank to implement stricter and more rigorous technical and organizational measures, as well as trainings for its employees, under Art. 32 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 58 (1) a), e) GDPR, Art. 58 (2) i) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with Data Processing Authority's orders
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company failed to comply with the Romanian Data Protection Authority’s requests for information, thus violating Art. 58 (1) a), e) GDPR and Art. 58 i) GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Qualitance QBS SA was fined EUR 1,000 by the Romanian DPA because it violated Art. 32 GDPR. The company sent information to 295 individuals by email, where it disclosed email addresses of all the other recipients. The ANSPDCP noticed that the company had not taken adequate security and organizational measures that would have ensured the confidentiality of the data subject’s personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA filed ING Bank N.V. Amsterdam – Bucharest Office with EUR 3,000 for unlawfully processing the personal data of a former customer without his consent (e-mail address, and name), as part of a procedure to update the customer’s data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 7 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company had a lack of information in the privacy policy section, and an inadequate obtainment of consent, since there was only a general type of consent without differentiating between various types of data processing purposes.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company unlawfully used personal data for marketing purposes.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 28 (3) g) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company processed the personal data of the data subject despite the termination of the contractual relationships between the two parties, which is a violation of Art. 28 (3) g) GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company used a personal photo of the data subjects for marketing purposes without a sufficient legal basis.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company was fined to the unlawful processing of personal data without having the sufficient legal basis, due to the incorrect information related to the owners of prepaid phone cards (the confusion was between the actual owners of the prepaid cards and the registered owners in the company’s business register).

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Caja Rural San José de Nules S. Cooperativa de Crédito
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company unlawfully published information containing the names and surnames of its employees. The data subject’s financial situates was illegally disclosed, as a result.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Centro de Investigación y Estudio para la Obesidad, SL
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The responsible party was fined for having transferred the data subject’s personal data to Evo Finance EFC, SA while processing a health insurance application, without being within its legal rights to do so, since the specific medical treatment was not carried out yet.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The restaurant used a CCTV that also captured public space, which is a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: No data protection officer appointed
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company, despite being a private security company for video surveillance systems, did not appoint a data protection officer, and it thus violated Art. 37 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company used a membership contract containing a pre-defined privacy policy that prevented any express consent and negotiation of the signing client.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company unlawfully used a CCTV camera surveillance system to capture the public space, which is a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data subject complained to the DPA that the company had unlawfully issued invoices to him, and also collected the respective amounts from his bank account, without the data subject even being a customer of the company. The complaints against the company have yet to meet with any legal success.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company’s website, which is a license plate seller, demanded personal information in the form of first and last name, copy of ID card and driver’s license, as well as the car’s VIN number, yet did not offer an updated data processing policy in accordance with the GDPR, or an encrypted transport protocol.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Despite receiving a warning issued by the AEPD (Spanish Data Protection Authority), the company neither granted nor justifiably denied the right of the data subject to erase his/her data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company unlawfully posted photos of a person on Facebook and accused the person of theft in other posts. The photos were obtained from the company’s video surveillance system. Moreover, the company encouraged others to share the posts and the photos, which resulted in hundreds of people humiliating, insulting, and threatening the respective individual. The AEPD fined the company EUR 10,000 for the publishing of the photos, and EUR 2,000 for failing to install a required sign for the video surveillance of the store.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company violated Art. 6, 13, and 14 GDPR, which prompted the Spanish DPA (AEPD) to fine the company with EUR 40,000. The company is the operator of a phone prank app where you can prank other people by entering their phone numbers. The recipient of the call is called from a suppressed number and “pranked”. The APED took notice of a violation of the operator’s obligation to offer information regarding the collection of personal data of the person to be pranked. Moreover, the company does not inform the data subject (the person to be pranked and recorded) of his/her right to consent according to the provisions of the GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Losada Advocats S.L. violated Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR by sending an e-mail to dozens of recipients, without including them on the BCC list (Blind Carbon Copy).

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Asociación de Víctimas por Arbitrariedades Judiciales, (JAVA)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The association unlawfully published personal data of data subjects on its website. The specific personal data had been recorded during a previous legal proceeding without the data subjects’ consent.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Following a complaint from a woman to Comercio Online Levante, the Spanish AEPD discovered that the woman in question received access to the personal information of another user when accessing her personal user account of the online store perfumespremium.es.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company unlawfully concluded a contract in the name of the data subject without obtaining consent from the data subject first. Moreover, the data subject learned of this matter when he/she received a complaint about a breach of his/her contractual obligations. The AEPD concluded that the company had unlawfully processed the data subject’s personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The doctor had no privacy policy on his website, which is a violation of Art. 13 GDPR. The original fine was in the amount of EUR 4,000, though it was reduced to EUR 2,400 because the responsible party immediately acknowledged the debt and paid it in full.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Borjamotor S.A. sent commercial advertisements to the data subject in question by means of e-mail and SMS, despite the data subject having revoked his/her consent to receive said advertisements, as well as a request to delete his/her personal data. Despite the company confirming this, the data subject kept receiving SMS and e-mail marketing materials.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (AEPD) fined Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentgaria S.A. with EUR 5,000,000 for violating Art. 13 GDPR (EUR 2,000,000) and Art. 6 GDPR (EUR 3,000,000). The bank had not used the precise terminology in its Privacy Policy, and it did not implement the necessary procedures to ask for the consent of the customers regarding the data processing. It also failed to provide the necessary information regarding the type of data it would process. The company’s privacy statement is not sufficiently clear about the legal basis of the data processing.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 8 (1) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) a) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company was fined with EUR 10,000 by the AEPD for violating Art. 13 GDPR, when it stated on its website privacy notice that a minimum age of 13 was required to subscribe to the newsletter. Moreover, when filing out the newsletter subscription form, the company would take that as a consent to the processing of personal data. However, Art. 8 GDPR states that people under-16-year-olds need the consent of the parents or persons with parental responsibility to consent to the data processing.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 48 (1) b) LGT, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 23 (4) LOPDGDD
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: One data subject received marketing calls from two different phone numbers of Iberdrola Clientes SAU, despite the data subjecting being registered in the Robinson list. The company acknowledged this human error, saying that the phone numbers that the data subject received promotional calls from were not usually used for promotional purposes.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Sweden
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The City of Stockholm had a data breach on a school education platform, where one of the systems lacked the ability to restrict user access to the personal data, thus allowing several staff members with protected identities to access information about their students. Another sub-system let parents access personal information about other students with relative ease. Through Google, you could enter an administrative interface where obtaining information about teachers with a protected identity was made possible.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Sweden
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR, Art. 36 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Municipality illegally used a video surveillance system in a care home for disabled people with specific functional disabilities.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Sweden
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 (2) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The hospital failed to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures to ensure proper information security. The Swedish DPA found that the hospital carried out no risk analyses regarding access to patient data. The hospital information systems (Cosmic, Nationell patienttoversikt, and TakeCare) had not assigned the authorization for users according to the principle of minimum access. All the users had full access to all patient data, irrespective of work purposes or not.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Sweden
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 (2) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The hospital failed to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures to ensure proper information security. The Swedish DPA found that the hospital carried out no risk analyses regarding access to patient data. The hospital information system TakeCare had not assigned the authorization for users according to the principle of minimum access. All the users had full access to all patient data, irrespective of work purposes or not.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Sweden
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 (2) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The hospital failed to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures to ensure proper information security. The Swedish DPA found that the hospital carried out no risk analyses regarding access to patient data. The hospital information systems Melior and Nationell patienttoversikt had not assigned the authorization for users according to the principle of minimum access. All the users had full access to all patient data, irrespective of work purposes or not. Moreover, the Melior information system did not keep any records of when or for what purpose the patient data was accessed.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Sweden
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 (2) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Östergötland Region failed to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures to ensure proper information security. The Swedish DPA found that the company carried out no risk analyses regarding access to patient data. The hospital information system Cosmic had not assigned the authorization for users according to the principle of minimum access. All the users had full access to all patient data, irrespective of work purposes or not.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Sweden
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 (2) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Aleris Sjukvård AB failed to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures to ensure proper information security. The Swedish DPA found that the company carried out no risk analyses regarding access to patient data. The hospital information system Nationell patienttoversikt had not assigned the authorization for users according to the principle of minimum access. All the users had full access to all patient data, irrespective of work purposes or not.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Sweden
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The University failed to apply the appropriate organizational and technical measures to ensure proper data security. As part of a research project on male rape, information about police reports, containing names, ID numbers, contact details, health information, and details about the sex lives of data subjects, as well as information related to the suspected crime, were stored in the cloud of a U.S. service provider. The Swedish DPA notes that the cloud services don’t properly protect the sensitive data in a way fitting its significance. Moreover, one investigation report was sent to the Swedish police in an unencrypted form, and the responsible party did not document or report this incident to the DPA.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Sweden
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The housing company installed a surveillance camera system to monitor a specific floor after repeated disturbances and security incidents occurred there. However, the surveillance system also captured the front door of a resident making it as such that, upon the door being opened, the camera would capture the inside of the apartment. While the original purpose of the housing company was legitimate, the residents’ right to privacy trumps that purpose.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: United Kingdom
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Ticketmaster UK Limited received a fine of GBP 1.25 million or EUR 1.405 million for using inadequate protection measures to secure the personal data of its customers. More than 9.5 million European customers may have been affected by a data breach between February 2018 and June 23, 2018, because of a faulty chat bot hosted on a third-party online payment site, which made it easy for a potential attacker to gain access to customer’s financial details. The ICO discovered that, among the affected personal details, there were names, expiration dates and CVVs, full payment card numbers, and Ticketmaster passwords and usernames. During the investigation, the ICO also found out that more than 60,000 payment cards belonging to the Barclays Bank customers were fraudulent. Other international banks reported fraudulent activities to Ticketmaster, as well.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: France
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company was fined EUR 20,000 by the French DPA for failing to supply its Privacy Policy with the necessary information required by the GDPR. Moreover, the company also did not offer sufficient information regarding the data processing during the app registration of its users.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Data Protection Authority of Lower Saxony fined the electronics retailer notebooksbilliger.de with EUR 10.4 million for failing to provide a legal basis for its 2-year video-surveillance of its employees. The video cameras covered recreation areas, warehouses, workplaces, and even sales areas. The electronics company noted that the video surveillance system had been put in place to prevent any criminal activity and to strictly follow the movement of goods in the warehouses. However, the GDPR states that, to prevent theft, milder alternatives need to be considered first, before moving on to video surveillance. Video surveillance should only be used if there are any reasonable suspicions of theft for specific individuals. However, notebooksbilliger.de had no such suspicions, and utilized the video surveillance indefinitely for two years, without limiting its scope to specific individuals. Some video recordings were even retained for 60 days, which is well over the required time period in such cases. Lastly, many customers of notebooksbilliger.de were affected by the video surveillance, as some cameras covered the seating areas, as well.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Norway
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Datasylnet, the Norwegian DPA, filed Innvasjon Norge, the national development bank, a total of EUR 95,000 (NOK 1,000,000). The data controller had performed four credit checks on the data subject without any contractual reasons to do so. It also did not ask for permission from the data subject when it checked financial data over a period of three months.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Norway
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company had performed four credit checks on individuals and companies without a sufficient legal basis to do so.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Norway
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data controller had performed four unsolicited credit checks on a single individual without having the legal basis to do so.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Norway
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The store’s manager recorded CCTV footage with his mobile phone and shared the video. According to the Norwegian DPA, Coop Finmark had no legal reason or motivation to share the CCTV footage. This is even more the case when the DPA found that the footage contained children, which would pose a serious risk to their privacy.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Śląski Uniwersytet Medyczny (Medical University of Silesia)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Medical University of Silesia received a fine of EUR 5,500 or PLN 25,000 from the Polish DPA (UODO) for illegally using the video identification of its students during medical exams held over videoconferences at the end of May 2020. After the exams were over, the exams’ recordings were not only available to the examinees, but also to various people who had access to the system. Moreover, any external individual could access the recordings and the personal data of each student by accessing a direct link. Finally, the University neither reported the data breach to the DPA, nor did it notify its students of the data breach.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Despite the data subject concluding a contract with the data controller (Vodafone Espana), the services provided were in the name of a third party, and not in the name of the data subject. The data subject contacted the data protection officer of Vodafone Espana by email to request an update to his/her personal data. However, no response was given. Eventually, the data subject phoned the company to solve the issue, yet he/she was addressed in the name of the third party by the Vodafone Espana operators. The company said that this issue was caused by a problem with a system migration. Due to the admission of guilt and early payment, the fined was reduced from EUR 90,000 to EUR 45,000.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Caixabank S.A. was fined EUR 6,000,000 by the Spanish DPA (AEPD) for violating Art. 6 GDPR, Art .13 GDPR, and Art. 14 GDPR. Caixabank was going to transfer its customers’ personal data to all other companies in the CaixaBank Group, and the customers would have to accept the new privacy policy. However, the data subjects were not provided with an option to refuse to consent to this. If they disagreed with this action from the bank, they were supposed to send a letter of disagreement to each of the companies in the CaixaBank Group. Clearly, this is an absurd predicament, as the AEPD concluded that the bank did not respect its information obligations according to Art. 13 GDPR and Art. 14 GDPR. The information provided to the customers in the privacy policy was not accurate and consistent, it had vague and imprecise terminology, and failed to offer a clear picture of the nature of the data processing as well as what type of information would be processed. Information on the data subject’s rights and the contact information of the data controller were not offered consistently and accurately. Moreover, the DPA also argues that the customers’ consent was not taken effectively, and that the data controller had processed the customers’ data partly illegally, beyond the required scope. Moreover, various deficiencies in the bank’s systems allowed it to obtain consent from customers who had not expressly offered their consent. The data processing was done without a legal basis, thus breaching Art. 6 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Alterna Operador Integral S.L. was fined with EUR 50,000 by the AEPD because it had switched a data subject to another electricity supplier without obtaining the consent of the data subject. Moreover, the personal data of the data subject were incorporated into the databases of the new electricity supplier without a valid contract existing between the data subject and the electricity supplier. In conclusion, the personal data of the data subject was processed without a legal basis.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company ignored the data subject’s objection to receiving advertising letters and continued to send an advertising newsletter by email.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company used a CCTV monitoring system in the proximity of the hotel, yet the cameras also captured public roads outside the hotel. The principle of data minimization was breached.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 7 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company unlawfully processed personal data of data subjects, including health data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company failed to take the proper technical and organizational measures to ensure the accuracy of personal data transmitted over the phone regarding the concluding of contracts. This means that specific contracts were concluded over telephone on behalf of other data subjects.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Various documents related to the personal data of a public tender were published on a website.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The community unlawfully published on its website personal data of various data subjects, including places of birth, names, birth dates, places of residence, and more.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Hungary
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information (NAIH)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company failed to comply with a data subject’s request to access information in a given time period.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Entrepreneur running a non-public nursery and pre-school
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with Data Processing Authority's orders
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The person was fined for not answering repeated requests for supplementary information from the data protection authority, regarding a data breach.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The community illegally published personal data on the community’s official website.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: France
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c), e) GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 28 GDPR, Art. L34-5 CPCE
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company sent advertising emails to various data subjects without being able to provide evidence of prior consent.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company unlawfully used a video surveillance system to monitor a residential community, which was not in compliance with the regulations of the GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Estonia
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Apotheka e-apteek, Azeta.ee e-apteek, Südameapteegi e-apteek
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Estonian DPA fined the three pharmacies EUR 100,000 for illegal processing of personal data without obtaining the consent of the data subjects. The personal data was related to the prescriptions for medicines. In this sense, other third parties could access another data subject’s current prescriptions on the online website of the pharmacies without the data subject’s consent. The access was made only on the basis of their personal identification code. The Estonian DPA also noticed that, indeed, an e-pharmacy should allow people to purchase prescription medicine on behalf of others, the processing of the data subjects’ personal data should still be done with the consent of the data subjects in question. The claim of another party that the data subject has given their consent does not equal to an official voluntary consent, since the pharmacy cannot check whether the data subject has indeed given their consent, and to what purpose.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c), e) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA fined Gaypa s.r.l. with EUR 20,000 because the data controller had kept the email address of a former employee active. The company had constant access to the data subject’s inbox, even though their contractual relationships had been concluded. The data subject wasn’t informed of this continued use of his/her email account, or about the continued storage of his/her incoming and outgoing emails on the servers of the company, or about the data processing.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA fined the company for having installed a video surveillance system that recorded three data subjects during their time at work. In this sense, the data subjects had not been properly informed about the processing of their personal data as part of the video surveillance.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 28 (2), (3) GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Multiple
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The municipality had been unlawfully processing the personal data of employees and users of TuPassi booking system used to manage appointments and various other services since 2015. The Italian DPA found out that the data controller had infringed upon several of the GDPA regulations related to the processing of personal data of employees and customers that had made appointments using the TuPassi system. Moreover, the municipality had not informed the data subjects of the data processing, and it also did not take the appropriate organizational and technical measures to safeguard the data processing.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), e) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 28 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: This company is the provider of the TuPassi booking system, which had been used by the Rome Municipality since 2015 to book appointments on the website of the data controller (www.tupassi.it) or through the app. Miropass S.r.l. collects personal data of the users for this reason, though the Italian DPA found out that the company had no legal basis to process personal data (health data regarding appointments at healthcare facilities), thus violating the principle of storage limitation.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Belgium
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 7 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 28 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Multiple
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Belgian DPA fiend the company, an advertising agency, EUR 50,000, for sending soon-to-be mothers gift boxes with product samples, vouchers, and information about pregnancy and birth. However, the items in the box would be sent by third parties, to whom the company offered the personal data of the data subjects. The company would ask for the consent of all data subjects regarding the transfer of the personal data to third parties for marketing purposes. However, the Belgian DPA was notified that the company ignored the revoking of a data subject’s consent, and continued to use her personal information for the purpose of advertising calls from third parties.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company was fined because it failed to cooperate with the Polish Data Protection Authority. The company failed to provide data reguested by the UODO.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Croatia
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 32 (1) b), d) GDPR, Art. 32 (2), (4) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: One data controller who was using the services of the security company reported to the DPA a breach a personal data. Apparently, an employee of the company had recorded the video surveillance footage with a phone only to share it with other third parties and make it available on social media and the media. The Data Protection Authority discovered that the breach occurred due to a lack of organizational and technical measures regarding personal data security that extended two and a half years in the past. Moreover, the company had failed to foresee any such breaches of security, while also foregoing to implement any security measures after the incident to prevent or minimize the risk of future breaches from occurring. As a result, a data subject was the target of insults and social ridicule following the exposure of the recordings on social media, and the security company did nothing to remove it. While the fine is unknown as of now, the DPA listed out the aggravating factors it would take into consideration when applying the fine – (i) the data processor failed to fulfill its obligations to inform the data controller of the breach as per Art. 33 (2) GDPR, (ii) the area of expertise of the company is technical protection, including video surveillance. The DPA also notes that the company in question is a leading company in this domain in Croatia, and as such should hold relevant opinions, advice, and also propose solutions regarding the use of video surveillance systems, setting an example through its conduct.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Cyprus
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company was fined EUR 40,000 by the Cypriot DPA for using an automated system and tool assessment based on the Brad-Factor to monitor, manage, and control the absence of employees because of sickness. The tool assessment was unlawful since the Cypriot law didn’t cover it. Moreover, the company did not offer the data subjects the liberty to offer their consent to the data processing of their personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Cyprus
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) e), f) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b), c) GDPR, Art. 33 (1) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic Bank was fined with EUR 25,000 for forgetting to move out a safe containing old documents of existing customers when closing down one of its branches in Nicosia, in 2015. The safe had been installed in a wall, prompting the employees to forget about it. The bank was notified about this incident in 2019, when the new tenant of the building found the safe and notified the bank. In turn, the Hellenic Bank reported this data breach to the Cypriot DPA who concluded that the bank had breached Art. 5 (1) e), f) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b), c) GDPR, and Art. 33 (1) GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Cyprus
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 31 GDPR, Art. 58 (1) e) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: A data subject of the Cypriot Real Estate Registration Authority demanded access to his personal data from the data controller, thus attempting to exercise his right under Art. 15 GDPR. However, the data controller failed to respond to his query, which prompted the data subject to notify the DPA. Following a investigation by the DPA, the data controller also failed to respond to the multiple requests of the DPA to offer comments on this allegation of the data subject.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Cyprus
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The real estate company KEPIDES submitted a list containing the names of the properties under its management to a parliamentary committee. However, the company did not anonymize the names of the data subjects, resulting in a data breach.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Denmark
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: On the 12th of February 2021, the Aarhus District Court decided to fine IDdesign with EUR 13,450, disagreeing with the initially proposed fine of EUR 200,850. The Court concluded that the fine amount should instead the calculated based on the company’s subjective turnover instead of the entire group. Moreover, mitigating circumstances according to Art. 83 (2) GDPR have also been accounted for. The company hadn’t previously breached the GDPR, and the data breach only concerned general personal data, resulting in no damage suffered by the data subjects. The data breach also had a negligent nature, which the Court also took into account.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The private individual unlawfully took pictures of vehicles and, in some cases, of their drives, emailing the photos to the city of Magedburg without encrypting them, allegedly as a report of violations of the Road Traffic Regulations.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The soccer club was fined with EUR 300,000 for a negligent breach of data protection accountability. Despite this, the data controller provided ample assistance to the DPA’s investigation and took the initiative to clarify the situation.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Ireland
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) e), f) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) GDPR, Art. 33 (1) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The College Dublin had a total of seven personal data breaches when unauthorized third-party entities accessed the University’s e-mail accounts, using the login credentials posted online. Apparently, the data controller did not take appropriate security and organizational measures to protect data security when processing personal data via the email service. Moreover, the data controller stored specific personal data in an email account that made it possible to identify the data subjects for longer than it was necessary. Finally, the University College Dublin failed to notify the DPC of a personal data breach timely.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) c), e) GDPR, Art. 6 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (3) b) GDPR, Art. 37 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 37 (7) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Multiple
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data controller had published a document containing personal data belonging to a council member. The document also contained data pertaining to a complaint procedure field against the council member by the mayor. Anyone could download the document freely without any authentical needed. Moreover, the municipality did not appoint a data protection officer, and did not notify the DPA of any such appointment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) c), e) GDPR, Art. 6 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (3) b) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Multiple
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The municipality had published on its website two documents containing data about a legal settlement of a data subject. Not only were the documents freely accessible but they could also be downloaded at any time. The personal data included about the data subject were the first and last name, confirmation of the payment of legal costs, the IBAN code of the data subject’s checking account, the amount paid in favor of the data subject, and information about the lawsuit.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Ordine degli Assistenti Sociali della Regione Lazio
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: When a data subject filed a request to the data controller demanding information about the data being processed about him and his daughters, the company gave no response to the request for information. A couple of months later, the data subject filed a complaint to the DPA, and eventually, his request for information was complied, though the company offered no explanation about the delay or the lack of an initial response.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Regione Lazio failed to designate the company entrusted with the management of its reservations for healthcare services in 1999, as a data processor. Apparently, the company did not enter a contract with Capodarco, which would have governed the role of the company as a data processor according to the requirements of the data protection law. Only in 2019 had a contract been concluded, which means the data had been unlawfully processed for 20 years.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data controller had used the biometric data of its employees to register their attendance. However, the Data Protection Authority (Garante) discovered that this data processing was no proportionate, resulting in an infringement upon the rights of the data subjects. Finally, the data processing of the biometric data was unlawful!

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: In one of the hospitals controlled by the data controller, 49 patients of the oncology ward were given discharge letters containing detailed pharmacological information belonging to other patients. Before the error was corrected, 14 patients had already accessed the documentation. Apparently, the error occurred due to a manual error of a technician.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: A theft was committed, and the data controller lost an external hard drive containing personal data. The data contained copies of identity documents, payroll records, and tax records. The DPA also discovered that the external hard drive had been located in a room where all the data controller’s employees had access. Moreover, the data controller failed to back up the data, which led to a permanent loss. Finally, the DPA concluded that the data controller violated its responsibility to implement the appropriate organizational and technical measures that would ensure the security of the data being processed.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
