The personal data was related to the prescriptions for medicines. In this sense, other third parties could access another data subject’s current prescriptions on the online website of the pharmacies without the data subject’s consent. The access was made only on the basis of their personal identification code. The Estonian DPA also noticed that, indeed, an e-pharmacy should allow people to purchase prescription medicine on behalf of others, the processing of the data subjects’ personal data should still be done with the consent of the data subjects in question. The claim of another party that the data subject has given their consent does not equal to an official voluntary consent, since the pharmacy cannot check whether the data subject has indeed given their consent, and to what purpose.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Estonia
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Estonian DPA fined Azeeta.ee e-apteek with EUR 100,000 for illegal processing of personal data without obtaining the consent of the data subjects. The personal data was related to the prescriptions for medicines. In this sense, other third parties could access another data subject’s current prescriptions on the online website of the pharmacies without the data subject’s consent. The access was made only on the basis of their personal identification code. The Estonian DPA also noticed that, indeed, an e-pharmacy should allow people to purchase prescription medicine on behalf of others, the processing of the data subjects’ personal data should still be done with the consent of the data subjects in question. The claim of another party that the data subject has given their consent does not equal to an official voluntary consent, since the pharmacy cannot check whether the data subject has indeed given their consent, and to what purpose.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Finland
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, § 3 Law 759/2004
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: A higher education institution received a fine of EUR 25,000 from the Finnish DPA for violating data protection regulations during the processing of employee location data. The data controller had previously implemented a mobile application, allowing teleworkers to clock in and out. However, to use this application on a mobile device, the workers had to provide location data. The data collection took place automatically when the workers clocked in, and it was an in-built feature of the app. Without this feature, the workers couldn’t clock in. Based on the information provided by the data controller, this location data was not used nor exploited in any specific way, but rather it was only processed when the workers clocked in, for technical reasons. However, the simple fact that the app doesn’t allow workers to clock in without collecting their location data doesn’t make it a necessity to collect that data. The company could have devised the app differently. At that point, the Finnish DPA concluded that the company had violated data collection principles as well as the principle of data minimization, since it wasn’t necessary to collect location data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) f) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA (also known as HDPA) fined Ιγνατιάδης Νικόλαος και ΣΙΑ Ε.Ε. with EUR 2,000 because the data controller had installed and used surveillance security cameras in areas where company employees were present. The data controller claims that these cameras were there for security purposes after some theft incidents had occurred in the past. The security system was meant to detect and take notice of anyone entering the facilities. However, the DPA found out that the camera installations weren’t only used for property protection purposes. So, the DPA concluded that the company had violated the principle of data minimization.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA fined a pediatrician with EUR 5,000. The data controller did not comply with a father’s request to view his son’s medical records through e-mail.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Hungary
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Budapesti Műszaki és Gazdaságtudományi Egyetem (Budapest University of Technology and Economics)
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 9 (2) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Multiple
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hungarian DPA (also known as NAIH) fined the Budapest University of Technology and Economics with EUR 22,200. The data controller had unlawfully processed the personal data of many individuals during the audit of social scholarship applications. The data controller had no legal basis to process the personal data, especially sensitive data, since there was no good reason to process it for the evaluation of the applications.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Hungary
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) d) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 12 (2), (3), (4) GDPR, Art. 17 (1) GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: he Hungarian DPA (also known as NAIH) has fined Magyar Telekom Nyrt. with EUR 28,400. The data controller had mistakenly sent email newsletters to the data subject because a third-party had entered the wrong email address to the newsletter list. Then, the data subject requested numerous times for the data controller to delete his personal contact data. But despite this, he continued receiving the newsletter, and the data controller sent him a link that he could use to unsubscribe from the newsletter.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Mapei S.p.A. did not respond to the request for access to personal data from a data subject. Additionally, the company did not close down the email account of the data subject even after terminating the work contract.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) fined Charly Mike s.r.l with EUR 3,000. The data controller is an operator of Hotel Olimpo in Alberobello. The Italian DPA received a complaint about the hotel’s video surveillance system. The investigation pointed out that the hotel had installed 17 fixed cameras and one with 360° recording. These cameras were placed both inside and outside the hotel, and they recorded customers and employees alike. This system had been operated without any sign of its existence, as well.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Azienda Unita Sanitaria Locale Toscana Sud Est
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 28 GDPR, Art. 30 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) fined Azienda USL Toscana Sud Est with EUR 100,000. The data controller works in the healthcare sector and has launched the “Sanita di iniziativa” program. This program encompasses participating companies transmitting healthcare data of chronically ill patients to the data controller. Then, the controller will develop personalized health plans for these patients, based on the provided health data. However, the Italian DPA noticed several data protection violations regarding the program. One such violation regarded the consent that data subjects would have to provide to have their health data processed. The data subjects weren’t properly informed about the length of the data storage, their rights (right of access and complaint), for what purpose and how their data would be processed. Moreover, the data controller didn’t keep a register of the processing activities. It also did not protect the data processing and also did not conduct a data protection impact assessment, despite this being necessary because of the sensitive nature of the personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), f) GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) fined Istituti ospedalieri Bergamaschi with EUR 45,000. During an investigation prompted by a report of a data breach, the DPA found out that a patient had mistakenly received clinical documentation and medical records from seven patients in this digital medical record.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) fined Azienda Ospedaliera Universitaria Careggi with EUR 6,000 for violating Art. 5 GDPR and Art. 9 GDPR. The institution had previously notified the Italian DPA of a data breach as per Art. 33 GDPR, regarding the transmission of health data to a wrong individual. Apparently, the institution had sent medical documents belonging to a patient to another person, by mistake. The data controller claims that this incident took place because of a printing process. Out of two printers present at the ward where the affected patient was being treated, one had preloaded medical health data of another patient, which a doctor sent to his print job (documents of the wrong recipient).

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Ministero dell’Istruzione, Ufficio Scolastico Regionale per il Lazio
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined the Lazio Region School Authority with EUR 4,000. A parent had previously filed a complained against the school authority because it had forwarded personal data of his disabled son to the Office of Public Administration. This personal data included information about the underaged child’s health condition. The parent had complained in the past about various irregularities found in the allocation of support hours for disabled students at the I.C.G. Pitocco school of Castelnuovo di Porto. Apparently, the school authority had transmitted that personal data to discard this allegation, but the DPA concluded that the data transfer was unlawful.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Azienda Provinciale per i Servizi Sanitari di Trento
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) fined Azienda Provinciale per i Servizi Sanitary di Trento with EUR 150,000. The data controller mistakenly sent 293 medical records of 175 patients to their respective general practitioners, despite the patients requesting them not to do this. Two of the affected patients were minors, and several other patients were women who had undergone abortions. During the investigation, Garante discovered that the health data was transmitted because of an error in the patient report management software.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) fined Azienda Usl della Romagna with EUR 120,000. The health authority of Romagna had mistakenly transmitted the abortion health report of a patient to a general practitioner despite the patient requesting not to inform her general practitioner about the abortion. The report was transmitted via the regional network “Sole.” During the investigation, Garante found out that the software that manages discharges, transfers, and patient admissions glitched, which resulted in the data transmission.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Aeroporto Guglielmo Marconi di Bologna S.p.a.
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The identity of the whistleblowers that contributed to this report requires protection from special confidentiality because the processed information is sensitive. Moreover, the risk of retaliation and discrimination in the work environment is unusually high. Moving on, the data controller is always obliged to comply with the principle of data protection, as well as ensure the security and integrity of the data. In this context, the Italian DPA (also known as Garante) fined Aeroporto Guglielmo Marconi di Bologna S.p.a. with EUR 4,000 and its software supplier, aiComply S.r.l. with EUR 20,000. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the application used for managing and collecting criminal reports had been accessed without a security protocol. Moreover, the application failed to provide encryption for the reporting party’s identification data, the attached documents, and any information about the reports. The DPA concluded this was a violation of the obligation to take adequate organizational and technical measures that would ensure a proper level of security relevant to the risk to the data subjects. Moreover, the DPA found out that the data controller should have carried out an impact assessment, considering how sensitive the processed data was, and the magnitude of the vulnerabilities of the data subjects.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Norway
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b) GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Norwegian DPA (also known as Datatilsynet) fined the municipality of Asker with EUR 100,000. Back on the 20th of May 2020, the DPA received a complaint about the unlawful publishing of personal data on the municipality’s official website. Anyone could view document names that were previously sent through the municipality’s email distribution list. Additionally, these documents also contained dates of birth and names of more than 127 people, and this included children. Even though the distribution lists were checked by two people daily, the municipality failed to detect this security breach. The Norwegian DPA states that this data breach was at least partly caused by a lacking security routine regarding the email lists.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: ID Finance Poland Sp. z o.o.
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 25 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b), d), (2) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Polish DPA (also known as UODO) fined ID Finance Poland Sp. z o.o. with EUR 235,300. Because of an error during the restart of a server, a server’s security server suffered an error and its settings were reset. This made the personal data of 140,699 individuals become publicly available. This data contained information about their addresses, first and last names, marital status, and nationalities. Moreover, the database containing this information was downloaded and deleted from the servers by an unknown third party who later asked the company for a ransom if they wanted the database back. The DPA concluded that the data controller had taken inadequate and insufficient organizational and technical measures that would protect the data processing, despite the existence of a high risk for the data subjects.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Marbella Resorts S.L. with EUR 7,000. In this case, a data subject had previously booked a room in the company’s hotel complex. When the data subject was scheduled to arrive, a concierge copied the data subject’s data despite not being authorized to do this. The concierge should only have verified the data subject’s reservation and give the data subject the keys to the room. After the provided the concierge with his personal data, the data subject noticed that his personal data was published on a website with online content for adults. Therefore, the DPA concluded that the data controller didn’t show enough diligence in taking care of its clients’ personal data, violating Art. 29 (3) GDPR. The fine is composed proportionally of EUR 2,000 for a breach of Art. 22(2) LSSI and 5,000 EUR for a breach of Art. 28(3) GDPR. However, the original fine of EUR 7,000 was reduced to EUR 4,200 due to the immediate payment and admission of guilt.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Sweden
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 (2) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Västerbotten Region failed to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures to ensure proper information security. The Swedish DPA found that the company carried out no risk analyses regarding access to patient data. The hospital information system Cosmic had not assigned the authorization for users according to the principle of minimum access. All the users had full access to all patient data, irrespective of work purposes or not.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Netherlands
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Dutch Supervisory Authority for Data Protection (AP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Dutch DPA (also known as AP) fined Overijssel with EUR 7,500 because it failed to notify the DPA of a personal data breach, violating Art. 33 GDPR. Due to a human error, an email containing information about a meeting had been set through an open distribution list. All 101 recipients were addressed as “Friends of the PVV” in this email, which openly stated their political beliefs, something that’s unlawful and against their basic privacy.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Netherlands
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Dutch Supervisory Authority for Data Protection (AP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Dutch DPA (AP) has imposed a fine of EUR 525,000 on Locatefamily.com. Locatefamily.com is a platform where people can search for the contact information of family members they have lost contact with or other people they would like to get in touch with. The data subjects complained that their contact information (name, address, phone number) was published on the website without their knowledge. The data subjects were not able to request the deletion of their data published on the site easily, because Locatefamily.com did not have any representation in the European Union. Organizations offering goods or services in the EU must have a representative to whom EU citizens can turn to obtain information or exercise their data protection rights. Accordingly, the Dutch data protection authority found a breach of Art. 27 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Netherlands
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Dutch Supervisory Authority for Data Protection (AP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Dutch DPA (also known as AP) has fined CP&A with EUR 15,000. As part of the recording procedures of employee absences due to illness, the data controller documented the causes of illness and complaints of the data subject. However, the DPA discovered that this was unlawful because health data has special protection from this. Employers aren’t allowed to record the causes or reasons of sick leave. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the data controller failed to implement the required organizational and technical measures that would protect the data processing when recording absences. More specifically, the absence registration was accessible online with no authentical procedure in place. Normally, when the absence system is available online, it should have a multi-factor authentication procedure in place. According to the DPA, a more complex form of authentication. should have been put in place, aside from the normal login procedure.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Netherlands
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Dutch Supervisory Authority for Data Protection (AP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Dutch DPA (also known as AP) has fined an orthodontic clinic with EUR 12,000. As part of the online sign-up procedure for new patients (mostly underaged), there were mandatory fields with various patient personal data. This data, after being entered into the fields, was sent to the orthodontic clinic through an unencrypted connection. Clearly, this pose a massive risk of unauthorized access from unknown third parties, exposing the data subjects to danger.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Netherlands
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Dutch Supervisory Authority for Data Protection (AP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Dutch DPA (also known as DPA) has fined TikTok, a video portal, with EUR 750,000 because it violated the privacy of young children. The privacy policies presented to Dutch users (mostly underaged children) was in English, making it difficult for them to understand the policies. Because the privacy policies were not in Dutch, TikTok failed to adequately explain how their app processes, collects, and reuses personal data. The DPA concluded that this is a violation of the company’s duty to provide accurate information.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Ireland
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Facebook owned messaging app WhatsApp has been fined by the Data Protection Authority of Ireland with a huge sum of €225 million. This concludes an investigation spanning from 2018. The Data Protection Authority of Ireland commented that WhatsApp discharged its GDPR transparency obligations with regard to the provision of information and the transparency of that information to both users and non-users of WhatsApp’s service. This includes information provided to data subjects about the processing of information between WhatsApp and other Facebook companies.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Fundację Promocji Mediacji i Edukacji Prawnej Lex Nostra
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Polish DPA (also known as UODO) has fined the Fundację Promocji Mediacji i Edukacji Prawnej Lex Nostra with EUR 3,000. The institution promoted the mediation and legal education. But the data controller did not inform the DPA about a data breach regarding some data subjects. A couple of folders with personal data were stolen from the data controller in 2020. These folders had names, addresses, telephone numbers, and even PESEL numbers of more than 96 data subjects.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Denmark
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Danish DPA has fined Midtjylland Region with EUR 53,800. On the 12th of June, 2020, the DPA was notified by the region regarding a personal data security breach as per Art. 33 GDPR. According to the region, all staff and patients at a lifestyle center could access a building where approximately 100,000 physical patient records were stored. These records included health information and personal identity number details. This data breach took place because both staff and patients had received key cards that allowed them to access all three buildings of the lifestyle center, even though the users may not require to use them. Additionally, passersby could see the covers of some records though a window on the building. These covers showed personal data such as identity numbers and names. Therefore, the DPA concluded that the Midtjylland Region had failed to take adequate security measures to store the personal data. Moreover, the region had further failed to establish enough guidelines for access restrictions when creating the security key cards, and had also failed to conduct the necessary periodic testing, assessment, and evaluation of the security measures it had taken. In assessing the question of whether a fine should be imposed, the Danish DPA took into account, as an aggravating factor, that the region processed large amounts of sensitive data, such as health data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Ireland
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Irish DPA has fined Vodafone Ireland Limited with EUR 1,400. Vodafone had previously sent marketing SMS, emails, and made telephone calls without obtaining the consent of the data subjects. Despite several complaints of the data subjects, Vodafone continued sending SMS messages, emails, and making calls to the data subjects. In one case, a former customer had contacted Vodafone a total of seven times, asking not to receive any more advertising calls on his cell phone. Despite his request, he continued to receive advertising calls. In another case, a customer had received an advertising call on his mobile phone number and told Vodafone that he did not want to receive more advertising calls. Despite this complaint, Vodafone made twelve more marketing calls to his cell phone. Another data subject filled out a form where he stated that he wanted Vodafone to refrain from making advertising calls to his cell phone. However, the employee who processed his request did not register the customer’s marketing preferences. So, the customer subsequently received fourteen more unsolicited commercial messages – seven emails and seven text messages.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) c), e) GDPR, Art. 6 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (3) b) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined the Region of Lombardy with EUR 200,000. The region had previously published on its website the personal data of more than 100,000 students who had applied for state scholarships or financial grants to buy technical equipment, textbooks, and teaching materials. During the preliminary audit of Garante, one could view and download the full list of approved and funded applications, as well as the lists of state scholarship recipients, and the list containing ineligible applications on the official website of the region. These lists contained personal data that could identify each individual, including the names, IDs, grades, names and codes of the school, and the application number. The DPA concluded that the personal data of applications applying for these economic benefits should be protected at all times through special ways in order to prevent and social and economic problems.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 30 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Flowbird Italia s.r.l.  with EUR 30,000. Garante had previously launched an investigation because of a complaint from a data subject who had issues with the new parking meters that were installed in the city of Rome in 2018. In fact, the company Atac s.p.a., which was contracted by the city to manage the aforementioned parking lots, had performed a technical upgrade of the parking meters to provide new services (such as the payment of fines/fees or the purchase/renewal of public transport tickets) and introduce new payment methods that could also take into account the vehicle’s license plate number. Some of the equipment had been supplied by Flowbird Italia s.r.l. All the parking information was then put through and managed by a centralized system that could also be accessed through an app by any employees responsible for managing parking fees. During the investigation, Garante discovered that Flowbird Italia had not established a data processing register either.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 30 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Atac s.p.a.  with EUR 400,000. Garante had previously launched an investigation because of a complaint from a data subject who had issues with the new parking meters that were installed in the city of Rome in 2018. In fact, the company Atac s.p.a., which was contracted by the city to manage the aforementioned parking lots, had performed a technical upgrade of the parking meters to provide new services (such as the payment of fines/fees or the purchase/renewal of public transport tickets) and introduce new payment methods that could also take into account the vehicle’s license plate number. Some of the equipment had been supplied by Flowbird Italia s.r.l. All the parking information was then put through and managed by a centralized system that could also be accessed through an app by any employees responsible for managing parking fees. It was also discovered that the companies had failed to establish a data processing register. Moreover, the retention periods for the collected data had not been specified, and appropriate security measures had not been taken. For instance, the DPA found out that, at the time of the audit, some data leaks going to and from the system installed by Atac had been going through insecure channels. Additionally, officials of the city could have easily checked any license plate en masse and repeatedly to, say, find out a person’s parking location and habits.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: President of the Zgierz District Court
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 25 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b), d), (2) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Polish DPA (also known as UODO) has fined the president of the Zgierz District Court with EUR 2,200. The president had previously reported a data breach that involved the loss of an unencrypted USB stick by a probation officer. The stick was used to store the data of about 400 persons under probation supervision. The lost and unencrypted data carrier has been found yet, so this means that unauthorized persons could still be able to access the personal data it contained. The president had wrongfully assumed that the duty to secure the data wasn’t his but the respective probation officers’ who were using this data stick. However, the DPA found that the president himself should have secured the USB sticks.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 28 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 33 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA (also known as ANSPDCP) has fined Actamedica SRL with EUR 3,000. The data controller had previously informed a data subject about the misplacement of her biological samples as well as a sum of money sent via a courier service. When the data subject inquired on the specific personal data that had been discloses during this data breach, and whether the company had informed the ANSPDCP, the data controller provided only the contact details of its lawyer as well as the email address of the courier service that the data subject could complain to. The ANSPDCP discovered a data breach regarding the controller’s obligation to implement organizational and technical measures that would ensure a proper level of protection appropriate to the risk to data subjects, as well as a breach of the controller’s obligation to notify the ANSPDCP of the data breach.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a company owner with EUR 2,000. A private individual had applied for a job at the data controller’s company and sent the controller his CV through WhatsApp. From that point on, the data subject was not informed about the processing of his personal or his data subject rights. The AEPD considered this to be a violation of Art. 13 of the GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined an agency with EUR 1,800. The data controller had improperly disposed of documents containing personal data of its clients in the garbage. The AEPD claimed this to be a total lack of security and data protection countermeasures as outlined by Art. 32 GDPR, which states that ‘the controller and processor shall implement appropriate technical and organizational measures to ensure an adequate level of security.’ The original fine of EUR 3,000 was reduced to EUR 1,800 due to voluntary payment and acknowledgement of guilt.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined an owners’ association with EUR 1,000. The data controller had illegally installed a video surveillance system in a residential complex that recorded, among others, public areas like the swimming pool, and of the public space. Additionally, surveillance cameras had been installed in the rooms where the guards of the residential complex changed their clothing, without any notice being given. The DPA considered this to be a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 21 (4) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) fined FurnishYourSpace S.L. with EUR 6,000. The AEPD had previously received a complaint from the Berlin DPA through the EU Internal Market Information System regarding the inadequate design of the data controller’s privacy notice. More specifically, both the contact data and the identity of the data controller were included in the privacy notice, but they were provided under false pretenses. Additionally, the data controller did not clarify the goals of the data processing. Moreover, he provided no legal basis for the processing and retention of the personal data, and no information was offered regarding the data subjects’ rightto object. Also, the privacy notice was complicated, with the wording containing grammatical errors and making use of uncommon and needlessly complex terminology. Finally, the privacy notice also required a tax identification number in order to issue a simplified invoice, i.e., an invoice that did not exceed the amount of EUR 3,000. The AEPD stated that this was a violation of the principle of legality. The fine is composed as follows: EUR 3,000 for a breach of Art. 12 GDPR and Art. 13 GDPR; EUR 1,000 for a breach of Art. 21 (4) GDPR; and EUR 2,000 for a breach of Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR and Art. 6 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 21 LSSI
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Automecanica Jerez, S.L. with EUR 4,000. The data controller had previously sent several commercial e-mails to a large number of people without obtaining their consent. By doing so, the data controller did not anonymize the personal data of the recipients, such as the surname, first name and email address. This allowed the other recipients to view the data of other recipients, as well. The AEPD concluded that this was a violation of Article 5 (1) f) GDPR and Article 32 GDPR, since the controller had ultimately failed to implement technical and organizational measures that would ensure a sufficient level of security in the processing of personal data. Furthermorem the AEPD found a breach of Art. 21 LSSI.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Cyprus
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Cypriot DPA has fined the soccer club APOEL FC with EUR 40,000. Because of a lack of security measures in the club’s ticket sales system, unauthorized individuals could access the even disclose personal data of fans visiting the club’s website. This data involved the names, the fan card numbers and the ID numbers of the data subjects. The DPA concluded that the club had failed to implement the adequate technical and organizational security measures that would protect the personal data. In separate proceedings, the DPA fined AC Omonia and Hellenic Technical Enterprises Ltd. for the same violations.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Cyprus
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Cypriot DPA has fined the soccer club AC Omonia with EUR 40,000. Because of a lack of security measures in the club’s ticket sales system, unauthorized individuals could access the even disclose personal data of fans visiting the club’s website. This data involved the names, the fan card numbers and the ID numbers of the data subjects. The DPA concluded that the club had failed to implement the adequate technical and organizational security measures that would protect the personal data. In separate proceedings, the DPA fined APOEL FC and Hellenic Technical Enterprises Ltd. for the same violations.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Cyprus
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Cypriot DPA fined the Hellenic Technical Enterprise Ltd. with EUR 40,000. The data controller had designed the ticket sales system for the two soccer clubs, APOEL FC and AC Omonia FC. Because of a lack of security measures in the club’s ticket sales system, unauthorized individuals could access the even disclose personal data of fans visiting the club’s website. This data involved the names, the fan card numbers and the ID numbers of the data subjects. The DPA concluded that the club had failed to implement the adequate technical and organizational security measures that would protect the personal data. In separate proceedings, the DPA fined APOEL FC and AC Omonia FC for the same violations.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Denmark
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Danish DPA has fined the Favrskov Municipality with EUR 10,000. Back on the 19th of August, 2020, the DPA received a notification from Favrskov Municipality regarding a personal data breach under Art. 33 GDPR. The notification claimed that, during a break-in at the municipality’s premises, a laptop had been stolen that contained a program which provided overviews of the municipality’s care facilities and information about the names and personal identity numbers of more than 100 individuals with mental or physical disabilities. The specific computer hard drive was unencrypted and the program, which contained sensitive and private personal data, wasn’t equipped with any security measures. While investigating the case, the DPA discovered that the Favrskov Municipality had failed to ensure the encryption of the laptops’ hard drives for a long time before August 12, 2020, which resulted in an inadequate level of security. The DPA considered this to be a violation of Art. 32 GDPR, since the municipality had failed to implement the proper technical and organizational measures that would ensure a level of protection commensurate with the risk.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Denmark
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Danish DPA fined the Syddanmark Region with EUR 67,200 on. On March 9, 2020, the DPA received a notification from Syddanmark Region regarding a personal data breach pertaining to Art. 33 GDPR. The Syddanmark Region claims that, since May 2011, a PowerPoint presentation made at Odense University Hospital for training purposes and containing personal data (ID card number details and health information of 3,915 patients, was made public on the official website of the region. The region had been using a screening tool to analyze for inadvertent posting of any personal identity numbers on its website. But this tool couldn’t scan any data in PowerPoint presentations. As such, the DPA discovered that the region had failed to implement the proper organizational and technical measures that would ensure the adequate level of protection appropriate to the risk at hand. When assessing the necessity of a fine, the DPA also considered that aggravating factor of the region’s processing of large amounts of personal data, which also included health data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: France
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 16 GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR, Art. 30 GDPR, Art. 31 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The French DPA (also known as CNIL) has fined Société nouvelle de l’annuaire français (SNAF) with EUR 3,000. SNAF operates the website annuairefrancais.fr, which lists French companies based on data published by the French Statistical Office. Between 2018 and 2019, the CNIL received a total of sixteen complaints that indicated problems when requesting the erasure and rectification of personal data. As a response, the CNIL promptly requested that SNAF complies with the requests within two months, which SNAF failed to do. Henceforth, the CNIL imposed the fine on SNAF, mainly for failing to comply with the rights of rectification and erasure of the data subjects, as well as for the lack of cooperation with the CNIL.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Insufficient data processing agreement
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The DPA from Hamburg has fined Vattenfal Europe Sales GmbH with EUR 900,000. The fine relates to data matching, which the data controller had carried out between August 2018 and December 2019 in the course of contract inquiries for special contracts. These special contracts were issued in order to attract potential new customers, and also came with bonus payments for these customers. The data controller made a comparison between contracts concluded by existing customers and potential customers who had previously submitted inquiries for special contracts. The data controller would reject the application for special contract if it was revealed that the application had previously signed a contract with the data controller then switched to another supplier. This was done to avoid any “bonus shopping”, which companies find unprofitable. However, the data controller failed to inform the customers about the data processing involving these comparisons. The DPA then concluded that the data controller had violated the company’s transparency policies and information obligations, since over 500,000 people had been affected in this data breach.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined Dixons South East Europe ΑΕΒΕ-ΚΩΤΣΟΒΟΛΟΣ with EUR 20,000. A data subject had previously filed a complaint against the data controller after it failed to comply with his right to information. The data subject tried returning a product, and proceeded to ask the data controller through Facebook Messenger to inform him about his request to cancel the credit card statement that was sent electronically to the bank. Despite this justified request, the data controller refused to comply, so the data subject demanded the bank to do the same. The bank, however, did not reply.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined the National Bank of Greence with EUR 20,000. A data subject had previously filed a complaint against the bank and a company after the data controllers failed to comply with his right to information. The data subject tried returning a product, and proceeded to ask the data controller through Facebook Messenger to inform him about his request to cancel the credit card statement that was sent electronically to the bank. Despite this justified request, the data controller refused to comply, so the data subject demanded the bank to do the same. The bank, however, did not reply.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: NOW DOCTOR – Εταιρία Παροχής Ηλεκτρονικών Υπηρεσιών Αναζήτησης και Προβολής Ιατρών Ε.Π.Ε.
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), e) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 12 (2), (3) GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined the operator of the nowdoctor.gr medical platform that enables the online booking of medical appointments. A doctor had previously filed a complaint with the DPA. At the same time, she had also repeatedly stated that she didn’t wish to work with the data controller, while requesting the deletion of her data on the platform. The data controller failed to comply with the request of the data subject on the spot. Instead, the data deletion took place 18 months later, after the DPA had requested to data controller to proceed with the deletion. The DPA concluded that this was a clear breach of the data controller’s accountability obligations. It was further found that the data controller had been storing the data of the data subject for longer that was necessary for the intended processing purposes (providing online display services). These display services would stop existing at the moment the data subject used her right to stop working with the data controller. Additionally, the DPA found out that the data controller failed to facilitate the data subject’s access to her rights as per Art. 12 GDPR. Finally, while the data controller provided a public email address on its website through which the data subject could maintain communication, the controller was understaffed and there was no one to process this communication.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 12 (3) GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Greek DPA fined the Rhodes Municipal Transport Company with a fine of EUR 8,000. One of the former employees of the transport company filed a complaint against it with the DPA. At that time, the employee was engaged in a legal dispute with the transport company after the employer had reported him for alleged embezzlement. In this context, the employee had requested from the employer a copy of the video recordings taken by the bus’s video surveillance system during the data that the alleged embezzlement occurred. This video recording was necessary for this defense. However, the data controller failed to respond to this request. The DPA concluded that this was a clear violation of the data subject’s right to information, as per Art. 12 (3) GDPR and Art. 15 GDPR. Moreover, the data controller provided the former employee with a certificate of his former employment. Among others, the certificate contained the duration and type of the employment, as well as a notice of dismissal on charges of criminal offenses. This was a violation of the principle of proportionality as per Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR, according to the GDPR. The issued fine consists of EUR 3,000 for violating Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR and EUR 5,000 for violating Art. 12 (3) and Art. 15 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Norway
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 28 (3) GDPR, Art. 32 (2) GDPR, Art. 44 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Norwegian DPA has fined Ferde AS, which is a Norwegian toll company, with EUR 496,000. After receiving a report from NRK, state-owned broadcasting company, the Norwegian DPA started investigating Ferde AS, discovering that the company had been transferring information on passages in various toll rings to a data processor in China. In this context, the DPA started a large-scale investigation into the company, with the purpose of finding out whether the company had implemented measures and routines that could ensure the information security of this information transfer to China. It should be noted that Ferde AS was also responsible for registering passages at toll booths through a chip in the car. If a car had no chip or if the chip wasn’t properly registered, a photo of the car’s license plate would be taken. These images would then be sent to an automatic optical character recognition system that would digitally read the license plate. If the image wasn’t clear enough, it would go through manual processing. Ferde AS had contracted Unitel Bratseth Services (UBS) to do this job. During the investigation, the DPA found out that the subcontractor also had employees in China. Moreover, Ferde AS had violated many obligations under the GDPR for 1-2 years. In on instance, Ferde failed to conduct a risk management assessment before the processing of personal data and the processing of manual images. This risk assessment was necessary to assess any underlying risks associated with the data transfer, and to also determine whether further security measures should be taken. Additionally, the DPA discovered that Ferde did not enter an official processor contract with UBS. Therefore, the transfer of personal data to China occurred without a legal basis. When determining the value of the fine, the DPA also considered the large amount of the affected personal data as an aggravating factor. However, the implicated data subjects received no material or immaterial damage, which had a mitigating effect on this whole affair.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined GESTIONES AUTO LOW COST S.L. with EUR 1,000 because the company’s website did not contain a privacy policy.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a hairdressing salon with EUR 1,000 because the data controller had installed a video surveillance system in its premises without properly informing the data subjects about the data processing.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Frigorifica Botana S.L. with EUR 4,000. The company’s main activity is freezing, processing, and storing seafood. A data subject issued a complaint with the AEPD against the data controller, which prompted the DPA to begin investigations. Apparently, the data controller had installed an audio and video surveillance system that captured certain parts of the conference room. The DPA stated that the data controller had violated the principle of data minimization by processing this data without having a legal basis. It also failed to inform the data subjects about the data processing.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (AEPD) has fined CEDICO, CENTRO DE DIAGNOSTICO POR LA IMAGEN, S.L. A data subject complained to the AEPD against the data controller. He had previously gone to get an MRI scan of his knee because of a work-related accident. He had also contacted his insurance company for a sick leave. After the insurance company contacted the data controller, the latter transmitted the medical records of the data subject to the insurance company. But by doing so, the data controller offered the insurer a report of another MRI scan of the knew that the data subject had received for an event outside of work. While assessing the need for a sick leave, the insurer considered the MRI report in the medical records outside working hours, attributing the data subject’s incapacity to work to this event. So, they granted no sic leave to the data subject. The DPA considered that the data controller unlawfully disclosed the MRI report to the insurer, violating the principle of integrity and confidentiality. The original fine of EUR 30,000 was briefly reduced to EUR 18,000 because of voluntary payment and admission of guilt.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Denmark
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Danish DPA has fined the Danish Cancer Society with EUR 107,000 for not complying with the requirements of the GDPR related to the appropriate security measures. The Danish Cancer Society had previously reported a total of four data breaches according to Art. 33 GDPR to the DPA. Two of these data breaches involved computer thefts and two phishing attacks – all four were caused by the Danish Cancer Foundation’s failure to implement organizational and technical measures that would ensure a level of security appropriate to the risk to data subjects. A similar personal data breach had already occurred in August 2018, when the Foundation encountered spoofing and phishing hacking attacks. The Danish Cancer Society claimed that it should increase protection via multifactor authentication. However, the society did not implement this. The data of at least 1,448 individuals was compromised, and in several cases, it involved sensitive personal health data, including medical history.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined the real estate portal La Prima S.r.l. with EUR 5,000. A data subject had complained against the controller with the DPA, saying that she had received a contact request on LinkedIn by one of the La Prima employees. The employee wanted to offer real estate services regarding a specific property owned by the data subject in question. The data controller had apparently obtained the contact data of the data subject as well as information about the ownership of the property from a public register. But the data subject had not consented to this contact request. During the DPA investigation, the data controller argued that it doesn’t need consent in this case because the data subject had a public profile. However, the DPA stated that the exchange of information on a social network should only be carried out within the relevant terms of use. The DPA further claimed that the social media platform is in its right to enable the exchange of contact information to make job offers. However, social media platforms aren’t meant to be used to send messages to other users to sell services. Moreover, it doesn’t matter if the profile was public or not. So, the DPA concluded that the data controller had processed this data unlawfully.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Luxembourg
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) a), b) GDPR, Art. 33 (1), (5) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Luxembourg DPA has fined an insurance company with EUR 135,000. On the 19th of October, 2018, an employee of the data controller had sent an e-mail to a foreign third party instead of the data subject. This took place because of an error committed by the employee who had incorrectly inputted the e-mail address of the data subject. Aside from the name and gender of the data subject, the e-mail also talked in great detail about the data subject’s illnesses. Additionally, the attachment contained three forms regarding the illnesses that the data subject had previously reported in connection with a life insurance policy the subject had concluded. On the 29th of November, the same incident took place. The second misdirected e-mail contained, aside from the data subject’s name, specific questions about a particular pathology, the last name of the data subject’s life insurance doctor, the address of the doctor, and two blank forms related to this pathology that should be filed out by the data subject or his doctor. The DPA further stated that the data controller had failed to notify the data breach in due time, as per Art. 33 GDPR. Moreover, the insurance company failed to comply with its documentation obligation as per Art. 33 (5) GDPR. The DPA also concluded that the data controller did not implement the necessary organizational and technical measures that would ensure the protect of the data subjects’ private information.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a bar owner with EUR 3,000 because of a data subject’s complaint to the DPA. The data subject had been the victim of an accident in the bar, and the whole event was recorded by the surveillance system. The data controller claims that the security cameras had been installed for security reasons. Later on, this video had been distributed through WhatsApp and then published on a digital newspaper online. The data subject states that this event had personally affected his reputation. The DPA concludes that the data controller unlawfully publicized these images, as it was not done for the purpose of the video surveillance, violating Art. 5 (1) b) GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined CYNGASA, S.L. with EUR 5,000. When a data subject requested a work report from the company, he found out that the data controller had disclosed his personal data to an unauthorized third party company without obtaining his consent first. This data involved his first and last name, as well as his social security number.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: No data protection officer appointed
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined ACONCAGUA JUEGOS, S.A. with EUR 10,000 because the data controller failed to appoint a data protection officer, violating Art. 37 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined the owner of a store with EUR 2,000. The data controller had previously installed a video surveillance system that covered the public street, among other areas. The DPA concluded that the data controller had violated the principle of data minimization by filming the public street.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Caldereria Y Soldadura De Estructuras Metalicas, SL
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined CALDERERIA Y SOLDADURA DE ESTRUCTURAS METALICAS, S.L. with EUR 5,000 because of an unlawful processing of a data subject’s data. CYNGASA S.L, another company, had disclosed the data subject’s private information to the data controller without obtaining consent of the data subject. This data included, among others, the first and last name of the data subject, as well as his social security number. CYNGASA, S.L. was fined separately for the same offence.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) e) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b), d) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined CLUB DEPORTIVO SANSUENA, S.L. with EUR 4,000 because it unlawfully added the phone number of a data subject to a WhatsApp group without obtaining the consent of the data subject.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined ORANGE ESPAGNE, S.A.U. with EUR 30,000 because a data subject complained to the DPA about receiving 30 calls and SMS messages between 03/01/2021 and 03/03/2021 from Jazztel employees, which is a subsidiary of Orange Espagne, S.A.U. These phone calls and SMS messages were sent to the data subject despite the fact that the data subject hadn’t ever been a customer of the company. The data subject requested that the company delete her data, but she kept receiving phone calls and SMS messages, despite the fact that the data controller confirmed the deletion of her data. The original fine of EUR 50,000 was reduced to EUR 30,000 because the data controller admitted his guilt and voluntarily paid the fine.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined MAF.COM ESQUI CLUB with EUR 10,000. The mother of an underaged girl who attended ski lessons with the data controller complained to the DPA that the data controller had published videos of her daughter on its official website and social media without obtaining the mother’s consent. The data controller had obtained the consent of the father, but at the time, the two parents were divorced, and the DPA claimed that the data controller should have obtained consent from both parents. This means that the data controller processed the images without a valid legal basis, so the Spanish DPA issued a fine of EUR 10,000 for this offence.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Ireland
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 12 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 (1) c) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: An organization called None of your business (NOYB) published a draft decision of the Irish DPA on the 13th of October, 2021, indicating that the DPA wants to fine Facebook between EUR 28 million and EUR 36 million. Apparently, the draft addresses the fact that Facebook had included specific details on data processing in its terms of service, following the provisions of Art. 6 (1) b) rather than Art. 6 (1) a) GDPR. Some critics call this a loophole that Facebook intelligently uses to bypass the strict GDPR requirements of consent, those of Art. 6 (1) a). On the other hand, the DPC clearly states that the GDPR doesn’t establish any hierarchy of specific legal bases that a company can use to process personal data. However, the DPC further noted that Facebook did not provide any clear information regarding the legal basis it used for the data processing, further emphasizing that Facebook provides discontinuous information. The company also sends users to various texts and documents of the terms of services and data policy. The DPC thus concludes on its draft that Facebook had violated Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, art. 12 (1) GDPR, and Art. 13 (1) c). This draft decision has been forwarded to other European data protection authorities.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 12 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined the Ciechi Ardizzone Gioeni di Catania residential home for blind people with EUR 5,000 because of a complaint of a visitor to the residence. Apparently, the data subject saw that a video surveillance system had been installed in the accommodation. This video surveillance system recorded, among others, the connecting corridor  between the accommodation and the communal showers. This footage was recorded and displayed in real time on the staff’s monitors, thus creating a risk that the footage could be seen by suppliers or the visitors. During the DPA’s investigation, the administration of the institution argued that they had installed the video surveillance system to combat theft and provide adequate safety to the residents by preventing unauthorized access during the pandemic. However, the DPA stated that the institute had violated the principles of transparency, lawfulness, and data minimization. Even though the institution claimed that the quality of the footage showing the passage of the residents to the shower room was not clear enough and also of a short duration, the DPA states it was still unlawful. The DPA also claims that the institute could have ensured the safety of its residents in other, less invasive ways that would not restrict the freedoms of the data subjects, referring to a temporary switch-off of the cameras when filming the corridor to the shower rooms, or ensuring the security of these locations through other measures aside from video surveillance. Moreover, the DPA states that the institute failed in properly informing its residents about the video surveillance. They only provided information about the surveillance system to their residents after the DPA investigation had formally begun. Ironically, the information they offered wasn’t suitable for blind or visually impaired people. Instead, the institute should have provided its residents with pre-recorded audio-messages that the residents could listen to.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c), e) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR, Art. 44 GDPR, Art. 46 GDPR, Art. Art. 2-sexies Codice della Privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Bocconi University with EUR 200,000 after a student had filed a complaint with the DPA regarding alleged GDPR violations related to the use of a surveillance system during written exams. During the emergency situation of the Covid-19 pandemic where students couldn’t take live exams and in person, the university acquired a remote monitoring software called Respondus, from the American company called Respondus Inc. This software would monitor the students’ behavior via video recordings and snapshots taken at random intervals. Additionally, the exam was also audio-visually recorded, and the students had their photographs taken at the beginning of the exam. When the exam finished, the system would process the video and insert warning signals attached to each video, regarding potential indications of incorrect behavior (foul play). Among others, the system assigned “review priorities” to various videos so the examiner could further analyze whether there was any foul play in the video. During an investigation, the DPA discovered that the students hadn’t been informed about the processing of their personal data via Respondus. For instance, the students hadn’t been informed that they would be audio-visually recorded, and that these images would then be processed. Moreover, the students weren’t provided with any information regarding the retention period of this data. They also weren’t given enough information about whether or not their data would be transferred to the United States. Instead, they were only told that their data would be processed both inside and outside the European Union. Moreover, the DPA also found that even the information provided to the students had been chaotic and disorganized, placed in multiple documents in a fragmented form. This is a clear violation of the principles of fairness, transparency, and lawfulness, according to the DPA. The DPA also found that the university had processed this personal data without a proper legal basis. They needed to obtain the consent of the students regarding this personal data, before they participated in the exams. Alternatively, the university proposed in-person exams but the pandemic meant that this option presented certain health risks. The students also thought that refusing to take the online exams would clearly impact their grades. So, the DPA concluded that the students had not voluntarily given their consent. Moreover, the DPA also discovered that the university had retained the data for 12 months, despite this not being necessary for the purpose of making sure that the exams were valid. Finally, the DPA also discovered several violations regarding the transfer of data to Respondus. Namely, the processing agreement between Respondus and the university relied on the data protection agreement between the USA and the EU, the Privacy Shield agreement, which had previously been invalidated by the Schrems II ruling of the Court of Justice of the European Union. Thus, the DPA concluded that the university unlawfully transferred the personal data of the students to a third country, despite this not being compliant with the conditions stipulated in Chapter V of the GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 7 GDPR, Art. 12 (2) GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 28 GDPR, Art. 29 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) fined Sky Italia S.r.l. with EUR 3,296,326 for illegal telemarketing. The DPA received numerous complaints from people claiming that they’d received unsolicited telemarketing calls and SMS messages from Sky Italia directly and via various call centers of other companies. So, the DPA started investigating the phenomenon. They found out that Sky Italia had made the calls without properly informing the users how they got their hands on the data subject’s personal data. If Sky Italia had done this, the data subjects could have opposed to the data processing by contacting the company who had their data and objecting to the data processing. If the data subjects gave their consent, only then would Sky Italia be allowed to send them commercial offers. Instead, the company used the personal data obtained from various companies for these promotional purposes. However, despite the fact that the data subjects had given their consent to the disclosure of their data to said third party companies, Sky Italia had no right to acquire these lists of personal information and use them for its own promotional purposes. Additionally, Sky Italia also failed to check the list of individuals who had objected to the data processing regarding the advertising messages. Instead, the company proceeded with the marketing calls without taking this into account. Several data subjects who had objected to the data processing ended up receiving advertising calls. Moreover, the DPA discovered that Sky Italia did not appoint its data suppliers as data processors. When calculating the fine, the DPA considered the fact that Sky Italia’s violations implicated a “systemic” conduct that was integral to the company’s other operations, as well as the fact that the company should have made better decisions considering its experience and competence. Given its long-term presence in the market and constant contact with the authorities, Sky Italia should have known better.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Norway
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Norwegian DPA has fined the Østre Toten municipality with EUR 412,000 because the municipality had previously suffered a cyberattack in January 2021. As a result, the hackers encrypted much of the municipality’s data and deleted the backups. Then, about 30,000 documents were published on the dark web. The documents contained various data such as health status, sexual orientations, religious beliefs, ethnic origin, political opinions, union memberships, and banking data of the municipality’s employees and residents. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the municipality had various security deficiencies regarding the personal data and other internal security controls. For instance, the municipality did not use two-factor authentication during the log-in procedure into the system, and also lacked proper backup systems.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) a) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA (also known as ANSPDCP) fined Glove Technology SRL with EUR 5,000 because the data controller had installed a video surveillance system using audiovisual monitoring at the employees’ workplace, recording various conversations between them. The DPA discovered that the data controller had also violated Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, and Art. 6 (1) GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Vodafone Espana, S.A.U. with EUR 70,000. A data subject had previously complained to the DPA that he had received multiple promotional emails from Vodafone even though he had not consented to the data processing, and he also did not have a contractual relationship with Vodafone Espana. The data subject made it clear that he did not want to receive further emails, objecting to the data processing, and Vodafone confirmed this. Still, the data subject received four more advertising emails a couple of months later. This fine is made up for EUR 50,000 for a violation of Art. 21 GDPR, and EUR 20,000 for a violation of Art. 21 LSSI.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined BEEPING FULFILMENT S.L. with EUR 2,000. The data controller had failed to provide the adequate information regarding the purpose and characteristics of the data processing on the website’s privacy policy. The DPA concluded this was a violation of Art. 13 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Caixabank Payments & Consumer EFC, EP, S.A.U.
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined CAIXABANK PAYMENTS & CONSUMER EFC, EP, S.A.U. with EUR 3,000,000. A data subject had complained against the data controller because it had formally requested his information from a third-party company, even though the data subject had not been a customer of Caixabank ever since 2014. The data subject was also included in an advertising campaign for a pre-grant credit. Caixabank had not obtained the data subject’s consent when assessing their credit worthiness using personal data. The data controller used this data to create financial profiles of the data subjects, as well as for advertising specific financial services like credit loans. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller did not obtain the consent of its data subjects, at least not specifically for this. The data subjects had given their consent to CaixaBank for the data processing, but the data controller did not properly inform them about the details of the data processing. The data controller only offered the data subjects general information about the profiling processing operations, so the data subjects did not clearly know what they had consented to.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined MERCEDES GERENCIA, S.L. with EUR 3,000 because the data controller did not respond to a request for information from the DPA in a timely manner.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Servicios Logisticos Martorell Siglo XXL, S.L.
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined SERVICIOS LOGISTICOS MARTORELL SIGLO XXL, S.L. with EUR 16,000. The data controller had installed a total of five terminals with fingerprint control systems that would record the employees’ working hours. As such, the company did not conduct an protection impact assessment. The AEPD then discovered a violation of Art. 35 GDPR, which prompted it to issue a fine of EUR 20,000 that was reduced to EUR 16,000 due to voluntary payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: United Kingdom
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
