allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The British DPA (also known as ICO) has fined the non-profit organization HIV Scotland with EUR 11,800. The data controller had previously sent an email to 105 people containing all the data subject’s email addresses in the mailing list. A total of 65 email addresses also contained the data subject’s names. So, it was possible to draw conclusions regarding the data subject’s HIV status based on its personal data provided. The DPA concluded that the organization did not implement the proper organizational and technical measures that would ensure sufficient security appropriate to the risk. For instance, the organization did not conduct efficient employee training and also used the inadequate methods to send bulk emails via blind copy.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) c), e) GDPR, Art. 6 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (3) b) GDPR, Art. 9 (1), (2), (4) GDPR, Art. 2-ter (1), (3) Codice della privacy, Art. 2-septies (8) Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined the municipality of Montalbano Jonico with EUR 5,000. Previously, a data subject had filed a complaint against the municipality with the DPA. He had complained that the municipality had publicized a document on its official website. The document contained personal data about the data subject and his father. Moreover, the document could be freely accessed in the “Documents and Data” section of the municipality’s website. Therefore, anyone could access a decision regarding a settlement for the overcoming and removal of architectural barriers in their home by simply filing out a search form. This decision contained the personal data and private information of the data subject in the text and subject line, information such as the name of the complainant and his dependent father, referencing him as a disabled person. Furthermore, the decision also contained the complainant’s date of birth and place of residence, and information about the settlement sum. The DPA concluded that the publication of this data was a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA (also known as ANSPDCP) has fined IKEA ROMÂNIA SA with EUR 1,000. The data controller had notified the DPA regarding a personal data breach under Art. 33 GDPR. Apparently, the data controller had organized a drawing contest involving the children of many of IKEA’s employees. Participants were supposed to upload their drawings in an online platform along with their entry forms that contained the personal data of the children and their parents, including the parents’ consent. However, to vote for the best drawing, the company posted the children’s drawings on the online platform, but they also posted the personal data in the participation forms by accident. During the investigation, the Romanian DPA concluded that this security incident had resulted in the unauthorized disclosure of personal data of IKEA family members (first name, surname, and age of minors, and the first name, surname, country, city, email address, IKEA family membership number, and the signature of the parents) on the company’s online platform that was accessible only to IKEA family members in Romania. This incident affected a total of 114 people, half of which were minors. The DPA determined that the data controller had breached its obligation as per Art. 32 (1) b), (2) GDPR that required it to implement organization and technical measures that would ensure a level of security appropriate to the risk for the data subjects.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA (ANSPDCP) has fined S.P.E.E.H. Hidroelectrica S.A. with EUR 5,000. The data controller notified the DPA of numerous breaches of personal data protection as per Art. 33 GDPR. The data controller breach ended with the data of 325 data subjects being unlawfully accessed or passed on to the wrong recipients. The DPA determined that this was a breach of data protection by the controller as per Art. 32 (1) b), (2) GDPR regarding the implementation of appropriate organizational and technical measures that would ensure adequate security appropriate to the risk incurred by the data subjects during the data processing. Additionally, the DPA discovered that the data controller had processed various amounts of personal data from three customers after they had clearly exercised the rights to delete their data and revoke their consent to the data processing. This data processing had been carried out without a legal basis. The DPA fined the company with EUR 5,000 for breaching Art. 32 (1) b), (2) GDPR. As for the violation of Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR and Art. 6 (1) a) GDPR, the DPA only issued a warning.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined VODAFONE SERVICIOS, S.L.U. with EUR 40,000. The DPA received a complaint against the data controller from a data subject who was a client of the controller. Upon checking his bills on the official MY VODAFONE website during last December, the discovered that he had four outstanding bills that were inaccessible. He had also received various requests to pay them. He was then informed that there was a parallel account registered with Vodafone using details that partly corresponded to him. Apparently, fraudsters had concluded a mobile phone contract using the personal data of the data subject. But then, this personal data that had been entered into the company’s information systems was not verified, and the lawfulness of the contract concluded in the data subject’s name was not assessed. The original fine of EUR 50,000 was reduced to EUR 40,000 because of voluntary payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Cyprus
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Cypriot DPA has fined WS WiSpear Systems LTD with EUR 925,000 because the company had previously collected data from individuals (data like International Mobile Subscriber Identity data and Media Access Control addresses) without obtaining their consent. This data was collected as part of presentations of technologies and tests. The DPA found that the company had violated the principles of objectivity, legality, and transparency.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: France
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 5 (1) e) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The French DPA (also known as CNIL) fined the Régie autonome des transports parisiens (operator of public transport system in Paris) with EUR 400,000. Back in May 2020, the CNIL received a complaint from a trade union alleging that promotion decision files included the number of strike days exercised by staff. The CNIL then investigated several RATP bus centers. This way, the CNIL confirmed that this was true in three of the RATP bus centers. The French DPA further confirmed that files referring to performance evaluations and prospects should only even contain data that was necessary for evaluating employees during work hours. More specifically, it would have been sufficient that these files indicated the total number of days of absence without detailing and distinguishing between days of absence and days where the workers exercised their right to strike. The CNIL discovered that the data related to the number of days the staff members were on strike haven’t been used for the right purpose, so the RATP had violated the principle of data minimization as per Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR. Furthermore, the DPA also found that the RATP has excessively retained some of the employees’ data. More specifically, the RAPT had retained files regarding the evaluation of staff members for more than three years after the promotion commission had taken place. The data retention term was 18 months after the commissions were held, so the RATP also violated this principle. The CNIL discovered that the RATP hadn’t differentiated between staff authorization levels properly either, allowing more staff members than necessary to retain certain data. In conclusion, the CNIL considered that the RATP failed to implement the appropriate organizational and technical measures to ensure a proper level of protection appropriate for the risk at hand.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: PREMIUMMEDIA ΠΑΡΑΓΩΓΗ ΟΠΤΙΚΟ-ΑΚΟΥΣΤΙΚΩΝ ΕΡΓΩΝ ΙΔΙΩΤΙΚΗ ΚΕΦΑΛΑΙΟΥΧΙΚΗ ΕΤΑΙΡΙΑ
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined the company PREMIUMMEDIA ΠΑΡΑΓΩΓΗ ΟΠΤΙΚΟ-ΑΚΟΥΣΤΙΚΩΝ ΕΡΓΩΝ ΙΔΙΩΤΙΚΗ ΚΕΦΑΛΑΙΟΥΧΙΚΗ ΕΤΑΙΡΙΑ with EUR 5,000. A client of the company had tried to unsubscribe from the official newsletter mailing list of the company but didn’t succeed. This failure to unsubscribe was caused by an internal technical error of the company.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Isle of Man
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Information Commissioner of Isle of Man
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The DPA of the Isle of Man fined Cosmetic Medical Limited with EUR 3,250. A data subject had previously filed a complaint to the DPA regarding the data controller’s failure to comply with her request of access to personal data. During the investigation, the DPA requested for information that would clarify this case from the data controller. However, the data controller failed to respond the DPA in due time. Since the data controller did not properly cooperate with the authorities, the DPA concluded the company had violated Art. 31 of the GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Polish DPA (also known as UODO) has fined Bank Millennium S.A with Eur 78,000. The UODO has previously become aware of a data protection breach that followed a complaint against the bank. As it turned out, the correspondence that the bank had sent through a courier service containing personal data (first names, last names, PESEL numbers, account numbers, home addresses, and identification numbers of customers) had been lost. Therefore, the UODO concluded that the bank did not report the incident to the DPA and failed to provide adequate notice to the affected data subjects.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company failed to provide the requested information to the Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) with the required timeframe, violating Art. 58 (1) GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA ((also known as AEPD) has fined Vodafone ESPANA SAU with EUR 40,000. A data subject had filed a complaint to the DPA against the data controller. He claims that he’s received text messages from Vodafone on September 2020 informing him of his debts to the services he had ordered from Vodafone. The billing address is that of an old house where the data subject had lived with his ex-partner in the past. Vodafone states that this mistake was due to a system error, however this resulted in the data subject appearing as the holder of his former partner’s customer account. The original account of EUR 50,000 was reduced to EUR 40,000 because of voluntary payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined a neighborhood community with EUR 1,000. This happened because the information sign of the video surveillance system installed in the community did not contain enough information as required by Art. 13 GDPR. This sign didn’t contain any reference to the data controller nor any address to contact if they wanted to exercise their data subject rights.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined ANIVERSALIA NETWORKS, S.L. with EUR 2,000 because the privacy policy posted on the company’s website did not comply with the requirements of Art. 13 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data controller did not provide information requested by the Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) for investigative purposes.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Netherlands
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Dutch Supervisory Authority for Data Protection (AP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Dutch DPA has fined the airline Transavia with EUR 400,000. In 2019, the airline had suffered a data breach in which a hacker gained access to the company’s systems via two accounts held by the IT department of the company. This may have potentially allowed the hacker to gain access the personal data such as dates of birth, names, email addresses, genders, phone numbers, flight information, and booking numbers of more than 25 million passengers. The DPA discovered that the hacker downloaded the personal information of 83,000 people. In 367 cases, this personal data also included medical information of people who had requested wheelchair transportation or additional services due to being deaf or blind. The DPA further noted that the lack of security measures allowed the hacker to access the company’s systems. Apparently, accessing the airline systems could be done simply by entering the required password. That’s because the systems did not have any multi-factor authentication measures in place. Moreover, the accounts themselves didn’t only have access to the necessary systems but also to other systems as well, which allowed the hacker to gain access to multiple systems of Transavia. The DPA concluded that the airline company Transavia had breached its duty to implement proper technical and organizational measures that would ensure a level of security appropriate to the perceived risk of the data subjects.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Denmark
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Danish DPA has fined the municipality of Frederiksberg with EUR 13,450. Back on March 1st, 2021, the municipality reported to the DPA a data breach as per Art. 33 GDPR. The dental care service of the municipality was operated by a system through which the parents could access the dental care letters of the children online. Then, this system was made available to parents with joint custody. Therefore, in many cases, parents could gain information about the other parent and the child’s address despite the fact that the other parent and the child were under name and address protection. The DPA concluded that the municipality breached its duty to implement adequate organizational and technical measures that would ensure a proper level of security adequate to the risk to the data subjects.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Finland
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 33 (1) GDPR, Art. 34 (1) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Finnish DPA has fined the Vastaamo psychotherapy center with EUR 608,000. Back in September 2020, the psychotherapy center reported a data breach on its patient database. Apparently, an unauthorized third party had gained access to the medical database of Vastaamo on two occasions (that we know of), one in December 2018 and the other in March 2019. The attacked had stolen data and left a ransom note on the database servers. Because of insufficient data logging, the DPA couldn’t identify the exact date of the breach nor the network addresses that the attacker used. As for the cause of this data breach, it was most likely an unprotected port on the database where the root user account was not protected by a password. The patient database server was left open to the Internet without firewall protection between November 26th, 2017, and March 13th, 2019. In these circumstances, the DPA concluded that the personal data of the patients wasn’t properly protected against unauthorized and unlawful access, processing, destruction, accidental loss, or damage. The data controller also failed to implement the proper measures that would secure the processing of the personal data. During its investigation, the DPA determined that the data controller had known about the data breach of its patient medical data and about the unauthorized access of the attacker ever since March 2019. The Vastaamo psychotherapy center should have reported the security breach to the patients involved and the DPA as soon as it happened. However, the data controller was very late in meeting this obligation. The fine is composed of EUR 145,600 for breaching Art. 33 (1) GDPR, EUR 145,600 for breaching Art. 34 (1) GDPR, and EUR 316,800 for breaching Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: ΚΑΠΑ ΛΑΜΔΑ ΩΜΕΓΑ ΔΙΑΦΗΜΙΣΤΙΚΗ ΕΜΠΟΡΙΚΗ ΜΟΝΟΠΡΟΣΩΠΗ ΕΤΑΙΡΕΙΑ ΠΕΡΙΟΡΙΣΜΕΝΗΣ ΕΥΘΥΝΗΣ
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 12 (2) GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA fined ΚΑΠΑ ΛΑΜΔΑ ΩΜΕΓΑ ΔΙΑΦΗΜΙΣΤΙΚΗ ΕΜΠΟΡΙΚΗ ΜΟΝΟΠΡΟΣΩΠΗ ΕΤΑΙΡΕΙΑ ΠΕΡΙΟΡΙΣΜΕΝΗΣ ΕΥΘΥΝΗΣ with EUR 20,000 because the company had carried out marketing calls without the consent of the data subjects on several occasions. Even though the data subjects notified the data controller that they didn’t want to keep receiving marketing calls, the company kept sending them advertising.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 28 (3) c) GDPR, Art. 32 (2), (4) GDPR, Art. 11 (1) Νόμος 3471/2006
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined One Way Private Company with EUR 30,000. The DPA received a total of 17 complaints about illegal telephone calls made to data subjects regarding advertising. The DPA discovered that these telephone calls were made to subscribers because of an error in the application. Some of the subscribers were in the list of protection against unsolicited advertising calls. The DPA concluded that the data controller failed to implement the proper organizational and technical measures that would ensure a level of security appropriate to the risk of the data subjects.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Hungary
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 12 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hungarian DPA fined a car importer with EUR 13,500. A customer of the one of the data controller’s authorized repair shops complained to the DPA about receiving unsolicited emails about customer surveys from the company after a car inspection. The Hungarian DPA discovered that the data controller didn’t have a valid legal basis to contact the data subject. Moreover, the data controller didn’t comply with its duty to inform as per Art. 13 GDPR and Art. 13 GDPR. These emails didn’t contain any contact information of the data controller.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Iceland
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Icelandic Ministry of Industry and Innovation
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 7 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 28 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Icelandic DPA has fined the Ministry of Industry and Inovation with EUR 51,000 and YAY ehf with EUR 27,200. The fines are related to the ministry’s campaign to encourage Icelanders to travel domestically in the summer of 2020. This involved a digital gift voucher obtainable through the app of the company YAY ehf. The DPA received several complaints from data subjects regarding the fact that using these travel gifts required too much personal information and access to the user’s phones. Therefore, the DPA launched an investigation against the YAY ehf company and the ministry. Apparently, the ministry had violated the principles of transparency and legality. The participating individuals could participate in then voucher promotion by only agreeing to the General Terms of Use of the YAY app. However, by doing so, the data subjects expressly consented to the processing of their personal data as well. The DPA found out that that the information provided about the data processing wasn’t sufficient to warrant it. Moreover, YAY ehf and the ministry didn’t implement proper organizational and technical measures that would ensure the appropriate security of the personal data processing. Because of a configuration error of the YAY company, the amount of processed data was more than needed, so the DPA also determined this to be a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Iceland
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 28 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Icelandic DPA has fined the Ministry of Industry and Inovation with EUR 51,000 and YAY ehf with EUR 27,200. The fines are related to the ministry’s campaign to encourage Icelanders to travel domestically in the summer of 2020. This involved a digital gift voucher obtainable through the app of the company YAY ehf. The DPA received several complaints from data subjects regarding the fact that using these travel gifts required too much personal information and access to the user’s phones. Therefore, the DPA launched an investigation against the YAY ehf company and the ministry. Apparently, the ministry had violated the principles of transparency and legality. The participating individuals could participate in then voucher promotion by only agreeing to the General Terms of Use of the YAY app. However, by doing so, the data subjects expressly consented to the processing of their personal data as well. The DPA found out that that the information provided about the data processing wasn’t sufficient to warrant it. Moreover, YAY ehf and the ministry didn’t implement proper organizational and technical measures that would ensure the appropriate security of the personal data processing. Because of a configuration error of the YAY company, the amount of processed data was more than needed, so the DPA also determined this to be a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined a physician with EUR 2,000. A patient had previously complained to the DPA that the doctor had disclosed some of his personal data to third parties without obtaining his consent first. The doctor had recommended medical products to the data subject as part of his treatment. However, a few days later, the data subject received a telephone call from a marketing consultant that was behind the products the medic had recommended. The data subject told the marketing consultant that he hadn’t consented to the disclosure of his personal data. Garante discovered that, generally, when it comes to the processing of personal data required for medical treatments, no specific consent of the patient is needed. However, this case is different because the data was processed for product promotion, so explicit consent of the patient was needed as per Art. 9 GDPR. The physician had processed the patient’s data unlawfully.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined the Health Protection Agency of Sardinia (ATS) with EUR 8,000. Apparently, a patient had received in his medical file the medical records and clinical documentation of another patient, by mistake.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined OTTO s.r.l. with EUR 2,000. As part of an administrative inspection of a store managed by OTTO, law enforcement agents found a video surveillance system with three security cameras installed in the store. However, the data controller didn’t provide enough information about the presence of the CCTV. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of Art. 13 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Anfiteatro s.r.l. with EUR 2,000. As part of an administrative inspection of a hotel managed by Anfiteatro, law enforcement agents found a video surveillance system with three security cameras installed in the hotel. However, the data controller didn’t provide enough information about the presence of the CCTV. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of Art. 13 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Lithuania
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Lithuanian DPA has fined UAB Prime Leasing, an operator of a short-term car rental platform called CityBee, with EUR 110,000. The DPA carried out an investigation on its own initiative after it received information about a potential personal data breach (Art. 33 GDPR) that became public in February 2021. According to company records and claims, they only learned about the security breach from a cybersecurity provider who informed them that customer data of about 110,302 CityBee users had been unlawfully published on the hacking forum RaidForums.com. The personal data included names, phone numbers, addresses, personal identification numbers, email addresses, type of payment cards, the last four digits of the data subject’s card numbers, and diver’s license numbers. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the published personal data came from an unsecured backup copy of a database of the company. The DPA further discovered that this data breach had taken place because of the company’s failure to comply with its obligation to implement the required organizational and technical measures that would ensure adequate security appropriate to the risk of the data subjects. For instance, the company didn’t appoint a person competent enough to oversee the security and risk management. It also didn’t ensure that accesses to database files were logged and evaluated. Moreover, the company hadn’t encrypted the stored databases. A person with enough technical knowledge could gain full access to the data contained in the file after downloading it. As for the personal codes stored in the database, they were unprotected. The passwords in the database were only encrypted with an algorithm that was determined to be insecure.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Norway
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c), e) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 9 (2) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Norwegian DPA has fined the Norwegian State Pension Fund (SPK) with EUR 98,000 after the data controller notified the DPA about a data breach as per Art. 33 GDPR. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller had unlawfully collected income information since 2016. For instance, the controller had collected health-related information about disability pensions despite not being required. About 24,000 individuals had been affected by these incidents. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the Norwegian State Pension Fund didn’t implement routines to review and delete excessive information collected until 2019.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Norway
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Norwegian DPA has fined Grindr LLC with EUR 6,300,000. Grindr is a location-based social networking app that was designed for bi, gay, trans, and queer people. Back in 2020, the Norwegian Consumer Protection Authority had filed a complaint against Grindr to the Norwegian DPA, alleging that the platform had shared information about its users’ GPS location, IP address, cell phone advertising ID, age and gender to other third parties for marketing, without obtaining the consent of the data subjects. As per GDPR, that personal data should have only been shared with consent from the data subjects. However, the DPA discovered during its investigation that the consent collected by Grindr was invalid. Users had to accept a privacy policy when using the app but the policy didn’t explicitly ask them whether they consented to their data being shared to third parties for marketing purposes. Moreover, information about the disclosure of personal data wasn’t immediately clear or accessible to users. The DPA shows that the type of data disclosed could identify a Grindr user as a member of a sexual minority. The users would sometimes use this app anonymously without inputting their full name or uploading a photo of them. As for the sexual orientation of the users, it was made part of a special category of personal data that is subject to a special, high level of protection. The DPA concludes that this infringement was particularly serious and it justifies a high fine as a deterrent. GDPR considers that this type of fine should act as a strong deterrent for business models based on behavior-based marketing, which are widespread in the digital economy today.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 29 GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b) GDPR, Art. 32 (4) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA (also known as ANSPDCP) has fined Valoris Center S.R.L. with EUR 2,000. The data controller notified the DPA about a data breach as per Art. 33 GDPR. One of the call center employees of the data controller had accidentally sent to one of the customers an Excel file containing data from various other customers of the data controller. During the investigation, the DPA found out that this data breach resulted in the unauthorized disclosure of personal data like user ID, email address, username, customer code, customer name, and customer PIN of a total of 11,169 natural persons. The DPA further concluded that the data controller didn’t successfully implement the necessary organizational and technical measures that would ensure a level of security appropriate to the risk of the data subjects.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company was fined by the DPA because it failed to provide the requested information within the required timeframe to the DPA, as per Art. 58 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined UNION FINANCIERA ASTURIANA S.A. E.F.C. with EUR 9,000. The data controller had performed a credit check on the data subject without a contractual basis for doing so. The original fine of 15,000 was reduced to 9,000 because of voluntary payment and admission of guilt.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 48 (1) b) LGT, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 23 LOPDGDD
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined TIGERS MARKET, S.L. with EUR 4,000 because a data subject had received advertising calls from the data controller even though the data subject was included in the Robinson advertising exclusion list.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.source: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a restaurant owner with EUR 1,000 because the data controller failed to provide any information signs about the CCTV surveillance system it had installed in its establishment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: ASOCIACIÓN ESPAÑOLA PARA LA ENSEÑANZA ONLINE
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined ASOCIACIÓN ESPAÑOLA PARA LA ENSEÑANZA ONLINE with EUR 5,000 because a data subject showed that he kept receiving advertisements from the data controller even though he had objected to receiving such newsletter subscriptions and even requested the data controller to delete all his data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined DAVISER SERVICIOS, S.L. with EUR 20,000. The company was processing biometric data (fingerprints) of all its employees who accessed certain rooms, even though it could use less intrusive means (key cards). This way, the privacy of the data subjects could have been retained better. The AEPD discovered that the data controller had violated the principle of data minimization, as well.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 48 (1) b) LGT, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 23 LOPDGDD
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects’ rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined INTRODUCTION BUSINESS CAPITAL MEDIA, S.L. with EUR 5,000. A data subject received advertising calls from the data controller even though the data subject was registered in the Robinson advertising exclusion list.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) fined IMAGINA FRANT SPORT, S.L. with EUR 2,000 because the company’s privacy policy didn’t comply with the requirements of Art. 13 GDPR. In one case, the website contained outdated information that wasn’t actualized.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) fined a store owner with EUR 1,000 because he failed to provide information signs about the CCTV surveillance system in its establishment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined NBQ Technology S.A.U. with EUR 24,000. A data subject complained to the DPA against the data controller after he was denied a financial transaction because of an alleged outstanding payment on a loan. However, as it turned out, a third party had stolen the data subject’s identity and obtained his personal information without authorization. He proceeded to apply for a loan from the data controller on behalf of the data subject. The data controller approved this loan. However, the AEPD determined that the data processed during this operation of granting the loan didn’t belong to the loan beneficiary but the data subject. So, the AEPD determined that the data controller had no legal basis for the data processing. The data processing was unlawful and it went against Art. 6 (1) GDPR. The original fine of EUR 40,000 was reduced to EUR 24,000 because of admission of guilt and immediate payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined IZA OBRAS Y PROMOCIONES, S.A. with EUR 50,000. One of the data controller’s employees filed a complaint with the DPA against his employer, alleging that the data controller had disclosed his personal data to a third-party company from which it had received a construction order. The data controller did this without authorization. The data subject had been working as a construction manager on the project but had been absent from work for some time on account of an illness. The data controller informed its client about this and further disclosed the data subject’s email address and certain health information. The DPA concluded that this disclosure of data wasn’t necessary and the data controller clearly violated the principle of data minimization.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Netherlands
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Dutch Supervisory Authority for Data Protection (AP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) e) GDPR, Art. 8 Wbp
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Dutch DPA (also known as AP) has fined the Minister of Finance with EUR 2,75 million. Regarding the context of childcare benefit applications, several tax offices had processed data about the dual nationality of applications for many years. However, the DPA discovered that this data on the dual nationality of Dutch citizens wasn’t necessary to assess the applications for childcare benefits. This data was also processed for combating organized fraud and to automate the classifications in the authority’s risk system. That being said, even if these were reasons, the data processing still wasn’t necessary. To this end, the tax and customs administration were supposed to delete the data on dual nationality ever since January 2014. However, as of May 2018, data about the dual citizenship of about 1,4 million people was still registered in the systems of the customs and tax administration. The DPA determined that this data had been unlawfully processed because of a lack of valid legal basis. Moreover, the DPA claims that the data subjects had been discriminated against because of their nationality.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: United Kingdom
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The UK DPA (also known as ICO) has fined the Cabinet Office with EUR 585,000. Back on December 27th, 2019, the Cabinet Office had published a file on GOV.UK that contained the uncensored names and addresses of more than 1,000 individuals who had received New Year’s honors. Among the affected individuals were people ranging from various profession across the United Kingdom, even individuals with high public profiles. After the Cabinet Office learned of this data breach, it removed the web link to the file hosted on the internet. However, the file was still contained within the cache and was accessible online to people who had access to the same exact website address. This personal data was disclosed online for two hours and 21 minutes and had been accessed a total of 3,872 times. This data breach occurred because of an error in the setup of the Cabinet Office’s new IT system, apparently. The United Kingdom ICO discovered that the Cabinet Office didn’t take the appropriate organizational and technical measures that would ensure a proper level of protection appropriate to the risk of the data subjects.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Austria
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Various offences
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Austrian DPA has fined REWE International AG with EUR 8 million. Back in the summer of 2021, a subsidiary of the company, Unser Ö-Bonus Club GmbH, received a fine of EUR 2 million. The Salzburger Nachrichten newspaper said that the fined is based on various violations of the GDPR. Other details aren’t known yet.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: France
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 28 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 34 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The French DPA (also known as CNIL) has fined the payment institution SLIMPAY with EUR 180,000. Back in 2015, SLIMPAY carried out an internal research project where it processed personal data in its databases. Back when the research project had ended in July 2016, the data remained stored on an unencrypted server and it was freely accessible on the internet. This data breach affected approximately 12 million people. During the investigation, the CNIL discovered that the company failed to implement the adequate technical and organizational measures that would ensure a proper level of security appropriate to the risk of the data subjects. Therefore, the server wasn’t secured in any way, so anyone could access it on the internet between November 2015 and February 2020. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the company did not inform the data subjects about the data breach. In several cases, company-concluded contracts with processes were inadequately drafted because they didn’t include envisaged clauses that would force the process the personal data of data subjects in accordance with the GDPR requirements.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: France
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The French DPA (also known as CNIL) has fined FREE MOBILE with EUR 300,000. The CNIL had received several complaints about the company’s failure to comply with the rights of the data subjects. During the investigation, the CNIL discovered that the company did not respond to the data subjects’ requests in a timely manner. Additionally, the company didn’t comply with the rights of objection of the data subjects, since it kept sending advertisements to the data subjects despite them having expressly mentioned that they don’t want to receive ads anymore. Moreover, the CNIL found out that the company didn’t implement the necessary organizational and technical measures that would ensure a level of security appropriate to the risk of the data subjects. For instance, the company sent user passwords via email in clear text.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: France
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Back on the 31st of December, 2021, the French DPA (also known as CNIL) fined Google LLC with EUR 90,000,000. The CNIL received several complaints about the manner in which google.fr and youtube.com approached the manner in which users could refuse cookies on these websites. The CNIL did an online review of these websites and discovered that, despite there being a button to accept the cookies instantly, there was no such button to reject them. To reject the cookies, you had to go through several options, as opposed to one option for accepting the cookies. The CNIL concluded that, in most cases, users accepted the cookies out of convenience rather than because they agreed to it. It also concluded that the way these cookie deposits were designed is an interference with the freedom of consent of internet users, violating Art. 82 of the French Law on Informatics and Freedoms. When determining the fine, the CNIL took into consideration the large number of people who were affected in such an aggravating manner. Additionally, the CNIL also considered the significant profits that the companies could make from advertisements generated indirectly from the data collected through these cookies. The CNIL also pointed out the fact that the authority had previously notified the Google companies of this breach in February 2021. Aside from the fine, the CNIL also issued an order that required the companies to provide all internet users in France with a simple way of rejecting cookies, just as simple as accepting them, within three months of receiving this notification. Otherwise, both companies would have to pay a fine of EUR 100,000 per day of delay.
