allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined Εγνατία Οδός Α.Ε. with EUR 1,000. The company operated a video surveillance system that monitored the payment of tolls. One car owner received a fine for not paying the toll and then exercised his right to information as defined by the GDPR. He requested photographic material that was captured in the context of the fine. He also requested a copy of the documentation of the incident. However, the company didn’t provide this information to the data subject. After the DPA intervened, the company did offer this information but didn’t disclose any photographic material. For this reason, the DPA concluded that the company had violated Art. 13 (3) GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 11 Law 3471/2006
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined PLUS REAL Advertisement with EUR 25,000. The data controller had previously conducted several advertising calls without the data subjects’ consent. Additionally, it didn’t adequately inform the data subjects about the processing of their personal data. Therefore, it violated its information obligations.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 11 Law 3471/2006
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined INFO COMMUNICATION SERVICES with EUR 30,000. The data controller had previously conducted several advertising calls without the data subjects’ consent. Additionally, it didn’t adequately inform the data subjects about the processing of their personal data. Therefore, it violated its information obligations.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 33 GDPR, Art. 37 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined the Greek Ministry of Tourism with EUR 75,000. There was a data breach which, according to the DPA, involved the attempt of a citizen to enter his/her credentials on the online platform of the Ministry. This resulted in the displaying of another person’s credentials, including full name, social security number, tax number, phone number, postal address, email address, and other fields that indicated their disability. The DPA discovered that the Ministry did not implement the required organizational and technical measures that would ensure the proper security of the personal data. It also did not report this incident to the DPA. So, the DPA concluded that this was a violation of Art. 33 of the GDPR. During the investigation, it was found that the Ministry of Tourism hadn’t appointed a data protection officer even though the authority’s platform mentioned an email address of a supposed data protection officer. However, this email address was inactive, as it was later found out.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Ireland
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) GDPR, Art. 33 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Irish DPA has fined the Irish Teaching Council with EUR 60,000 after the Council notified the DPA about a data breach under Art. 33 GDPR. Apparently, two Council employees had accessed a phishing email that allowed them to establish an automatic forwarding system from their personal email accounts to a malicious email account. As a result of this, a total of 323 email were forwarded to this unauthorized email address between the 17th of February, 2020, and the 6th of March 2020. These emails contained personal details of 9,735 data subjects as well as the sensitive personal data of one data subject. The DPA concluded that the Council did not implement the required organizational and technical measures that would ensure a proper level of security for the personal data of the data subjects. Additionally, the DPA discovered that the Council did not report this data breach in a timely manner.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Ireland
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Irish DPA has fined Limerick City and County Council with EUR 110,000. During the investigation, the DPA carried out a complete audit of the processing of personal data done by the council or on the council’s behalf using video surveillance systems, body-worn cameras, automatic license plate recognition software, and other technologies that may have been used to monitor individuals. The DPA discovered that the Council had violated a number of data protection laws when using these technologies. The DPA issued a fine for these GDPR violations. More specifically, the DPA found out that the Council had violated Art. 13 GDPR regarding its relation to the processing of data using traffic cameras. The Council did not provide any information on the identity of the data controller, the contact details of the data protection officer, the purposes for the data processing, or the authorities from which further information could be obtained, as required by Art. 13 GDPR. Additionally, the Council did not provide any information in an easily accessible manner such as signs near the video surveillance cameras. Furthermore, the DPA discovered that the Council did not post a video surveillance policy in a plan and understandable language, in an easily-accessible place on the Council’s website. Therefore, the DPA concluded that the Council had infringed on Art. 12 GDPR. The Council further denied requests for personal data access that was processed by surveillance cameras during traffic management. As a result, the DPA concluded that the Council had also violated Art. 15 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined the mobile operator TIM S.p.A with EUR 150,000 because it denied a data subject access to his phone data required to defend himself in a criminal case. The data subject hadn’t received a response to his requests in a timely manner, so he asked the DPA to obtain the data in time for the hearing of the criminal proceedings.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Società H San Raffaele Resnati s.r.l.
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Società H San Raffaele Resnati s.r.l. with EUR 6,000. The DPA started an investigation against the healthcare provider after the latter had reported a data breach to the DPA. Apparently, a patient had mistakenly received medical records and clinical documentation from two patients because of an employee error.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined ICA s.r.l. with EUR 30,000. The municipality of Collegno had previously implemented a system that allowed citizens to pay fines for traffic violations. The system was designed and developed by ICA s.r.l. Apparently, because of a lack of security precautions, it was possible for unauthorized individuals to access the personal data stored in the program. The DPA concluded that ICA did not implement the proper organizational and technical measures that would provide a level of security sufficient for the protection of the data subjects’ personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Società Med Store Saronno s.r.l. with EUR 7,000. The nursing home had notified the DPA about a data breach as per Art. 33 GDPR. The facility had gone through a cyber attack done by a hacker who gained access to personal data and published it online. The personal data included radiological images of patients. He published them on his Twitter account. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the nursing home had secured the data with simple passwords only. So, the DPA concluded that the nursing home failed to implement adequate organizational and technical measures to protect the data subjects’ personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Casa di cura Fondazione Gaetano e Piera Borghi s.r.l.
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Casa di cura Fondazione Gaetano e Piera Borghi s.r.l. with EUR 30,000. The nursing home had notified the DPA about a data breach as per Art. 33 GDPR. The facility had gone through a cyber attack done by a hacker who gained access to personal data and published it online. The personal data included radiological images of patients. He published them on his Twitter account. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the nursing home had secured the data with simple passwords only. So, the DPA concluded that the nursing home failed to implement adequate organizational and technical measures to protect the data subjects’ personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Azienda USL di Parma with EUR 5,000. A patient had filed a complaint to the DPA because she was mistakenly sent two reports of diagnostic tests that belonged to two other patients.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), d) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR, Art. 25 (1) GDPR, Art. 30 GDPR, Art. 31 GDPR, Art. 130 (1), (2), (4) Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Various offences
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Enel Energia S.p.A. with EUR 26,5 million for several data breaches and violations of the GDPR. After a thorough preliminary investigation launched after the DPA received hundreds of reports from users, the DPA discovered that the data controller had been illegally processing the personal data of millions of users for telemarketing purposes. The DPA also discovered that the data subjects had been receiving unsolicited promotional calls made in the name of Enel Energia. In some cases, the calls were also recorded. Several data subjects were still receiving advertising calls even though the had objected to them and asked Enel Energia to delete their personal data a couple of times. More specifically, the DPA discovered that Enel Energia did not provide the data subjects with timely feedback on the requests of the data subjects to exercise their rights of access and opposition. Additionally, the DPA discovered that the company had insufficiently cooperated with the DPA during the investigation. For instance, Enel Energia did not respond to several inquiries made by the DPA. In assessing the issued fine, the DPA took into consideration the following aggravating factors: the seriousness of the violation, the large number of individuals affected, the duration and repetition of the violations, and the negligence of the conduct.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Malta
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 9 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 33 GDPR, Art. 34 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Many
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The DPA has fined C-Planet (IT Solutions) Limited with EUR 65,000. The DPA has carried out an investigation on C-Planet in April 2020 after being informed of a data breach. The DPA found out that C-Planet had violated Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 9 (1), (2) GDPR, Art 14 GDPR, and Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR regarding data processing. The DPA discovered that C-Planet did not implement adequate organizational and technical measures that would ensure the proper security commensurate to the risk of the data subjects. This is a violation of Art. 32 GDPR. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the data controller did not notify the DPA in a timely manner and did not inform data subjects about the personal data breach. This is a violation of Art. 33 GDPR and Art. 34 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Norway
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Norwegian DPA (also known as Datatilsynet) has fined Elektro & Automasjon Systemer AS with EUR 20,000 because it had implemented credit checks on an individual even though there was no legal base to do so.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Norway
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Unknown
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Norwegian DPA (also known as Datatilsynet) as fined T. Stene Transport AS with EUR 3,900 because of an unfair credit check on a data subject.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 24 (1) GDPR, Art. 25 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 (1), (2) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Polish DPA (also known as UODO) has fined the Warsaw University of Technology with EUR 10,000. The university had previously reported a data breach to the authority as per Art. 33 GDPR. An organizational unit of the university had used an application created by the staff of the university to register for courses and access assessments of exam results, teaching history, and billing of fees. Back in January 2020, an unauthorized third party had downloaded a database from this application that contained the personal data of students and faculty staff (more than 5,000 individuals). During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the Warsaw University of Technology did not implement the required organizational and technical measures that would ensure a proper level of security of the personal data. The DPA also discovered that the university did not conduct a formal risk assessment of the program.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Portugal
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c), e) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 13 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 35 (3) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Portuguese DPA has fined the Lisbon City Council with EUR 1.25 million. This fine is the sum of 225 fines issued because of several violations committed by the municipality since 2018. The municipality had previously sent 111 notifications regarding the demonstrations to various departments and offices in the municipality and to third parties, to ensure that they could perform their public duties accordingly. These notices contained sensitive data of the organizer of the demonstrations and the demonstrators themselves. This data revealed the political opinions, philosophical beliefs, religious beliefs, and sexual orientations of the data subjects. The DPA discovered that the transfer of this data wouldn’t have been necessary for the involved entities to properly perform their public tasks. Therefore, the processing of the personal data was illegal. Additionally, the DPA discovered that the municipality had undergone the data processing without informing the data subjects, without establishing a policy regarding the retention of their personal data, and without conducting a preliminary data protection impact assessment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA (also known as ANSPDCP) has fined Kaufland România SCS with EUR 3,000. The DPA carried out an investigation based on a complaint from an individual who stated that the data controller did not provide them with the complete copy of the video recordings of when they had been in the store premises. The DPA argues that the data controller is obliged to disclose the video images of the data subjects after they exercise their right of access. Furthermore, the data controller may choose to blur the images that, if shown, would violate the rights and freedoms of other natural persons.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria S.A. with EUR 60,000. A data subject had previously filed a complaint with the DPA against the data controller because he kept receiving SMS messages about non-payment from the data controller, even though he had no contractual relationship with the data controller. Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria argued that these unsolicited SMS messages had been sent because of a human error from its employees. The original fine of EUR 100,000 was reduced to EUR 60,000 because of admission of guilt and voluntary payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined an online retailer with EUR 2,000. A data subject purchased a product from the online store of the data controller through eBay, and paid the purchase using PayPal. However, he received his order via Amazon. The data subject hadn’t consented to the transfer of his data to Amazon, so the DPA concluded that the data controller had processed his data unlawfully.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined CLUB DEPORTIVO RITMO DE ANDALUCIA with EUR 4,000. The DPA claimed that the data protection notice of the data controller didn’t comply with the requirements of the GDPR regulations. The information notice breached Art. 13 GDPR because not enough information was provided. Additionally, the data protection notice also didn’t provide an adequate opportunity for people to consent to the data processing.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: FUNDACION ESPANOLA DE MEDICINA ESTETICA Y LONGEVIDAD
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined FUNDACION ESPANOLA DE MEDICINA ESTETICA Y LONGEVIDAD with EUR 2,000. The DPA claimed that the data protection notice of the data controller didn’t comply with the requirements of the GDPR regulations. The information notice breached Art. 13 GDPR because not enough information was provided. Additionally, the data protection notice also didn’t provide an adequate opportunity for people to consent to the data processing.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Sfam Espana General s.l. with EUR 5,000 because a data subject had complained that the data controller charged her for several services that she hadn’t ordered.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined HUBSIDE IBERICA, S.L. with EUR 5,000 because a data subject had complained that the data controller charged her for several services that she hadn’t ordered.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined LA OFICINA BAR with EUR 1,500. The bar was operating a video surveillance system that captured the public traffic area. The DPA considered that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: This corporate website didn’t have a privacy policy on its main page.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined REAL CLUB NAUTICO DE RIBADEO with EUR 6,000. The data controller had uploaded on its Facebook page and website several links to court decisions that contained personal data of data subjects.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined the manager of a call shop with EUR 2,000. Regarding a job vacancy at the call shop, the manager had set up a stand where applicants could submit their applications if they paid a fee of one euro. However, the manager didn’t properly inform the data subjects that their personal data would be processed, as per Art. 13 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Violation of the principle of data minimization because of a usage of CCTV cameras that captured public roads outside.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined EDUCANDO JUNTOS SL with EURO 9,000. The data controller had previously published several photos of an employee on various social network channels and on its website. However, the data controller hadn’t obtained the consent of the data subject before publishing these photos. As a result, the data subject asked the data controller repeatedly that the photos be taken down from the website and the social networks. However, the data controller didn’t comply with this request. As a result, the GDPR fined the data controller with EUR 6,000 for violating Art. 6 (1) GDPR and EUR 3,000 for violating Art. 17 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 1,500. The data controller had installed several video surveillance cameras that also captured the public space. The DPA considered this to be a violation of the principle of data minimization. Moreover, the data controller didn’t properly inform the data subjects about the processing of the data via the video surveillance, and this violated its duty to inform. The fine contains EUR 1,000 for violating Art. (1) c) GDPR, and EUR 500 for violating Art. 13 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined PHARMA TALENTS, S.L.U. with EUR 2,400. A data subject had complained against the company after he discovered that there was personal data about himself and hundreds of other health sector professionals on a database of the company. This data contained email addresses and telephone numbers. The website and this particular database were freely accessible to anyone. The DPA discovered that the company didn’t implement the proper organizational and technical measures that would ensure adequate security commensurate to the risk of the data subjects. There were no password or username required to access the database. The original fine of EUR 4,000 was reduced to EUR 2,400 because of admission of guilt and voluntary payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fiend MEETING PUERTO C.B. with EUR 2,000. The data controller had unlawfully published a picture of the data subject next to his partner on Facebook and Instagram. This picture was accompanied by insulting comments.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined GARLEX SOLUTIONS, S.L. with EUR 15,000. A data subject had received a call from the company regarding the renewal of the electricity supply contract. Then, the data subject received an SMS with a link leading to an electricity supply contract that had their personal data already entered. The data subject didn’t know how the company had entered his/her personal data into the contract since they had never provided it nor consented to its processing.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Sweden
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Swedish DPA has fined the Uppsala regional board with EUR 28,500. As a result of the investigation of Uppsala region, this fine was applied for various reasons. The DPA had previously received two reports of incidents regarding personal data from the Uppsala region. These incidents involved sensitive personal health data that was transferred unencrypted to recipients both in and out of Sweden. The regional board had sent this sensitive personal data and identity numbers via email. The transmission itself was encrypted, but the information inside the emails wasn’t. The emails contained patient data that was automatically directed to health administrators in the region. Some patient data was manually sent to physicians and researchers in the region. Therefore, the DPA concluded that the regional board had taken insufficient organizational and technical measures to protect the data from any unauthorized access.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Sweden
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Swedish DPA has fined the Uppsala hospital board with EUR 152,000. As a result of the investigation of Uppsala region, this fine was applied for various reasons. The DPA had previously received two reports of incidents regarding personal data from the Uppsala region. These incidents involved sensitive personal health data that was transferred unencrypted to recipients both in and out of Sweden. Uppsala University Hospital had also sent emails that contained patient data to senders in three countries without encrypting them. Additionally, the hospital administration had stored this sensitive personal data in the Outlook email service. Therefore, the DPA concluded that the hospital board had taken insufficient organizational and technical measures to protect the data from any unauthorized access.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Belgium
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c), f) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Belgian DPA has fined a researcher with EUR 1,200. The fine had been issued regarding another fine issued to the NGO EU Disinfolab. The researcher had been an employee at this NGO. Back in 2018, the NGO had published an analysis to help identify the political origins of tweets that were circulating on a heated controversy in France, the “Benalla affair”. During the analysis, the NGO had processed the data of 55,000 Twitter individuals. 3,300 of these had been classified as political. The information obtained from these accounts was published without taking minimal security precautions (anonymizing the data). The DPA noticed that the publication of this data could expose the data subjects to discrimination or discreditation because of the non-anonymous political profiling. Additionally, these files contained information about the data subjects’ sexual orientations, religious beliefs, and ethnic origins. As a result, the DPA concluded that several principles of the GDPR like the transparency to data subjects or the lawfulness of processing and data security, had been violated.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Belgium
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c), f) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 30 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Belgian DPA has fined the NGO EU Disinfolab with EUR 2,700. Back in 2018, the NGO had published an analysis to help identify the political origins of tweets that were circulating on a heated controversy in France, the “Benalla affair”. During the analysis, the NGO had processed the data of 55,000 Twitter individuals. 3,300 of these had been classified as political. The information obtained from these accounts was published without taking minimal security precautions (anonymizing the data). The DPA noticed that the publication of this data could expose the data subjects to discrimination or discreditation because of the non-anonymous political profiling. Additionally, these files contained information about the data subjects’ sexual orientations, religious beliefs, and ethnic origins. As a result, the DPA concluded that several principles of the GDPR like the transparency to data subjects or the lawfulness of processing and data security, had been violated.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Belgium
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 9 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 12 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 24 (1) GDPR, Art. 30 GDPR, Art. 31 GDPR, Art. 32 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 37 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Belgian DPA has fined IAB Europe with EUR 250,000. The DPA had previously received many complaints against IAB Europe ever since 2019. Regarding this complaint, the DPA questioned the compliance of IAB Europe with the “Transparency & Consent Framework (TCF). The TCF had been developed by IAB to promote compliance with the GDPR through organizations that used the OpenRTB protocol. This protocol is used for “real-time bidding” like the automated online auctions of user profiles regarding the purchase and sale of advertising space on the web. Users would visit websites that contain ad space that technology companies can bid for in real time through automated auction systems. This was done to display personalized advertising to users. Upon visiting a website for the first time, an interface would appear asking users for consent to the collection, sharing, and other types of processing of their personal information. During this process, the TCF employs a specific consent management tool that allows users to reject certain types of data processing. This TCF remembers the users’ preferences via the consent management tool by generating a TC string and sending it to everyone that participates in the OpenRTB system. This TC string allows user profiles to be compiled and sent to advertisers. The advertisers will see the types of data processing that the users have agreed to. The DPA noticed that the IAB had violated several of the GDPR regulations during the investigation. It discovered that these TC strings already contained personal data, which required a legal basis for its processing, which IAB did not have. IAB couldn’t prove that it had any legal basis to process these TC strings, though. For instance, when users were informed about the data processing, the information provided to them was far too generic and vague to properly understand the purpose of the data processing. Moreover, IAB did not maintain any register of its data processing activities and had also failed to appoint a data protection officer. It also did not conduct any data protection impact assessment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Finland
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Finnish DPA has fined a travel agency with EUR 6,500. One of the customers of the travel agency informed the DPA about the company being suspicious because it may not process customer personal data in a GDPR-compliant manner. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the travel agency did not ensure a secure processing of personal data. For instance, the visa application forms that customers filled out were publicly available on the web server of the travel agency. This form contained, among other things, the data subjects’ names, passport numbers, and contact details. Additionally, the travel agency did not comply with the data subjects’ requests to delete their personal data from the systems.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Finland
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 25 (2) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Finnish DPA has fined a motor insurance center with EUR 52,000. The data controller had requested too much patient data from the healthcare system for the purpose of processing claims. Most of the requested data wasn’t required to process the claims, though. For instance, the DPA discovered that the motor vehicle insurance center had collected patient visit notes that would determine whether the healthcare provider had been billing visits unrelated to examinations or treatments caused by moto accidents. The DPA also noted that the Finnish Motor Insurance Act doesn’t justify such direct and free access to patient data. Moreover, the information requested must be required for the processing of the claims. As such, the DPA noted that the motor insurance center had violated the principles of egality, minimization of data processing, and transparency.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 25 (1) GDPR, Art. 26 GDPR, Art. 28 GDPR, Art. 35 (7) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined Cosmote Mobile Telecommunications S.A. with EUR 6 million. Cosmote had previously reported to the DPA a data breach as per Art. 33 of the GDPR. The that that was stolen included sensitive information from subscribers of Cosmote, such as age, contract information, and gender. About 10 million people were affected by this incident. As such, the DPA concluded that Cosmote did not implement the adequate technical and organizational measures to ensure a proper execution of the data anonymization procedure. Additionally, Cosmote didn’t conduct a sufficient data protection impact assessment and also didn’t properly inform the data subjects about the processing of their personal data. Moreover, the DPA also discovered that Cosmote didn’t explicitly regulate the allocation of roles within the data processing of its subsidiary, the OTE Group. When calculating the fine, the DPA took into account the aggravating factor of the long duration of these breaches (6 years), the large number of affected data subjects, and the lack of pseudonymization measures of the data that hadn’t been implemented for such a long time.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined the Cosmote subsidiary OTE Group with EUR 3,2 million. OTE group had contributed to the security infrastructure of Cosmote, which had reported a data breach as per Art. 33 of the GDPR. A hacker was able to penetrate Cosmote’s systems because of a lack of security measures. The hacker obtained and leaked vital customer data in the aftermath of the attack. This data included sensitive information about Cosmote customers, such as age, gender, and contract information. About 10 million people had been affected by this incident. Consequently, the DPA discovered that OTE Group didn’t implement the adequate organizational and technical measures that would ensure a proper level of security proportional to the risk of the data subjects.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined ΛΙΜΕΝΟΣ ΗΡΑΚΛΕΙΟΥ Α.Ε. with EUR 30,000. A data subject who had gone through a car accident on the premises of the organization had filed a complaint against ΛΙΜΕΝΟΣ ΗΡΑΚΛΕΙΟΥ Α.Ε. to the DPA. The organization operated a video surveillance system that recorded the car accident. Regarding this accident, the data subject requested the organization to give them access to the recordings. However, the organization didn’t comply with their request, which led to the fine.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Hungary
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 9 (1) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hungarian DPA fined a lawyer with EUR 843 because they’d disclosed documents containing the person data of their client during criminal proceedings without any legal basis.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 37 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Centro di Medicina preventive s.r.l. with EUR 10,000. The data controller had previously reported a database breach that suffered a cyberattack by a hacker group. During this attack, the hacker gained access to the list of patient data which was then published on Twitter. This list contained sensitive personal data of the patients such as radio-diagnostic tests. The DPA discovered that the data controller didn’t implement the appropriate organizational and technical measures that could ensure the proper security of the personal data. For instance, the servers of the medical center disclosed the requested personal data without verifying the credentials and identity of the person who requested it. This allowed unauthorized people to gain access to the data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c), e) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 157 Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company had left the email account of the data subject active after the termination of the data subject’s employment. The account automatically forwarded incoming emails to the data subject’s email. The company didn’t offer enough information about this.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Ubi Banca Spa with EUR 100,000. A data subject had previously filed a complaint to the DPA for having received a letter about an “anomalous credit Chieti” from the data controller. However, this letter didn’t contain any payment reminders. It only contained information about the transparency of the bank and financial services. Consequently, the DPA noted that the data controller had violated the principles of transparency, lawfulness, and data minimization. Moreover, the term on the envelope could potentially enable third parties to get information about the financial situation of the recipient, and this doesn’t take into account the contents of the envelope.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined FCA Italy s.p.a. with EUR 20,000. A former customer of the data controller had requested from the data controller the transcripts of telephone conversations between him and the company’s customer service regarding a previous communication about the malfunction of the instruments of his vehicle. He also requested the documents regarding this case. However, the data controller didn’t comply to the data subject’s request.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined UNiversita Teleamtica Internazionale Uninettuno. A professor had complained to the DPA against the education institution. Apparently, the professor had applied for a position at the university and provided his CV to this end. The university published it online without blurring or blacking out personal data that regarded his personal life. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined ASL Latina with EUR 10,000. The data controller had sent documents containing health data of the data subjects to unauthorized third parties by mistake.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Azienda Sanitaria Locale Frosinone with EUR 7,500. During the investigation against this medical facility, the Italian DPA has discovered that their privacy policy was deficient and incomplete. For instance, the facility indicated that the data processing had several purposes, but the legal bases for them weren’t clear and visible all the time. Moreover, the legal bases that were stated were contradictory or incorrect. Additionally, the facility didn’t provide enough information about the storage periods of the collected data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The data controller didn’t respond to the data subject’s request for access to their data in a timely manner.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Azienda sanitaria unica regionale Marche with EUR 14,000. The DPA launched an investigation against the health department after media reports showcased deficiencies in the system that collected and managed Covid 19 screening data. The health department used an app that generated QR codes for people who received tests for Covid 19. These QR codes were generated based on progressive criteria and not randomly. So, each person received a number. Therefore, it was possible for unauthorized individuals to gain access to another person’s profile by changing a digit. The DPA discovered that the health authority didn’t implement the adequate technical and organizational measures that would ensure a proper level of security that’s appropriate to the risk of the data subjects.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The nursing care facility didn’t signal its use of CCTV systems within its premises.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined A.S.L. Napoli 1 Centro with EUR 1,000. One of the employees at the health authority had previously filed a complaint against the authority to the DPA. The health authority had previously published a press release on its website that contained data about the data subject and information regarding a disciplinary procedure. The health authority thought that the publication as lawful since the data subject had willingly provided this information to the press, and the press had published a report on the topic. However, the DPA noted that the health authority still needed a legal basis to publish the information, even if the same information had been used by other media.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined the private club “Ruian” with EUR 2,000. The data controller had previously installed video surveillance cameras that, among other things, covered the public space as well. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. Additionally, the data controller didn’t properly inform about the processing of the data through the video surveillance system, violating its duty to inform.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 157 Codice della privacy, Art. 166 (2) Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined T.S.M. s.r.l. with EUR 40,000. A data subject had previously filed a complaint to the Dpa against the company because the latter failed to comply with the data subject’s request to delete their data and to object to the future processing of their personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Norway
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Norwegian DPA (also known as Datatilsynet) has fined Etterforsker1 Gruppen AS with EUR 5,000. The data controller didn’t have a legal basis for carrying out a credit check on a data subject.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA (also known as ANSPDCP) has fined SC Grupex 2000 SRL with EUR 1,000. The data controller didn’t have a legal basis to upload videos of patients on its website.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b), c), f) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined the civil law firm “Sabou, Burz & Cuc” with EUR 1,000. The DPA launched an investigation when a client complained that the data controller had published some of their personal data on a WhatsApp group used by lawyers of a bar association. This was done without the consent of the data subject. The DPA discovered that the data subject had processed the personal data of the data subject without obtaining their consent and without a legal basis. They had published the data for a purpose that was different from the originally agreed-upon purpose.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined IAMSAT Muntenia SA with EUR 3,000. A former employee complained to the DPA that their former employer had continued to process their personal data even after the employment contract had been terminated in 2020. The data subject had stated that they wouldn’t agree to the continued use of their email address and that they also objected to the use of their personal data by the data controller and other related third parties after the employment contract was terminated. During the investigation, the DPA found out that the data controller didn’t inform its employees, even the data subjects, about the processing of their personal data through a video surveillance system installed at the workplace.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The property owner association used CCTV cameras in the building complex without properly informing the property owners and obtaining their consent.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Cyrana Espana General S.L. with EUR 5,000. The data controller had previously sent an invoice to the data subject even though there was no contractual relationship between them.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined INCOPROSOL, S.L. with EUR 5,000. The data controller had recorded a telephone conversation with a customer without the data subject’s consent.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined ORANGE ESPANA VIRTUAL, S.L. with EUR 70,000. Two Orange Espana Virtual customers had complained to the DPA against Orange. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that several fraudsters had pretended to be the data subjects and demanded a copy of their SIM cards. Then, they concluded contracts in the name of the data subjects and carried out several transfers. According to the DPA, Vodafone didn’t properly verify the identity of the fraudsters before issuing the SIM cards. They also didn’t ensure that the fraudsters were really the SIM card holders. A lack of proper security measures led to this.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Orange Espagne, S.A.U. with EUR 700,000. Two Orange Espagne customers had complained to the DPA against Orange. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that several fraudsters had pretended to be the data subjects and demanded a copy of their SIM cards. Then, they concluded contracts in the name of the data subjects and carried out several transfers. According to the DPA, Vodafone didn’t properly verify the identity of the fraudsters before issuing the SIM cards. They also didn’t ensure that the fraudsters were really the SIM card holders. A lack of proper security measures led to this.

allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined XFERA MOVILES S.A. with EUR 200,000. Two Xfera customers had complained to the DPA against Orange. Then, they concluded contracts in the name of the data subjects and carried out several transfers. According to the DPA, Vodafone didn’t properly verify the identity of the fraudsters before issuing the SIM cards. They also didn’t ensure that the fraudsters were really the SIM card holders. A lack of proper security measures led to this.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined TELEFONICA MOVILES ESPANIA, S.A.U. with EUR 900,000. Four TELEFONICA customers had filed a complained to the DPA against the company. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that several fraudsters had pretended to be the data subjects and demanded a copy of their SIM cards. Then, they concluded contracts in the name of the data subjects and carried out several transfers. According to the DPA, Vodafone didn’t properly verify the identity of the fraudsters before issuing the SIM cards. They also didn’t ensure that the fraudsters were really the SIM card holders. A lack of proper security measures led to this.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The café several CCTV cameras that captures, among other things, the public space outside of the business. This resulted in a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined PINTODIS, S.L. with EUR 10,000. The data controller had previously installed several video cameras that covered food areas and changing rooms where employees changed. The Spanish DPA claimed that the data controller violated the principle of data minimization because this much surveillance was unnecessary.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined RECLAMADOR, S.L. with EUR 1,600. Apparently, a data subject filed a complaint against the data controller, claiming that the latter continuously sent him SMS advertisements even though he’d previously requested the deletion of his data. The data controller even confirmed the data deletion. The fine is composed of EUR 1,000 for a breach of Art. 17 GDPR, and EUR 1,000 for a breach of Art. 21 LSSI. The original fine of EUR 2,000 was reduced to EUR 1,800 because of voluntary and immediate payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 10 GDPR, Art. 10 LOPDGDD
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Amazon Road Transport Spain S.L. with EUR 2,000,000. The AEPD had previously received a complaint from a certain trade union against the Amazon Road Transport Spain company. The company quired certificates that confirmed the absence of criminal records when it hired drivers. Amazon Road though that these certifications weren’t under the umbrella of Art. 10 GDPR. However, that wasn’t the case. The AEPD concluded that this data does fall under Art. 10 GDPR. During the investigation, the AEPD concluded that the processing of this data wasn’t compliant with the requirements of Art. 10 GDPR. Therefore, the DPA came to the conclusion that Amazon Road had processed the data regarding the absence of criminal record without a valid legal basis.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined RESTAURANTE FUENTEBRO, S.C. with EUR 1,500 because it failed to provide information signs about the CCTV surveillance in the establishment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined MALAGATROM S.L.U. with EUR 1,000 because the company failed to comply with an order issued by the DPA.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a hotel operator with EUR 3,000. The data controller had previously installed video surveillance cameras that, among other things, covered the public space and parts of the hotels pool area. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. Moreover, the data controller also didn’t comply with its duty to properly inform data subjects about the CCTV system.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Belgium
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) e) GDPR, Art. 9 (2) g) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 13 (2) e) GDPR, Art. 35 (1), (3), (7) b) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Belgian DPA has fined the Brussels Airport Zaventem with EUR 200,000. An investigation was launched against the airport after several media reports about temperature monitoring of persons in the airport surfaced. Because of the Covid-19 pandemic, the airport used these thermal imaging cameras to filter out individuals who had body temperatures above 38 degrees. The people who were filtered had to answer several questions about potential coronavirus symptoms. The DPA noticed that the airport did not have a legal basis to process this health data. Essentially, health data is sensitive data as per Art. 9 GDPR, and it can only be processed in exceptional cases as per Art. 9 (2) GDPR. For instance, an exceptional case would be to process the data in the public interest. But if this is the case, the data processing should proceed on a clear legal norm. As for the airport case, the data processing was based solely on a protocol that didn’t meet the necessary requirements. Additionally, the DPA discovered deficiencies in the data protection impact assessment. Moreover, the airport also did not properly inform the data subjects about the data processing.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Belgium
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 6 (3) GDPR, Art. 9 (2) i) GDPR, Art. 12 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 13 (2) e) GDPR, Art. 35 (1), (7) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Belgian DPA has fined the Brussels Airport Charleroi with EUR 100,000. An investigation was launched against the airport after several media reports about temperature monitoring of persons in the airport surfaced. Because of the Covid-19 pandemic, the airport used these thermal imaging cameras to filter out individuals who had body temperatures above 38 degrees. The people who were filtered had to answer several questions about potential coronavirus symptoms. The DPA noticed that the airport did not have a legal basis to process this health data. Essentially, health data is sensitive data as per Art. 9 GDPR, and it can only be processed in exceptional cases as per Art. 9 (2) GDPR. For instance, an exceptional case would be to process the data in the public interest. But if this is the case, the data processing should proceed on a clear legal norm. As for the airport case, the data processing was based solely on a protocol that didn’t meet the necessary requirements. Additionally, the DPA discovered deficiencies in the data protection impact assessment. Moreover, the airport also did not properly inform the data subjects about the data processing.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Belgium
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Belgian DPA has fined Ambuce Rescue Team with EUR 20,000. This fine is closely related to the fines issued for the Brussels Airports Zaventem and Charleroi for using thermal imaging cameras to filter out people who may have coronavirus symptoms. In the context of the Covid-19 pandemic, the two airports used thermal imaging cameras to filter out people with body temperatures above 38 degrees. Then, they were provided a questionnaire to complete. This questionnaire was made by Ambuce Rescue Team. The DPA discovered that the processing of this medical data was done illegally since there was no valid legal basis for it. Health data as sensitive as this can only be processed in exceptional cases as per Art. 9 (2) GDPR. For instance, an exceptional case would be to process the data in the public interest. But if this is the case, the data processing should proceed on a clear legal norm. In this case, the data processing was based solely on a protocol that didn’t meet the necessary requirements.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Croatia
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Croatian DPA has fined this energy company who own petrol stations and sells fuel to its customers. One data subject who is a customer of the energy company has filed a consumer complaint regarding the inaccurate measuring and charging of fueled petrol at one of the petrol stations owned by the energy company. The data subject also requested a copy of the personal data of the company, including a copy of the video surveillance footage narrowed to a specific time and area. However, the energy company denied this request, justifying by: (i) a lack of a written request by the competent authorities to deliver this footage, (ii) the lack of a justified purpose for the request, and (iii) the claim that offering a copy of this footage would negatively affect the rights and freedoms of the petrol station’s customers and personnel. After the DPA issued its general opinion and claimed that the energy company is under legal obligation to provide the surveillance footage to the data subject, the energy company informed the customer that this wasn’t possible. The energy company claimed that the video surveillance footage archives are being erased after seven days. The DPA concluded that the energy company had violated the fundamental rights of the data subject and issued a fine of HRK 940,000,000. The DPA also took note of the indirect damage incurred by the customer and also the potential financial gains of the company due to indirectly avoiding a customer dispute. Moreover, the DPA also considered that, by deleting the video footage, the company has eliminated importance evidence.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Croatia
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art 32 (1) b) and d) GDPR, Art 32 (2) GDPR, Art 32 (4) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: A retail company has reported a breach of personal data to the DPA. The company claimed that its employees have recorded video surveillance footage with mobile phones. This was unauthorized and against the company’s instructions and internal acts. This recording was made public by leaking it to social media and various media outlets. The DPA concluded that the data controller failed to take the adequate actions to prevent employees from recording the company footage. The company did undertake specific measures like adopting internal acts regarding the access to video surveillance footage, and also educated the employees by implementing confidentiality statements. However, the DPA noted that the retail company did not ensure the appropriate technical and organizational security measures that would minimize the risk of such data breaches. Additionally, the data controller didn’t regularly inspect the efficiency of the organizational and technical measures that were implement to maintain the integrity, confidentiality, and accessibility of the personal data. The DPA fined the retail company with HRK 675,000,000 for failing to take the appropriate organizational and technical measures. It also clarified that this fine should have preventive effects and raise the awareness for all data controllers and processors on the obligations regarding correct data processing.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Cyprus
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Cypriot DPA has fined the English School Staff Union (ESSA) with EUR 5,000. The school notified the DPA about a data breach as per Art. 33 GDPR. A teacher, who was also a member of the staff union, had used the email addresses of the students’ parents for another purpose than the one originally intended with the data collection process. The DPA noted that the staff union failed to take the appropriate organizational and technical measures that would ensure the protection of person data and preventing such incidents from happening.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Cyprus
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Cypriot DPA has fined the English School Cyprus with EUR 4,000. The school notified the DPA about a data breach as per Art. 33 GDPR. A teacher used the email addresses of the students’ parents for another purpose than the one originally intended with the data collection process. The DPA noted that the school failed to take the appropriate organizational and technical measures that would ensure the protection of person data and preventing such incidents from happening.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Denmark
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Danish DPA has fined the Danish National Genome Center with EUR 6,700. The center had previously conducted a data protection impact assessment that revealed certain circumstances which, if exposed, could pose a high risk to the rights of the data subjects. The DPA fined the Genome Center because it had unlawfully processed the personal data of the data subjects without consulting the DPA, despite the fact that the impact assessment had a high risk to the data subjects. The Danish National Genome Center did comply with all the DPA’s requests and has been very cooperative throughout the investigation.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Denmark
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Danish DPA has fined Danske Bank with EUR 1.3 million. The DPA has opened an investigation against the bank after it was informed that the bank had an issue with the personal data deletion. During the investigation the DPA discovered that the bank did not document the rules for the storage and deletion of personal data in more than 400 systems. As a result, the bank could not prove that these regulations even existed in the first place. The DPA concluded that this was a breach of the bank’s accountability obligation as per Art. 5 (2) GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Finland
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 12 (1), (2), (3), (4) GDPR, Art. 13 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 15 (1), (3) GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Finnish DPA has fiend a medical clinic with EUR 5,000. One of the customers of the clinic had previously complained to the DPA that he hadn’t received access to his medical records from the clinic even after he requested this information. Additionally, the clinic didn’t adequately inform its clients about the data processing. More specifically, the DPA noted that the clinic didn’t inform its clients about the extent of the data processing activities.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The DPA of Bremen has fined the housing association BREBAU GmbH with EUR 1.9 million. BREBAU GmbH has processed about 9,500+ datasets related to potential tenants without a valid legal basis. More specifically, the DPA discovered that the data controller had also processed very sensitive data as per Art. 9 GDPR. For instance, the data controller unlawfully processed information regarding the ethnic origin, skin color, sexual orientation, religious affiliation, and health status of the data subjects. BREBAU GmbH has also deliberately ignored several requests from data subjects for transparency regarding the processing of their personal data. When issuing the fine, the DPA also took into consideration, as an aggravating factor, the depth of the violation of fundamental rights to data protection. However, the company also cooperated fully during the investigation which led to some of the damage being mitigated. The company also clarified the facts on its own and made sure that such violations wouldn’t be repeated in the future.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fiend an employer with EUR 2,000. One of the school’s employee who worked there as a language teacher, has filed a complaint to the DPA against the school. Apparently, the data controller kept monitoring the employee during the Zoom online courses despite them objecting to this. The DPA noted that the data controller had violated its duty to comply with the data subjects right to object. Moreover, the DPA also discovered that the data controller didn’t properly inform the data subject about the processing of his personal data, as per Art. 13 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Iceland
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Iceland DPA has fined Hörpu tónlistar- og ráðstefnuhúss ohf. With EUR 7,000. The DPA had received a complaint about the concert hall’s collection of ID numbers and date of birth information regarding an electronic ticket purchase. This incident took place before the start of the Covid-19 pandemic, and the registration of personal data for contact tracking wasn’t yet required at that time. The DPA concluded that the data controller had no real reason to collect this data for issuing a ticket. The purchase could have been completed with this data being collected. For this reason, the DPA noted that the concert hall had violated the principle of data minimization.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Ireland
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Irish DPA (also known as DPC) has fined Meta Platforms Ireland Limited with EUR 17 million. This decision is based on 12 notifications of data breaches that took place between June 7, 2018, and December 4, 2018. The DPC’s investigations ended with Meta being charged with a violation of Art. 5 (2) GDPR and Art. 24 (1) GDPR. During the investigation, the DPC found out that Meta could not prove that it had taken the necessary organizational and technical measures that would protect the data of EUR users. The fine proceedings were carried out with cross-border data processing, and that’s why a decision was only met through the co-decision procedure under Art. 60 GDPR, involving all the European advisory authorities. Although two other European DPAs objected to the draft decision of the DPC, a consensus was reached in the end. As it stands, the DPC’s decision to fine Meta with EUR 17,000,000 is the collective decision of all the other European DPAs.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Ireland
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 33 GDPR, Art. 34 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Irish DPA has fined the Bank of Ireland with EUR 463,000. The Bank has reported a total of 22 data breaches to the DPA, as per Art. 33 GDPR. During the investigation, then DPA discovered that the bank had provided false information to the Central Credit Register because of a mix-up of bank customers’ account data. This error could have impacted the creditworthiness of many data subjects. The DPA also found that the personal data breach had taken place due to the lack of appropriate organizational and technical measures from the bank. Additionally, the bank didn’t immediately inform the data subjects and the DPA about the data breach.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company has left the email account of the data subject active even after the termination of the subject’s employment and also failed to provide information about this.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b), e) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 27 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the US-based Clearview Al with EUR 20 million after it was found that the company had been using biometric surveillance on Italian territory. The company owns a database of over 10 billion facial images from all over the world. In the context of the fine, the company offers a search service that allows profiles to be created based on the biometric data from the images. These profiles can be further improved using information such as geolocation or image tags. The DPA investigated this company after it was revealed that it also enables the search of Italian national and residents, despite having denied this initially. The DPA discovered that the personal data held in the company’s databases were processed unlawfully and without a valid legal basis. Additionally, the DPA also discovered that the company had violated several GDPR principles. For instance, the company had clearly violated the principle of transparency when it failed to properly inform users about the data processing. Clearview had also violated the principle of purpose limitation when it processed the users’ data for purposes other than the ones it had revealed online. Finally, the company also violated the principle of storage limitation because it did not specify a time period for the data storage.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Azienda socio sanitaria territoriale Melegnano e della Martesana
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Azienda socio sanitaria territorial Melegnano e della Martesana with EUR 3,500. The DPA started investigating the data controller after receiving a report about a data breach. A patient had received by mistake the medical records and clinical documentation of another patient, apparently.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Region of Tuscany with EUR 10,000. The region had previously notified the DPA about a data breach as per Art. 33 GDPR. The region further stated that it had published the personal data of 3,548 applications for administrative assistant positions by mistake. The data information that the region had shared was part of a pre-selection test for the application. The region had mistakenly published a URL that people could access to see the results of these tests.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Scanshare S.r.l. with EUR 10,000. This fine is related to another fine imposed on the Region of Tuscany. The region claimed that it had published the personal data of 3,548 applications for administrative assistant positions by mistake. The data information that the region had shared was part of a pre-selection test for the application. Apparently, Scanshare was entrusted with organizing these pre-selection tests. Because of an error on the part of Scanshare, a URL was published by mistake through which the personal data and tests results of all data subjects could be accessed.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The community published on its website information about a court case. This information included the name and professional information of the data subject.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR, Art. 157 Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Arte del vivere S.r.l. with EUR 5,000. A data subject had previously filed a complaint against the data controller because his personal data had been published on the website www.mondoshiatsu.com operated by the data controller. The data subject was also included in the Shiatsu Portal after he had participated in a one-year Shiatsu training. However, the data subject requested the deletion of his persona data since he had never worked in this field. However, the data controller did not fulfill their obligation despite saying that they would delete the data subject’s personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 12 (3) GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Studio Colli Aniene Verderocca S.r.l. with EUR 1,500. A data subject had filed a complaint against the data controller for sending unsolicited telephone advertising to him. Additionally, the data subject stated that he didn’t receive any response to his request for information and deletion of his personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Insufficient fulfilment of data breach notification obligations
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Polish DPA has fined Santander Bank Polska with EUR 118,000 because it did not notify the data subjects about a data breach. One of the former employees of the bank managed to gain unauthorized access to one of the databases used for electronic services. This led to numerous Santander customer’s data becoming accessible to the former employee. Because of the high risk for this data, the bank was obliged to inform the data subjects about the data breach. However, the bank did not do this and instead continued to state that it wouldn’t comply with this obligation in the future.
