The DPA took note of this and concluded that it was a major intrusion for the data subjects because they couldn’t take the necessary steps to protect their rights.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Fortum Marketing and Sales Polska S.A.
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art 24 (1) GDPR, Art. 25 (1) GDPR, Art. 28 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 (1), (2) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Polish DPA has fined Fortum Marketing and Sales Polska S.A. with EUR 1,000,000. The company had previously reported a data breach to the DPA in accordance with Art. 33 GDPR. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that unauthorized individuals had managed to access and steal customer data. This data breach had taken place during the introduction of a modification in the IT system of the company. This modification was introduced by a processing agent who created another customer database as part of the IT modification. However, the database was stored on a sever that was insufficiently protected, and that’s why unauthorized individuals managed to gain access to it. The DPA also discovered that the data processor did not pseudonymize and encrypt the data. Additionally, the processing agent was using real customer data instead of test data to test the IT modification to the system. As such, the DPA concluded that the data controller did not take the appropriate organizational and technical measures that would ensure the protection of the personal data. Moreover, the DPA found that the data controller should have monitored the work of the data processor to make sure that the personal data of the data subjects is constantly protected.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 28 (3) c), f) GDPR, Art. 32 (1), (2) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Polish DPA has fined PIKA Sp. z o.o. with EUR 53,000. The fine relates to the fines issued to Fortum Marketing and Sales Polska S.A. Pika was the data processor for Fortum. . During the investigation, the DPA discovered that unauthorized individuals had managed to access and steal customer data. This data breach had taken place during the introduction of a modification in the IT system of the company. This modification was introduced by a processing agent who created another customer database as part of the IT modification. However, the database was stored on a sever that was insufficiently protected, and that’s why unauthorized individuals managed to gain access to it. The DPA also discovered that the data processor did not pseudonymize and encrypt the data. Additionally, the processing agent was using real customer data instead of test data to test the IT modification to the system. As such, the DPA noted that PIKA did not take the appropriate organizational and technical measures to ensure the protection of the personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA (also known as ANSPDCP) has fined Operatorul Briza Land S.R.L. with EUR 2,000 because the data controller did not respond properly to a request for information.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Condor SA with EUR 2,000. The data controller had suffered a data breach where unauthorized individuals managed to access a couple of documents that contained the personal data of employees and former employees (first name, surname, position, salary, bank details, place of work). During the investigation, the DPA noted that the data controller did not take the appropriate organizational and technical measures to ensure the proper protection of the personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA (also known as ANSPDCP) has fined a property owner’s association with EUR 500 because it failed to provide the information requested by the DPA during an investigation.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: FRUTAS Y VERDURAS LOS CAMPEONES, S.L.
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined FRUTAS Y VERDURAS LOS CAMPEONES, S.L with EUR 1,200. The data controller had installed a video surveillance system but it did not place any signs informing about the presence and use of this system.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined WORLDWIDE CLASSIC CARS NETWORK, S.L. with EUR 1,500. The data controller several video surveillance cameras that covered the public space, among others. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. Moreover, the data controller failed to comply with its duty to inform about the CCTV system.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Sweden
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 12 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 (2) f) GDPR, Art. 14 (2) g) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Swedish DPA has fined Klarna Bank AB with EUR 720,000. Klarna is a bank, a financial company that processes large numbers of personal data for various reasons. During the investigation, the DPA found that Klarna did not comply with its information obligations. In one case, the data controller did not provide enough information on its website about the purpose and the legal basis for the processing of personal data. Moreover, regarding the transfer of data to various Swedish and international credit agencies, Klarna provided incomplete information regarding the recipients of the personal data. The data controller also did not provide information about third countries where the personal data was going to. In the end, the DPA concluded that Klarna did not sufficiently inform its data subjects about their rights as per the GDPR regulations.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Netherlands
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Dutch Supervisory Authority for Data Protection (AP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Dutch DPA has fined DPG Media Magazines B.V. with EUR 525,000. The DPA had previously received many complaints about the manner in which the data controller was handling requests from customers. Clients who wanted to know what type of personal data the data controller stores or to have their data deleted, had to upload and send proof of their identity first. The DPA concluded that it was not necessary to send proof of one’s identity to process these requests. Additionally, the mailing process made it extremely difficult for data subjects to exercise their rights.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Netherlands
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Dutch Supervisory Authority for Data Protection (AP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Dutch DPA has fined the Dutch Foreign Ministry with EUR 565,000. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the National Visa Information System (NVIS) had major security deficiencies. This is a serious matter seeing as though the Foreign Ministry processed around 530,000 visa applications per year over the last 3 years. The personal data processed during those applications was, as it seems, insufficiently protected. This data included sensitive information like name, address, fingerprints, place of residence, country of birth, nationality, and purpose of travel. Because of these inadequate security measures, unauthorized individuals could have accessed the data at any time. The DPA noted that the Foreign Ministry had been aware of this security weakness for quite some time. However, they didn’t do anything to adjust the security system. This is why DPA concludes that the ministry was negligent. It was also found that the Foreign Ministry didn’t adequately inform individuals who applied for visas that their personal data would be shared with third parties. This resulted in a fine of EUR 565,000 being issued to the Dutch Foreign Ministry.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Belgium
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 12 (2) GDPR, Art. 21 (2), (3), (4) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Belgian DPA has fined the Belgian National Railroad Company (Nationale Maatschappj der Belgische Spoorwegen) with EUR 10,000. The Belgian DPA has received a complaint from a Twitter user who had received an email newsletter from the railroad company. Apparently, this newsletter didn’t have an option to unsubscribe. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the railroad company had no valid legal basis to process the personal data of the Twitter user through the newsletter. The railroad company claimed that the newsletter was essential for the performance of the contracts established between the company and the passengers, but the DPA disagreed. This performance interest wasn’t a valid legal basis to process the personal data of the Twitter user. Moreover, the DPA found that that the data subject’s right to object wasn’t sufficiently considered since there was no option to unsubscribe from the newsletter through the email received.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Denmark
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Danish DPA has fined the Danish Agency Civilstyrelsen with EUR 13,400. The DPA discovered that a USB containing more than 800 pages of sensitive and confidential information belonging to the Civilstyrelsen company was lost. During the investigation, the DPA found out that this USB stick was not encrypted. Moreover, the agency didn’t have policies in place that instructed its employees on how to use removable and portable media. The DPA also discovered that the agency did not report the data breach even though it was aware of it. This is a breach of Art. 33 GDPR. The DPA concluded that the agency did not take the necessary organizational and technical measures to ensure the proper protection of the personal data. For instance, the USB stick should have been encrypted since it contained such sensitive information and personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: France
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 28 GDPR, Art. 29 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The French DPA (also known as CNIL) has fined DEDALUS BIOLOGIE with EUR 1.5 million. The company is a distributor of software solutions for medical analysis laboratories. Back in February 2022, the press revealed a massive data leak involving DEDALUS, and which resulted in the leak of personal data belonging to more than 500,000 individuals. This data included information about the first names, surnames, data on medical examinations and illnesses, social security numbers, and the names of the physicians. During the investigation the CNIL discovered that DEDALUS BIOLOGIE had violated several GDPR regulations. For instance, DEDALUS had violated Art. 29 GDPR by processing more data than was necessary during the processing of two laboratories’ patient data. Moreover, the DPA also discovered that DEDALUS did not implement the necessary organizational and technical measures that would ensure the proper protection of the personal data. This is a clear violation of Art. 32 GDPR by itself. The company did not implement any specific security procedures during the data migration operations. Moreover, the data that was leaked was not stored on an encrypted server either. The DPA also discovered that DEDALUS had not implement authentication for access in the public area of the server. This is the main reason why the data leak took place, in fact. Furthermore, the DPA discovered that none of the contracts established between DEDALUS and its clients complied with the requirements set by the GDPR in Art. 28. The DPA took into consideration the aggravating factors and the seriousness of the violations, as well as the large number of data subjects who had been affected, when imposing the fine.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 33 GDPR, Art. 34 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined Piraeus Bank with EUR 10,000. Apparently, the bank had sent by mistake a document containing the personal data of the data subject to a third party. This error took place because a co-owner of the account entered a wrong email address. Even though the bank was aware of this error, they didn’t stop communicating with the third party. Instead, they told the data subject that they can request a correction of the inaccurate data that was sent to the third party. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the bank had violated the principle of confidentiality because it did not take any actions to stop the communications with the third party. The DPA also noticed that the bank did not report the data breach to the DPA and the data subject in a timely manner.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Iceland
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Icelandic DPA has fined the City of Reykjavik with EUR 36,000. The city had been using the digital education system “Seesaw” in different schools. This system processed, among other things, the personal data of minor students, including the teacher feedback and information about the private affairs of the students. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the City of Reykjavik had not sufficiently defined the purpose for the processing of the children’s data. As such, the DPA stated that this was a breach of the principle of data minimization and data proportionality. Additionally, the DPA concluded that the city did not implement the required organizational and technical measures that would have protected the personal data of the children adequately. This was necessary, especially given the high risk that the data could have been processed and transferred in the United States. When assessing the fine, the DPA took into consideration that no damage had been caused by the data breaches.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), f) GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Azienda USL Toscana Centro with EUR 10,000. The DPA started an investigation against the data controller after it received a report of a data breach as per Art. 33 GDPR. The data controller had send patient medical records to the wrong patients by mistake. The DPA concluded that the Azienda USL Toscana Centro did not take the necessary organizational and technical measures to properly protect the personal data of the patients.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 37 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Azienda sanitaria provincial di Caltanissetta with EUR 6,000. In the context of legal proceedings, a data subject had asked the data controller to send all communications related to this matter only to the data subject’s personal email inbox. However, the data controller sent this communication to the data subject’s business email address. Moreover, the data subject had also requested access to their data. The data controller did not comply with this request either. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the health care facility did not report this to the DPA. Moreover, it also did not communicate the name and contact details of the new data protection officer, and did not update this information on its website either.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Agenzia Regionale per la Tutella dell’Ambiente dell’Abruzzo
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 10 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy, Art. 2-octies Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Agenzia Regionale per la Tutella dell’Ambiente dell’Abruzzo with EUR 8,000. One of the former employees of the environmental agency had complained to the data about the fact that the agency had published documents containing his personal data on its official website. These documents could be accessed freely by anyone and contained, among other things, information about the data subject’s criminal information and previous employment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Brav s.r.l. with EUR 10,000. An operator of the online platform Brav s.r.l. reported a data breach to the DPA as per Art. 33 GDPR. Apparently, unauthorized third parties had gained access to the platform that the Genoa Police used to manage traffic violations, also coming into the possession of the personal data contained within these documents. According to the City of Genoa, several employees of Brav s.r.l. had disclosed the access passwords to the platform, violating official regulations, and this led to the data breach. As such, the DPA discovered that the data controller did not take the necessary organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data. The data controller should changed the passwords regularly in order to prevent such unauthorized access exploits by third parties.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), f) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 30 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Azienda ospedaliera di Perugia with EUR 40,000. During the investigation on the healthcare facility, the DPA discovered multiple violations of the GDPR. This investigation took place in the context of several inspections that dealt with the processing of data and several whistleblower systems at the employers. Azienda ospedaliera di Perugia the healthcare facility had been using an open-sourced whistleblowing web application when the data breach took place. The app was accessed through several systems that hadn’t been properly configured. As such, the users’ browsing data could be recorded and stored, which led to the identification of these users, who could have been whistleblowers. Regarding the processing of the personal data, the healthcare facility did not inform its employees prior to it. Additionally, the DPA discovered that the healthcare facility did not conduct a data protection impact assessment and also did not register the data processing in the register of processing activities. So, the company did not carry out the required risk assessments regarding the rights and freedoms of the data subjects.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined ISWEB S.p.A. with EUR 40,000. This fine was issued in regard to another fine against the healthcare facility Azienda ospedaliera di Perugia. ISWEB was the company that provided the whistleblower application for the healthcare system. During the investigation at the healthcare facility, the DPA discovered multiple GDPR violations regarding the whistleblower system. This investigation took place as part of a series of several inspections aimed at the whistleblower system data processing on the employers’ systems. Regarding ISWEB, the DPA discovered that they had been using an external provider to host the whistleblower systems. Moreover, ISWEB did not provide the external provider nor the healthcare facility with specific instructions about the processing of the data subject’s data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined ASST di Lodi with EUR 1,000. The healthcare facility had previously reported a data breach as per Art. 33 GDPR. A patient had offered two contacts that the healthcare facility could contact regarding the data subject’s medical affairs. In the case of an emergency, the facility could obtain medical information about the patient from these two persons. During an important diagnostic examination of the data subjects, a healthcare facility employee tried contacting the two authorized contacts but could not reach them. Instead, they contacted a family member that they personally knew for this information. During the investigation the DPA discovered that the healthcare facility had processed the data subject’s information without the data subject’s consent. Therefore, this action had no valid legal basis. Additionally, the DPA concluded that the healthcare facility did not take the appropriate organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data of the data subject.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Norway
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Norwegian DPA has fined Lillestrøm Municipality with EUR 30,000. The municipality had previously published (by accident) a document containing a total of 21 attachments. 10 of these attachments contained personal data of the students, such as names, test results, dates of birth, and assessments of the students’ challenges and behaviors. The error hadn’t been detected by the responsible administrator and went through several manual quality checks at the documentation center. The error wasn’t detected there either. A journalist noticed the data breach and brought it to the municipality’s attention. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the municipality had not taken the necessary organizational and technical measures to protect the personal data of the data subjects. Moreover, the DPA also considers it a clear lack of security rigorousness that the incident wasn’t discovered by the municipality.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined IKEA România S.R.L. with EUR 1,000. A data subjects had filed a complaint to the DPA, stating that IKEA did not comply in a timely manner with their request to delete their personal data from the company’s user account. The DPA concluded that IKEA Romania had violated Art. 12 (3) GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Concordia Capital IFN S.A. with EUR 4,000. The data controller had unlawfully installed several video and audio cameras in its employees’ offices. This video surveillance system was meant to protect the goods and the employees of the company. However, the DPA discovered that the data controller had violated Articles 5 and 6 GDPR because such extensive surveillance was uncalled for and unnecessary.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined the gas station operator LORIS FUEL SOP SRL with EUR 1,000. A person had previously filed a complaint to the DPA because pictures of him had been published on Facebook by the gas station. These images were taken by the video surveillance system installed in the controller’s gas stations. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller had not taken the required organizational and technical measures that would ensure the confidentiality and anonymity of the personal data generated by the CCTV system installed in the gas stations. This led to third partiers accessing these images, filming them, and then posting them online on social networks.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined BASER COMERCIALIZADORA DE REFERENCIA, S.A. with EUR 150,000. A customer of this company had previously filed a complaint to the DPA because their electricity supply contract had been modified without their consent. This had resulted in an increase in the electricity supply. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that a fraudster had been pretending to be the data subject. They provided the data subject’s name and ID number, which led them to be able to modify the contract of the data subject. The DPA stated that the data controller had not properly verified the identity of the fraudster before modifying the contract. This lack of security measures led to the fraudster being mistaken for the data subject, which led to the data breach.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined a homeowners association with EUR 500. The executive board of the association had publicly posted a list of defaulting owners. The DPA considers that this is a violation of the principle of integrity and confidentiality, as set out by Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined RAMONA FILMS, S.L. with EUR 8,000 because the data controller did not ensure that their privacy policy complied with the requirements of Art. 13 GDPR. More specifically, the website contained outdated information and was referring to laws that weren’t in effect anymore. Moreover, the DPA discovered deficiencies in the cookie use of the company’s website. The original fine was reduced from EUR 10,000 to EUR 8,000 because the company paid the fine immediately and acknowledged its guilt.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined FLORAQUEEN FLOWERING THE WORLD S.L. with EUR 1,800 because it failed to provide the information requested by the DPA during one of its investigations. The original fine of EUR 3,000 was reduced to EUR 1,800 because the company paid the fine immediately and acknowledged its guilt.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 22 (2) LSSI
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined JIMBO NETWORKS, S.L. with EUR 9,000. During the investigation, the DPA discovered several security deficiencies on the data controller’s website. For instance, the data controller was processing data of visitors on the website without obtaining their consent. Additionally, the privacy policy of the website did not comply with the requirements of Art. 13 GDPR. The privacy policy contained outdated information and also referred to laws that were not in effect anymore. Moreover, the DPA also found deficiencies in the cookie use of the website. The original fine of EUR 15,000 was reduced to EUR 9,000 due to immediate acknowledgement of guilt and payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined DOOR2DOOR SPAIN, S.L. with EUR 600. The data controller had failed to implement in due time the required measures that the DPA ordered several times. Moreover, the data controller also did not provide the DPA with the requested information. The original fine of EUR 1,000 was reduced to EUR 600 due to immediate acknowledgment of guilt and payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined MOVALIA TRASLADOS, S.L.U. with EUR 1,200. During the investigation, the DPA discovered several security deficiencies in the data controller’s website. For instance, the data controller was processing the personal data of visitors to the website without obtaining their explicit consent. Moreover, the data controller also did not have a privacy policy, contrary to its obligation under Art. 13 GDPR. The original fine of EUR 2,000 was reduced to EUR 1,200 because of immediate payment and acknowledgment of guilt.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) a) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined CAFFE VECCHIO, S.L. with EUR 1,500. One of the former employees of the café had filed a complaint to the DPA, stating that the operator of the café had replied to several negative online reviews, while disclosing the personal data of the former employee. Additionally, the operator had published information regarding the future employment termination of the contractual relationship between the data subject and the café.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined MEDEROS MOVITEN, S.L. with EUR 15,000. A data subject had signed a mobile service contract with the company but the company had invoiced the data subject for services that the data subject did not consent to. These contracts had the data subject’s name on them but no personal signature. Because the contracts were not valid, the DPA concluded that the company had illegally processed the personal data of the data subjects, violating Art. 6 (1) GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined the credit information agency Working Capital Management Espana, S.L. with EUR 40,000. A data subject had complained to the AEPD that the several fraudsters had taken a loan with NBQ Technology S.A.U. in the name of the data subject without there being a valid contractual relationship in place. After the data subject refused to make the payments, NBQ disclosed the data subject’s information to Working Capital Management. The AEPD concluded that Working Capital Management had processed the data subject’s information illegally since the personal data was processed and entered into the company’s information systems without ensuring that the data subject had given their consent to this.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined CLINICA DENTAL SAN FRANCISCO, S.L. with EUR 4,200. A data subject had complained to the DPA that the data controller kept sending him advertisements via WhatsApp after sending several data deletion requests to the data controller. The original fine of EUR 7,000 was reduced to EUR 4,200 because of immediate payment and acknowledgement of guilt.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined LABORATORIOS GONAZALEZ, S.L. with EUR 16,000. The laboratory had apparently sent results of a Covid-19 test that the data subject had taken to them and also their boss (without consent. The original fine of EUR 20,000 was reduced to EUR 16,000 because of immediate payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined MISTORE CANARIAS, S.L. with EUR 5,000. A client who made a purchase from the company had filed a complaint to the DPA, stating that the company had collected her first name, surname, and bank account details during a purchase. During the purchase, she was offered products from three other companies, which she refused. However, it was still clear that the data controller had sent her data to the three companies without obtaining her consent first.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined CONTIMAG INVEST, S.L. with EUR 1,200 because the company failed to provide enough information about the video surveillance systems that it operated in its restaurants.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a bar owner with EUR 600. The bar was operating a video surveillance system where the observation angle of the cameras captured the public space too. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization and issued a fine of EUR 600 to the bar owner.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Netherlands
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Dutch Supervisory Authority for Data Protection (AP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b), d), e) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) GDPR, Art. 35 (2) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Dutch DPA has fined the Dutch Tax and Customs Administration with EUR 3,7 million. This marks the largest fine ever issued by the Dutch DPA after an investigation. During the investigation, the DPA discovered several violations of the GDPR but the Dutch Tax and Customs Administration. The data controller had been keeping a list of indications of fraud for several years. This list contained information on more than 270,000 data subjects, including minors. The administration had processed the personal data, which included citizenship, health, and criminal personal data, as part of the list maintenance. The DPA initially discovered that the administration had no valid legal basis to process this personal data. As such, the data gathered had been processed unlawfully. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the information in this list was also incorrect at times, where many individuals had been falsely registered as possible fraudsters. Additionally, the investigation also revealed that the maintenance of this list resulted in the discrimination against several data subjects. The risk of fraud was also determined based on the nationality and appearance of some of the data subjects. For instance, donations to mosques were considered a risk factor for fraud in the administration’s list. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the administration had violated its obligations to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures that would properly protect the collected personal data. As such, the administration had not adequately secured the personal data of the data subjects. The DPA found out that the administration had also violated the principle of storage limitation by keeping this data for longer than was necessary and contrary to the retention period set by the administration itself. The DPA also found out that the processing of this personal data was not necessary for the administration to perform its duties, so the data processing was disproportionate to the claimed purpose. Also, the administration hadn’t clearly defined the posers for the data processing, violating the principle of data limitation as a result. The fine consists of: EUR 1 million for breaching Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR and Art. 6 (1) GDPR; EUR 750,000 for a breach of Art. 5 (1) b) GDPR; EUR 750,000 for a breach of Art. 5 (1) d) GDPR; EUR 250,000 for a breach of Art. 5 (1) e) GDPR; EUR 500,000 for a breach of Art. 32 (1) GDPR EUR 450,000 for a breach of Art. 35 (2) GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Hungary
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) b), c), GDPR, Art. 6 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 13 (1), (2) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hungarian DPA has fined a workshop with EUR 1,300. Apparently, the workshop had previously installed a video surveillance system to protect its assets. However, these cameras also captured parts of the employees’ work areas. The DPA discovered that it wasn’t necessary for the CCTV to record the employees in order to protect the assets of the company, so the surveillance was disproportionate to the declared purpose. The DPA also discovered that the workshop had not sufficiently complied the its information obligations as per Art. 13 GDPR. The workshop claimed that its legal basis for using the CCTV system was the consent given by the employees. However, the DPA declared that the workshop could not use this consent as the legal basis for the video surveillance because the voluntary consent in an employer-employee relationship is questionable to begin with. The workshop should have used a legitimate interest to use the video surveillance instead.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 33 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA (also known as ANSPDCP) has fined Kredyt Inkaso Investments RO S.A. with EUR 5,000. A data subject had filed a complained to the DPA against the data controller because the former had disclosed their personal data and the personal data of their minor child to several medical institutions without their content. The data subject also had no relationship to these medical institutions. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller had disclosed sensitive information such as professional status, home address, and data from the data subject’s employment contract. Additionally, the DPA found that the data controller did not notify the DPA about this data breach in a timely manner, as demanded by Art. 33 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) b), c) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA (also known as ANSPDCP) has fined MAYR MELNHOF PACKAGING ROMANIA S.R.L. with EUR 1,500. The data controller had installed a video surveillance system on its premises for protecting the company assets and ensuring the safety of its employees. However, during an investigation, the DPA discovered that these cameras also covered the employee cafeteria and smoking area, which means the employees were monitored outside the working areas. The DPA states that these recordings of the employees are not necessary to ensure the purposes of the surveillance system, so the recordings are disproportionate. The DPA concluded this to be a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 48 (1) b) LGT, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 23 (4) LOPDGDD
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects’ rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined TIGERS MARKET, S.L. with EUR 8,000 because a data subject kept receiving advertising calls from the data controller even though the data subject had been registered in the Robinson advertising exclusion list.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined RAMONA FILMS, S.L. with EUR 18,000 because data controller had failed to provide the information requested during a DPA investigation. The original fine of EUR 30,000 was reduced to EUR 18,000 because of immediate payment and acknowledgment of guilt.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined INSEKT FOODS, S.L. with EUR 4,000. A data subject had filed a complaint to the DPA against the data controller because the former had published the personal data of the data subject on three WhatsApp groups. This led to a total of 541 members of these WhatsApp groups gaining unauthorized access to key personal data of the data subject, such as first name, surname address.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Alfa Shipyard s.r.l. with EUR 10,000 because the data controller failed to implement the measures ordered by the DPA in due time.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined SCF ZHU, S.L. with EUR 600 because the data subject did not have enough data processing information regarding a video surveillance on the business premises. The original fine was reduced to EUR 600 from EUR 1,000 because of acknowledgment of debt and immediate payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined MED LIFE S.A. The company had previously disposed of several documents that contained sensitive patient data by disposing of them in a publicly accessible garbage can. Someone found these documents and filed a complaint to the DPA. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that MED LIFE did not take the adequate organizational and technical measures to protect the personal data and to avoid such incidents.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), e) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 12 (3) GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 157 Codice della privacy, Art. 166 (2) Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Palumbo Superyacht Ancona s.r.l. with EUR 5,000. The company had previously blocked an employee’s company email account without obtaining the subject’s consent first. The employee had reported this incident to the company and asked that his email inbox be restored since it contained both business and private emails. However, the company did not comply with his request. During the investigation, the DPA discovered further violations such as the company’s failure to respond to a request of information from the DPA, violating the principle of limiting data retention.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 7 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 130 (3) Codice della privacy, Art. 157 Codice della privacy, Art. 166 (2) Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Made in Italy s.r.l.s. with EUR 20,000. A data subject had previously filed a complaint with the DPA after he kept receiving promotional calls from the data controller, even though he had not consented to them. The data controller did not stop these calls even after the data subject had objected to them. The data subject also requested the information about the origin of the data, as well as the deletion of the data. However, the data controller did not respond to this request. Moreover, the data controller did not sufficiently cooperate with the DPA during the investigation.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Findomestic Banca spa with EUR 10,000. A customer had previously filed a complaint to the DPA regarding a breach of confidentiality regarding a financial institution. The data controller had unauthorizedly sent over several payment reminders to the wife of the data subject regarding a loan that he had taken out in the past. The wife had guaranteed one of the loans taken by the data subject but not the one in question.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: United Kingdom
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The UK DPA (also known as ICO) has fined the law firm Tuckers Solicitors LLP with EUR 115,000. The law firm suffered a ransomware attack on its systems which led to a personal data breach. During the investigation, the DPA concluded that the law firm had failed to take the proper organizational and technical measures to protect this personal data. This failure had left its systems vulnerable to malware attacks. The attackers encrypted a total of 972,191 files, out of which 24,712 were related to court proceedings. The attacker also siphoned off 60 files and published them in underground data marketplaces. The files contained both personal and special category data such as witness statements, medical records, the names, addresses of the witnesses and victims, and the alleged crimes of the data subjects.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Finland
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Finnish DPA has fined a telemarketing company with EUR 8,300 for failing to comply with a DPA order. One of the customers of the company had requested access to the recording of a sales call. The company, however, did not comply with this request. So, the DPA formally ordered the company to provide the customer with access to the recordings. Later on, the customer reported that the telemarketing company did not comply with the DPA’s order and failed to provide the recordings call.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: United Kingdom
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), e) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 16 GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 22 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The UK DPA has fined Clearview AI Inc. with EUR 9 million. The company manages a database of more than 20 billion facial images, including those of UK residents and nationals, from all over the world. This data is collected online from platforms that are publicly accessible, such as social networks. The company has a search service that allows individuals to be identified based on the biometric data that is extracted from these images. The profiles of these individuals can be further improved with information associated with these images, like image tags and geolocation. Clearview AI doesn’t offer these services in the UK but it does offer them in other countries, so the personal data of UK residents is still used. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the personal data contained within the company’s databases was processed unlawfully without a valid legal basis. Moreover, when the data subjects wanted to exercise their rights under the GDPR, such as the right governed by Art. 15 GDPR, they had to submit more personal data in the form of a photograph that may be matched with the Clearview database. According to the DPA, this is a significant obstacle and deterrent in the exercise of the rights. Additionally, the DPA discovered that the company had violated several of the GDPR principles. For instance, the company had clearly violated the principle of transparency because it failed to adequately inform users about the data processing of their personal data. Clearview also violated the principle of storage limitation because it did not provide a data retention policy, failing to ensure that the data was held for longer than necessary. Finally, Clearview AI did not conduct a privacy impact assessment despite the obvious high risk to the data subjects’ data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Belgium
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) e) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 7 (1), (3) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Belgian DPA has fined Roularta Media Group with EUR 50,000. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the cookie managed used on two websites operated by Roularta failed to comply with the GDPR. To use these cookies, the data controller should have obtained prior consent from its users, except in the cases where the cookies are obligatory for the functionality of the website. The DPA discovered that the consent for the processing of the personal data on Roularta’s websites was not valid because not all conditions were met. Consequently, approximately 60 cookies that were not required were placed on the devices of the users without obtaining their consent first. Roularta also failed to sufficiently inform its users about these cookies. Additionally, the boxes for the consent in placing the third-party cookies were checked in advance even though the users hadn’t checked them (consented to them). Moreover, the DPA discovered that the users could not revoke their consent regarding the cookie placement as easily as they had offered it.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company failed to respond in a timely manner to the data subject’s request to access their data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), e) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) b), c) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian has fined Educationest s.r.l. with EUR 1,000. The daycare center had previously sent an email to the families of the children under its care, informing them about the pregnancy and maternity leave of one of the educators. The daycare center had sent this email to prevent any rumor spreading about the teacher’s absence being motivated by covid illness, and to protect her. However, the educator did not consent to the disclosure of her pregnancy status. The DPA concluded that the daycare center Educationest had unlawfully processed the educator’s personal data and violated Art. 5 GDPR and Art. 6 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined CORON ISLAND SLU with EUR 1,600. A customer had previously filed a complaint with the DPA against the restaurant. The customer had asked for a bill in her name after getting a meal at the restaurant. However, the manager said that he could only issue an invoice if the customer provided her telephone number. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Istituto Nazionale Assicurazione Infortuni sul Lavoro
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), f) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) e) GDPR, Art. 9 (2) g) GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy, Art. 2-sexies Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Istituto Nazionale Assicurazione Infortuni sul Lavoro (Public Accident Insurance for Workers) with EUR 50,000. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that on three occasions, both the accident and the occupational illnesses of various employees could be publicly viewed on an online system of the insurance carrier. This data breach had occurred because of an outdated version of the system. The DPA claimed that the insurance carrier did not sufficiently fulfill its duty to take the appropriate organizational and technical measures to prevent the personal data breaches. The insurance carrier should have clearly ensured that the online systems were updated and secured.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 10 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy, Art. 2-sexies Codice della privacy, Art. 2-octies Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Italian Ministry of Defense with EUR 10,000. One of the employees of the ministry had filed a complaint with the DPA. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that two emails containing sensitive information about the health status of the data subject and various legal proceedings, had ben forwarded without authorization.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 29 GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b) GDPR, Art. 32 (2), (4) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Kaufland Romania SCS with EUR 2,000. The data controller had reported two data breaches to the DPA as per Art. 33 GDPR. One of the employees who processed a complaint did not follow the internal procedures for handling complaints, and allowed a security guard to view and misuse the complainant’s data. Additionally, the data controller had mistakenly forwarded the personal data in one of the customer order forms to an unauthorized third part. This led to the disclosure of the personal data (first name, last name, telephone number, and email address) of the affected Kaufland customer to unauthorized sources. In this sense, the DPA discovered that the data controller did not take the appropriate technical and organizational measures that would ensure the protection and security of the personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Wens Experience SRL with EUR 1,500. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that Wens Experience, while it acted as the processor of the data controller, engaged another processor to process the employee data without obtaining prior authorization from the data controller. This is a violation of Art. 28 (2) GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined the restaurant operator LODEJU, S.L. with EUR 3,000. The data controller had previously installed several video surveillance cameras on its premises which also covered the public space. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. Moreover, the data controller did not properly inform the data subject about the processing of this data through the video surveillance, which is also a violation of its duty to inform.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Esselmann Technika Pojazdowa Sp. z o.o. Sp. k.
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Polish DPA has fined Esselmann Technika Pojazdowa Sp. z o.o. Sp. k. with EUR 3,500. The data controller had previously suffered a data breach during which a certificate of employment that contained personal data of an employee was lost. The data controller failed to report this data breach to the DPA, violating Art. 33 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy, Art. 2-sexties Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the “Isabella Gonzaga” high school with EUR 2,500. The school had previously published a document, which also contained the personal health data of several teachers, on an online platform for teaching staff. This document contained information about the benefits linked to the health status of the teachers who were entitled to receive such benefits. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the school had published this data without having a valid legal basis, and so, this was unlawful.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: A police officer had accessed the data in a police database for private research purposes. The officer in question had purchased a notebook for private use in an internet platform. The seller did not agree to the negotiations about the method of payment, so the officer used a police information system to obtain information about the seller. The police officer then sent several messages to the seller, mentioning the information he had obtained from the police database through his research. The goal was to force the seller to agree to the payment method suggested by the police officer.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: A job center employee had previously accessed the data in the social database systems and in the civil register for private research purposes.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The DPA from Berlin has imposed a fine on a medical clinic. Apparently, the clinic had installed 21 cameras on its premises for the purpose of protecting against crime and property damage. This led to the monitoring of the employees and patients around the clock. The clinic relied on the consent given by the employees and the information signs as the legal basis for the video surveillance. However, the DPA concluded that the clinic had no right to base the video surveillance on consent because voluntary consent in the employee-employer relationship is questionable. Moreover, the visible notices of the video surveillance did not allow the conclusion that the patients legally expressed their consent to the observation by simply entering the monitored premises. The DPA could also not find any other evidence that justified this extensive video surveillance of the clinic.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Unknown
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The DPA form Berlin has imposed a fine against a beverage retailer. Apparently, the retailer operated a video surveillance system where the observation angle of the cameras extended into the public space.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Unknown
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The DPA form Berlin has imposed a fine on a clinic. Apparently, the clinic had previously appointed the clinic managed, who was also a shareholder of the clinic, as the data protection officer. Regarding the data protection officer’s tasks and duties, the company must ensure that they do not create a conflict of interest. In this case, however, a conflict of interest had arisen because the clinic manager had to make economic decisions in his executive position. But he also had to monitor the clinic’s compliance with the data protection laws. The DPA concluded that this duality of his roles carried the extensive risk that the patients and employees would be hesitant to ask assistance from the data protection officer, who was also the hospital director, about various questions about the processing of personal data. So, the clinic was fined because it allowed this conflict of interest to exist.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Norway
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Norwegian DPA (also known as Datatilsynet) has fined Krokatjønnvegen 15 AS with EUR 30,200. The data controller had run credit checks on two of its data subjects without any contractual basis for doing this.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Sephora Cosmetics România SA with EUR 2,000. One of the company’s data subjects had received promotional SMS texts from Sephora even though they’d objected several times to the processing of their personal data for marketing purposes. Sephora had also confirmed the termination of the SMS sending. However, this continued until the data subject complained to the DPA.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined JAÉN SENTIDO Y COMÚN with EUR 2,000. Apparently, the data controller had sent an email to 241 people in an email open distribution list, thus making the email addresses of all recipients visible to one another.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: ESTUDIOS EUROPEOS DE POSTGRADO Y EMPRESA, S.L.
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined ESTUDIOS EUROPEOS Y EMPRESA, S.L. with EUR 3,000. One of the company’s employees had filed a complaint to the DPA. Apparently, she had received access to the company’s email account upon being hired. However, when she accessed the email account given to her, she found out that it was the email account of another employee. So, she was able to access all of the emails received and sent by that employee. During the investigation, the DPA determined that the data controller did not properly configure the email accounts and had thus breached its duty to implement the appropriate organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined LAST LAP, S.L. with EUR 9,600. This company organizes the San Silvestre road running race. During one of the shows, the race participants were required to show their vaccination certificates or offer a PCR or antigen test before participating in the race. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the company did not have any reasonable legal basis for processing this health data. The original fine of EUR 16,000 was reduced to EUR 9,600 due to admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), e) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR, Art. 38 (6) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: Art. 5 (1) a), e) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR, Art. 38 (6) GDPR Description: The Italian DPA has fined the Policoro Municipality with EUR 26,000. The Italian municipality had previously installed a video surveillance system without offering sufficient information about this. Additionally, the DPA discovered that the municipality had not established a data retention period for the video surveillance recordings, keeping them for an unjustified period of time. Moreover, the DPA also found that the municipality had not fulfilled its obligations in naming a data protection officer. The municipality had instead appointed its attorney as the data protection officer, but this is a conflict of interest, the DPA concluded.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Synlab Med srl with EUR 2,000. The company had previously conducted Covid-19 tests for various regional health authorities. Regarding these tests, the company had inadvertently sent the results of 31 people to the wrong health authority.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: CDI Transport Intern și Internațional SRL
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 12 (1) GDPR, Art. 58 (1) a), e) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined CDI Transport Intern și Internațional SRL with EUR 7,000. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the company’s website did not offer any information about the rights of the data subject regarding the GDPR laws, and how they can exercise those rights. Moreover, the company also failed to provide the DPA with the requested information in a timely manner.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a restaurant owner with EUR 600. The data controller had previously installed several video surveillance cameras. These cameras filmed, among other things, the public space. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. Additionally, the data controller also failed to comply with its duty to properly inform the public about the CCTV system.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Denmark
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Danish DPA has fined the Lolland municipality with EUR 6,700. The municipality had apparently reported a data breach to the DPA in accordance with Art. 33 GDPR. One of the employees of the municipality had their work phone stolen. This phone was used by the employee to access the work email account, which included the names of citizens, social security numbers, and their health data. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that this phone wasn’t protected by a password. This made it possible for anyone to access the information on the phone. The DPA concluded that this incident had clearly occurred due to the municipality’s failure to implement the required organizational and technical measures that would protect the data subjects’ personal data. At the very least, the municipality should have made sure that each employee has secured their phone with a password.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Wabag Water Services SRL with EUR 1,000. One of the company’s employees had complained to the DPA that their employer had processed their personal data without their consent, for the purpose of booking and registering a Covid-19 vaccination appointment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a private individual with EUR 600. The data controller had apparently installed several video surveillance cameras that also covered the public space, among other things. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. Furthermore, the data controller did not properly inform the data subjects about the processing of this data through the CCTV system, violating its duty to inform.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined Prodesspa Decoratius i Pintures, S.L. with EUR 9,000. One of the company’s former employees had complained to the DPA about the company’s unlawful disclosure of their personal data to a credit reporting agency. The original fine of EUR 15,000 was reduced to EUR 9,000 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Unknown
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The gym owner had apologized for the late opening of his gym but also shifted responsibility to an employee who was named. This resulted in the data subject’s personal data being unlawfully disclosed.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Unknown
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: One of the bank’s employees had constantly accessed the bank account of a bank customer for private purposes over a year.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Unknown
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: One of the employees of a political organization had sent an e-mail to 400 people in an open distribution list, making the email addresses of all the recipients visible to other recipients and revealing their political orientation.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined RODALI GESTION INMOBILIARIA, S.L. with EUR 5,000. An individual had filed a complaint to the DPA, saying that the data controller had not informed them about the processing of their personal data during an apartment acquisition. As such, the DPA concluded that the data controller had violated its information obligations, as per Art. 13 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Isle of Man
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Information Commissioner of Isle of Man
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c), f) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 34 GDPR, Art. 58 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The DPA of the Isle of Man has imposed a fine of EUR 202,000 on Manx Care Ltd. Apparently, the company had sent an unsecured attachment via email that contained a patient’s health information to more than 1870 recipients. The DPA issued an enforcement notice against Manx Care as a result. However, the company did not comply with the DPA’s orders. As such, the DPA concluded that the company should be fined. The DPA discovered that the company had not implemented the appropriate organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data. Moreover, the DPA found that the company had also violated the principle of data minimization as per Art. 5 (1) C) GDPR, by sending the patient’s data to individuals who weren’t related to the patient’s care. Finally, the DPA discovered that the company did not inform the data subject about the data breach.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 88 GDPR, Art. 114 Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Farpa s.r.l. with EUR 1,000. The company had previously installed video surveillance systems in social facilities under its operation. However, they weren’t authorized to use them. The DPA then discovered that this video surveillance system had various features other than the approved ones, and it had been installing them in a different position than approved. Moreover, the DPA found that the company did not offer sufficient information to the data subjects about this video surveillance.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) c), e) Art. 6 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (3) b) GDPR GDPR, Art. 2-ter (1), (3) Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Santa Ninfa Municipality with EUR 2,000. The municipality had previously published a resolution on its website containing the personal information, name and references about the enforcement title of the data subject.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined ECOZONO Y CULTURA with EUR 3,600. The company had previously collected data from various data subjects who agreed to disclose the data for their survey purposes. However, this data was then used to contract various individuals for advertising purposes. This fine was reduced from EUR 6,000 to EUR 3,600 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined FREE SUN ENERGY S.L. with EUR 6,000. One of the company’s customers had complained to the DPA that they’d received the invoice of another customer which contained that customer’s personal data, instead of receiving their own invoice. The original fine of EUR 10,000 was reduced to EUR 6,000 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined JOYPAZAR, S.A. with EUR 1,600. This company had previously installed video surveillance cameras that also covered the public playground, among other things. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: France
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, L. 34-5 CPCE
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The French DPA (also known as CNIL( has fined ACCOR SA with EUR 600,000. Both the CNIL and other European DPAS institutions have received various complaints against ACCOR from several data subjects. During the investigation, the CNIL discovered that the hotel guests who had made a booking directly through the hotel or one of its websites were automatically sent advertising newsletters because the consent box was automatically ticked in advance. Moreover, the CNIL found that many data subjects were unable to opt-out of these promotional emails because of technical errors. The CNIL also discovered that ACCOR had not provided sufficient data to the data subjects about the processing of their personal data regarding the promotional messages, violating Art. 12 GDPR and Art. 13 GDPR. Moreover, ACCOR failed to respond to the data subjects’ requests for access to their personal data in a timely manner, violating Art. 12 and 15 GDPR. The company also failed to comply with the data subjects’ right to object because of technical problems. The CNIL found a violation of Art. 12 and 21 GDPR. There was also a violation of Art. 32 GDPR because ACCOR allowed the use of passwords that were deemed unsecure. When imposing the fine, the CNIL considered it aggravating that the violations had affected several fundamental principles of personal data protection and involved a fundamental infringement of the rights of the data subjects.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Private Polyclinic and Diagnostic Centre of Pyle Axiou
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined the Private Polyclinic and Diagnostic Centre of Pyle Axiou with EUR 30,000. One of the patients had requested access to their personal data from an imagining examination. Due to a lack of availability of these images, the clinic was unable to grant the request for access. The DPA discovered that the clinic had failed to offer adequate storage facilities for these images, violating Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: DO VALUE GREECE LOANS & CREDITS CLAIM MANAGEMENT S.A.
