allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Cosmopol S.p.A. with EUR 20,000. An individual had previously filed a complaint with the DPA against the data controller. This individual had received invoices without having a contractual relationship with the company. So, the data subject then requested information about the origin of their personal data. However, the data controller failed to respond to the data subject’s request for information in a timely manner.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined INMUR JOYEROS, S.L. with EUR 180. The data controller failed to provide a notice with information regarding the video surveillance on its premises. The original fine of EUR 300 was reduced to EUR 180 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Intesa Sanpaolo Vita S.p.a. with EUR 20,000. The data subject had taken out a life insurance with the data controller and filed a complaint to the DPA against the data controller for the unauthorized disclosure of their personal data. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller had disclosed the data subject’s personal data (first name, last name, and information regarding the policy) to third parties without authorization. This unauthorized data disclosure had occurred because of an employee’s error.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined RESTEXPERIENCE, S.L. with EUR 5,000. The data controller had accidentally sent an email that contained the tax information of 36 individuals to 11 unauthorized individuals. The DPA claims that this was a breach of the principle of confidentiality and integrity. The DPA also discovered that the company had previously failed to implement the appropriate organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA (also known as ANSPDCP) has fined SC Materiale Constructii Online SRL with EUR 2,000 because the company failed to provide information requested by the DPA during an investigation.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Immobiliare Riscostruzione Meloria s.r.l. with EUR 2,000. The data controller had installed a video surveillance system at its office that also covered parts of the common entrance to the building, recording residents of the building. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the information signs regarding the video surveillance contained neither sufficient information about the purpose of the data processing, nor the contact details of the data controller.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined the gas station operator with EUR 3,000. A person had previously filed a complaint to the DPA against the data controller because the latter failed to grant them access to the images of their minor child recorded by the video surveillance system in the gas station. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of Art. 12 GDPR. Moreover, the operator shared these images with the police during the investigation without informing the parent first. The DPA also discovered that the failure to inform the parent was a violation of Art. 14 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined ALFA BANK S.A. with EUR 20,000. Regarding the use of certain debit/credit cards, information about the last 10 transactions were stored on the chip of the card without the explicit consent of the customers. This information could be read later by anyone. The DPA discovered that the bank had failed to inform the affected customers about the storage of this transaction information and violated Art. 13 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined the EUROBANK ERGASIAS S.A. with EUR 20,000. The Hellenic DPA has fined EUROBANK ERGASIAS S.A. with EUR 20,000. Regarding the use of certain debit/credit cards, information about the last 10 transactions were stored on the chip of the card without the explicit consent of the customers. This information could be read later by anyone. The DPA discovered that the bank had failed to inform the affected customers about the storage of this transaction information and violated Art. 13 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined PIRAEUS BANK S.A. with EUR 20,000. Regarding the use of certain debit/credit cards, information about the last 10 transactions were stored on the chip of the card without the explicit consent of the customers. This information could be read later by anyone. The DPA discovered that the bank had failed to inform the affected customers about the storage of this transaction information and violated Art. 13 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined NATIONAL BANK OF GREECE S.A. with EUR 20,000. Regarding the use of certain debit/credit cards, information about the last 10 transactions were stored on the chip of the card without the explicit consent of the customers. This information could be read later by anyone. The DPA discovered that the bank had failed to inform the affected customers about the storage of this transaction information and violated Art. 13 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Bper Banca S.p.A. with EUR 10,000. An individual had previously filed a complaint to the DPA about the failure of the data controller to fulfill their right to erasure of personal data. The individual had requested the bank to delete their personal data that had been processed by the institutions. However, the bank asked the data subject to send their identification documents so they can verify his identity and fulfill the request. The data subject submitted this data but did not receive any response to their request. This is why the DPA concluded that the bank had violated Art. 12 GDPR by failing to respond to the request in a timely manner.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: United Kingdom
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The British DPA has fined the construction group Interserve Group Limited with EUR 5,033,000. The data controller had previously notified the DPA about a data breach as per Art. 33 GDPR. Interserve had suffered a cyber attack in the past where the attackers had sent a phishing email to the mailbox of the company’s accounting team. The email had been opened by an employee who also downloaded and opened the zip file contained in the attachment. This made it possible for the attackers to install malware and steal personal data of 113,000 employees. The stolen data contained the social security numbers, bank account information, sexual orientation, ethnicity, and religion of the data subjects. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the attack was made possible because of inadequate security measures. Interserve employees had not been adequately trained on data privacy and the company processes personal data on unsupported operating systems that did not receive security updates anymore, so new system vulnerabilities weren’t covered. Moreover, Interserve had not conducted the adequate vulnerability scans and the information security team did not sufficiently investigate the attack because the antivirus software installed on the systems reported that the malware had been removed.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Servicio Idrico Integrato S.c.p.a. with EUR 15,000. The data controller had previously operated a website where the personal data was being processes without the use of SSL forms. The DPA discovered that the use of an SSL form was necessary to thoroughly protect the data. So, the DPA concluded that the data controller failed to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 30 (2) GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della Privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Clio S.r.l. with EUR 10,000. The company manages a whistleblowing reporting application for publica and private entities. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that Clio had not sufficiently regulated its relationship to the customers. Moreover, the company provided data on whistleblowing reports to customer without having a legal basis to do so. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR and Art. 6 GDPR. Lastly, the DPA found that the company had failed to maintain a register of its activities carried out in the role of data processor. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of Art. 30 (2) GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 28 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Acqua Novara.VCO S.p.a. with EUR 20,000. This fine is related to the fine issued to Clio S.r.l. which provided and managed a whistleblowing reporting application for public and private entities. Acqua Novara was one of its clients. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that Acqua Novara offered personal data to Clio in connection to several whistleblowing reports, which allowed Clio to collect and store the data without a valid legal basis. Lastly, the DPA concluded that Acqua Novara had not adequately regulated its relationship with Clio.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 48 (1) b) LGT, Art. 21 GDPR, Art. 23 (4) LOPDGDD
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) fined ADSL HOUSE, S.L. with EUR 8,000. The data subject had received advertising calls from the data controller, although the data subject was registered in the Robinson advertising exclusion list

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Thiene Municipality with EUR 3,000. One of the municipality’s former employees filed a complaint to the DPA because a document that contained their personal data was published on the municipality’s website. This document contained information about the termination of their employment relationship. The Italian DPA concluded that this was a violation of Art. 5 (1) a), c), GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, and Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: France
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 28 (3) GDPR, Art. 82 Loi informatique et libertés
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The French DPA has fined CITYSCOOT with EUR 125,000. The company apparently rents motor scooters for short periods of time. During the investigation, the DPA found out that CITYSCOOT had been collecting vehicle geolocation data every 30 seconds while renting the scooters, and was also storing the history of the trips. The company had claimed that they were collecting this data for the purpose of handling traffic violations, complaint inquiries, and helping users in the case of a crash, as well as handling theft cases. However, the DPA discovered that these reasons did not justify the permanent geolocation of the data subjects, and the company had violated the principle of data minimization by doing this. Moreover, the DPA found out that the contracts concluded by the company with its data processors did not contain all the necessary information.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c), e) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Tehnoplus Industry SRL with EUR 5,000. One of the company’s employees had complained to the DPA against the data controller because the latter had installed a GPS system in their company vehicle for monitoring the vehicle without offering them enough information about this installation. During the investigation, the DPA also discovered that the data controller had been processing the GPS data outside working hours and for other purposes than those originally stated. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. Moreover, the data controller was not able to prove that it did not store data for longer than legally permitted.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: CAIXABANK PAYMENTS & CONSUMER EFC, EP, S.A.U.
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined CAIXABANK PAYMENTS & CONSUMER EFC, EP, S.A.U. with EUR 70,000. The data subject had previously received a message from a debt collection company on behalf of Caixabank where it requested the payment of outstanding debts. However, the debt in question had previously been annulled which had been confirmed in a court ruling. For this reason, the DPA concluded that the disclosure of the data subject’s personal data for the purpose of being contacted regarding the debt settlement was unlawful.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined the SOCIEDAD ESPANOLA DE RADIODIFUSION, S.L. with EUR 50,000. Multiple media outlets, including the data controller in question, had published an audio recording of a rape victim’s testimony in court on their official websites as a way to report on the case. This case had attracted a lot of media attention at the time. During the investigation, the DPA concluded that the right to privacy of the rape victim outweighed the data controller’s freedom of information. Moreover, the audio recordings of the victim added no significant value to the reporting but rather compromised the victim’s privacy. This is why the DPA concluded that the data controller violated the principle of data minimization.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The DPA of Bremen fined a private individual. The person in question was working a Covid 19 testing center and had contacted a patient privately using the contact details they had provided for their Covid test.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Unknown
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The DPA of Bremen has fined a medical care center because the latter had scanned a customer’s ID card against their will and stored the copy for themselves. After the customer issued a complaint, they were threatened with the termination of their customer relationship. When assessing the fine, the DPA took into consideration that fact that the ID card had been scanned even though the data subject had explicitly objected to this.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Tensa Art Design SRL with EUR 3,000. An individual had previously complained to the DPA about receiving promotional messages even though he had filed an objection to receiving marketing messages and having their data processed for marketing purposes. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of Art. 21 (3) GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: ATRESMEDIA CORPORACION DE MEDIOS DE COMUNICACION, S.A.
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined ENFOKA SISTEMAS GLOBALES, S.L. with EUR 18,000. A customer had previously complained to the DPA that the data controller had carried out a change of their electricity supply company without getting their consent first. The original fine of EUR 30,000 was reduced to EUR 18,000 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined 20 MINUTOS EDITORA, S.L. with EUR 50,000. allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined INMARAN ASESORES S.L. with EUR 1,000 because it had failed to comply with an order issued by the DPA.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Azienda socio-sanitaria locale nr. 1 di Sassari
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Azienda socio-sanitaria locale nr. 1 di Sassari with EUR 4,000. The data controller had sent a document that contained health data of the data subject to the wrong recipient by mistake. The DPA discovered that the healthcare facility had not taken enough organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 32 (1) GDPR, Art. 33 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: A logistics company had disposed of the delivery lists in a public waste paper container. This list contained a large amount of detailed information like the first and last names of subscribers, their addresses, subscribed newspapers, and special delivery information like the location of their mailboxes and complaints from recipients. The DPA also noticed that the company had failed to inform the data subjects or the DPA about the data breach in a timely manner.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The DPA of Hamburg has fined a Covid-19 test center with EUR 1,000 because it did not comply with the right of the data subjects to have their personal data deleted.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined ALI MARKET with EUR 360. The data controller had failed to offer a notice with information about the video surveillance on its premises. Moreover, the data controller had also failed to make a proper register of the processing activities.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Ireland
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: A&G Couriers Limited T/A Fastway Couriers (Ireland)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Irish DPA (also known as DPC) has fined the A&G Couriers Limited T/A Fastway Couriers (Ireland) with EUR 15,000. Apparently, during of the changeovers of the IT systems, the data controller had suffered a cyberattack that allowed unauthorized third parties access to personal data. The DPA discovered that the data controller had failed to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data, thus facilitating the attack.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Finland
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Finnish DPA has fined Suomen Asiakastieto Oy with EUR 440,000. Apparently, the company failed to comply with an order issued by the DPA. During an investigation, the DPA discovered that the company had unlawfully stored financial data of multiple data subjects. The DPA then ordered the company to remove this data but the company refused to comply.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Croatia
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Croatian DPA (also known as azop) has fined a telecommunications company with EUR 20,000. One of the data subjects had filed a complaint to the DPA saying that the company was processing their personal data even though they had not been a customer of the company for more than ten years. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the company was still storing the data because of an alleged debt. This debt was not longer outstanding, though, but the company did not delete the data of the data subject because of a lack of measures required to verify that the stored data was up to date and accurate. The DPA then concluded that the company had been unlawfully processing the data of the data subject, acting in violation with Art. 6 (1) GDPR and Art. 5 (1) d) GDPR.

During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller had not implemented the required organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data.

During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller had not implemented the required organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Mondaone SRL with EUR 2,000 after an individual had filed a complaint with the DPA saying that they were receiving messages through email from the data controller even though they had objected to receiving such messages and this was confirmed by the data controller. Moreover, the DPA concluded that the requirements for exercising these data subject rights were inadequate.

allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Alianța pentru Unirea Românilor with EUR 10,000. The DPA also discovered that the data controller has been collecting data such as surname, last name, address, ID card number, and more not only on the official lwebsite but also on various forms that users could fill. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania

allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Partidul Uniunea Salvați România with EUR 4,000. The data controller had suffered a phishing attack where the attackers gained unauthorized access to personal data of data subjects, including first name, last name, phone number, email address, and the political affiliation of the data subjects. The DPA discovered that the data controller had failed to implement the required organizational measures like data encryption to protect this personal data, thus facilitating this type of attack on the organization.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland

allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 24 (1) GDPR, Art. 25 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 32 (1), (2) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Polish DPA has fined the Szczecin-Centrum District Court with EUR 6,400. Apparently, the court had reported a data breach to the DPA that involved the loss of three data carriers. One of the data carriers was an encrypted official one, while the other two ones were private and unencrypted that contained drafts of court rulings and statements with personal data. During the course of the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data carriers had not been verified and secured by the court’s IT department and had been used on unencrypted computers for many years. Moreover, the DPA discovered that, despite being regulations that prohibited the use of private data carriers, the court did not check whether employees actually complied with these regulations. Lastly, the court also failed to implement the necessary technical measures that would prevent the use of such private data carriers.

allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles

The healthcare facility had mistakenly sent a patient medical record to the wrong, and unauthorized patient. The DPA discovered that the healthcare facility had failed to take the necessary organizational and technical measures that would protect this personal data, allowing such incidents to occur.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Ufficio Scolastico Regionale per la Lombardia, Ufficio IV – Ambio Territoriale di Brescia
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy, Art. 2-septies (8) Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Ufficio Scolastico Regionale per la Lombardia, Ufficio IV – Ambio Territoriale di Brescia with EUR 6,000. Apparently, the school board had published a document that also contained the personal health data of a teacher on its official website. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that that school had published this personal data without a valid legal basis and had acted unlawfully while doing this.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Ireland
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Irish DPA has fined the Bank of Ireland 365 with EUR 750,000. The bank had then notified the DPA of 10 data breaches related to the bank’s app. Unauthorized individuals had managed to gain access to the app and various individuals’ accounts. The DPA concluded that these data breaches were facilitated by the fact that the bank failed to implement the required organizational and technical measures to protect the personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Norway
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to notify DPA of a data breach
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Norwegian DPA has fined Argon Medical Devices with EUR 220,000 when the data controller had failed to notify the DPA about a data breach that involved the personal data of all its European employees within 72 hours.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The DPA of Baden-Wurttemberg has fined a pharmacy with EUR 6,500 because the latter had improperly disposed of a large number of personal documents. These documents included medical prescriptions and diagnoses of data subjects, and were disposed of in trash containers that were accessible to other people.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The DPA from Baden-Wurttemberg has fiend a debt collection company with an unknown fine. The company in question had received various investor information from one of the employees of an insolvent company which it had previously used to offer its services to assist the affected investors that had insolvency claims. However, the DPA concluded that the company had unlawfully processed the personal data without a legal basis. Moreover, the debt collection company had failed to provide the data subjects with the necessary information like the origin of their personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) b), e) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 7 GDPR, Art. 12 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 (2) a) GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR, Art. 25 (1) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Douglas Italia S.p.a. with EUR 1,400,000 for various GDPR violations. During its investigation, the Italian DPA initially discovered that the customers were forced to give their consent to the privacy notices, the GTC and the cookie policy at the same time. However, the DPA claimed that this was a breach of Art. 6 GDPR and Art. 7 GDPR because the data subjects’ consent to the processing of their personal data could not have been given freely and voluntarily because of the lack of separate options for consenting to different notices. In the meantime, Douglas had also merged with other companies and also acquired additional personal data as a result. The DPA concluded that after it had acquired this personal data, Douglas had kept it for an excessive period of time without obtaining any consent from the data subjects regarding the use of their personal data for its own purposes. The DPA also discovered that Douglas had kept the personal data of customers who had not renewed their loyalty cards for an excessive period of time. Moreover, Douglas had not provided with customers with accurate nor sufficient information about the data processing. For instance, many of these customers were receiving SMS marketing messages even though they had only consented to telemarketing. In the end, the DPA concluded that Douglas had breached its accountability obligations regarding the processing of the clients’ personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Societa Lombarda Sport s.r.l. with EUR 4,000 because an individual had filed a complaint to the DPA against the company. Apparently, the data subject had undergone a sports fitness examination at this company for the purpose of attending sports courses. However, the company had then sent the result of this examination without a valid legal basis.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain

allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined PLANET COSTA DORADA SOCIEDAD LIMITADA with EUR 300. Apparently, the company had not provided any information notice about the video surveillance system installed on its premises.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Ireland
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Irish DPA has fined Centric Health Ltd. with EUR 460,000. The data controller had suffered a ransomware attack where the personal data such as the name, date of birth and contact details had been accessed, altered and destroyed without express authorization. The data records of more than 70,000 people had been affected, and 2,500 of them had been permanently affected. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the healthcare facility had not implement the proper organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data, thus facilitating such an attack.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 28 GDPR, Art. 37 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Amiu S.p.A. with EUR 200,000. Apparently, the company in question operates a waste collection service for the city of Tarento, and has acted as a processor for this service. The company had also installed several video surveillance cameras for the express purpose of monitoring any illegal waste disposal. However, the DPA discovered that Amiu had posted these images on Facebook, showing some individuals who were sufficient visible that they could be identified. During this investigation, the DPA discovered that Amiu did not have any valid legal basis to publish these images. They also found out that the data processing was not sufficiently regulated, as Art. 28 of the GDPR required in these cases. In the end, the DPA stated that Amiu had not even appointed a data protection officer.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 28 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Tarento municipality with EUR 150,000. Apparently, the company Amiu S.p.A. had operated the local waste collection service for the municipality in question. The company had also installed several video surveillance cameras for the express purpose of monitoring any illegal waste disposal. However, the DPA discovered that Amiu had posted these images on Facebook, showing some individuals who were sufficient visible that they could be identified. During the investigation, the DPA found that the municipality had improperly regulated the processing of data with Amiu S.p.A. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the municipality had not properly offered sufficient information about the video surveillance cameras installed by Amiu. The municipality also failed to conduct a data protection impact assessment concerning the installation of these video surveillance cameras. This would have been necessary considering the scope of such a large-scale systematic surveillance.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Veneto region with EUR 100,000. The DPA had received a complaint from several nursing and medical staff. Once the investigation started, the DPA discovered that, in the context of Covid-19 containment measures, the Region had offered lists of information about unvaccinated employees to various healthcare facilities as well as the physicians in charge there. The DPA discovered that the Region had no valid legal basis for such a systematic disclosure of these lists to the physicians. Only the disclosure of the lists to the relevant health authorities was covered by the legal degree imposed at that time.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 28 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Verizon Connect Italy S.p.A. with EUR 30,000. Apparently, an individual who had worked for a Verizon customer had complained to the DPA. Verizon had installed GPS systems in the delivery vehicles for their customers and was acting as a processor for them. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the relationship between the customer and Verizon was not sufficient regulated as requested by Art. 28 GDPR. As a result, the DPA found that the data that was processed as part of this commissioned data processing was done so without a valid legal basis for a long period of time.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 7 GDPR, Art. 12 (1), (2), (3) GDPR, Art. 21 (2) GDPR, Art. 24 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 25 (1) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Edison Energia with EUR 4.9 million. Several individuals had filed complaints against the company to the DPA for unlawful marketing activities. During their subsequent investigation, the DPA discovered that the company had contacted the data subjects by telephone for marketing purposes without obtaining their consent first. To this end, the company had used the contacts lists for certain third parties that, in many cases, had not contained any free, specific, informed, or documented consent taken from these users regarding the disclosure of their personal data. The DPA also found that Edison Energia had not provided the data subjects with an easy and direct method of objecting to the processing of their personal data. Moreover, Edison Energia had not responded the data subjects’ requests in a timely manner. What’s more, the DPA also found that the users of the company’s app and website had simultaneously consented to the user of their personal data for profiling and marketing purposes. This type of consent, according to the DPA, does not correspond to a specific or voluntary consent for both purposes simultaneously. In the end, the DPA discovered that Edison Energia had not provided its data subjects with transparent information about the processing of their personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain

allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined HERON CITY VALENCIA MANAGEMENT, S.L. with EUR 10,000. One of the data subjects had complained to the DPA that the data controller had not complied with their request for data access to the recordings of the video surveillance system where the data subjects was also captured.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain

allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined GRUPO NORCONSULTING, S.L. with EUR 15,000. allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain

allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined EUROPYMES SERVICIONS INTERGRALES, S.L. with EUR 800. allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the owner of the store “Woolen” with EUR 3,000. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the information signs about the processing of personal data by the cameras were not where they should be (missing).

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy, Art. 2-septies (8) Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined A.R.N.A.S. Civico with EUR 6,000 because two employees of the data controller had filed a complaint to the DPA. After the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller had previously published two documents that contained personal health data of the data subjects online without obtaining their consent, making that data public in the process.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Amazon Italia Logistics s.r.l. with EUR 20,000. One of the former employees of the company had requested documents from the data controller, however they did not receive them in due time. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller had not properly fulfilled its obligation to comply with the data subject’s request for data access.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Insufficient fulfilment of information obligations
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined Thomas International Systems. S.A. with EUR 40,000. The company performs psychological tests for other companies. In this particular instance, the company had conducted such a test for the company Agroxarxa, S.L. One of the participants to the test had complained to the data controller that they had to provide sensitive personal data (disability, ethnicity). However, Agroxarxa had clearly stated that the test did not request nor process such sensitive data. During the investigation the DPA discovered that that Thomas International had processed this sensitive personal data without obtaining the data subject’s and without it being necessary for the fulfillment of the contract between Agroxarxa and Thomas International. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of Art. 9 GDPR. The original fine of EUR 50,000 was reduced to EUR 40,000 because of voluntary payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Information obligation non-compliance
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Dante Internațional SA with EUR 1,000. One of the data subjects had filed a complaint to the DPA against the data controller because the data controller kept sending them advertisements even though the data subject had requested the deletion of their data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Ireland
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 (1) c) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Irish DPA (also known as DPC) has fined WhatsApp Ireland with EUR 5.5 million. The Austrian Organization “None of Your Business” (NOYB) had complained to the DPA on behalf of a data subject. WhatsApp had recently updated its terms of service shortly after the GDPR came into force. In the ToS, WhatsApp informed its users to click “Agree and Continue” to show that they agree with the new terms of service. This was also required for further access to the messaging service. WhatsApp assumed that this consent to the updated Terms of Service constituted a contract between the user and WhatsApp Ireland because the data processing would have been necessary for the provision and the improvements of the messaging service. The data processing was, therefore, lawful according to Art. 6 (1) b) GDPR. However, the complainant claimed that WhatsApp was trying to process the users’ data by relying on the fact that this consent was lawful. WhatsApp Ireland actually forced users to consent to the processing of their personal data by making access to its services conditional on the users’ consent to the updated Terms of Service. After the investigation, the DPC submitted a draft decision under Art. 60 GDPR to the other European supervisory authorities implicated. The DPC discovered that WhatsApp had not relied on user content as a legal basis, which further means that “coerced consent” did not apply in this case. Though, this also did not rule out the possibility that WhatsApp had relied on a contractual basis. As a response, the DPC received objections from 6 supervisory authorities. On the other hand, the DPC discovered that Meta had breached its transparency obligations as per the GDPR. Apparently, Meta had not clearly explained to its users for what purpose and on what legal basis would their personal data be processed. Since they couldn’t reach an agreement on these disputed points, the DPC initiated a dispute resolution procedure as per Art. 65 GDPR. When making its decision, the EDPB confirmed the violation of transparency obligations by WhatsApp. Apparently, the EPDB had a different perception than the DPC regarding WhatsApp’s entitlement to rely on the contractual legal basis to process the users’ personal data. The EPDB concluded that WhatsApp had violated Art. 6 (1) GDPR. So, the DPC agreed in its final decision and imposed a fine of EUR 5.5 million, as well as required WhatsApp to bring its data processing into compliance within 6 months.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Sweden
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Swedish DPA has fined Dalarna Region with EUR 17,900. The region had apparently sent out invitations for patient visits where the healthcare facility (children’s hospital) could be seen on the envelope window. The DPA discovered that this type of visibility granted access to unauthorized individuals to the patients’ personal data. The DPA concluded that the region had not implemented the proper organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined TECNO MOTOR LA MUELA, S.L.L. with EUR 360. The data controller had previously installed several video surveillance cameras that, among other things, also covered the public space. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of data minimization. Moreover, the data controller had not properly informed the data subjects about the video surveillance and had thus violated its duty to inform as per Art. 13 GDPR. The original fine of EUR 600 was reduced to EUR 3660 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Insufficient fulfilment of information obligations
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined a private investigator with EUR 2,000. And individual who had previously hired this investigator filed a complaint to the DPA. The claimed that the data controller had failed to inform them sufficiently about the processing of their personal data which was conducted during the investigation. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the data controller had a contact form on its website that offered no reference to the privacy policy.

allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Croatian DPA (also known as azop) has fined a company in the hospitality industry with EUR 1,991. allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Croatian DPA (also known as azop) has fined a jewelry manufacturer with EUR 2,654. allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain

allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined CASAL DE L’ESPLUGA DE FRANCOLI with EUR 3,000. The original fine of EUR 5,000 was reduced to EUR 3,000 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Istituto Comprensivo – IC Cosenza III “V. Negroni”
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy, Art. 2-septies (8) Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Istituto Comprensivo – IC Cosenza III “V. Negroni” with EUR 2,000. The educational institution had previously published a document that also contained the personal health of some of the teachers, on an online platform for the teaching staff. This document contained various information about benefits which were linked to the health status of the teachers who were entitled to receive them. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the school had publishe this data without a valid legal basis, so it acted unlawfully.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to notify DPA of a data breach
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA fined Dent Estet Clinic SA (a dental practice) with EUR 1,000. One of the employed dentists had published medical information of a patient (photos and x-rays) in an article on a medical blog. However, the dentist did not obtain the patient’s consent before publishing the medical data. Although the patient had informed the clinic, it failed to notify the DPA about this data breach in a timely manner.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Insufficient fulfilment of data subjects rights
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian data protection authority (AEPD) has fined the company Tensa Art Design SA with EUR 1,000. A data subject had previously objected to a further newsletter subscription but the company had kept sending him advertisements.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR, Art. 2-sexies Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Azienda Universitaria Friuli Occidentale with EUR 55,000. The health authority had previously created several patient profiles using algorithms and personal patient data that would indicate the risk of having complications regarding the even of a Covid 19 infection. This was implemented to better identify appropriate diagnostics and therapeutic solutions in a time manner, if complications ever occurred. However, the DPA discovered that the health authority had no valid legal basis to process the personal data of the patients through profiling. Moreover, the DPA also found out that the health authority had not conducted a data protection impact assessment. When calculating the fine, the DPA took into consideration the aggravating factor of there being a large number of individuals who were affected.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR, Art. 2-sexies Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Azienda Universitaria Friuli Centrale with EUR 55,000. The health authority had previously created several patient profiles using algorithms and personal patient data that would indicate the risk of having complications regarding the even of a Covid 19 infection. This was implemented to better identify appropriate diagnostics and therapeutic solutions in a time manner, if complications ever occurred. However, the DPA discovered that the health authority had no valid legal basis to process the personal data of the patients through profiling. Moreover, the DPA also found out that the health authority had not conducted a data protection impact assessment. When calculating the fine, the DPA took into consideration the aggravating factor of there being a large number of individuals who were affected.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR, Art. 2-sexies Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Azienda Universitaria Giuliano Isontina with EUR 55,000. The health authority had previously created several patient profiles using algorithms and personal patient data that would indicate the risk of having complications regarding the even of a Covid 19 infection. This was implemented to better identify appropriate diagnostics and therapeutic solutions in a time manner, if complications ever occurred. However, the DPA discovered that the health authority had no valid legal basis to process the personal data of the patients through profiling. Moreover, the DPA also found out that the health authority had not conducted a data protection impact assessment. When calculating the fine, the DPA took into consideration the aggravating factor of there being a large number of individuals who were affected.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined FACTOR ENERGIA, S.A. with EUR 24,000. One of the data subjects had complained to the DPA that they had received several advertising messages from the data controller even though there was no contractual relationship between them. According to the DPA, the data controller had processed the data unlawfully because it had no valid legal basis. The original fine of EUR 40,000 was reduced to EUR 24,000 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined STS Di Prisinzano s.r.l. with EUR 1,000 because the company had previously processed the data of a customer regarding a breakdown service without sufficiently informing the customer about the processing of their personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Insufficient fulfilment of data subjects rights
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Associazione Rescue Drones Network ODV with EUR 3,000. One of the founding members of the association had filed a complaint to the DPA, saying that he had learned of disciplinary actions taken against them. The founding member then wanted to use documents from their email account for their defense. However, the data controller had blocked access to that email account, preventing them from accessing the documents they needed. In this context, the data subject had asked the data controller to grant them access to that email account. However, the data controller never responded to this request. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the data subject’s right to information as per Art. 12 GDPR and Art. 15 (3) GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Insufficient fulfilment of data subjects rights
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Poste Italiane S.p.a. with EUR 10,000 after it failed to respond to the data subject’s request for access to their data in a timely manner.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 2-septies (8) Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Fondazione Regio di Torino with EUR 5,000. One of the foundation members had filed a complaint to the DPA, saying that the foundation had published a document on their website that contained personal data health of the data subject. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the foundation had published this data without a valid legal basis and the process was therefore unlawful.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Azienda Ospedaliero-Universitaria Careggi di Firenze with EUR 9,000. The data controller had mistakenly sent a patient medical record to the wrong patient, and the DPA discovered that the healthcare facility had not implement the appropriate organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data, allowing such an incident to occur.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 37 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Cisterna di Latina municipality with EUR 5,000. An individual had complained to the DPA, saying that the municipality had not replied to their request for access to their personal data in a timely manner. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the municipality had mistakenly sent the data requested by the data subject to another third party instead of the data subject. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the municipality failed to appoint a new data protection officer multiple months after the initially appointed data protection officer had resigned.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Conservatorio di Musica S. Cecilia di Roma
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 38 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Conservatorio di Musica S. Cecilia di Roma with EUR 6,000. One of the students of the educational institution had complained to the DPA, claiming that he had received a disciplinary sanction for a statement he had made during a student assembly. Although it shouldn’t have happened, the assembly was recorded and the institution used these recordings to base the disciplinary actions on it. During the investigation, the DPA concluded that the data controller had no valid legal basis to use the assembly recordings and process the personal data the student, making the procedure unlawful. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the data protection officer of the educational institution was also the institution’s director. The DPA rightly found this to be an unlawful conflict of interest.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to notify DPA of a data breach
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The DPA of Sachsen-Anhalt has fined the Magdeburg University Hospital with EUR 9,000. The clinic had previously failed to report to the DPA a data breach that involved one of the former employees having unlawfully disclosed personal data from the clinic’s systems to third parties.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Cyprus
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Cypriot DPA has fined the Hermes Airport Ltd. with EUR 6,000. The data controller had previously suffered a cyber attack that, according to the DPA had been clearly caused by the lack of organizational and technical measures required for the protection of the personal data, as well as a supervision of a processor.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Cyprus
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Cypriot DPA has fined DW Dynamic Works LIMITED with EUR 5,000. The data controller was a processor for Hermes Airport Ltd. When Hermes went through a cyber-attack, one of the guilty parties, according to the DPA, was Dynamic Works. Their lack of organizational and technical measures failed to protect the personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Cyprus
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Universal Life Insurance Public Co Ltd.
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Insufficient data processing agreement
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Cypriot DPA has fined Universal Life Insurance Public Co Ltd. with EUR 3,500. The processor of this data controller had went through a data breach where the personal data of several customers were mistakenly disclosed to other customers. During their investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller had not contractually regulated their relationship with the data processor. The DPA stated that the data controller had contracted this data processor without making sure that the data processor offered enough guarantees for the implementation of proper organizational and technical measures to protect the personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Cyprus
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Cypriot DPA has fined PRINTAFORM Ltd. with EUR 3,750 because the data controller, which was a processor for Universal Insurance Public Co Ltd., had went through a data breach where the personal data of multiple customers were mistakenly disclosed to other customers. According to the DPA, this data breach was clearly caused by PRINTAFORM’s lack of proper organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Cyprus
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Bank of Cyprus Public Company Ltd.
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 24 (1) GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Cypriot DPA has fined the Bank of Cyprus Public Company Ltd. with EUR 17,000. In the context of a sales of credit facilities, the Cypriot bank had mistakenly transferred the data of multiple customers whose credit facilities had not yet been sold to the buyer. These incidents had affected about 11,673 records and over 5,500 individuals. The DPA concluded that it was the bank’s failure to implement proper organizational and technical measures that led to the data breach.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Cyprus
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Insufficient data processing agreement
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Cypriot DPA has fined the Cypriot Ministry of Defense with EUR 5,000. The data controller had previously suffered a cyber attack that (the DPA states) had been caused by the lack of proper organizational and technical measures necessary to protect the personal data, as well as the lack of proper supervision of a processor.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Scuola Statale Secondaria di  I^ grado 'Bianco-Pascol'
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy, Art. 2-sexies Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the school “Scuola Statale Secondaria di  I^ grado ‘Bianco-Pascol’” with EUR 3,000. The educational institution had apparently published a document that contained personal health data of students in the school’s electronic register. During its investigation, the DPA discovered that the school had published this data without having a valid legal basis, acting in an unlawful way. Moreover, the school failed to respond to the several requests for information in a timely manner.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined MIRACLE IBIZA S.L. with EUR 500. The data controller had previously installed a video surveillance system that captured the front door of a data subject’s apartment. The DPA concluded that hits was a violation of the principle of data minimization as per Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined HOTEL VILLA SORO, S.L. with EUR 600. The data controller in question had apparently installed a video surveillance system without offering the required information as per Art. 13 GDPR. The original fine of EUR 1,000 was reduced to EUR 600 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Istituto di Istruzione Superior G. Renda di Polistena, Reggio Calabria
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the educational institution “Istituto di Istruzione Superior G. Renda di Polistena, Reggio Calabria” with EUR 900. One of the former employees of the municipality had filed a complaint to the DPA, claiming that a document containing their personal data had been unlawfully published on the institution’s website. This document contained information regarding the termination of the employment relationship between the data subject and the institution.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 10 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy, Art. 2-octies Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined the Italian Archery Federation (FITARCO) with EUR 10,000. One of the members of the of the federation had complained to the DPA that the federation had unlawfully published documents containing their personal data on its official website. These documents contained, among others, specific criminal information about the data subject.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art, 5 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 37 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Poliambulatorio Radiologico “il Sorriso” S.r.l. with EUR 15,000. One of the patients of the institution had complained to the DPA that they had not received enough information about the processing of their personal data. Among others, the data controller had not offered information about the data protection officer and the type of data that would be processed. The DPA also discovered that the data controller had not provided the contact details of their data protection officer to the DPA.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1), a) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Polish DPA has fined the law firm PIONIER with EUR 9,600. Apparently, the law firm’s professional area of expertise were the victims of traffic accidents regarding proceedings against insurance companies and other entities. Keeping this in mind, the law firm supports its clients in claims for damages and claims for reimbursement of medical treatment costs. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the law firm had processed personal data (including health data) of its potential clients without having a valid legal basis. The law firm obtained the personal data of potential clients based on press releases and other social media reports. This allowed it contact the potential clients and offer them their services. During the initial conversation, the law firm asked their clients for verbal consent to process their personal data until the conclusion of a contract. However, the DPA stated that consent should have been given in such a way that it could be proven later on (for instance, in a register of consents).

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Insufficient fulfilment of data subjects rights
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Azienda Sanitaria Locale di Brindisi with EUR 2,500. A data subject had complained to the DPA, claiming that the health authority failed to respond to their request for access to their personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 (2), (4) GDPR, Art. 37 (7) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined the Comune di Borgia with EUR 5,000. The municipality in question processed the biometric data of employees regarding the registering of their attendance. Garante discovered that this processing of data was not proportionate to its purpose, and therefore was an unjustified infringement of the data subjects’ rights. As a result, Garante stated that the processing of biometric data had occurred without a valid legal basis. Moreover, Garante also discovered that the municipality failed to provide the DPA with the contact data of their data protection officer.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 (2), (4) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined the Comune di Vicchio with EUR85,000. The municipality in question processed the biometric data of employees regarding the registering of their attendance. Garante discovered that this processing of data was not proportionate to its purpose, and therefore was an unjustified infringement of the data subjects’ rights. As a result, Garante stated that the processing of biometric data had occurred without a valid legal basis. Moreover, Garante also discovered that the municipality failed to provide the DPA with the contact data of their data protection officer.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy, Art. 2-septies (8) Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined the Comune di Bracciano with EUR 6,000. One of the institution’s former employees had complained to the DPA, stating that the municipality had published a document containing their personal health data on their website. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the municipality had published the persona health data without a valid legal basis, therefore acting in an unlawful manner.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b), e) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 30 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Comune di Salento with EUR 12,000. A data subject had complained to the DPA after being recorded by a CCTV camera (the recording proved that he had ignored the curfew introduced during the COVID-19 pandemic countermeasures). During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the processing of the data subject’s personal data with the purpose of proving the curfew violation was unlawful since the cameras had originally been installed for another purpose, that of combatting street crime. Hence, the municipality was not processing the data subject’s personal data for the original purpose, which is a breach of the purpose limitation principle included in the GPDR. The DPA also discovered that the municipality had stored these recordings excessively long and failed to provide sufficient information about the CCTV to the data subject. Moreover, the DPA also found out that the municipality had not responded to the data subject’s request for information in a timely manner. Last but not least, the municipality did not maintain a register of processing activities for certain periods of time.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Ordine dei Medici Chirurghi e geli Odontoiatri della Provincia di Cagliari
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Art. 5 (1) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Ordine dei Medici Chirurghi e geli Odontoiatri della Provincia di Cagliari (Board of Surgeons and Dentists of the Province of Cagliari) with EUR 3,000. Apparently, the data controller had disclosed the data of a doctor to several third parties without having a valid legal basis to do so.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) e) GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Comune di Monte Sant’Angelo with EUR 3,000. A data subject who had participated in a selection procedure had complained to the DPA because the municipality had published a list of candidates as well as their results in the selection procedure on its official website. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the municipality had no valid legal basis to publish the results and the personal data of the applications on its website. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the data controller had failed to comply with the data subjects’ requests for deletion of their personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined the Medijobs Platform SRL with EUR 5,000. The data controller had previously informed the DPA about a data breach as per Art. 33 GDPR. Several unauthorized third parties had successfully accessed the IT infrastructure of the data controller and managed to download, delete, and transfer personal data of the applications (name, professional history, email address, marital status, etc). The DPA discovered that the data controller had not implemented the proper organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data, which then led to the data breach.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy, Art. 2-sexies Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the school Direzione Didattica Statale 1° Circolo-Eboli with EUR 1,500. The educational institution had previously sent several documents that contained the names of all students and teachers (including health data) to all the parents and teachers, without making sure that teachers and parents receive only the information about the students that concern them.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 114 Codice della privacy, Art. 157 Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Rebirth s.r.l. with EUR 15,000. The data controller had installed a total of 14 surveillance cameras in a café it operated without informing about the video surveillance.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Hungary
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 7 (2), 4) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hungarian DPA has fined a news service with EUR 5,200. Apparently, one of the news service’s customers had complained to the DPA about subscribing to the newsletter in order to receive a daily news digest. However, they also started receiving direct marketing messages. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the processing of the data subject’s personal data for direct marketing purposes was unlawful. Because the data controller had failed to offer sufficient information to the data subject about their rights, the DPA concluded that the data subjects’ consent to receive the newsletter was not a valid legal basis to process their personal data for marketing purposes (due to insufficient information provided).

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 12 (3) GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Mister Brick S.a.s. with EUR 1,000. A data subject had complained to the DPA, claiming that the data controller had sent unsolicited marketing messages to them. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller did not have a legal basis to process the data subject’s data for marketing purposes. Moreover, the data controller did not respond in a timely manner to a request of the data subject who wanted to exercise their rights.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Luxembourg
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Manager of a real estate co-ownership
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 12 (3), (4) GDPR, Art. 15 (1) b), c) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The DPA of Luxembourg has fined the manager of a real estate co-ownership with EUR 1,500. The data controller had disclosed the personal data of a data subject to unauthorized third parties without having a valid legal basis to do so. Moreover, the data controller failed to respond in a timely manner to requests from the data subjects who wanted to exercise their rights.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 29 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 114 Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Tecnomed Trento s.r.l. with EUR 10,000. The data controller had operated several video surveillance cameras on its premises, and some of them had no authorization to be there. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the information signs about the processing of the personal data were missing. The DPA also found out that three individuals who shared credentials had authorized access to these recorded images. In conclusion, the DPA stated that this was not appropriate to guarantee the confidentiality of the information that was processed by the video surveillance system, as it did not allow anyone to check who carried out certain processing operations.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined a Property Owners Association with EUR 2,000. Two property owners had complained to the DPA. The two individuals had requested a copy of their financial documents to the board. However, the Association published the requests containing personal data of the two data subjects in question on the bulletin board, in a common area of that residential building. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of confidentiality.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy
