allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined the Villafranca di Verona municipality with EUR 4,000. The municipality had previously published a document that contained the personal data of an employee on its website.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined SUBREZIDENȚIAL Broker S.R.L. with EUR 10,000. One of the data controller’s employees had unauthorizedly published an Excel spreadsheet that contained personal data (first and last name, telephone number, email address, ID number and bank details) of 509 customers online. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller had not implement the appropriate organizational and technical measures to protect this personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 29 GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b) GDPR, Art. 32 (2), (4) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Kaufland Romania SCS with EUR 3,000. The Data controller had previously reported a data breach to the DPA according to Art. 33 GDPR. One of the company’s employees had taken pictures of the CCTV recordings using their cell phone and then transmitted the pictures to a third party. This third party then published the photos, in which two people and a license plate could be easily identified, on the website of a local newspaper. The DPA concluded that the data controller had not implemented the necessary organizational and technical measures to protect the personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) d), e) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the electricity supplier Areti spa with EUR 1 million. One of the company’s customers had complained to the DPA that Areti spa had classified them as a defaulting customer which made it impossible for the customer to switch to another electricity supplier. This was caused by outdated data in Areti spa’s databases, which hadn’t been updated after a mismatch in the company’s internal systems. This incident affected approximately 47,000 customers. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that Areti spa had stored this data for an inordinate amount of time. Moreover, Areti spa had failed to properly respond to requests from the customers who wanted to exercise their data subject rights.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 30 (1) c) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Sportitalia with EUR 20,000. The data controller processed the biometric data (fingerprints) of the employees to register their attendance. However, Garante found that such an extensive procedure was not proportionate to its purpose, and as such constituted an unjustified infringement of the rights of the data subjects. Moreover, Garante concluded that the processing of this biometric data had happened without the company informing the data subjects about the data processing.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 37 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Cisterna di Latina Municipality with EUR 5,000. An individual had complained to the DPA, claiming that he has submitted a request to the municipality to their personal data. However, due to an error, the data was instead disclosed to a third party instead of the data subject in question. In this context, the data subject did not receive any response to his request. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the municipality had not appointed any data protection officer.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 32 (1) b) GDPR, Art. 32 (2) GDPR, Art. 32 (4) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Apă Canal Ilfov SA with EUR 3,000. The data controller had sent an email with personal data to several recipients in an open distribution list, making it possible for every recipient to view the email addresses of all the other recipients.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined MAE WEST SYSTEMS, S.L. with EUR 400. The data controller had previously installed video surveillance in a bar it was operating without offering enough information about it.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined the Transport Workers’ Union of Aragon with EUR 3,000. The union had previously published a document with personal data (including the first and last name and identity card number) of all the members of a strike committee on various social networks. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that this incident could have happened because of the union’s failure to implement the required organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Insufficient data processing agreement
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The company failed to provide the requested information to the Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) within the required timeframe, violating Art. 58 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined BRISTOL LOGISTICS SA with EUR 10,000. The DPA received a notification from BRISTOL LOGISTICS SA of a personal data breach as per Art. 33 GDPR. This notification stated that a binder that contained the personal files of 12 employees had been stolen by someone. This led to a third party gaining unauthorized access to the personal data. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of Art. 32 GDPR, since the municipality had failed to implement the appropriate organizational and technical measures that would have ensured a proper level of protection for the data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined I-Model s.r.l. with EUR 10,000. Apparently, a data subject had complained to the DPA against the data controller, claiming that the data controller kept sending them SMS advertisements even though they had requested the deletion of the data and the data controller had confirmed the deletion.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined EDITORIAL RIBADEO S.L. with EUR 1,000 because it failed to comply with an order issued by the DPA.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: SERVICIOS INTEGRALES DEL HOGAR TENERIFE, S.L.
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined SERVICIOS INTEGRALES DEL HOGAR TENERIFE, S.L. with EUR 3,000. One of the company’s former employees had complained to the DPA, claiming that the data controller had unauthorizedly disclosed their personal data through WhatsApp after the data subject left the company. The original fine of EUR 5,000 was reduced to EUR 3,000 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined SUMINISTRADOR IBERICO DE ENERGIA, S.L. with EUR 24,000. A customer had previously filed a complaint to the DPA after the data controller had carried out a change of their gas and electricity supply company without obtaining the data subject’s consent first. The original fine of EUR 30,000 was reduced to EUR 24,000 because of voluntary payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 114 Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the owner of the Joy Unique Collection store with EUR 6,000. The data controller had been operating video surveillance cameras on its premises without any authorization. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the information signs regarding the processing of personal data through the video surveillance system were missing.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Lithuania
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 9 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 30 (1), (3) GDPR, Art. 35 (1), (3) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Lithuanian DPA has fined Praktiškas UAB, which is the operator of the SportGates sports club, with EUR 6,000. The data controller had processed the biometric data of several customers in the context of their access to specific sports facilities. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the customers’ consent to the processing of their biometric data couldn’t be considered to be provided voluntary. That’s because the data controller had not offered the provision of any other type of information to gain access to the sports clubs. It also did not provide the data subjects with any information about potential alternatives to access the sports club. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the data controller had not provided the data subjects with enough information about the processing of the personal biometric data. The data controller also failed to conduct a data protection impact assessment before the personal data processing.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Ireland
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Irish DPA has fined the nursing home operator VIEC Limited with EUR 100,000. The data controller had notified the DPA about a data breach as per Art. 32 GDPR. This was a phishing attack where an unauthorized third party had gained access to the email account of a VIEC Limited manager. As a result of this, the third party managed to access the personal data (health and biometric data) of home residents. The DPA discovered that this was a breach of the principles of confidentiality and integrity. The DPA also stated that the data controller had failed to implement the appropriate organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Finland
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Insufficient fulfilment of data subjects rights
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Finnish DPA has fined the debt collection company Alektum Oy with EUR 750,000. The DPA started an investigation against the data controller after three people had filed complaints against them. During this investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller did not respond at all or completely to requests from data subjects regarding their data protection rights. The DPA also discovered that the data controller had not sufficiently cooperated with the DPA.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined Intellexa SA with EUR 50,000. The data controller had not properly cooperated with the DPA during the investigation.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Insufficient cooperation with supervisory authority
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Polish DPA (also known as UODO) has fined TIMSHELL Sp. z o.o. with EUR 6,800 because it failed to provide the information requested by the DPA during an official investigation.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b), c) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA (also known as ANSPDCP) has fined REGENCY COMPANY SRL with EUR 3,000. Apparently, the data controller had installed several video surveillance cameras on its premises to monitor the access of people and the security of its premises and property. However, this made it possible for it to monitor its employees extensively. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the video surveillance had been partly carried out without the clear consent of the company employees. The purpose of the surveillance could have easily been achieved through less intrusive means that did not encroach on their employees’ privacy.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined BANCO BILBAO VIZCATA ARGENTARIA, S.A. with EUR 84,000. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller had registered the alleged debts of one of its former clients to the Spanish Central Bank’s risk information center without having a legal basis to do so. The DPA also discovered that the data controller had failed to comply with the former customer’s request for access to their personal data. The original fine of EUR 140,000 was reduced to EUR 84,000 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fiend INGENIERIA Y TELECOM JAEN, S.L. with EUR 10,000. The data controller had extended the data subject’s contract without obtaining their consent first.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Hungary
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 12 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hungarian DPA has fined TV2 Media Csoport Zrt. with EUR 26,700. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller had operated two of its websites without offering the necessary information about the handling of the personal data. The DPA also discovered the fact that the data controller did not obtain the consent of its users in a clear and transparent manner on these websites.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 75 Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Azienda Ospedaliera Bianchi Melacrino Morelli. The data controller had mistakenly sent a document that contained health data of the data subject to the wrong recipient. The DPA discovered that the healthcare facility had failed to impose the required organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Azienda Ospedale-Universita Padova with EUR 5,000. The data controller had sent to several recipients an email that contained the consent forms for the participation in a clinical trial, and it was in an open distribution list. This made it possible for all recipients to view the email addresses of each other (19 in total).

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined WUNSCHURLAUB S.L. with EUR 1,800 because it stored passwords in plain text on its website (www.meine-auszeit-jetzt.de). The DPA concluded that this was a violation of Art. 32 GDPR. The original fine of EUR 3,000 was reduced to EUR 1,800 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined ECOMM MOVADGENCY S.L. with EUR 600 after sending out direct marketing agency, even though the data subjects

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Insufficient legal basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined CITIZENGO FONDATION with EUR 3,000. An individual had filed a complaint to the DPA that the data controller had sent them an email that contained election advertising without getting the individual’s consent first. The original fine of EUR 5,000 was reduced to EUR 3,000 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Insufficient fulfilment of data breach notification obligations
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Polish DPA has fined a housing operative with EUR 11,100 because the data controller had disclosed specific personal data of a member of this cooperative to an unauthorized individual. The incident had been recorded in an internal register of violations but the data controller did not inform the DPA or the data subject about this incident in a timely manner.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Misterbianco municipality with EUR 5,000. One of its employees had issued a complained to the DPA because the municipality had published, on its website, a document that contained their personal data. During the investigation, the DPA noticed that the municipality had published this data without a valid legal basis, acting in an unlawful manner.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Eurosanita S.P.A. with EUR 120,000. The data controller controls various healthcare facilities and one individual in particular had issued a complaint to the DPA after mistakenly receiving a document that contained the medical records of another individual. The DPA discovered that the data controller had failed to take the necessary organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data and avoid such incidents.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Real Federacion Espanola de Tenis de Mesa
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Insufficient fulfilment of information obligations
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined the Real Federacion Espanola de Tenis de Mesa with EUR 10,000. One of the participants in the examination for a table tennis coach qualification had issued a complaint to the DPA because they were asked to provide a Covid test to access the examination premises. During the investigation, the DPA found that the data controller had no valid legal basis to process this data, since the legal provisions regarding hygiene concepts at that time did not require any proof of testing before accessing a business’ premises.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b) GDPR, Art. 6 (1), (4) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined Vodafone with EUR 10,000. Apparently, an individual had filed a complaint to the DPA because they had received a package that contained promotional gifts from a company that worked with Vodafone. This happened even though the data subject had expressly objected to the use of their data for any promotional purposes. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller had processed this data without having a valid legal basis, acting unlawfully. The DPA found that the data controller could also not offer any evidence that it had comprehensively informed the data subject about the processing of their personal data, as required by Art. 13 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined ORANGE ESPAGNE S.A.U. with EUR 100,000. One of the company’s customers who had purchased a cell phone from ORANGE contacted the DPA with a complaint afterward. He claimed that ORANGE had issued a condition to deliver the cellphone: the delivery person had to photograph the front and back of the customer’s ID card. ORANGE had implemented these measures for security purposes, in order to prevent identity theft and fraud. Despite having these legitimate justifications, the DPA discovered that there were other methods, which far war less intrusive to the data subject’s privacy, to achieve this other than photographic the ID card and processing a variety of personal data in the process.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Insufficient fulfilment of data subjects rights
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Deca s.r.l. with EUR 1,600 after several employees had complained to the DPA that the data controller had not complied with their requests for access to their personal data processing during the attendance check.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 31 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Insufficient fulfilment of data subjects rights
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined the company ΜΑΡΙΑ ΠΕΔΙΩΤΗ ΚΑΙ ΣΙΑ Ο.Ε. with EUR 7,000. The company had insufficiently complied with the request for information from an individual (the information was both late and incomplete). Moreover, the data controller had not sufficiently cooperated with the DPA.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Insufficient fulfilment of data subjects rights
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined GUUDJOB WORLDWIDE S.L. with EUR 800. An individual had filed a complaint to the DPA where they claimed that the data controller had failed to comply with their request to delete their personal data. The individual in question had posted a review on the data controller’s site. After seeing that their name had been published, they asked for their data to be deleted immediately. However, the data controller failed to comply with this request on time. The original fine of EUR 1,000 was reduced to EUR 800 because of voluntary payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The DPA of Brandenburg has fined a restaurant operator with a five-digit fine. Apparently, during the Covid-19 pandemic, the operator in question had required its restaurant visitors to fill out forms that asked for their name, address, email address, and telephone number for the purpose of contact tracing as required by the law. However, the law didn’t require the collection of an email address back then. Visitors were also required to check a box that stated that they agreed to be contacted by the restaurant. However, the restaurant then used the email addresses of the subjects to send promotional newsletters. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the processing of the email addresses for advertising purposes was unlawful because of the fact that the requirements for giving reliable consent were not met. It was unclear to the data subjects that the restaurant would use the email addresses for advertising purposes. The restaurant operator also did not inform the data subjects about their right of withdrawal of consent.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The DPA of Brandenburg has fined the operator of an outdoor swimming pool with a five-digit fine. The data controller had processed more visitor data that it was legally required for contact tracing purposes during the Covid pandemic.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The DPA of Brandenburg has fined an aid organization with a five-digit fine. Apparently, the aid organization offered transportation for people with illnesses and it reported a data breach to the DPA where the data of the subjects had been published online after a hack. During the attack, the data controller’s database contained more than 80,000 records of data that included information about the health status of all the data subjects. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the bank had not taken the appropriate organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data. This allowed the breach to occur. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the bank had not concluded a processing agreement with its data processors.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fiend ALBERTO FORTE COMPSITE, S.L. with EUR 12,000. Apparently, the company had taken pictures of its employees at the entrance to record their working hours. However, the company did not conduct a data protection impact assessment. The original fine of EUR 20,000 was reduced to EUR 12,000 due to admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Insufficient fulfilment of information obligations
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined INFINITY ECOM S.L. with EUR 5,000 because it failed to ensure that the privacy policy on its official website met the requirements of Art. 13 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b), c) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 7 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 130 Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Ediscom S.p.a. with EUR 300,000. The marketing company had apparently collected the data from over 21 million individuals through various online portals to use it for marketing activities. The company also used “dark patterns” to manipulate and mislead users into consenting to the processing of their data for marketing purposes and to transfer their data to various third parties. The DPA discovered several violations, including the fact that in some cases of data processing, the company could not prove that it had obtained the consent of the data subject.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b), e) GDPR, Art. 12 (2) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 30 (1) GDPR, Art. 22 (2) LSSI
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined Burwebs S.L. with EUR 75,000. Apparently, Burwebs operates websites with adult content. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the company did not process its users’ data in a transparent manner. Moreover, the company also retained its users’ personal data for an indefinite period of time. The DPA also found out that Burwebs processed the data of its minor users without requiring parental consent. Burwebs also complicated the exercising of the data subjects’ rights as per the GDPR and did not sufficiently inform its users about the data processing and the storage of their personal data in its privacy policy. Lastly, the DPA discovered that the record of processing activities was not complete.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined BANQUETES SANTA ANA, S.L. with EUR 5,000. Apparently, the data controller had asked a couple who was celebrating the wedding on its premises to provide the personal data of their guests, including ID card numbers, for the purpose of contact tracing regarding the Covid-19 pandemic laws. The DPA claimed that such a broad request for personal information was unnecessary for contract tracing purposes and that the provision of names would have been more than sufficient.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Hungary
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Unknown
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hungarian DPA has fined the supermarket chain Aldi with EUR 253,000. Apparently, Aldi had entered and then stored the date of birth of several of its customers during the checkout system when purchasing alcoholic beverages. This procedure was introduced to make the cashiers’ work easier since the software could easily calculate whether the person was over 18 or not. However, it was considered excessive by the DPA. Moreover, Aldi did not answer any questions regarding the legal basis of this data processing.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 7 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 130 Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Aesse S.r.l.s. with EUR 3,000. An individual had filed a complaint to the DPA about the fact that the data controller had made an unsolicited advertising call. The complainant claimed that they had never given their consent to receive such advertising communication. Moreover, the data controller did not quite comply with their request for information regarding the origin of the personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined GSMA LTD. with EUR 200,000. Apparently, an individual had filed a complaint to the DPA because they wanted to transfer some special categories of personal data (the ID card data) to the data controller to register for an event. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller did not conduct a data protection impact assessment for these processing operations.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined FUNDACIO PRIVADA UNIVERSITARIA EADA with EUR 1,200. Apparently, an individual who had participated in a training event filed a complaint against the aforementioned educational institution. The data controller had used various pictures of the training event that showed the data subject for promotional purposes, without getting their consent. The original fine of EUR 2,000 was reduced to EUR 1,200 because of admission of responsibility and voluntary payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined a homeowners’ association with EUR 2,000. A property owner had complained to the DPA about the fact that various members of the association had previously accessed the community’s video surveillance footage and shared it via WhatsApp.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Hungary
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) e) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 31 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hungarian DPA has fined a hotel with EUR 8,000. The data controller had previously installed various video surveillance cameras that covered the dining room and a whirlpool area and permanently recorded guests. The data controller had installed these cameras to protect the individuals and their property. However, during the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller’s purposes were not proportionate to the severe interferences with the guests’ privacy. The DPA also discovered that the data controller had not provided enough information about the video surveillance.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Hungary
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Unknown
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hungarian DPA has fined a beauty salon with EUR 80,700. The data controller had installed various video cameras on all its premises that permanently recorded customers and employees. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller did not have the required permission to operate the video surveillance system. Moreover, the data controller processed the data of these customers for marketing purposes and did not have a valid legal basis. They did not inform the customers about it either.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Hungary
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 7 (2) GDPR, Art. 12 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hungarian DPA has fined a coin dealer with EUR 80,700. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the privacy policy did not have enough information about the data processing regarding the data of both new and prospective customers. The DPA also discovered that, because of a lack of information, the data subjects were not able to give their informed consent about the data processing, and the process was unlawful as a result.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Croatia
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 (1) GDPR, Art. 28 (3) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b), d) GDPR, Art. 32 (2) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Croatian DPA (AZOP) has fined the debt collection agency “K2 Kapital d.o.o.” with EUR 2,265,000. This is the highest fine ever issued by AZOP as well as the first case where the data controller was publicly named. AZOP had received an anonymous complaint back in December 2022 claiming that a large number of the debtors’ personal data was processed by the collection agency without proper authorization. There was a USB stick attached to the complaint that contained personal data (name, date of birth and personal identification number) of 77,317 debtors. During the investigation, AZOP discovered that the data controller did not offer enough information about the processing of the personal data on its privacy policy. Furthermore, it did not provide information about the legal basis concerning the refund of overpaid funds. The breach affected around 132,652 individuals. Moreover, AZOP also found that the data controller had not entered into a data processing agreement with a data processor that monitored simple consumer bankruptcies. This put the data of around 88,896 individuals at risk. This breach persisted for over 2 years. In the end, AZOP discovered that the data controller had not implemented the required organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data. There were deficiencies in the security system which allowed the insecure processing of personal data on a very large scale, and this resulted in the unauthorized filtering of the data. AZOP also noticed that the breach had been ongoing ever since 2019 and was not addressed. AZOP also took into consideration various aggravating factors such as: the controller’s failure to reasonably cooperate with the DPA during the investigation. Moreover, the data controller had not even informed AZOP of additional measures it had taken to prevent any future risks of identified violations, and it had also not made its privacy policy compliant with the GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Cyprus
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) f) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Cypriot DPA has fined the newspaper Πολίτης with EUR 7,000. The data controller had unlawfully published the names and pictures of two police officers without their consent.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Cyprus
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 24 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Cypriot DPA has fined Epic Ltd. with EUR 3,250. The data controller had issued several unsolicited calls to 332 former customers without having a valid legal basis. The DPA also discovered that the data controller had not taken any appropriate technical and organizational measures to prove that the data processing was carried out in compliance with the GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Cyprus
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b), d) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Cypriot DPA has fined NAGA Markets Europe Ltd. with EUR 9,000. The data controller had suffered a data breach where an unknown person had accessed the company’s database, holding the data of more than 342,000 customers hostage. The DPA discovered that the data controller had not implemented the required organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data, and this made it possible for the breach to take place.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined ASSOCIACIO DE CAÇADORS D’ALZIRA with EUR 2,000. One of the members of the association had issued a complaint to the DPA because the chairman of the company had published a letter they had written to a WhatsApp group with 195 members without obtaining their consent.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Consorzio Concessioni Reti Gas S.c.a.r.l. with EUR 2,000. Apparently, the data controller had continued to leave the business email account of one of the interns active, even after the termination of the employment contract. The DPA also found that the data controller could not prove compliance with its information obligations as per the GPDR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Hungary
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) a), b) GDPR, Art. 32 (2) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hungarian DPA has fined a party with EUR 8,000. The party has issued a data protection breach that resulted in six Excel files which were made accessible on the internet. These files contained the personal data of the party members. However, this incident affected around 2,000 data subjects. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the party had failed to take the appropriate organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data, and this allowed such an incident to occur.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Hungary
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 9 (2) GDPR, Art. 13 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 24 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hungarian DPA has fined the spa operator I&S Limited Kft with EUR 80,500. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller had installed various video surveillance cameras on its premises. These cameras permanently monitored the guests and employees. The DPA also found out that the data controller had no valid legal basis for such an extensive video surveillance. The data controller also failed to inform the data subjects about the data processing of their personal data. Moreover, the data controller had processed the data of its customers for marketing purposes without having a valid legal basis.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Hungary
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hungarian DPA has fined a credit institution with EUR 2,700. Several individuals had issued a complaint to the DPA about the fact that the data controller had previously sent claims for their loan agreements to another bank without getting their consent first.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined ESTUDIO INMOBILIARIO SAN ISIDRO with EUR 5,000. Apparently, an individual had complained to the DPA that employees of the data controller had visited their home in order to promote various rental services without obtaining their consent first.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 33 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined the Bolzano municipality with EUR 30,000. Apparently, the health authority of the Bolzano municipality had reported a data breach to the DPA where there was unauthorized access to the health records of multiple patients. This data breach was caused by a deficiency in the electronic health record services that a data processor had been delegated to operate. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the municipality should have taken the necessary organizational and technical measures to avoid such incidents, even though the data leak took place at the processor’s site.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Informatica Alto Adige Spa with EUR 10,000. The municipality of Bolzano had reported a data breach to the DPA where there was unauthorized access to the health records of multiple patients. This data breach was caused by a deficiency in the electronic health record services that a data processor had been delegated to operate. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that Alto Adige Spa had not taken the necessary organizational and technical measures that would prevent such incidents from happening.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR, Art. 28 GDP
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined Razmataz Live s.r.l. with EUR 1,000. The company had contracted a data processor to carry out various marketing campaigns, which the data processor did not execute in a privacy-compliant manner. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that Razmataz had not carried out the adequate controls at the data processor.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Bulgaria
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 32 (1) b), c), d) GDPR, Art. 32 (2) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Bulgarian DPA has fined the Bulgarian Posts EAD with EUR 500,000. The data controller had previously suffered a hacking attach where attackers had managed to access the controller’s databases. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller had not implemented the necessary organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data and prevent such events from happening.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Bulgaria
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Bulgarian DPA has fined a trucking company with EUR 5,000. The data controller had previously disclosed the personal data of several former employees to various third parties without a valid legal basis.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined VODAFONE ONO, S.A.U. with EUR 40,000. The data controller had previously carried out a credit check on an individual without first making sure that there was a customer relationship or another affiliation between them. The personal data of the data subject was processed without a valid legal basis. However, the original fine of EUR 50,000 was reduced to EUR 40,000 because of voluntary payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Netherlands
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Dutch Supervisory Authority for Data Protection (AP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Dutch DPA has fined the Dutch Social Insurance Institution (SVB) with EUR 150,000. Apparently, the data controller had previously suffered a data breach where the client’s data had been leaked to various unauthorized third parties. An unknown third party had managed to request the benefit information through the data controller’s telephone helpdesk. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that this had happened because the data controller had not implemented the required organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data. For instance, the DPA discovered that the system which they used to verify the identity of the callers was not good, and the verification questions were too simple.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Insufficient fulfilment of data subjects rights
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The failure to respond to the data subject’s request for access to their data within the required timeframe.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), f) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The DPA of Hessen fined a Covid-19 test center with EUR 1,800. Apparently, one of its employees had taken an adhesive label from the trash, wrote the test center’s email address on it, and then attached it to the center’s window. However, because of a lack of care, the employee did not notice that the label also contained the personal information of an individual. The data was visible to various third parties for 24 hours until it was removed from the premises.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Unknown
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: A police officer had previously accessed data in police databases for his own private research purposes for a period of three years.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Unknown
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: A police officer had been accessing data in police databases to obtain information about a colleague.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined KFC RESTAURANTS SPAIN, S.L. with EUR 25,000. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller has previously failed to appoint a data protection officer. Moreover, the DPA also found that the data controller had not offered all the necessary information as required by Art. 13 GDPR on its official website.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c), f) GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 25 (1), (2) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Azienda sanitaria locale di Bari with EUR 50,000. The healthcare facility had previously published several reviews of former patients online and offered access to hundreds of documents on which it was possible to identify these patients. The information about these patients had been insufficiently redacted so that data was disclosed. More specifically, information regarding the patient’s health, diagnoses and clinical data of operations were visible.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Sweden
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Swedish DPA has fined the Skåne region with EUR 17,600. One of the region’s employees had lost an unencrypted USB stick that contained the social security numbers as well as the sensitive personal data of more than 2,000 people. The DPA discovered that the region had not implemented the required organizational and technical measures that would protect the personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Austria
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Austrian DPA has fined the operator of a public toilet with EUR 25,000. Apparently, the data controller had installed a video surveillance camera on the restrooms and secretly recorded the people using the toilets. The DPA discovered that the data controller had no legal basis to install these cameras. When assessing the fine, they took into account the fact that the privacy of the data subjects had been significantly violated.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined SECURITAS DIREC ESPANA, S.A. with EUR 25,000 because it failed to comply with an order issued by the DPA.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined DIGI SPAIN TELECOM, S.A. with EUR 70,000. Apparently, someone had filed a complaint to the DPA because the company had issued a duplicate of their SIM card to an unauthorized third party without obtaining their consent. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the company had failed to verify the identity of this third party or get the data subject’s consent. This made it possible for the fraudsters to obtain access to the data subject’s bank account and make unauthorized transactions.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Denmark
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Danish DPA has fined the law firm SIRIUS with EUR 67,200. The law firm had previously suffered a cyber-attack where the gathers had gained access to the firm’s servers and encrypted them. This allowed the hackers to access information about the firm’s clients and other business partners. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the law firm didn’t have basic security measures in place, and this increased the risk of unauthorized access to client data. The firm’s systems, for instance, had insufficient verification measures like multi-factor logins, in place.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the owner of the store “Turkish City” with EUR 2,000. The data controller had previously installed several video security cameras on its premises without properly informing the data subjects about the data processing of their data. The DPA discovered that the data controller had violated its duty to inform as per the GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Cyprus
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Insufficient fulfilment of data subjects rights
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Cypriot DPA has fined the Cyprus Judo Federation with EUR 5,000. The father of one of the members had complained to the DPA that the judo coach of his minor son had previously published photographic and audiovisual material on various social media platforms without obtaining his prior consent. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the trainer had not sufficiently cooperated with the DPA, so a fine of EUR 5,000 was issued for violating Art. 31 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Azienda Socio Sanitaria Territoriale Dei Sette Laghi
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA (also known as Garante) has fined the healthcare facility Azienda Socio Sanitaria Territoriale Dei Sette Laghi with EUR 7,000. One of the facility’s patients had received medical records and clinical documentation from another patient by mistake.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) c), e) Art. 6 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (3) b) GDPR GDPR, Art. 2-ter (1), (3) Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the City of Rome with EUR 10,000. The city had previously published a document on the municipal website about a mother who couldn’t pay her canteen fees. This document contained the personal data of both the mother and her minor child. The city claimed that, due to the absence of a permanent address of the mother to where the notice could be sent, it had published this document as a notification to the homeless mother of the debtor. However, the DPA discovered that this wasn’t considered a sufficient legal basis for processing the personal data, so the city had unlawfully processed the data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Unknown
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: A police officer had accessed the police database for private research purposes. This police officer had queried the investigation process of a friend regarding the background of a judicial hearing. Through WhatsApp, he had shared information that he had obtained through unauthorized retrievals. In this sense, the DPA of Brandenburg had imposed a fine for violating § 32 Absatz 1 BbgDSG. The Brandenburg Data Protection Act is clear about the supplementary regulations necessary to adapt the GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR, Art. 33 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined the DKV Seguros y Reaseguros, S.A.E. with EUR 132,000. An individual had complained to the DPA after he’d received multiple emails from the data controller. These emails contained information from an unknown person. In total, the data controller had sent 51 emails with medical certificates containing the names, surnames, and medical tests data of the data subjects to wrong recipients. The complainant had notified the data controller about the wrong mailing of this data. However, the data controller did not respond until it learned about the complaint to the DPA. The data controller hadn’t reported any data breach to the DPA either. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the company had constantly failed to implement the necessary organizational and technical measures to ensure a sufficient level of data protection security. The original fine of EUR 220,000 was reduced to EUR 132,000 due to admission of guilt and voluntary payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined a bar owner with EUR 5,000. Apparently, the bar owner had unlawfully shared the recordings from the CCTV in the bar on WhatsApp and various social media platforms.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish Data Protection Agency has fined an employee of a bookstore with EUR 4,000. A data subject had complained to the DPA that he had received an invoice of another person containing that person’s personal data. The employee had mistakenly sent the invoice to the wrong recipient.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined BANKINTER, S.A. with EUR 56,000. The data controller had mistakenly sent a report about the data subject’s investment portfolio to a third party. The data controller claims the mis-sending happened because of a computer error. As such, the DPA determined that the data controller had violated the principle of integrity and confidentiality as set out by Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 12 (3), (4) GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Afragola Municipality with EUR 10,000. One of the former employees of the municipality had complained to the DPA that the municipality had published his resume with personal data on the municipality’s official website, even though their employment relationship had ended. Additionally, the former employee had previously filed a request to object to the disclosure of his personal data. However, the municipality had not replied to this request.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 37 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 37 (7) GDPR, Art. 38 (6) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Villabate Municipality with EUR 6,000. The municipality had previously disclosed the personal data of a former employee to unauthorized third parties without obtaining the data subject’s consent. The DPA also discovered that the municipality had failed to appoint a data protection officer.
