allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Convitto Nazionale Statale ‘Giordano Bruno’ di Maddaloni (boarding school) with EUR 6,000 because the data controller had published a document on its website containing personal data of the data subject without consent.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Croatia
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with general data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Croatian DPA has fined a car dealership with EUR 4,000. The data controller had installed several video surveillance cameras on its premises without properly informing the data subjects about the data processing done by the surveillance cameras.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 2-ter Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Universita Agraria di Nettuno with EUR 4,000. One of the former employees of the university had previously filed a complaint with the DPA because the university published a document containing his personal data. The document showed information related to a legal dispute between the data subject and the university. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the publica was unlawful in the absence of a valid legal basis.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the owner of the store Singh Market with EUR 2,000. The data controller had previously installed video surveillance cameras on its premises without properly informing the data subjects about this processing of their data. The DPA concluded that the data controller had violated its duty to inform as per the GDPR regulations.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), f) GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR, Art. 32 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the healthcare facility Azienda sanitaria universitaria Friuli Centrale with EUR 70,000. Several employees of the healthcare facility had accessed the patient’s health data despite not being involved in the treatment of these patients. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the healthcare facility’s IT platform had allowed any employee to access the personal data of patients despite not being in charge of treating those patients. Additionally, the DPA found out that the IT platform also did not install systems that identified the improper use of the personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Unknown
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the healthcare facility Azienda sanitaria universitaria Friuli Occidentale with EUR 50,000. Several employees of the healthcare facility had accessed the patient’s health data despite not being involved in the treatment of these patients. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the healthcare facility’s IT platform had allowed any employee to access the personal data of patients despite not being in charge of treating those patients. Additionally, the DPA found out that the IT platform also did not install systems that identified the improper use of the personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Comune di Napoli Corpo di Polizia Municipale
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 88 GDPR, Art. 113 Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the police authority Comune di Napoli Corpo di Polizia Municipale with EUR 12,000. The data controller had sent a list of names, tax numbers, addresses, contact details and appointments for covid-19 employee tests to various administrative units through email. The authority mentioned that employees had given consent to the data processing, and this was the legal basis for it. However, the DPA concluded that the data controller couldn’t rely on the consent because voluntary consent is questionable in the employee-employer relationship.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Unknown
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The DPA of Hamburg had fined an energy supplier with EUR 12,500. The company had previously outsourced and sold the heating energy division. However, customers affected by this transfer were informed about the transfer and were given the right to object. In such an event of a declared objection, no personal data of the customers could be transferred to the new company. However, despite some customers having declared their objection, their data was still transferred to the new company.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Unknown
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The DPA of Hamburg had fined an energy supplier with EUR 12,500. The company had previously outsourced and sold the heating energy division. However, customers affected by this transfer were informed about the transfer and were given the right to object. In such an event of a declared objection, no personal data of the customers could be transferred to the new company. However, despite some customers having declared their objection, their data was still transferred to the new company.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Unknown
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The DPA of Hamburg had fined a car trading group with EUR 10,110. The company had previously informed its customers that they were restructuring because of the absence of an employee due to illness. The company informed the 3,000 customers about the exact date on which the employee’s inability to work happened and that this situation would continue for an indefinite period of time. The DPA discovered that the company failed to present a valid legal basis for the transfer of this personal data, so the transfer was unlawful.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA (also known as AEPD) has fined ESVETEL, S.L. with EUR 40,000. The data subject had previously received an advertising call from the data controller made on behalf of Vodafone Espana, S.A.U., despite the subject having been registered in the Robinson advertising exclusion list.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 28 GDPR, Art. 30 GDPR, Art. 35 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: nsufficient fulfilment of information obligations
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The DPA of Lower Saxony has fined Volkswagen with EUR 1.1 million. The company had previously installed several cameras on a test vehicle. This vehicle was used to test and train the functionality of a driving assistance system that would prevent traffic accidents. To this end, the traffic around the vehicle was recorded with these cameras. However, Volkswagen did not provide any information about the data processed by the cameras attached to the vehicle, according to Art. 13 GDPR. The DPA discovered that, as opposed to its obligations under Art. 28 GDPR, Volkswagen did not conclude a processing a agreement with the company that carried out these journeys. Moreover, no data protect impact assessments as per Art. 35 DSGVO were carried out. Lastly, the organizational and technical protection measures hadn’t been outlined in the list of processing activities. Still, Volkswagen had cooperated extensively with the DPA.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined CINCON S.C. with EUR 500. The company had failed to provide any information required by Art. 13 GDPR on a form that allowed potential customers to access a free course.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The DPA of Lower Saxony has fined the Hannoversche Volksbank with EUR 900,000. The bank previously analyzed the data from active and former customers without obtaining their consent first. To this end, the bank analyzed the digital usage behavior and assessed, among other things, the purchases in app stores, the total number of transfers in online banking compared to the use of in-branch services, and the frequency of bank statement printers. Moreover, these results had been cross-checked with a credit agency. The goal was to find those customers with a greater willingness to use digital media and to focus on them intensively through electronic communication channels for promotional purposes. Most of the customers were given a notice beforehand. However, the DPA concluded that this did not replace the required consent. When determining the fine, the DPA took into account the fact that the bank did not use the results of these evaluations for anything else. Moreover, the bank cooperated with the DPA during the investigation.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: EFS MANTENIMIENTO Y SERVICIOS TECNICOS, S.L.
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined EFS MANTENIMIENTO Y SERVICIOS TECNICOS, S.L. with EUR 800. The trade union had previously complained to the DPA that the company in question had shared information about one of its employees with the works council without the proper authorization. The information shared caused this employee to be put in a disadvantageous position. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principles of confidentiality and integrity.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: Territorial Administration of the Government of Genoa
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) c), e) Art. 6 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 (3) b) GDPR GDPR, Art. 2-ter (1), (3) Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Territorial Administration of the Government of Genoa with EUR 11,000. The department had previously published a file on its website containing a table that listed information about the lawyers of two companies as well as their adult cohabiting family members. During the investigation, the DPA concluded that the department had published this information without a valid legal basis.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: University Hospital of the Medical University of Warsaw
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Insufficient fulfilment of data breach notification obligations
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Polish DPA has fined the University Hospital of the Medical University of Warsaw with EUR 2,120. The university hospital had previously suffered a data breach where the patient had received a referral from a doctor that contained, among other things, the personal data (name, address, etc) of another patient. The DPA concluded that no one had informed the DPA about the data breach, not the patient and not the doctor.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: France
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The French DPA (also known as CNIL) has fined the UBEEQO INTERNATIONAL with EUR 175,000. The vehicle rental company had previously collected geolocation data about rented vehicles at every 500 meters. The company then stated that they collected this data to monitor the condition of their cars, locate it in case of theft, and assist the customer in case of an accident. However, the DPA discovered that the company still had no valid legal basis to collect the geolocation data in such detail. As such, the DPA found that the company violated the principle of data minimization as per Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR. The DPA also discovered that the company had stored the vehicle data for longer than it was necessary This data was kept during the duration of the business relationship with the customer and an additional three years after the termination of the vehicle rental. Additionally, the personal data of users who were inactive for more than eight years were still stored in the company’s databases. The CNIL found out that this long retention of data was a violation of Art. 5 (1) e) GDPR. The DPA also concluded that the users had not been adequately informed during the registration process on the company portal, and this was a violation of Art. 12 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1), c) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 2 ter-Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The commune published information regarding a court case on its website. This information included personal data such as the name and professional information of a data subject.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the restaurant operator Ekss s.r.l. with EUR 2,000. The data controller had previously installed video surveillance cameras in its premises without properly informing the data subjects about the processing of this data. The DPA discovered that the data controller had violated its duty to inform as defined by the GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 9 GDPR, Art. 12 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the newspaper Il Sole 24 Ore S.p.a. with EUR 40,000. The newspaper had previously published an article regarding the recognition by the Italian authorities of a U.S. judge’s decision regarding the adoption of a child by a same-sex couple. However, the newspaper also published personal data on the adopted child and the couple, by mistake. The couple demanded the deletion of the personal data and requested that the newspaper revoke access to the information made available to the public. The newspaper deleted this personal data but did not comply with the data subjects’ right of access.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Germany
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The DPA of Brandenburg has fined a real estate because she had contacted an individual to offer him to sell a property she owns. The data subject had not previously offered his personal data to the real estate agent, so he inquired how the real estate agent got a hold of his personal data. He also requested that his personal data be deleted. The real estate agent then informed the data subject that she had deleted his personal data, however she also did not comply with the data subject’s right to access the data. Sometime later, the data subject again received a message from the real estate agent even though the data deletion was confirmed by the agent. This is why the DPA concluded that the real estate agent had processed the data of the data subject without a valid legal basis and unlawfully.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined S.C. Wine Point S.R.L. with EUR 3,000. A data subject had previously filed a complaint with the DPA for receiving several advertising emails from the data controller. These emails contained a distribution list where the email addresses of 810 other people were visible to the other recipients. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data controller had failed to take the necessary organizational and technical measures to ensure the confidentially of the personal data processed.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR, Art. 7 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Nos s.r.l.s. with EUR 20,000. Nos was the data processor for Vodafone and managed advertising tasks for the telecommunications company. In this sense, Nos had previously acquired and processed personal data from the companies Kdata ltd. and Dynamic Web Solution ltd. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the data subjects hadn’t consented for the use of this personal data, and they hadn’t been informed about it by Nos either.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Belgium
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 6 (1) a) GDPR, Art. 7 (1) GDPR, Art. 12 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Belgian DPA has fined the media company SA Rossel & Cie with EUR 50,000. During the investigation, the DPA discovered several GDPR violations on three of the websites operated by this company. For example, the company had placed unrequired cookies on one of its websites without obtaining the consent of the website visitors. Moreover, the company considered that visiting other website was a given consent for further cookie placement on these pages. Moreover, the boxes for the consent on third-party cookies were already ticked. The cookie policy was also incomplete and difficult to access for the visitor. Finally, the DPA discovered that the company was always placing new cookies despite the users revoking their cookie consent.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Norway
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Norwegian DPA (also known as Datatilsynet) has fined the Norwegian Labor Inspectorate “Arbeidstilsynet” with EUR 14,500. The data controller had previously carried out a credit check on the data subject without obtaining any valid legal basis.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the healthcare facility Ospedale San Raffaele s.r.l. with EUR 70,000. The hospital had previously reported two data breaches to the DPA as per Art. 33 GDPR. In the first case, the neurology department of the hospital had distributed a newsletter in an open distribution list. This resulted in the email addresses of the recipients being visible to all other recipients. Out of the 499 email addresses affected, 321 were related to patients and 46 to family members or caregivers of the patients. This also allowed the individuals to be identified by name. In the second case, the surgical department had sent a newsletter in an open distribution list, so the same problem appeared. Out of the 90 email addresses affected, 75 were related to patients and/or family members or caregivers of the patients, so the recipients could be identified by name. The DPA concluded that this was a violation of the principle of integrity and confidentiality. This principle requires that the personal data is processed in a way that ensures the necessary security against unauthorized access. This includes protection against unlawful processing and accidental loss/ destruction or damage, through appropriate organizational and technical measures. Regarding the fine, the DPA took into account the aggravating fact that the hospital had introduced several measures to prevent these events specifically, but also the fact that the hospital was highly cooperative with the DPA during the investigation.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined the bar operator SCOTCH CORNER BAR with EUR 1,000. The data controller had previously installed a CCTV system that also covered parts of the public space. Moreover, the data controller had failed to provide the DPA with the necessary information.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined SC Interactions Marketing SRL with EUR 1,000. The data controller had previously sent advertising messages through email to several people for another company. One of the recipients had filed a complaint with the DPA because the data controller had sent several advertising messages in an open distribution list, thus making the email addresses of all the recipients visible to the other recipients.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c), e) GDPR, Art. 5 (2) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined Asociația de Proprietari Aviației Park, which was the operator of the residential facility, with EUR 7,000. The data controller had previously processed the personal data, which includes the surname, first name, ID number and series, arrival time, destination, departure time and remarks, of all delivery persons and couriers without a valid legal basis. Additionally, the DPA discovered that the data controller did not sufficiently inform the data subjects about the processing of this personal data. Moreover, the DPA discovered that the data controller did not establish a data retention period for this personal data that was processed by the video surveillance system, keeping it longer than was necessary.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Denmark
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Danish DPA has fined the publisher Gyldendal A/S with EUR 134,000. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the company had kept most of the data (approximately 685,000 unsubscribed members of Gyldendal’s book clubs), for longer than was necessary. Instead of deleting this data of the deregistered book club members, Gyldendal had kept the data in a database. The data of 395,000 former members had been retained for more than 10 years. Moreover, the DPA discovered that Gyldendal did not have any guidelines in place regarding data deletion.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), c) GDPR, Art. 114 Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the company Zito Auto di Gianfranco Zito with EUR 3,000. The company had previously installed several video surveillance cameras that monitored, among other things, the public spaces and employees. The DPA thought that this was a violation of the principles of data minimization (Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR).

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Polish DPA has fined Stołeczny Ośrodek dla Osób Nietrzeźwych with EUR 2,100. The data controller is a center of people suffering from alcoholism. During this investigation, the DPA discovered that several video surveillance cameras had been installed at the facility. This surveillance system recorded both the sound and images of the residents. The facility justified this video surveillance system based on the purposes related to the health and safety of the alcohol-impaired individuals. However, the DPA concluded that these official purposes did not constitute a sufficient legal basis and the center had, in fact, unlawfully processed the personal data of the residents.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Hungary
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Hungarian National Authority for Data Protection and the Freedom of Information
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), b) GDPR, Art. 6 (1), (4) GDPR, Art. 12 (1) GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 21 (1), (2) GDPR, Art. 24 (1) GDPR, Art. 25 (1), (2) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hungarian DPA (also known as NAIH) has fined the Budapest Bank Zrt. With EUR 634,000. The NAIH reports that the bank used an artificial intelligence-driven software solution to automate the evaluation of customers’ emotional states. This speech evaluation system assessed which of the customers needed to be recalled based on their mood. The bank used this application to prevent complaints and to keep customers happy. However, the bank did not inform the data subjects about the processing of their data, so the customers were not in a position where they could object to the data processing. Therefore, the rights of the data subjects regarding the adequate information and the right to object had not been observed and guaranteed. The DPA discovered that the bank did not have a substantiated legal basis for processing the personal data of the customers, and their interest in doing so was illegitimate. That’s because the bank had not sufficiently examined the interests of the data subjects. So, the bank had processed the personal data without a valid legal basis.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.controller: CORPORACION DE RADIO Y TELEVISION ESPANOLA, S.A.
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined the CORPORACION DE RADIO Y TELEVISION ESPANOLA, S.A. with EUR 30,000. Multiple media outlets, including the data controller, had published on their websites and on Twitter an audio recording of a multiple rape victim’s testimony in court. The case had attracted a lot of media attention back then, so the DPA started an investigation. It discovered that the rape victim’s right to privacy outweighed the data controller’s freedom of information. The audio recordings of the victim didn’t add any significant value to the reporting. Instead, they severely compromised the victim’s privacy. As such, the DPA concluded that the data controller had violated the principle of data minimization. The original fine of EUR 50,000 was reduced to EUR 30,000 because of admission of guilt and voluntary payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined RADIO TELEVISION MADRID, S.A. with EUR 30,000. Multiple media outlets, including the data controller, had published on their websites and on Twitter an audio recording of a multiple rape victim’s testimony in court. The case had attracted a lot of media attention back then, so the DPA started an investigation. It discovered that the rape victim’s right to privacy outweighed the data controller’s freedom of information. The audio recordings of the victim didn’t add any significant value to the reporting. Instead, they severely compromised the victim’s privacy. As such, the DPA concluded that the data controller had violated the principle of data minimization. The original fine of EUR 50,000 was reduced to EUR 30,000 because of admission of guilt and voluntary payment.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Romania
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Romanian National Supervisory Authority for Personal Data Processing (ANSPDCP)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Romanian DPA has fined the Continental Automotive Romania SRL with EUR 2,000. The data controller had previously reported a data breach to the DPA as per Art. 33 GDPR. The data controller had discovered 135 unauthorized and improperly configured cameras on its premises. These cameras captured images of employees in the production area, among other things. These cameras were connected to unprotected and unofficial camera systems. That’s why the DPA concluded that the data controller hadn’t taken the necessary organizational and technical measures to ensure the security of the employees’ personal data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined FLY FUT, S.L. with EUR 3,000. FLY FUT, S.L. is a company specialized in drone footage at soccer matches. A father had filed a complaint to the DPA against the company, saying that the company had filmed his underaged daughter playing soccer during a match at a local club without obtaining his consent first. As such, the DPA discovered that the data controller had processed the daughter’s data without having a valid legal basis to do so.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: United Kingdom
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The UK DPA (also known as ICO) has fined the Tavistock & Portmann NHS Foundation Trust with EUR 91,000. The foundation is a mental health specialist trust located in London. Back in September 2019, the trust wanted to run a contest where it asked patients at the adult gender identity clinic to provide artwork so they can renovate the clinic building. For this reasons, two emails were mistakenly sent with an open distribution list (one of them was sent to 912 recipients and another to 869 recipients). The emails made it clear that all of the recipients were patients of the clinic. The trust immediately acknowledged this error and tried to recall the emails without success. During the investigation, the ICO determined that the trust had no organizational or technical measures in place that would prevent or mitigate the predictable human errors. The ICO also rated as high the harm done to the affected individuals because the relationship of the affected individuals with the gender identity clinic is classified as very sensitive personal information.  Because of immediate implementation of security measures and extensive cooperation with the ICO, the fine was reduced from EUR 910,000 to EUR 91,000.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined a pediatric psychologist with EUR 3,000 because he had improperly cooperated with the DPA during an investigation.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Spain
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with lawful basis for data processing
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Spanish DPA has fined Alquiler Seguro SA with EUR 42,000. This company had previously advertised a job for which a data subject had applied. During the application process, the company requested specific information about the creditworthiness of the data subject from a credit agency. However, the data subject had not consented to this query of their creditworthiness by Alquiler Seguro SA. They had also received no information about it. This is why the DPA concluded that Alquier Seguro had processed the data of the data subject without a valid legal basis, violating Art. 6 (1) GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Finland
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 12 (1), (2), (3), (4), (6) GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 17 GDPR, Art. 25 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Finnish DPA has fined Otavamedia OY with EUR 85,000. Previously, the DPA had received 11 complaints regarding Otavamedia between 2018 and 2021. In these complaints, the data subjects complained about the lack of response on their inquiries. Otavamedia explained that some of these privacy requests had not been fulfilled due to a technical problem with the email management. During such an incident, the messages that were received in the privacy inquiry email box had not been forwarded to the customer service representatives. This situation had only been discovered after seven months. However, the DPA also discovered that Otavamedia should have tested the new email system before putting it live so that it could guarantee the response to the requests and the rights of the data subjects. The requests could also be sent analogously but the request form had to be signed by the data subjects for identification purposes. But Otavamedia was not processing the signature data in any other context, so the signature could not be cross-checked. The DPA concluded that Otavamedia had collected an unnecessary amount of data for identification purposes, making the exercise of data subjects’ rights harder by requiring signatures.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Insufficient fulfilment of data subjects rights
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined a parliamentary election candidate with EUR 2,000. A data subject had previously filed a complaint with the DPA because he’s been receiving unsolicited election advertising via SMS from the politician. The data subject had previously given the politician (who was a minister before the election) their contact details but not for the purpose of this election advertising. The politician had therefore processed the personal data for a purpose other than the one agreed upon, and the data subject had not consented to this or received any information about it. The data subject then requested the deletion of their data and the ceasing of the SMS sending. However, the politician did not comply with this request and the SMS continued to be sent.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Greece
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Insufficient fulfilment of data subjects rights
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Hellenic DPA has fined WIND Ελλάς Τηλεπικοινωνίες ΑΕΒΕ with EUR 2,000. One of the customers of the company had previously sent an email where they requested access to the footage recorded by the store’s cameras on which they appeared. The data subject had never received a response to this request. The DPA then asked for a response and then data controller replied that the data subject’s request couldn’t be fulfilled because the recorded material had been deleted. The DPA concludes that this was a violation of Art. 15 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) c) GDPR, Art. 6 (1) c), d) GDPR, Art. 6 (2), (3) GDPR, Art. 9 (1), (2), (4) GDPR, Art. 2-ter (1), (2) Codice della privacy, Art. 2-septies (8) Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined the Azienda Sanitaria Locale Roma with EUR 46,000. The healthcare facility had previously published the names and health information of 1337 patients on its website. This data involved the health records of the data subjects, including disability assessments, medical documents, technical reports, tests, etc. The DPA concluded that the healthcare institution had processed this data unlawfully and violated the principle of data minimization.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) a), f) GDPR, Art. 6 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined Intesa Sanpolo S.p.A. with EUR 100,000. The bank had unlawfully disclosed the personal data of the data subject to unauthorized third parties (the father of the data subject). The father of the data subject, one of the former employees of the bank, had been authorized to access his daughter’s bank data until she reached the age of maturity. However, the daughter had already reached the age of maturity when the father had asked for access to her data. One of the employees of the bank suspected that the father had authorization to access the data, so he passed on the daughter’s data.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Norway
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 (1) f) GDPR, Art. 32 (1) b), d) GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Norwegian DPA has fined the Norwegian Parliament with EUR 195,000. The Parliament had previously suffered a data breach where unauthorized individuals had gained access to the email accounts of several members of parliament and parliamentary administrative staff. The attackers had succeed in stealing the data, including personal data on bank accounts, dates of birth and health-related data, of several data subjects. During the investigation, the DPA discovered that the parliament failed to incorporate sufficient security mechanisms like two-factor authentication, even though a 2020 risk analysis found that it posed a high privacy risk. For this reason, the DPA concluded that the parliamentary administration did not take the appropriate organizational and technical measure to achieve a sufficient level of security.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: France
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 14 GDPR, Art. 15 GDPR, Art. 21 GDPR
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-compliance with subjects' rights protection safeguards
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The French DPA has fined TotalEnergies Electricite et Gaz France with EUR 1,000,000. During the investigation, the DPA noted that the controller had violated its information obligations as per Art. 14 GDPR by failing to offer data subjects enough information during contact by telephone about the processing of their personal data for advertising purposes. Moreover, the company also did not comply with the data subjects’ requests to object to the data processing for advertising purposes. Lastly, the data controller also did not respond to requests from data subjects in a timely manner, as outlined by Art.12 GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Italy
allItemsPriceGrouped.articleViolated: Art. 5 GDPR, Art. 13 GDPR, Art. 114 Codice della privacy
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Italian DPA has fined a company called Bazar di Hu Xiaoyan with EUR 20,000. The data controller had operated a video surveillance system on its premises without a required permit. The DPA also discovered that there were not information signs about the processing of personal data by cameras.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Cyprus
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Non-cooperation with Data Protection Authority
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Cypriot DPA has fined the Oroklini Municipal Council with EUR 2,000 for not properly cooperating with the DPA during an official investigation.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Cyprus
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to comply with data processing principles
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Cypriot DPA has fined the publisher Εκδοτικού Οίκου Δίας with EUR 10,000. A public figure had previously filed a complaint with the DPA. The publisher had published the incorrect information about the data subject’s financial situation on a website. During the investigation, the DPA weighed the publisher’s right to freedom of expression against the data subject’s right to privacy and protection of personal data. The DPA noted that the publisher had unlawfully processed the data of the data subject.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: Poland
allItemsPriceGrouped.authority: Polish National Personal Data Protection Office (UODO)
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Failure to implement sufficient measures to ensure information security
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The Polish DPA has fined the public cartography institute Głównego Geodetę Kraju. The institute had previously suffered a data breach where numerous land register numbers had become visible on the website of the institute for more than 48 hours. These land register numbers allows specific data of owners to be accessed, including their last and first names, the names of their parents, and the addresses of said properties. The institute had failed to report this data breach to the DPA, but the DPA still found out about this from media reports. The institute also did not inform the data subjects about the incident. As such, the DPA determined that the data controller had violated Art. 33 (1) GDPR and Art. 34 (1) GDPR.

allItemsPriceGrouped.name: France
allItemsPriceGrouped.type: Unknown
allItemsPriceGrouped.summary: The French DPA has fined Clearview AI with EUR 5.2 million. The DPA had previously fined the company in 2022 with a fine of EUR 20 million for the unlawful collection of personal data. The DPA also ordered the company to make its processing of the personal data compliant with the data protection laws in a period of two months. However, the company offered no evidence of compliance within this period.
